40953652.review:
This is the most fun tactics game I have played, I like it even more than SteamWorld Heist. The different mechanics fit together really well. Gives you meaningful in-game reasons to do goofy, Saturday Morning TV, superhero stuff-- acrobatic stunts, power-ups, team-attacks. The team members play off each other in ways that are as satisfying as any RPG I've played.

I even enjoy the crafting and studio upgrades (though I'm usually not much into resource management) because it gives you awesome bonuses during the episodes. And getting "drops" of crafting materials from killing enemies is really crunchy and fun.

Really a joy to play, and I hope it influences other RPG and tactics games to be this much fun. Also, it lets you give important game elements any ridiculous name you want. If you're thinking about buying it, just go for it.

40949150.review:
Chroma Squad es un juego de combates estratégicos calcado a títulos como Fire Emblem o Final Fantasy Tactics.

Empiezas creando un grupo de Power Rangers (bastante bien el editor) que básicamente son especialistas de escenas de acción que deciden producir su propia serie.

Cumple sobradamente con su propósito nostálgico, con la música, gráficos e incluso con el desarrollo de la historia. También me ha gustado el componente de gestión de la productora de televisión; aunque la administración de equipo, recursos y demás es un 10% del juego y el resto son cinemáticas y combates (no hay más).

He echado en falta la posibilidad de explorar algún tipo de mapa y más libertad en ese sentido. El final del juego se me ha hecho bastante pesado y también fácil. Si lo que buscas es un reto mínimo, mejor jugarlo en la máxima dificultad directamente. 

En la mayoría de escenarios hay un momento de combate de mecha, que viene a ser un minijuego de precisión. Me parece simpático porque hay un taller en el que personalizas el maquinote y le pones habilidades y tal, pero sigo sin entender por qué se cura automáticamente cada vez que derriba a un enemigo. Es imposible que te maten con ese tiesto, hasta tal punto que me ha costado trabajo sacar el logro de que me derriben. 

El combate podría pulirse. Si te equivocas en el movimiento te fastidias ya que no puedes andar hasta que se agoten tus puntos de movimiento, sino que antes de hacer clic tienes que contar las casillas y hacer todos los cálculos. También faltan peculiaridades del terreno. Todos los escenarios son dibujos planos y no puedes interactuar con nada. En Fire Emblem si te pones detrás de unos arbustos te dan un bonificador para esquivar ataques a distancia y esas cosas. 

En general: un juego curioso que, si bien no está mal, podría ser infinitamente más de lo que es con unos mesecillos más de desarrollo.

NOTA: 6/10

40862858.review:
Chroma Squad

Chroma Squad, published and developed by Behold Studios after a very successful Kick-Starter campaign is a turn based, tactical RPG inspired by Saban's Mighty Morphin Power Rangers.

The basic story is that five stunt actors filming a hit TV show decide to quit the show and start their own studio and film their own Mighty Morphin Power Rangers inspired TV show.

You begin by casting the actors, then as you progress through filming episodes and building up a fan base you can upgrade your studio, purchase or craft equipment for your actors and build and customise a giant Mech which is used for final battles.

Anyone who was a fan of the Power Rangers in the nineties will get a kick out of the nostalgia, I personally spent a lot of time as a kid pretending to be power rangers with my friends, and Chroma Squad brings back all those memories.

Memories of me jumping off roofs, doing totally sick flying kicks, smashing through walls and fighting giant monsters from outer space, while my friends would watch in awe as the mighty Green  Ranger ( me) would beat up all the bad guys single handedly and then turn on his squad members ( my friends) and beat them up too all while screaming GO GO POWER RANGERS as loud as humanly possible.  It was awesome. Everybody loved it.

Chroma Squad allows you to re-live all those great childhood moments as well as engaging in a great story line as you film episodes, upgrade your studio, craft gear and improve your squad and Mech with a wide range of equipment made of cardboard, plastic and a shit-load of tape.

One thing I found very cool was how the game constantly broke the 4th wall by introducing characters as Kick-starter Backers, the bad spelling of the narrator and constantly referring to itself as a game and TV show and cracking jokes about the original Power Rangers show. Chroma Squad doesn't take itself too seriously, but you can, because on higher difficulties it is actually pretty hard.

I played the game on the 'Interesting' difficulty, and most of the way through wasn't too hard, there were a few restarts but it never felt impossible, that is, until the final level.  The difficulty seemed to ramp up significantly. So much so that after about 25 attempts at the final level I had to resort to dropping the difficulty in order to finish the game so I could write this review.

I had a great time playing Chroma Squad, my first play-through took a good 25 hours. There is a lot of replay value here also, I played with the default squad but there are over 20 different cast members to choose from and all their interactions with each-other is different. There are multiple endings also depending on your squad composition and the choices you make throughout the game. And upon completion of your first play-through there is a New Game+ also. So for the price of $15AUD you will get hours and hours of content and it is all very enjoyable, at no point did I get bored or feel like the game was wasting my time.

So we have nostalgia, entertaining story all the way through, crafting and upgrades, great pixel art, light RPG elements and challenging, Engaging tactical game-play.  AND it's Power Rangers.

Chroma Squad 9/10. 
I had to deduct a point for the difficulty spike on the last level if not for that it would have been a solid 10/10

http://store.steampowered.com/app/251130/Chroma_Squad/

GO GO CHROMA RANGERS!

40498080.review:
It's Saturday morning. You've just grabbed your bowl of Cinnamon Toast Crunch and orange juice. You sit down in front of the TV, so close, in fact, that your eyes burn a little bit as you stare at the white static going across the screen. You click through channels until you hear it. The iconic guitar riff plays as the opening credits roll showing you the many faces of the actors that would appear over the next 30 minutes. Finally, it ends with the logo that fills your heart with excitement, "Saban's Mighty Morphin Power Rangers." This is what Chroma Squad represents. The feelings I had watching Power Rangers was a major driving force for how much I enjoy this game. 
Pros: 
-Story is funny in the sense that it's just as cheesy as the original Power Rangers.
-Soundtrack is retro 8-bit stuff and really helps with setting up the scenes.
-Villains are hilarious and offer fun narrative to the story.
-Easy to understand upgrade system that allows you to go back and make changes without penalty.
-Name your squad and studio whatever you want.
-Easy to understand gameplay that allows ease of entry into TRPGs.

Cons:
-No real difficulty. The game was kind of a breeze throughout and never really felt like a challenge. Could be different for others, but that's just how I felt playing.
-Character customization is a little basic and doesn't add a ton of diversity.
-Kinda short. Wish there were more side missions and whatnot.
-The sponsorship system never really added a ton to me. Once again, just my opinion, but I never saw a ton of use in it.

TL;DR: Chroma Squad is a great, simple TRPG based on the Power Rangers series and is great for anyone trying to get into TRPGs or anyone who loves Power Rangers.

I can't get enough of this game.

40211176.review:
ChromaSquad is a Tactical Squad Based RPG where you play as a group of stunt men that make episodes for a Z-rate TV series featuring all the tropes that we have come to love from Kaiju, Power Rangers, Gundam, and Anime. You get to choose a squad of Ersatz celebrities (some of whom are so close to the original it is eerie) and then off you go. The story sends you hither and thither and is a overall lighthearted romp with colourful graphics, excellent music, and easy to learn hard to master gameplay.

The Good: The gameplay is fun, the graphics are bright and appealing, the 8-bit aesthetic is strong, and the music soundtrack is good enough that I would recommend listening to it even if you aren't playing the game. I liked customizing my squad and naming them after my fave celebrities; Emily Haines, DMX, Kanuuk the Beaver (Go Canada!), KKB, and Jean Claude. The game has multiple endings though I don't know if I will go back and play through again to unlock them all since I was satisfied with the ending I got. The game is difficult enough to keep me entertained, I played through on Challenging on the first play through and only had a few missions that I needed to restart.

The Bad: The game is short but worth the price of admission, I would have liked more useful characters or a larger squad, and a few bosses are quite punishing if you don't know what you are doing. The side-plot with Dr. Soap is never really resolved, which would have been nice.

The Ugly: Colin's Bear.

There's multiple endings encouraging multiple playthroughs and the story was great, actually encouraging you to see the others. The game is very reasonably priced at $15 USD and definitely worth it.

39883220.review:
Some games focus on encouraging stylish/flashy play, some on efficient/optimal play.
In this game, being flashy and going out of your way to complete silly side objectives and stuff like that IS what the game encourages.
And heck, you get to run a Power Rangers bootleg show. What's not to love? [spoiler]Besides Fishmaid[/spoiler]

Now, the presentation might be a bit misleading, it is not a tycoon/management game, there is not that much to actually manage. Some studio upgrades which are purely functional (but do include some nifty visual upgrades for the background of your studio managing menu), like unlocking more upgrades or getting better bonuses for completing director's orders for an episode.
What this really is, is a light RPG. You progress through chapters, get equipment in various ways and at the end of each season (set of chapters), every character in the squad earns a new skill slot (where you can choose between, generally, 2-3 passive or active skills, and switch them after every chapter if you want to try a different build).

Managing your various resources (audience/fans, crafting materials, money...) is important, but not some hardcore experience that'll screw you over if you don't play it optimal.
Now, the RPG aspect is quite a bit fleshed out. Although there are no levels at all to gain (a good thing in my books, as it helps tailor the difficulty of every stat of every enemy and similar perfectly for every chapter, without overlevelling or underlevelling impacting it, plus no grinding), there are plenty of wildly different builds to take depending on which perks, skills and equipment you have on each of your five different classes: Assault, Techie, Support, Scout and Leader.
Trying to get the optional objectives, and as many fans as possible is actually quite challenging as well.

The difficulty was on point for me, and there are four different settings that change enemy stats. The highest difficulty also features something great: Enemies aren't going to blindly rush at you anymore, but instead focus the weakest chararcter, or generally those they have the best chances of taking out, almost as if the AI was playing like a real player. It's still AI, but it's definetly a welcome change if you're tired of dumb and easy to exploit AI.

The writing is really funny, I enjoyed all the puns and references and generally lost count of how many times this game made me laugh out loud. Plus, it's translated into a bunch of languages. It's been ages since I played a game in spanish, instead of the usual "English/Original language or no deal" that a lot of games feature, and I was very pleased with the quality of the translation, which wasn't a bad straight translation, but adapted the humor to the language and generally did a fantastic job at making it feel authentic.
I love the job the translators did here.

The finale was epic, and a fun challenge as well [spoiler]even though I have to admit I did ragequit the first stage with the massive spam[/spoiler]. I had the best gear I could, so I don't think you can cheese it via overwhelming stats, unless you lower the difficulty enough (I played on the highest, and toned it down to the equivalent of Hard later on).

Now the game is not without it's flaws, it can be (slightly) buggy in a few rare cases, and enemy phase can drag out a little if there are a lot of enemies (the mines individually exploding on that one chapter...), but if you're willing to put up with a little bit of annoyingness, the game is really worth it.

Overall, a blast for anyone, and completely worth the price.
Oh, there's also giant mech battles just like in the Rangers' shows, fully customizable one-liners and controller support.
That's cool too.
Almost as cool as the fantastic retro soundtrack.

39221476.review:
O melhor jogo brasileiro que joguei na minha vida, e um dos melhores jogos de rpg de turno que joguei. É um game muito bem elaborado, animado e diverto, os dialógos foram muito bem escolhidos, a criativade com que cada personagem foi feito, tendo cada um suas características, torna o jogo bem complexo, por mais que pareça algo simples, não se engane, esse jogo necessita de estratégia e cautela na hora de executar ações (como grande parte dos jogos em turnos), ainda mais se você busca a perfeição. No início, achava que seria um jogo bobinho, apenas para passar o tempo, mas quando comecei os primeiros episódios do meu esquadrão, fiquei deslumbrado e não parei mais, o jogo te prenderá bastante.

No game você controla um esquadrão de "sentai" no qual, você além de administra-los, você irá controla-los em combate, é uma mistura de gerenciador, com combates. Nunca tinha jogado um game assim, que você gerencia e ao mesmo tempo tem ação, geralmente jogos de gerenciar algo, são um pouco tediosos, mas nesse tem bastante ação, bastante coisa para você fazer, que você irá ficar perdido. A parte de gerenciação, diferente do combate, é um pouco fácil, não é difícil você coletar verba/recursos para melhorar seu esquadrão e o seu estúdio, porém isso não é ruim, é bem melhor do que você se matar por algo, que custa uma fortuna, no game é tudo baratinho, então da pra você ter muitas coisas sem sofrer jogando 1000h ou morrendo 100x, ao meu ver, o balanceamento de recompensa é bem justo.

Só tenho a elogiar o game, meus parabéns a produta brasileira, espero que façam outro game tão bom quanto, nunca fui muito de comprar/jogar jogos nacionais, mas essa é uma demonstração que a industria nacional tem muito a oferecer, tanto pela criatividade, quanto pela qualidade, é um game para gamers de todos os gostos, garanto que será divertido jogar.

39152976.review: It's hard to decide whether or not I want to review this game. The premise of it is great. A bunch of power ranger stunt actors quit and make their own studio with their own monsters. The writing of it is a bit awkward and sometimes is hard to stomach. Gameplay is fine, turn based, RPG class fighting with unlockable skills. There are memes littered throughout the entire game so take that as you will. The gameplay never really changes through the 13 hours I played it, The game isn't hard by any means, there's no challenge through any level or any of the "director's instructions" (challenges made to decide how the battle will go). The story gets awkward halfway through when they start trying to write in some romance dialogue that's off putting and feels out of character. "Do you like coffee?" "... yes.." "Ok. I'll leave you alone forever now." "...thanks..." I guess it boils down to whether or not I actually enjoyed the game. With all of its bad writing and gameplay that becomes stale pretty quick, you'd think I didn't, but it was fun. It gets a little draining, but overall it was enjoyable.

39119362.review:
Chroma Squad é um jogo brasileiro que consegue prender a sua atenção desde o início, é claramente inspirado nos Power Rangers, com direito até a batalhas de megazords.

Possui uma estória interessante (com 3 finais diferentes, dependendo das suas escolhas), gráficos em pixel art muito bem feito, uma trilha sonora legal e uma jogabilidade incrível.

É um RPG tático onde é possível combinar os ataques dos rangers. Cada ranger tem uma classe e cada classe tem seu papel na batalha e sua própria árvore de habilidades.
Possui elementos de gerenciamento de equipe, através de melhorias para o estúdio e contrato de agências de marketing.

Recomendo demais para quem gosta do gênero e para quem não gosta também. :D

[h1] Onde Começar [/h1]
[b] Um dos melhores jogos que ja vi em toda minha vida. [/b]

[h1] RESUMO [/h1]

O jogo é sobre um grupo de dublês de um seriado no estilo Power Rangers que se cansa de seu diretor e decidem fazer a própria série, e você dono do jogando sendo o [i] "diretor" [/i] da trama, controlando os passos, cenas de luta e etc. [spoiler] (mesmo sendo eles fazendo tudo, você meio que controla... Ah! Você entendeu! [/spoiler]

[h1] Gráficos [/h1]

Em questão gráfica, mesmo não sendo um Gta V, ou Quantum Breack da vida, os gráficos são [i] lindus [/i] D+, são coloridos e divertidos, sem contar que toda vez que algum personagem fala ele faz um pose! [spoiler] (oque é mais legal que power rangers que fazem POSES, POSES!!!!!) [/spoiler] , tem também a questão de variedade de roupas e de armas, são 6 leves de roupas [spoiler] loucas dos super joper's (é o nome dos minha equipe ;-;) [/spoiler] o comum, o incomun, o raro, o mega, o alien e o lendario [spoiler] (não me pergunte o por quê de alien) [/spoiler] , a também o ROBO GIGANTESCAMENTE GIGANTE FODASTICO e suas 5 partes personalizáveis, cada pedaço do robo (pernas, braço direito, cabeça, braço esquerdo e o torax) podem ser modificadas para LUTAS EPICAS.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Já na questão de gameplay o jogo na fica para traz, ele é um tatical Rpg, ou seja, um jogo onde vocês controla os todos os personagens [spoiler] (que são os SEUS OBVIAMENTE SEU FILHOTE DE MORSA) [/spoiler], assim seu objetivo geralmente é acabar com o Chefão, mas a também os objetivos do diretor que te a ajudam na coisa mais importante de todo o jogo, a audiência, ela serve literalmente para te dar seu dinheiro, quanto mais você conseguir em um episódio (que são as fazes) mais fãns e MONEY MONEY MODAFACA você ganha.
[list]
[*] Crie sua equipe com lider, superte, tecnico, lutador e batedor.

[*] Ganhe moneys.
[*] Gaste tudo em roupas e armas desnecessárias.
[*] Faça combos epicos.
[*] DIVIRTA-SE
[/list]

38918815.review:
[h1] Chroma Squad [/h1]

What can i say about Chroma Squad? I think it's the only game i've ever played that REALLY made me have some kind of connection with the characters. I started doing another run (to get the game 100% completed) and almost gave up because i didn't want to play the game with a different team (i actually could choose the same team and give the same names to the characters but after playing the game and seeing that the attributes i chose in my first run were messed up, doing the same thing again would be stupid). I guess i can explain better with the classic pros and cons.

[b] Pros [/b]

[list]
[*] Extremely catchy story
[*] Extremely catchy soundtrack (i recommend buying it)
[*] Very funny speech lines (at least on the portuguese version)
[*] Replayability (to get all achievements, you need to play the game at least 3 times, which means 30+ hours)
[*] Awesome combat system (similar to Wakfu and Dofus)
[*] Makes you feel like the characters are actual people
[*] May be a little bit cliche, but the game (mainly because of the soundtrack) still gives you chills
[*] Crafting system
[*] Pixelized Power Rangers
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]

[list]
[*] Doesn't have a sequel
[/list]


[b] Conclusion/Resume: [/b]

Chroma Squad is a really good and unique game. You can customize literally everything you want in your team, craft new items and swap abilities anytime you want. It has a very good, attractive and easy to master battle system. The characters and the humor of the game are simply awesome, the story (even though cliche) is very addictive and will get you playing for hours and the soundtrack is a masterpiece. I'd easily give this work of art a 10/10.

If you're reading the reviews to decide if the game is worth buying, well... i'd press the "Add to Cart" button for you, but i can't. 




[spoiler] A useful tip for the beginners: In battle, you can switch between characters by clicking on the square (on the left of the screen) of the respective character [/spoiler]

38888029.review:
I'm only 3 hours in and already love the game. It's not as in-depth as similiar, more traditional turn based games like Final Fantasy Tactics but it's still very satisfying. Enemies drop items that can be used to craft weapons and armor which I didn't expect from this type of game. Each of your characters get new skills each season and which ones you choose give you a sense of personalization, its not as in depth as a job system (FFT) but it's nice. A big part of the game is "teamwork" which will let your characters do things like throw one another around to get over an obstacle or use multiple characters and do a team attack which is essentially just like 3 characters kicking the shit out of one enemy. Staying in line with the power rangers theme there are giant robot battles which are based more off timed attacks and blocking than actual strategy (think FF Lightning Returns). 
It's a little cheesy and actually funny in a lot of parts as even the characters at some points are like "isn't this a little much?" or "why are we doing this?". I got this game on sale for 3$ but would most certainly pay more knowing how enjoyable it is. If you like strategy games or just want some light hearted comedy, get this game.

38776413.review:
[b]An enjoyable tactical RPG with cheese galore for all your super sentai nostalgia.[/b]

I loved my time with this game, quite honestly, in a large part thanks to the perfect understanding of what made the old shows amusing. Cheesy lines, silly storylines played up until you get a shiver saying "epic" despite your best reasoning and a sense of satisfaction from the repeated, well-made sequences of transformation, finishing moves and whatnot. Giving the ability to customise often used lines and even the team name allows to turn this factor up to eleven.

This is backed up by a very well made content of missions, each of them a chain of several tactical fights, sometimes ending with a quick-timey battle in your Mecha. While this last part might sound bad, its execution is better than you would expect - the fights are basically just timing button presses with a little bit of strategy sprinkled in, but the audio-visual effects and plenty of impactful, meaty slowdowns make this feel better. And honestly, how interesting can you make something as awkward as the kaiju fights from Power Rangers and the like?

The on-foot combat is much more nuanced, with a few enemy types introduced over the course of the game and a tonne of boss monsters. Fair warning, some of them are very similar, including two that are basically reskinned - I didn't like that decision, but thankfully the RNG in those fights made it actually engaging. Equipment and skills are drip fed to the player as well, helping to familiarize yourself slowly with how the game works. Puzzlingly, that doesn't mean everything is explained all that well; skill regen is the main example, it is more convoluted than you would expect, requiring some digging to familiarize yourself with the inner workings of it. At the same time, this might be just me being pedantic - for a normal player, the idea that the higher it is, the better for your skills is probably everything needed.

The combat stands out from a run-of-the-mill tactical grid in two ways. First, there is a big focus on 'teamwork' stance, another engine for sentai nostalgia. Your characters can propel each other around for high-distance jumps, join forces in an attack and even perform a finishing move when the entire squad joins in (with a bonus, [b]very[/b] Power Ranger-esque animation if that is done with weapon attacks). Several nuances are built into this mechanic - Lead boosts your Audience and damage if he is a part of a team move, Assault can throw people really far while Support heals in AoE every time they enter teamwork.
And yes, I said Audience, that is the second thing. Your team is a bunch of stuntmen working on an indie super sentai show, which means you have to go through every mission (dubbed 'episode') in a possibly most fan-pleasing way. There are special goals (director's instruction) that give you bonus audience, aside from steady income on teamwork moves and just beating baddies. Each character can unlock skills catering to their fanbase: Support lovers will want to see them heal even more, while Scout is cheered for when they zip across the battlefield. The audience is no small deal, and sometimes you will have to either sacrifice fan growth (and thus money) for efficiency in combat or vice versa. Later on, director's instructions become quite the challenge, satisfying to fulfil.

The game is not without its fault, and the difficulty curve is pretty uneven; I played on Challenging, which meant that most of the time game required reasonable tactical thinking, but some episodes/instructions can send you back to the drawing board many-many times. I already touched on the problems with copy-pasted enemies and not everything being perfectly clear, so let me add two more to this list. One, it is pretty hard to switch your strategy on the inventory level. The crafting system demands a lot of materials, so destroying old weapons is mandatory. Now, that wouldn't be so bad if not for the inherently random nature of crafting, that means you might go up a tier of equipment but finish with a substandard set of traits (especially dangerous on class-specific items). You can still make it through the game, or lower the difficulty if you are desperate, but the problem exists.

All in all, however, we have a loveable indie title here, one that brings you back to the time when you rushed, as a kid, to the TV for yet another same-ish episode of Power Rangers. Except here, it is self-aware of everything that entails.

Que decir de Chroma Squad?Un juego que todo el que le tenga cariño a el Sentai le va encantar,con explosiones,volteretas,poses exageradas y guays ademas de luchas de mechas contra Kaijus¡¡

Despues de jugar en maxima dificultad y estar haciendo otro final,me apetecio empezar el analisis(por que si,tiene tres finales)

Chroma Squad es un juego tactico RPG,tenemos dos ocasiones para movernos,una normal y otra para movernos mas o hacer alguna accion,el juego empieza con ataques muy basicos,pero con el tiempo,tendreis mas habilidades,las cuales,podeis cambiar entre algunas de las ramas,creedme,cuando mas avanzes,mas divertido es¡¡(y por supuesto,mas dificil)

Si debo resaltar del juego son casi todo cosas buenas
+La traduccion al español es de las mejorcitas que he visto,se nota que esta hecho con aprecio¡¡(cosa rarisima de ver,lo hicieron con esfuerzo y dedicacion y se nota)
+El humor es super simpatico
+Referencias a tutiplen,personalmente,de los juegos que mejor las llevan y usan
+Gestionar tu estudio es genial,es muy tactico y es la parte mas calmada del juego,incluso te envian mensajes que puedes responder
+Por una cosa u otra,segun lo que escojas puede cambiar una escena,lo que hace que puedan pasar varias cosas¡
+Los finales alternativos se diferencias bastante bien(especialmente uno de ellos,que es otro mundo)
+La intro en japones,una maravilla¡¡
+Con mucha personalidad

Eso si,hay cosas que desmejoran por alguna cosa
+-La musica es pegadiza y se adapta a la situacion,aunque puede llegar a hacerse repetitiva

y aqui vienen algunos fallos que tambien hay que decir
-La variedad de escenarios no llega a ser tan grande
-Las batallas puede hacerse pesadas,especialmente al principio,ya que no tendremos casi habilidades
-Bugs extraños de personajes fusionandose,fuera de combate o dentro(por suerte solo me paso una vez en combate)

Para mi Resumen,chroma Squad es un juego que e disfrutado y me da buenos recuerdos de cuando era pequeño y  veia los power rangers con mi hermano pequeño,me ha hecho sonreir y reir y eso...no tiene precio¡¡

This game is a very good example of how an outstanding game can be made without resorting to fancy graphics, 3D stuff, orchestral music etc. If you have a good idea and creativity it is possible to achieve amazing results and this is exactly the case of this game.
The story is based on the famous Japanese sentai series. It has the perfect measure of being silly, cheesy, funny, and very enjoyable, especially if you used to like those kinds of TV programs. The plot progression is quite cool and the scenarios are fun to play through. Besides, the music is well done and adds a lot to the game’s atmosphere.
The gameplay is quite nice and enjoyable, even though you do not have a lot of choices to develop your characters and the equipment variety doesn’t add much to the strategies you can use – usually it is very easy to identify the best equipment available at the time and forget the rest.
In sum, although it is not at the level of a Final Fantasy Tactics or a Tactics Ogre, I had a great deal of fun with this game and would certainly recommend for those who like turn-based strategy games.

Buggiest piece of shit I have ever had the dishonor of dealing with. It runs on Windows, but if I clear certain director side missions, the game freezes (Humble DRM-free version). And I can't clear certain bosses on certain game modes. Wow. What a waste of time, but I figure eh, maybe it's cuz it isn't the Steam version.

So I try it on Linux.

Somehow it's even more disappointing than just randomly wasting my time. Now I can't even play it.

9/10 times on Linux the window resizes itself to so small I can't see it or so big it crashes the DE (it tried to take 2 TiB of RAM to allocate this much room in the Sys monitor. Then it crashed the whole thing). Wow. But you know, maybe it's just the engine or something, right? Maybe it's just fuckin' with me and wants me to do things a certain way. Fine.

I finally get it to work. I'm excited I can finally give it a try. Overjoyed if you will. The exciting music at the title screen gives me a goddamn boner. I move the mouse down and click, and the mouse is reset to the middle of the screen. Oh, the game is just trying to capture my mouse I think. Now it has it, I should be good. I go to click it again. 36901339.review:
This is a good, albeit flawed gem.
On one side, the combat is solid, with the need to control the battlefield being the top priority, movement can be enhanced through partnership and powers, and it has a good-ish story that don't deviate from the 'power of friendship and hope' from older shows. Every member of the squad has specific roles that can and will be needed at all times, and some references are spot-on. The music is based on the super nintendo era, and some pieces are really good, specially "Hardboiled" and "Monster Jam".

On the other hand...

The loot and crafting is messy and can be quite a headache if you need specific gear for your team, everything is randomized, how many items you get, if you get said items, and which items. There are two kinds of gear, crafted, and bought. Bought items always have specific stats, and crafted ones have the advantage of two or three 'extra' stats. The problem is, said stats are randomized too.

And boy, it can be quite buggy. In my run, the game auto-skipped the first speech of every character in a scene, the music would suddenly stop, and sometimes it interloped with the menu music if I started the stage too fast.

So, if you want a nice strategy game, and are not afraid of some minor bugs, get this gem!

36152139.review:
Chroma Squad is a pleasant, but somewhat janky TRPG with a solid grasp of Super Sentai's themes and feel. The game is quite easy, at least on Normal difficulty, but adds challenge via special instructions for each mission. While it is linear, you are also able to choose the order of regular missions building up to the season boss.

As a TRPG, it works. Each class has unique skills available to them, though I found little-to-no reason to ever change from the build I assembled, and as there's no way to change actors once a file has been made, it's possible to give a character an asynergetic role, especially when salaries are presented as a factor you'll need to concern yourself with when they're meaningless beyond Season 1.

Chroma Squad brings a few fresh concepts to the table, as well. A "Teamwork" button allows gang-up attacks and throwing allies, but because gang-ups must be basic attacks and throwing distance is individualized, I ended up just having my slow strongman pitch my leader where I want the team, then using his group up skill to bring everyone else over. Teamwork also enables you to use the often-mission-fulfilling finishing move, but it can be a bit awkward positioning every ally adjacent to the boss, especially when many foes have knockback and at least one unit is range-based. Finally, Teamwork locks in a turn. If anything results in your not being adjacent to the target when it's time to combo them, such as the fixed camera angle concealing a tile or random knockback, the turn is wasted.

Assembling a mecha is one of the more enjoyable parts of the game, and adds some variety. Mecha battles used to be pure RNG, but have been updated to a more timed-hit basis. Still, even a perfect guard takes chip damage, which I imagine can frustrate players.

Overall, Chroma Squad is palpably a mobile game, but an excellent one, only lacking in freedom of variety due to locking in characters and having such static roles for static missions. The soundtrack is also excellent, but $5 is a little steep for any soundtrack, if you ask me.

35432554.review:
Chroma Squad is by all accounts an entertaining game, and if you have been craving a Tactical RPG - and you're willing to overlook many a flaw - it will certainly satisfy that desire; but will it leave you coming back for more? 

Probably not.

Chroma Squad has so much going for it: the visuals are vibrant, the music is catchy, the battles are fun, the upgrades are plentiful, and the ability to create your own Squad is a dream come true; which is why its flaws are so infuriating.

Chroma Squad suffers from an incredibly bad story. More often than not, I found myself skipping through painfully stale dialogue that constantly fails to make any sense at all. Chroma Squad attempts to replicate the 'terrible-but-entertaining' stories of the TV shows it's influenced by, but it doesn't quite manage to achieve the same effect. The story is tongue-in-cheek and far too self-aware, causing an already incoherent plot to throw any hope of logic out the window.

Now if it sounds like I'm being too hard on a game that doesn't take itself too seriously, remember that a Tactical RPG generally focuses heavily on two areas: strategy and story, and when the one element is lacking, it's usually left up to the other to compensate.

Unfortunately Chroma Squad doesn't involve much strategy at all.

Each character fills a specific role in your squad; the Assist squad member has supporting skills that allows them to heal other members, the Scout squad member has a larger movement range, etc. As you complete seasons, you unlock more skills, gaining the ability to further customise your characters to fit your play style. These skills - while fun to execute - serve only to hasten the inevitable victory.

The battles are simple; while that isn't a bad thing, it does cause the game to lose its appeal with the limited challenge the game presents. Episodes generally devolve into a routine of clearing waves of enemies and then battling a giant-sized version of the boss with your Mech while completing a set of tasks called 'Director's Instructions' for bonuses to your Audience meter. This means more long-term fans and money.

Speaking of money, you'll be able to outfit your squad with a number of different items purchasable from the store or crafted yourself from the materials enemies drop. It's such a treat to watch as your squad who started out wearing buckets for helmets progress to wearing awesome space helmets.

The soundtrack is catchy at best and repetitive at worst. At the start of the game, the music will seem like a beautiful work of Chiptune - which it is - but as you approach Season 5, the limited number of tracks becomes annoyingly obvious.

Chroma Squad is rife with bad design choices, but it isn't an entirely bad game, and you'll either love it or hate depending on whether you can get behind its story and one-tone gameplay. I had fun with it for little over two hours, but two hours do not justify that price. 

I would suggest looking elsewhere for your Tactical RPG fix.

35406755.review:
[h1] CHROMA SQUAD [/h1]

Depois de platinar o jogo há alguns meses, decidi fazer esta análise pra expressar o sentimento que esse jogo me causou.
O jogo foi desenvolvido pela incrível empresa brasileira "Behold Studios", que na minha opinião é de longe uma das melhores empresas indies, estando no mesmo nível que a Chucklefish e a The Behemoth.

O jogo é incrível em todos os aspectos, um gráfico fantástico, com uma animação excelente, lotado de referências (que convenhamos, são todas geniais) e efeitos especiais de cair o queijo.
A trilha sonora muito bem feita, inclusive a música tema (que é fantástica) e as músicas de batalha [spoiler] (a música da batalha contra o Lord Gaga é fantástica) [/spoiler] .

O enredo dispensa comentários, muito bem elaborado, com 3 finais totalmente diferentes e partes até emocionantes que te fazem sentir um herói de verdade que protege a terra contra qualquer mal, existem também diversos momentos engraçados com uma comédia leve e genial, afinal, quem nunca brincou de [strike] Power Rangers [/strike] Chroma Squad com os amigos?

As mecânicas do jogo são únicas e muito bem programadas, não encontrei um bug sequer durante todo o gameplay, todo o sistema de [i] crafting [/i] funciona muito bem, o sistema de [i] marketing [/i] é extremamente simples e essencial, mas pode te levar para outro nível de dinheiro se usado de forma inteligente,  as batalhas são o ponto forte do jogo, sistema muito bem balanceado, exige bastante estratégia e conhecimento das diversas habilidades disponibilizadas para cada classe, o sistema de coop entre os personagens me salvou de diversas situações apertadíssimas e os chefes são todos muito bem elaborados, até mesmo durante as FUCKING BATALHAS COM O ROBÔ GIGANTE.

Por fim, posso dizer que esse jogo DEVE estar na biblioteca de todo bom fã de RPG's Táticos, mesmo a preço inteiro, vale cada centavo definitivamente, não me decepcionei em nenhum momento.

PS: As recentes atualizações deixaram o jogo mais perfeito ainda com o remake do sistema de batalha nas segundas vidas dos chefes.

Gráfico 10/10
Mecânicas 10/10
Trilha sonora 10/10
Enredo 10/10

This is consummately charming. A clever homage to the self depricating fandom surrounding sentai shows that uses simple systems to provide a perfectly playable strategy game.

Some abilities from the player's side don't work as clearly as I'd like them to (especially the teamwork jumps) and some of the monster abilities feel a bit unfair but once you wrap your head around those things the game plays smoothly and is perfect for a few minutes of sentai fun.

The crafting system unfortunately is the major downfall, some items being so rare to find but so common for building that I only used the cash gear for an entire tier of equipment out of expedience rather than any meaningful, tactical choice on my part. Additionally some of the numbers and upgrades to the crafting system make absolutely no sense. After beating it I still don't know what "Crafting Rate" means.

Still, I enjoyed the meat of the game. The style (which is perfectly Behold Studios) is a lot of fun, the strategy was a good time, and I got to wax nostalgic for something I haven't really thought about for 20 years.

34873080.review:
Because other negative reviews of this game are so bad that the reviews deserve negative reviews, I thought I would provide some input. I actually did seek this game out unlike some others, though I did acquire it in a bundle, I bought that bundle just for this game. Pretty good deal, really. 

I love Super Sentai stuff, I love Voltron, I loved the new Power Rangers movie. I love tactical RPGs; Final Fantasy Tactics, Front Mission, etc. It seemed like this would be the perfect game for me. Unfortunately, there's also a tactical RPG I hate: Disgaea. Disgaea and this game only have a few things in common.

In Disgaea there is a Sentai (Power Rangers) Parody mission, and Disgaea's plot is full on joke after joke with never a serious moment. The Power Rangers mission was the best joke in the game, but it gets dull, especially when you don't find the jokes funny. Like many Indie games, Chroma Squad cannot fucking turn it off. It's full on quirky so much that even the cute jokes like Construction Walkers (Zombies Construction Workers) lose their appeal in the sea of 'hilarity'. It's too much. 

Yes the writing in those older shows, and some of the newer stuff based off of them, was not Shakespeare. But, let's be real. It was not as terrible as people remember, and some of the plots are legendarily entertaining. This game does not have good writing, or good plots. It's just 'intentionally' bad. The stories Framework as being in a studio pretending to film a Sentai show wears thin, and meaningless upgrades are rendered to you via a meta joke that gets old fast. In fact, since it's an indie game you can expect endless meta jokes. In fact, the plot of this game where they cannot really tell reality from what they're doing sometimes because it's all so meaninglessly squished together itself becomes a meta joke, which begets the plot, which was another joke all along. It ends up being a confusing, incoherent mess that wasn't enjoyable. It totally fails to capture the enjoyment of the genre it's parodying and it comes off as not even understanding it.

The gameplay itself is low rent. It's missing vital options like enabling the grid, which really would have helped with coordinating movement ranges which become a major thing. Especially when mid game becomes a bounce house of everyone being tossed all over. Ultimately the gameplay is 'fill this meter by repeatedly using the same tired special skill over and over'. It's fun at first, but then it gets old fast. 

Then you have the mecha fights, which should be the absolute coolest. They aren't. Do you like QTE? Because it's a QTE. And after a certain point it's in every mission. 

There's something called Director's Missions which are technically required. You could ignore them but it would result in basically failing after a certain point. Some of these missions are poorly worded, and use very unclear terminology that the game hasn't actually gone out of its way to explain. Other times they're literally impossible without foreknowledge or RNG. One example was to get 6 consecutive combo on an enemy in mecha. Unfortunately I was too strong and it proved literally impossible due to the way the QTE sequence is designed to reset after each health bar is knocked off. 

As far as RPGs go, there's no leveling up. It's 100% equipment based. Some of the equipment does look pretty cool as you move on, however it also all has its own unique look. So that kind of makes the squad look weird when half of them are dressed differently, again somewhat going against the theme of the game. 

Sometimes the game itself doesn't even know what it's talking about. In the late game I still have trouble hitting a certain mook who's been around since chapter 2 at least, if not 1. Yet it tells me a boss has a super high hit rate and that I have to use skills, but I never once miss the boss. Now you could say 'that's just the RNG' and speaking of RNG, one of the director's missions was to never miss a hit once. Thanks, you can guess how well that went over. 

I don't hate this game, but I would not recommend it to anyone unless you love indies and need to kill time. This is a weak excuse for a tactical RPG or a Sentai/Power Rangers reference. I just can't help but feel that the vision of what was announced for this game is not the end result. Not even for $15 do I think this game is worthwhile. Maybe $5.

34700719.review:
Lights, Camera, Chromatize!

I've 100% completed this game so I not only feel entitled, but also morally obligated to shove my opinion down your throat. Deal with it.

Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG in the same vein as Nintendo's Fire Emblem series, but with a strange twist. Instead of being a knight or a dude with spikey hair and a giant sword, you play as a group of five stuntmen who act in a Power Rangers inspried show, complete with cheesy catchphrases and mech battles.

Chroma Squad's story is pretty simple. Your goal is to film each of the gangs' adventures for their TV show. Things seem fine at first, but the group begins to realize that their adventures may be more fact than fiction. I won't spoil any of the three endings, but they're all great.

Gameplay: As previosuly mentioned, this game runs in a similar way to the Fire Emblem series. For those who are uninitiated into weeb culture, Fire Emblem (and this game) do away with the idea that in turn-based battles your characters all stand in a line. Instead, you move them around a grid to get an advantage and perform special moves. One of this game's most important features is its' teamwork specials. By having a member of Chroma Squad perform the Teamwork move, other member can perform teamwork attack, Finishers, or Team Acrobatics which extend your sprint range. At the end of each episode, how well you did will be tallied into "Audience Points", which are then converted into your profit and fans. You'll also recieve materials which can be used to craft better weapons and armor for your squad.

Mecha Battles: These are, in my opinion, the most fun part of the game. At the end of most episodes from Season 2 and on, the boss you fight will grow to gigantic size! In order to combat this, your Squad gears up thier Mecha bot. Your bot and the enemy then take turns hitting eachother, defending, and performing specials. Each time you attack, your percent chance of hitting goes down by 10%, meaning you'll have to be careful to balance your attacks and defences. You can also use the materials you recieve or buy to upgrade parts of your mecha in order to increased attack, defence, hit chance, or give new specials.

Customization: There are a total of 5 rangers on your squad. The techie is best at dealing ranged damage. The Scout is the best at sneaking in, dealing damage, and getting out. The Assualt is good at hitting things really really hard. The Support is for healing your team, and the Lead is for keeping your team organized so they don't become too thinly spread. Within each ranger, there are 6 actors you can choose from who each gives their own extra stats. For instance, the lead in my first playthrough had the Asimobot actor, while my second playthrough used Mr. Beaver. Beyond that, you can also choose the nicknames of your rangers and what colors their suits are! :D

Pros:
1. Simple gameplay that's easy to pick up, but still has some depth for experienced players
2. The story is just interesting enough to keep you invested
3. Multiple endings adds a ton to the replay value
4. Four levels of difficuly most different types of players (Casual for those who want to see the story, up to Legendary for those who want a callenge)
5. It's so gosh darn charming! Each boss has their own personality and taglines, and it makes me feel so fuzzy inside. <3

Cons:
1. There are occasionaly a few visual glitches, but unless you're a real stickler, they shouldn't hinder your experience much.
2. The only real complaint I have is how short the story is. In total, one playthrough of the campaign takes about 15 hours. Again, this is brought up to about 45 hours between 3 different endings, but the 2nd and 3rd playthrough are mostly filler until the last season.

If you don't play this game, you're doing a disservice to yourself. This game is filled with so much charm with it's characters, palette, and story, you'll find it hard to stop playing. Prop all of that up with awesome gameplay, and you've got yourself an awesome way to spend 40+ hours.

9.5/10, HIghly recommended.

34659434.review:
Chroma Squad ou l'univers étrange des Sentai, ces séries TV japonaises complètement barrées et frisant l'amateurisme qui ont en commun des héros en armure de lycra luttant contre des monstres de latex venus de l'espace.

Le jeu nous propose de contrôler 5 amis, acteurs amateurs, qui décident de produire leur propre série de Sentai. On alternera tout au long de la partie entre deux expériences de jeu : un gameplay gestion durant les phases de production et un gameplay tactical durant les phases de tournage, le tout saupoudré d'une BO déjantée et entraînante.

Les phases de gestion se révèlent bien fun, entre créations de costumes maison (du craft avec des boites de carton et des morceaux de plastique), achat de matériel de tournage, courrier des fans et un peu de marketing pour faire connaître la série. L'amateurisme total de notre équipe de héros n'a d'égal que leur générosité et leur passion sans borne. Une aventure humaine assez proche finalement de la création d'un jeu indépendant comme nous le rappelle fréquemment les développeurs à travers de nombreux clins d'oeil et brisage de 4e mur. On regrettera juste une interface perfectible (pas accès aux statistiques des héros depuis le menu de craft notamment), mais dans l'ensemble on s'amuse, ça fonctionne bien.

Du côté des phases tactical, on retrouve bien évidemment cet humour aussi généreux que ridicule avec poses absurdes, réparties bidons et oublis de scénarios. L'expérience tactique se montre plutôt light. On reste sur les basiques avec des rôles bein définis, auxquels le jeu ajoute des acrobaties et attaques coordonnées pour coller à la thématique, ainsi qu'une poignée de pouvoirs à cooldowns.
On regrettera tout de même un level design en dessous de tout, avec quasiment pas d'obstacles (seule une map en propose), une IA qui n'agit plus quand elle est hors de l'écran et une difficulté davantage gérée par le nombre de points de vie plutôt que par la forme du niveau ou les comportements ennemis -il y a pas mal de variété pour le coup mais l'effet est plombé par la platitude du level design. Il y a aussi ces phases récurrentes en mecha, mal foutues et monotones, mais bon, le ton parodique et léger du titre fait passer la pilule.

Au final il m'aura fallu une vingtaine d'heures pour terminer le jeu une première fois (il y a 3 fins différentes, déblocables via le new game+ ou en créant une nouvelle équipe de héros). Ce n'est pas le tactical du millénaire, loin s'en faut, mais si vous n'êtes pas un fan hardcore de Fire Emblem et consors, et ouvert à la parodie un peu débile, j'aurais tendance à le recommander.

34537598.review:
I bought Disgaea 5 on the Nintendo Switch and it was my first experience with a tactics/strategy RPG. I sold it after about an hour of forced gameplay due to the price I'd paid.

This is now my second experience with a game like that... and I think this game is downright fun, and amazing. The 2 games are not identical by any means, but for those new to a strategy RPG, Chroma Squad is an excellent place to start whereas something like Disgaea dropped you in with no guidance at all.

It is most definitely influenced by the likes of Power Rangers and other hits from this genre. The gameplay is so much fun and it's made incredibly easy by design. I love the challenge that this game has but it also is very understanding for those who have trouble learning the tactics of a game like this.

I know that there are plenty of games similar to this and many have their favorites. When I saw the first level of this was strategy play, I immediately thought "here we go again with another crap game I got in a bundle" but then I beat the first level. And another... and another.

And I kept playing and I haven't stopped. Something about being able to make your own team of fighters is so much fun. You have a lot of options to make the Chroma Squad feel like your own. The bosses are really funny and play into the mechanics well. It banks hard on nostalgia does it perfectly.

The story is not amazing but it's definitely cheesy and hits all of the right notes for the game. I skip the scenes every once in awhile because I'm just ready to play more of the game. This is a lot of fun for the right price, or if you're looking for this type of game I'd recommend it.

34136975.review: Basically, you run a studio that makes Power Rangers titles. Each "episode" of your show is comprised of some rudimentary plot and a turn-based tactical battle reminiscent of Final Fantasy Tactics. Episode ratings are determined by the flashiness of the skills you perform, the damage you take, and other such metrics. The actual gameplay itself lacks depth in all aspects, from the actual battle system (which is the meat of the title) to the under-developed studio management. Essentially, you will increase ratings by hiring the most expensive promotion team, using all of your skills in every fight, and buying the most expensive equipment. I had fun playing it, but there's a lot of other titles that are more deserving of your money.

можно подходить с определённой выдумкой и тактикой.

В субьективный недостаток можно, справедливости ради, записать графику - это пиксель арт который, скажу честно, даже мне несколько надоел уже. Но тем не менее надо признать что нарисовано всё тщательно и с вниманием к деталям.

Напоследок хотелось бы добавить что в игре чувствуется ДУША. Действительно видно что игру делали ребята которым нравилось то что они делают, что тема игры взята не просто для того чтобы сыграть на ностальгии а потому что они по настоящему любят всё это. Понимаете о чём я?

Это не супер шедевр но зато это очень приятная, тёплая и добрая история с которой не хочется расставаться точно так же как с какой-нибудь хорошей книгой.

33919119.review:
Micromanage a team of rangers as they try and save Earth!

Graphics:
Being a loved of pixel graphics, this game immediatley appealed to me.  The art style and bright colors really popped out to me and made me smile.  All the spites are well detailed and animated.  A lot of love whent into the graphics!

Sound:
Bieng that I bought the soundtrack, that tells you that I LOVED the sound of this game.  The soundtrack was always a joy to listen to and the sound effects were funny and great!  So much as that I BOUGHT the soundtrack! I especially loved the impact sounds when you got a critical on enemies!

Control:
Bieng this was point and click, there were few issues with it, save for an instance here or there were it would seem you can click a spot when you can't.  Other than that, no issues whatsoever!  I did not get to try the addiction joystick controls that were recently added.

Gameplay:
Managing a team of stuntment as they evolve into actual rangers may seem silly, but it works well!  You have a finite amount of resources to deal with as your try to buy equipment or crafting supplies and crafting equipment or new parts for your mech.  You gain money from beginning of season grants, completing episodes and crafting supplies from enemy drops.  You also control what abilities they bring into battle, and they gain more as you complete seasons.

Each battle is a careful dance of keeping your rangers alive and trying to complete Director Instructions, additional episode objectives that gain you extra money and audiance, but can be difficult to do at time.  Many battles were very difficult but never unfair or cheap, and at least for me, you could always come back from a major screw up.  The mecha battles used to be difficult, having to deal the RNG, btu after the Director's Cut, this is now alleviated by a reaction bar minigame, making it easier to perform combos and survive battles.

The story also gave me a smile with each episode, which felt like I was watching an old tokusatsu show!  From dealing with a silly moment to saving citizens from petrification, this game's episodes were always fun to play!  The jokes werte always funny and never ham fisted.  Props to the writers!

This is an excellent game to play and watch!  My lil sister enjoyed watching it as well.  She never got to see the ending, but I know she would have loved it.  Please, support the devs and BUY THIS GAME!

33917461.review:
I know I've only played 43 minutes, but that's about all of this game I can take. There's just not a lot to be liked here, and quite frankly I don't know why it has so many positive reviews. The game can't decide if it wants to take itself seriously or not, constantly switching between in show dialog. (character to character) and studio dialog (actor to actor out of character) This makes the game feel really jerky, and the transitions don't make any sense. The game play is repetitive and confusing. The way you move to determine your attack range isn't intuitive, and doesn't really make a whole lot of sense. One character might be able to make a hit from a specific distance, but another character (even with the same general stats) can't make the same hit. 

As stated above, the game can't decide if it's going to be serious or not. The game can't decide if it's going to be an action oriented, turn based RPG, or just a humorous game with RPG elements thrown it. When it tries to be serious it never succeeds, and when it tries to be funny the humor just falls flat. It's full of all the kitschy cliches you could ask for, and not even the endearing kind.  The game also has a real “what the hell are we doing?” kind of vibe. No single idea in the game seems to be fleshed out enough. It's very jerky, and can't really stick to one plot line long enough. 

I can't really recommend this one, and will be asking for a refund. It's even more of a disappointment because I had heard such good things about this game, and had such high hopes for it. 

It fails,both as an RPG and a tribute to all things Power Rangers and Super Sentai

1/5 Highly disappointing.

33711594.review:
EXTREMELY catchy chiptune soundtrack, hilarious and often self-aware parodical humor, lovely visuals, fire emblem-esque combat system with a few cool twists and spins, challenging fights, and multiple choices & endings for some replayability as the cherry ontop of this already satisfying treat. (A few in-between micromanagement mechanics for some added depth as well.)

Yup, these ingredients are a recipe for an incredibly fun game that's deserving of it's Overwhelmingly Positive rating, and these ingredients are also what makes up Chroma Squad, the challenging and quirky Sentai parody game. Weird concept, but they executed it oh so well. It makes my personal indie GOTY list for sure!

Oh, and did I mention you can almost completely customize your squad; being able to change the name of your squad, it's team members, your studio, certain abilites, and a few other plot points? Seeing how all that affects the dialogue in the story makes it feel incredibly personalized, especially if you're like me and form the Groovy Rangers, the best team of monster-fighting disco-themed-friends on Earth!

Trust me, y'all got nothing to lose from buying this game. Maybe $15, but what else were you gonna buy with that? A pizza? Who needs that when you've got a full course meal of fun content for your buck?

33604122.review:
I'm a big fan of SRPGs, and Chroma Squad definitely delivers. I was never a huge fan of Power Rangers, but I had fun with the style and the references. I thought the writing was pretty good as well - it's always nice to see progressive messages pop up in gaming these days. In terms of gameplay, you get to pick different roles at the beginning and those are your characters for the whole game, so I could see really managing to mess yourself up right from the getgo if you don't pick a balanced team. The "director's instructions" really add a lot to each fight, encouraging you to complete little mini-objectives for bonus money and fans.

In terms of the mecha fights, I was playing before the big patch and found mecha fights to be very scary, requiring me to really balance my resources between my team and my mecha. After the patch, I found them to be almost laughably easy and I never suffered another knockdown, so I think they may have over-corrected somewhat. But still, they're fun and cool ways to end big battles.

It is hard to say this game is worth 15 bucks when Disgaea costs 20, but I got about 10 or 12 hours out of it (I play offline frequently which messes up my stats), and in those terms it's easily a fair price.

33594835.review:
As a huge fan of Power Rangers, and I mean a HUGE fan, I love this game. It has so many jokes, references, and fun packed in to this great indie title. This is not just "inspired by Power Rangers", it's its soul. This is no "Power Rangers" game. THIS IS POWER RANGERS. And for that, I am so greatful. This is one of the best games I've ever played, and one of the best written. It is a masterpiece in that respect.

As it is in others. The gameplay, a short buisness management and crafting side pairs nicely with the more heavily present Mecha Fights (skill-based QTEs) and a Turn-Based Squad-Focused element, similar to XCOM, but not as complex. It is beautifully done. It is extremely well polished, and I have encountered little to no bugs on my runs through this game, and those present are fixed by hitting ESC and resuming.

Aside from gameplay, this game's Soundtrack is one of the best I have ever heard. Great variations from area to area, amazing use, as well as being catchy as hell and never gets old or grinding on the ears. The pixelated art style and an 8-bit inspired composition have been done before, but not as fantastically as done here, in my opinion.

Any fan of Turn-Based RPGs, any fan of Power Rangers (or the Sentai), or any fan of a good game with kind devs and great content updates (for free) buy this game. It comes very highly recommended.

33293299.review:
Charming setting, but flat mechanics.
Graphics and humour are on point, but gameplay suffers from limited options.
Behind the facade of an XCOM-like grid-based combat lies very little opportunity to make decisions of any impact.
Equipping the actors is a simple matter of upgrading to the best item available at the tier, further restricted by classes.
Every encounter has an optimal strategy, so tactical options are limited to dispatching the enemies as fast as possible or trying to follow the director's instruction for extra fans and cash. Extra difficulty just gives enemies more HP, making combat more frustrating than fun.
Mecha combat is a simple betting game between how many hits to try before going into defence.

Get it if you love sentai shows and don't mind a simple combat system.

33267838.review:
Excellent (must buy)
Good 
[h1] Average (maybe when on sale) [/h1]
Avoid (not worth your time and money)
 
[h1] Summary	[/h1]
A turn based strategy game that has a promising concept but is let down with simple combat and a poor script. It’s very easy on lower difficulty levels. Full game takes roughly 12 hours to finish.
 
[h1] Review	[/h1]
You oversee a group of actors as they film a knock off Power Rangers TV series and gain popularity. The main gameplay offers very basic turn based strategy battles where you fight monsters and power up for mech duels. Between filming episodes you organise your squad, buying and crafting new gear, reply to fan mail and activate bonuses with ‘fan power’ that is earned by completing goals in each episode.
The game has been updated recently. The mech battles have been changed to use timed button presses. They seem very easy but they aren’t long so they don’t become annoying.
	The graphics are well designed with different sets and monsters. Each characters has a different class with unique abilities. However the fighting quickly becomes tedious, there is very little enemy variation or new mechanics, so virtually every battle plays the same. The main strategy is just to use your special abilities when possible. 
Although there is a story the player has little input so it lacks involvement. It focuses on the actors rather than the characters in the TV show. It fell flat for me because it was written for laughs but the jokes were too referential. I appreciate that the source material is not serious but I feel that focusing on each episode as a quest where you could make key choices would make each episode feel more unique.
	Overall it’s decent but I don’t recommend it at full price unless you want something to play without much thought required and don’t mind repetitive battles.

33265280.review:
Like many reviewers, I received this game in a bundle. I did not specifically seek this game out but decided to give it a shot since I have many games sitting in my library. I do not believe this game is worthy of a $10-15 price tag. I have put in a few hours and have enjoyed the gameplay and story to a lesser extent, but it gets very repetitive in many ways and is quite shallow for the price they're asking. It's an XCOM style turn based combat system with quirky yet tiring dialogue and storyline. In recent episodes, I've found myself skipping through entire sections. The upgrade system doesn't do much for me as there seems to be very little consequence for playing poorly. Often times the director's instructions are tedious or just too easy.

I cannot justify recommending this game. If you're able to find a cheaper copy or find it in your library as a bundle, I would say it's worth trying out the first "season" and see what you think.

33244013.review:
If you want a light bit of strategy that you can hop into for 30 minutes or several hours, this is the game for you. For the price, especially if it's on sale, if you think you might like it based on the marketing propaganda, you almost assuredly will.

Pros:
- The subject matter is fantastic.
- The UI is instantly usable, in fact, the game is instantly approachable.

33063506.review:
Chroma Squad é um RPG tático com elementos de simuladores de gerenciamento. Nele você controla uma equipe de cinco dublês que deixam seu trabalho para abrir seu próprio estúdio de super sentai. Você deve criar o novo grupo, escolhendo os nomes dos personagens, da equipe, as classes de cada personagem. Conforme vai ganhando fãs e dinheiro consegue melhorar as armas e os equipamentos que o time vai usar, contratos de marketing e melhorias do estúdio. Cada escolha conta para melhorar a equipe e aumentar a audiência do programa, de maneira que as decisões do jogador afetam a história e o final da narrativa. [b]Existem vários finais possíveis.[/b] 

Os combates seguem o estilo de jogos clássicos como Disgaea, Ogre Battle e Final Fantasy Tactics. Há a possibilidade de cooperação entre os membros da equipe, esta cooperação se dá por meio de saltos acrobáticos, permitindo que o personagem alcance pontos distantes no mapa que não alcançaria naquele turno, ou ataques combinados, o que garante mais dano. Caso todos os Rangers apliquem o ataque conjunto, teremos o ataque especial. Os Rangers unem suas armas para formar a invencível Power Bazooka. Não poderiam faltar as lutas com robôs gigantes fechando o combate com os chefes e a chegada de um sexto Ranger, coroando todos os grandes clássicos do super sentai.

Apesar do jogo ser muito divertido e nostálgico para os fãs de super sentai as fases são repetitivas e pouco variadas. Outra falha é a legenda que oscila entre o inglês e o português, mesmo se tratando de um jogo totalmente brasileiro. 8/10

33058114.review:
Incredibly charming top-down tactical RPG w/ base management elements.

You play as a studio / group of stunt actors who create their own TV show similar to Power Rangers. You'll go through 5 or 6 "seasons" with multiple episodes (read: battles) each, in which not only do you have to survive and defeat the bad guys, but you have to try to follow additional "Director's Orders" to maximize your audience gain. In between, you do some studio management in which you can craft gear for your heroes, upgrade your mech, and enhance your studio.

The game is very earnest in a way that charmingly captures that sense of silly enthusiasm that you find in shows like Power Rangers. You can tell the game creators knew their genre very well.

I thoroughly recommend this game for fans of tactical RPGs (XCom, FFT, Disgaea, etc).

An extra word on difficulty: As a veteran of tactics RPG, I played & beat this on challenging (the hardest available starting difficulty). It was indeed challenging and often frustrating (sometimes in a good way, sometimes not). If you're not a fan of difficulty, I'd recommend the middle difficulty setting instead.

33015775.review:
Chroma Squad is a Strategy RPG in the style of the Disgaea games that has a lot of strong ideas that are implemented fairly well. 

It has a nice snap to the combat, there's lots of neat little ways you can customize your crew. The game also has very little fat to it - the whole thing from start to finish will run you between 8-12 hours. There's no need for grinding, which is great, because there isn't a convenient way to grind. So to that end everything requires strategy - every decision about marketing and team building matters because they're all permanent.

It would be incredibly difficult to have a fully decked out team by the end of the game, which is fine. The game is balanced well, and you can lower your difficulty at any point in the game.

The music is very nice, the graphics are vibrant, well animated, and have lots of variety. The camera zooms around a lot, so if you're prone to some kinds of motion sickness it could possibly set you off in story heavy chunks of the game.

If you do not like a dash of meta in your story telling - AVOID - this game's story is 100% meta. It's one of the first games I've ever played that has essentially no forth wall at all. It being SO abundant made it less grating than it can sometimes come across in games that rely on it a lot but not always. 

I didn't care for the mech battles. They're a little on the slow side.

I feel this game has enough content that they could have stretched it a little further. While I appreciate that the game has very little padding, some optional bonus episodes within the seasons wouldn't have hurt. There are several monsters you only see once or twice, several backgrounds you only see a couple times, mechanics that don't get explored to the fullest they could be. While I appreciate the brevity of this game, especially in a genre where games tend to stretch well past the 60 hour mark pretty frequently, I wouldn't have minded a little more optional padding.

33011610.review:
Orgulho nacional, Chroma Squad é um daqueles jogos que apostam no fator "retro" e acertam em cheio, podendo ser do agrado tanto de fãs de Super Sentai quanto jogadores que se encaixam no nicho do RPG tático.

 Seu estilo gráfico e trilha sonora são agradáveis e não enjoativas, algo que ajuda na imersão e aproveitamento do jogo, contendo diversas faixas memoráveis. O enredo e narrativa do jogo não são excepcionais, mas funcionam muito bem e com um bom dinamismo e até mesmo com alguns twists, apesar de que algumas das piadas podem não ser tão engraçadas para aqueles não acostumados com o universo Sentai (isto é, se você acreditar que humor não é  relativo). 

 Suas mecânicas de jogabilidade são inovadoras em certos pontos e tradicionais no resto, o que dá uma sensação de familiaridade, porém, com o desafio aumentando ao decorrer do jogo. O jogo é uma mistura de RPG tático com administração de empresa, já que, como diz na descrição do jogo, você não controla um grupo de "Power Rangers" de verdade, e sim um grupo de dublês que decidem montar seu próprio estúdio de gravação.

 Finalizando, Chroma Squad é um jogo que tem suas genialidades e que com certeza  merece sua atenção IMEDIATAMENTE, e vale a pena comprar mesmo pelo preço normal dele (R$ 27,99 no momento em que escrevi essa análise).

32745486.review:
Music is great. I especially enjoyed the [spoiler] Gaga's [/spoiler] theme.

Control is very simple yet immersive. 

Characters and dialogue is silly in a humorous way

Overall gameplay was not hard at all given that I was able to get upgrades quite easily.
The game can be repetitive, fighting minions and boss. Again and again.
However, the little side missions of each episode changes the dynamic of your tactics such as getting rid of minions before getting the boss, finishing a fight within limited turns, hitting the boss monster at least once every turn, etc.

I did not invest too much on Mecha as making sure it defend itself on time saved me from losing too much health.
In fact the Mecha fights are so simple that I wished it was just a little more complex.

I also did not bother too much with marketing because even without it I always had maximum number of audience but for those people that are yet to play this game, it is there and it is one of the variables that may make this game replayable.

I found the dialogue tiresome after few hours and kept skipping it so having an option to fast forward was great.
The only downside to this fast forward feature was that it looked like fast forwarding retro video tapes which is cute but made the screen rapidly move up and down, add noise to the resolution and ultimately hurt my eyes very much. When every time I was fast forwarding dialogues I had to look away from the monitor.

I guess this game is replayable as you get to choose 5 team members from preset characters with different stats.
There are number of preset characters you can choose from and they are all plain silly.

I also thought the email tab where you get a few fan mails after each episode was a cute addition - just a little something to get your mind off a little from the repetitive nature of the game.

32402720.review: Chroma Squad is unexpectedly genius in its design. I came into this game with very low expectations, having not followed the kickstarter at all and getting the game as part of a massive bundle with other games. But the premise of the game, which is that you're not just trying to defeat the enemies, but defeat the enemies in ways that increases views for your show, makes the game actually really fun. All the things that usually seem tedious in tactical RPGs, repositioning units and maneuvering, here are all part of the 'show' and often get you views on their own. Beyond that, the teamwork function, giving increased mobility to allied units and also setting up high damage combos, means that individual units being out of position can still often have functionality. I've only gotten through "Season 1" but for someone that does not have a fixation on the tokusatsu genre (and really never has), I found this a surprisingly satisfying tactical RPG. It's fundamentally a good game, and that it's also charming and ripe with in-jokes is really just a perk.

32231627.review:
This is one of the most fun turn-based games I've played in a while. The idea of pandering each hero pandering to the audience by taking certain actions (along with "dramatic" optional objectives) to rack up points while you fight is great fun in concept, and breathes a bit of life into combat. The focus on using "teamwork" to launch people through the air and perform combo attacks is also very fun and helps sell the feel they're going for. Each party member feels very different and can be built several ways, and skills feel varied and useful. The humor is also top-notch and lends to a light-hearted but entertaining story.

Other pluses: It's quite long and has multiple endings, and also multiple actors to pick from. There's also great music and good pixel art. And lots of good jokes.

It's not perfect though. The audience system, despite being a central mechanic, isn't fully explained in-game (specifically which actions each person can perform to earn points, what effect death has, how much director's instructions are worth, and whether the mecha battles affect it). On some particularly easy levels (or levels with nigh-impossible director instructions) it can also lead to you wasting turns farming audience to max it out (which could have been mitigated a lot if it told you how much each director instruction is worth).

Also, the difficulty curve is backwards; the first season is the hardest because you have very few skills, and in the last few missions your heroes are ridiculously durable if you have the best available equipment. It's probably balanced towards you NOT maxing out your audience every level, but perfectionists will almost always do that. Still doesn't keep it from being fun though.

Those are small complaints though. By the time you notice those problems you should already be hooked. I'd definitely recommend this game.

32156577.review:
Chroma Squad is like if Fire Emblem collided with the Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers. 

You manage a team of superhero TV show actors, who go from episode to episode fighting evil, beating up mooks, transforming into a giant robot to battle skyscraper sized kaijus etc. The battle engine is surprisingly in depth and fun, and the missions are really well designed. They are challenging, varied and do a good job of keeping faithful to the TV show conceit.

The game is also surprisingly funny and features a lot of humor, both original and reference-based. I had a great time with it and really want to go back and complete it one day.

I enjoyed this game. It politely makes fun of Power Rangers and itself. If you have nostalgia for the original Might Morphin Power Rangers series, you will probably appreciate what this game has to offer.

As for gameplay: it's not the most in-deptch tactical game out there, but it's better than a lot. It might be a simple mechanic, but it's still fun and allows for some strategy.

My only complaint had been the final boss, but the Devs took the complaint serious and actually worked on it. 

Without going into too much detail, the final boss has four stages. I'd usually just rage quite during the third stage, but that's not a problem anymore. As a result, I finally made it to the fourth stage, and it was exactly what I was hoping would happen! I'm glad I gave the game another try.
