Croma Squad...esa joyita! Creo que lo mejor que tiene este juego...es que lo hace muy tuyo, intentaré explicarme...

Un grupo de actores quieren hacer una serie sentai (estilo power rangers) pero...poco a poco se irá volviendo todo en una completa aventura única y épica! cada uno tiene su especialidad tenemos al oteador, el líder, tecno...

El juego no solo se queda en combatir contra los malos a lo más puro serie antigua, si no que abre una puerta hacia la dirección del programa, tu elijes todo!, que se compra para el estudio, los actores que formaran a estos nuevos "indie sentais", las agencias de publicidad, que responder a los fans y sus correos y también a unos mails que daran pie a un desarrollo de la trama de una forma u otra.(Aunque parece complicado, que va, es sencillo y divertido, promesa!)

32122050.review:
[h1]Chroma Squad: la venganza del kickstarter[/h1]

Primero hablaré de los dos aspectos negativos del juego, los cuales, para la gran mayoría, pueden no influir demasiado en su decisión para explorarlo o quizás no vean en ellos gran problema en su decisión para adquirir el juego. Quienes acostumbramos a jugar RPGs tácticos nos damos una idea de lo largos que pueden ser y lo complejos que son. Los gamers que preferimos este género sabemos que ciertos mecanismos son vitales para mantener nuestro interés vivo en el juego. Jugué Final Fantasy Tactics, por ejemplo, dos o tres veces (quizás más de 100 horas en total). El primer Agarest lo jugué, al menos, 120 horas (o lo que diga mi cuenta de Steam). He jugado Disgaea, Phantom Brave y Ogre Tactics (y también me veo tentado a incluir dos Suikodens, aunque son más RPG que tácticos).

Es un género al que suelo tenerle cariño por varios motivos: a diferencia de un RPG normal, un RPG táctico suele tener historias más maduras o complejas (traición, conspiración, enfrentamiento a los dioses o reinos en guerra) y los personajes pueden crecer de maneras increíbles, lo cuál hace más interesante y personal su desarrollo. Estos juegos suelen estar acompañados de dificultades y retos tan exigentes como una buena partida de ajedrez, lo que a veces lleva a un par de horas de frustración, pero cuando el juego tiene buena historia te empujas a continuar hasta entender cómo resolver alguna batalla.

El primer aspecto negativo va por el lado de la historia y el guion. Tiene algunos rasgos interesantes de metaficción y la estructura es atinada para hacernos dudar de la realidad, o el universo, de ficción adentro del juego; es imaginativo y crea capas de realidad que son interesantes (véase Mario 3, el cuál hace un trabajo excepcional y sin una línea de diálogo), pero la narrativa tiene errores de redacción —incluso se atreven a convertir esto en una broma recurrente—, varios de los capítulos son forzados y abundan los lugares comunes. Entiendo el espíritu paródico del juego, veo que respeta y se divierte con los show sentai, pero múltiples giros y chistes pudieron evitarse para dar pie a una historia un poco más rica.

En vez de hacer chistes sencillos sobre la traducción y un reiterado esfuerzo por romper la cuarta pared, el equipo de desarrollo pudo enfocar sus energías en pulir la historia, mejorar la redacción general y buscar un sano balance entre la seriedad y la comedia. La historia es vital para un RPG, sobre todo un táctico. La narrativa es un mecanismo importantísimo para que un espectador ceda horas de su vida a un juego como este.

El segundo aspecto negativo tiene algo que ver con el primero. No sé exactamente cómo propusieron las recompensas del kick starter, pero era demasiado evidente que agregaron varias batallas y personajes como una recompensa para quienes aportaran más dinero. Entiendo que esto puede parecer interesante y atractivo para los inversionistas, pero en el caso de Chroma Squad, en ciertos escenarios, ciertos personajes fortuitos, excusa para poner el nombre de algún kickstarter, simplemente secuestraron el juego. Esto último, aunado a batallas repetitivas y sencillas (en dificultad mediana (o interesante, como lo llamaron los desarrolladores)) no ayudaron a cubrir la falta de recursos narrativos, al contrario, exhibieron todas sus debilidades. Consejo para cualquier creador en kickstarter: no permitan que su propia obra los sobrepase y no permitan que el buenaondismo se los coma y se robe lo que puede ser el trabajo de sus vidas. Quizás, lo más difícil, es no comprometer la obra.

A pesar de los comentarios negativos del juego no pienso que sea malo.

Chroma Squad no tiene una gran dificultad, para nada, morí una o dos veces y eso fue porque las mecánicas del juego me parecieron demasiado amplias y me intimidaron. Apenas le moví durante los primeros episodios (o batallas). Si morí, fue porque no me había metido de lleno en los atributos y las posibilidades del juego. Eventualmente me animé; una vez que te acostumbras a las opciones y navegas por todo lo que puedes hacer: producción, vestuarios, habilidades y actores, el juego se vuelve progresivamente más sencillo y mucho más interesante.

El aspecto de simular la producción es entretenido y enriquece el juego de maneras inesperadas pero también facilitan el juego muy rápido. Las únicas batallas que realmente me emocionaron fueron las últimas dos o tres. Hubiera preferido algo más difícil pero temía que si lo ponía en la dificultad más alta se pusiera perrísimo como suele suceder en un RPG Táctico. Pienso jugarlo, en un futuro, en la dificultad más alta (los desarrolladores prometieron una actualización que agrega un modo de Nuevo Juego+). En total me tomó unas 10-15 horas terminarlo.

Los pixeles me parecieron divertidos, muy bien trabajados, la animación en las capas de los héroes, por ejemplo, me ponían de buenas. El diseño de los villanos, por lo general paródicos de varios géneros televisivos, cultura pop, cómics y de videojuegos, me encantó. Los minions cambian poco a lo largo de las temporadas y la historia, pero así están bien, uno se familiariza con ellos y sus habilidades, y más o menos ya sabe qué esperar de ellos. La música y el sonido es excelente sobre todo los temas de entrada y de salida. Se nota que hay un gran equipo artístico y un buen trabajo de dirección atrás del juego, por ello me cuesta mucho trabajo perdonar sus errores en cuanto a historia y narrativa.

El juego tiene varios finales y caminos, pero no recomiendo sacarlos todos de una sentada. En serio. A algunos quizás les importe este detalle, y normalmente a mí me llamaría la atención y me animaría a dar la segunda vuelta, pero la calidad de su historia es tan errática que repelen mis ganas de dar la segunda vuelta.

¿Recomiendo Chroma Squad? Me cuesta trabajo recomendarlo a gente que adora los RPGs tácticos difíciles. Chroma Squad definitivamente es más casual que los reyes del género. En instantes construye escenarios agradables y graciosos, pero a veces es repetitivo y cae demasiado en el buenaondismo del kickstarter. En las horas jugadas pasé un rato agradable y me dejé llevar por sus aciertos, pero sus errores a veces me desconcertaban y rompían con mi deseo de involucrarme. Es casualón, entretenido y se disfruta más con las expectativas bajas.

==

Si gustas, puedes leer [url=http://www.agustinfest.com/tema/los-gustos/de-videojuegos/]más reseñas de videojuegos[/url] en mi página personal. O bien, únete a mi [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/arbol1000]grupo de Steam[/url] donde aviso de estas reseñas y trato de compartir notas útiles de videojuegos.

También puedes ver mi play through de este juego en twitch si das click aquí: https://www.twitch.tv/videos/145948746?collection=-sViee-4wRQDGQ

31751814.review:
Put 24 hours into this game over a less than 48 hour period of time. Time just escaped me while playing it.

You should know that I'm reviewing this from the perspective of someone who has never touched a tactical RPG in his life. I just like Super Sentai/Power Rangers and superhero games. I bought this on a whim and haven't regretted it since.

The game is fairly short. I beat it on Casual in less than a day and am probably 65 or so % of the way through my Normal mode playthrough about a day later. That said, the game warrants at least 3 replays due to the branching story which leads to multiple endings (not Mass Effect 3 style endings. REAL alternate endings). So far I've already encountered 2 brand new bosses and one new stage that I didn't play on my first time through during my second run.

The pixel art is really fun and doesn't take away from the experience at all. It runs like a dream and only takes about 5 minutes to download due to the small set of files. The music is very reminiscent of my Game Boy days and brings me back. It'll stick in your head in a good way and definitely helps you feel pride when you finish a really tough Megazord fight. The real selling point for me was the ability to fully customize your ranger team from what they shout when they morph to what they yell to summon the Megazord - you really feel like you're running a season of the show.

A couple of negatives include an inability to undo accidental purchases in the in-game currency shop system. I have to quit without saving and go through buying everything again which can be a pain if I regret buying a certain piece of gear or crafting a certain item. You can't preview the stat changes on craftable items before making them which pushes you to do the quit without saving thing a decent amount on your first playthrough. The RNG side of Megazord fights basically makes them a big gamble as my stats don't seem to be doing me any favors in my second playthrough. It's also somewhat boring compared to the ranger parts of the game due to basically only having the choice of attacking or defending as your pray to RNGesus to bless your next move.

Other than that, I can't praise this game more highly for fellow casual strategy game players. If you're more hardcore, you might find it too simplistic, but maybe the game's humor and charm can win you over into donating a few hours of your life to a little Power Rangers nostalgia.

31618129.review:
Chroma Squad ist ein 2D Taktik-RPG mit WiSim-Elementen in Pixeloptik. Wir übernehmen die Kontrolle über eine kleine Gruppe Stuntmen die sich mit einem eigenen Filmstudio unabhängig machen um eine Sentai-Serie zu drehen (angelehnt an die berühmt-berüchtigten Power Rangers). Also wird in einem Lagerhaus gedreht, mit Papprequisiten und einfachen Kulissen sowie improvisierten Handlungen. Ich muss sagen, dass ich etwas kritisch an das Spiel ging, mit Ausnahme von Starbound waren viele Pixel-Optik-Spiele die ich bisher gesehen habe eher mittelmäßige Games. Hier aber in einer wildverwegenen Genremischung finde ich ein richtiges Juwel vor. Die rundenbasierten Kämpfe zwischen den Stuntmen und den Komparsen und Hilfsschauspieler als Schurkentruppe, die  Story um die Stuntmen und ihren Traum, die kleinen Subkontextstories in den Mails, die liebevolle Hommage an die grottigen Trashserien aus Japan, der Ausbau des Studios. Das alles macht richtig Spass und immer neugierig wie es mit der Truppe weitergeht, mit den Papphelmen und der von Mama gebastelten Kostüme. Nur ein Wermutstropfen habe ich gefunden der mich auch wirklich verärgert hat, das unterentwickelte Speichersystem. Warum kann das Spiel nicht mehrere Speicherstände anlegen? Davon abgesehen, finde das Spiel wirklich großartig.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AcUjrT7sCSU

A competent strategy RPG with a good sense of humor, fun tweaks to the formula and most distinguishing of all a deep love and appreciate of all things Power Rangers! If you like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fire Emblem type games you should feel right at home during the battle sequences here. Although not quite as deep as the two previously mentioned titles Chroma Squad does stand on its own with a few interesting additions to the battles that keep things interesting and fun for the game's duration. 

In addition to fighting you'll be spending a good portion of time at your Squad's HQ crafting, upgrading, marketing and purchasing new equipment. This set up is initially a little confusing but to fans of strategy this section quickly becomes just as engaging as the giant Zord battles.

The real fun of this game though comes in its quirky dialogue, funny boss fights and Power Ranger nostalgia. For fans of Power Rangers, pop culture humor and fun pixel sprites this game is definitely worth the purchase and a lot of fun.

31329046.review:
Overall, I think Chroma Squad really has a lot of great ideas going for it. I'm not a power rangers/sentai fan, but I do like srpgs and I was pleasantly surprised by a lot of things in this game:

+ The gameplay is simplistic but satisfying. Where you can sometimes have maps that last for ~30 minutes in a game like X-com or FF Tactics, it's not uncommon to find yourself done with a Chroma Squad map in about 15 minutes. This is great if you have that strategy itch but you don't want to commit a lot of time. 

+ The teamwork abilities are a very nice inclusion that offer some depth. There is a nice sense of risk/reward in choosing how you control your team - for example, do you throw a ranger across the field to take out an enemy, potentially leaving them too far out? Do you chromatize now, or wait until your actors' health bars drop significantly in order to take advantage of the full heal? These are things I caught myself thinking about before I committed to any actions. 

+ The presentation and story are charming enough, even though I found myself skipping through the cutscenes more often than not. 

+ Micro base-building feature that allows you to do things like respond to fanmail and improve the studio so that you can make the most out of your next battle. 

+ It's obvious that the developers loved making this game and there's always something to be said for that.

There are some really deep flaws, though:
-The giant robot fight sequences. You trade out a decent-sized field for a setting similar to a really basic fighting game where your only options are to hope you click the right thing to defend (which only blocks a meager amount of damage) and hope your attacks keep hitting. Even if you lose this fight, there is a safe-guard that brings your health back to full, so I never really felt like these fights were as climactic as they probably should have been. Compared to the surprising depth you can get out of the field combat with the rangers, the giant robot fights feel really underwhelming and lazy. 

-Dumb boss fights. You can breeze through a set of interesting fights only to come across a season finale (aka boss) that can not only attack more frequently than half of your team -combined- but can also teleport or heal in addition to summon extra minions. These fights are sometimes difficult but always annoying. These fights come off as cheap ploy to increase difficulty rather than actually coax you into utilizing the best that your strategy has to offer. 

obligatory numerical rating: 7.5/10

31292847.review:
Chroma Squad is a game that begs to be great -- begs to be loved -- but just doesn't quite get there.

There is something lacking to this game in its basic combat system, and the way it feels. It's difficult to describe, whether attacks just don't feel satisfying, the skills your character possessing not being as useful as they ought to be, or maybe something else that somebody else can better elaborate. It doesn't help that it's almost impossible to pin down if the AI is just a little too good or just stupid enough to get lucky too often. Having played for almost two hours, managing budget, character equipment, studio perks, etc. seems just a little too frustrating and nervewracking.

The writing goes for light-hearted and funny, but it's just not up to snuff enough to be charming and actually land. Like everything else, it gets close, but doesn't quite hit the mark. Unfortunately, fixing that doesn't really make the game enjoyable.

If only the combat system was made a little more in-depth and satisfying, or if studio/equipment/money management didn't seem so futile, this game could be played and enjoyed. It doesn't even require both -- just one of the two will do the trick. But because the game is as it is, it falls flat and is almost perplexingly boring. And that is such a shame, because it looks fun from the outside -- and from the inside it really feels the game deserving of Chroma Squad's hype is buried just a couple inches away, but nobody's digging deep enough to hit it.

31220926.review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W9oJomEfERU

Chroma Squad starts as a simple Strategy Turn-Based Game but it offers many surprises. The teamwork mechanic is a simple concept that opens a lot of choices and suits well with the game genre and setting. Each character has a different role on the team and can be customizable from the name, looks, traits, abilities and equipment, making room for multiple play-styles and different tactics which make the game fell fresh and new as it proceeds. Fans of Sentai (A.K.A. Power Rangers-like shows) will be pleased to see that transforming into your Power Suit and gigantic Mech Battles actually play a role in the game.

	Aesthetically the game makes use of Pixel Art with vibrant colors that suits with the lighthearted tone of Chroma Squad. The sound design is spot on with a great Sentai themed main song and a happy chiptune music that fuses together with the game’s vibe. The bosses are really interesting both in abilities and design and also very silly (like the giant pigeon with macho arms) but the minions do start to get a little repetitive specially as they get recycled as stronger versions with a different color scheme. 

	The plot is not very forward thriving but it does have some intrigue right from the start and it is a fun setup for the rest of the game. You will most certainly have some good laughs with Chroma Squad as long as you are ready to read through the characters’ dialogues. Although the game is very smartly written, it may sometimes become boresome as the scripted events drag on. As mentioned the game has a very lighthearted tone and it doesn't take itself too seriously which is actually connected to the main story. 

• Final thoughts

	Chroma Squad is a game that excels in the strategic battle gameplay with great, fun core mechanics and offers other pleasant side activities like the Mech Battles, Crafting and Studio Management which make the game flow fell fresh and non-repetitive. The direction of the story may seem a little odd sometimes as the silly, lighthearted, “not taking itself too serious” plot develops but it is a game that I recommend, specially for those who enjoy a really good squad strategy turn-based game.

31023370.review:
Empezare este análisis simplemente haciéndoles una pregunta: ¿Alguna vez han jugado un Indie y sentir que es un juego hecho por una gran compañía de Videojuegos?. Pues si no lo han hecho es que no han jugado Chroma Squad.

Chroma Squad un maravilloso titulo de Rol Táctico creado por Behold Studios inspirado en los Power Rangers. En este juego tendremos la oportunidad de crear nuestro propio estudio de televisión que podemos  ir mejorando para hacer mejores episodios en cada temporada. 

Algo destacable de este titulo es que no solo nos permite tener batallas estratégicas al propio estilo de un Fire Emblem, si no que nos permite tener nuestro propio robot gigante o Giant Mecha como quieran llamarlo, con un entretenido sistema de combate por turnos y con diferentes habilidades que podemos ir desbloqueando mientras lo vayamos mejorando.

Me gusto mucho las referencias de este, ya de por si esta inspirado en los Power Rangers por lo cual se puede esperar que hayan muchas referencias a la serie de televisión como los combates con el Mecha y Cerebro, pero podemos encontrar algunas referencias como lo son: Correos Electrónicos de un tal Spider Boy al cual Nick no quiso invitar a su fiesta, un dinosaurio con una escopeta que se esconde en un traje de alguien llamado Barni y hasta desarrolladores del titulo diciéndonos que tengamos cuidado con un jefe que tiene errores de programación. 

Una historia muy, muy pero muy entretenida con una narrativa muy curiosa llena de referencias a la Cultura Pop con jefes cuanto menos curiosos.

Este titulo cuenta con tres finales distintos, si hemos jugado títulos como The Stanley Parable vamos a saber donde esta uno de esos finales Narrador: *guiño, guiño*.

Algo que llamo mucho mi atención fueron los créditos, muchos se preguntaran como es eso posible ya que solo son simples créditos y ya, pues no, Chroma Squad es una excepción, debido a que todos los créditos están acompañados de el maravilloso Soundtrack que contiene este titulo, que para ser un indie esta muy bien hecho. Los primeros minutos de los créditos solo vemos algunos de los jefes que hemos derrotado y otros que no, mientras pasan los nombres de los desarrolladores, la sorpresa es que cuando estan a punto de terminar empiezan a salir cientos de nombres de la A hasta la Z de todas aquellas personas que apoyaron en Kickstarter, tal vez tu nombre este ahí, compruebalo.

Para finalizar, un Soundtrack memorable y muy bueno, una gráficas estilo Pixel Graphics muy bonitas a la vista y una historia muy llena de referencias a la Cultura Pop. Tal vez podría hablar mas de este titulo pero es mejor dejarlo hasta aquí y que lo descubras por tu cuenta.

Este titulo puede ser adquirido en ofertas con el 70% de descuento a unos 4.49$ o 45 Pesos Mexicanos.

10/10 Pruébalo, sé que te va a encantar.

30995162.review:
Not a game for me. Reasons off the top of my head:

- Story, while ok for a short joke, is extremely boring and cliché for a long game. The conversations between the team members really don't help; "I am not good enough" -- "you are an important team member and we all love you" -- "I now know I am good enough" is just infantile writing.
- Mecha fighting is trivial with one repeated QTE that is just annoying. Yet is still a gear check, so if you were silly enough to not upgrade your mecha a lot in the start, you can get to impossible fights.
- Fighting with your team is reasonably varied, but gets very repetetive after you get far enough into the game.
- Fight setup is sloooooooow. Monsters arrive one at a time when fighting is about to start, and later stages have up to 20-25 monsters slowly jumping in and moving into place. Doesn't help when certain fights also do similar summoning of mobs/mines/etc. during them.
- Cutscene skipping is not a thing. At best you can fast forward (much too slowly), while the screen shakes, which quite frankly is annoying after the first time you use it.
- Studio upgrades (base upgrades, essentially) are not interesting and by mid-game there aren't any more new ones.
- Crafting, while interesting, has the very big weak point, that you buy upgrade packs with random items in it, which makes getting specific items annoying. Also, one item for mecha upgrades can only be found in mid-level fights (and certain one-off event), which makes getting specific upgrades for your mecha impossible once you use the last of that item and move on to higher level fights.
- I wish games would stop using the method of slowly typing spech one letter at a time for dialogue. Reading is not done by reading each letter and then building the word, it's based on recognizing the entire word and understanding what word it is, which is why you can read text even when all but the first and last letter have been jumbled up. Also, most people can read much faster than what games devs set the speech speed to.

I would not recommend this unless you honestly truly love power rangers in the way that bronies love my little pony; the joke setting really doesn't work for a long game and the core gameplay is not strong enough to make up for it.

30855322.review:
Gleich vorweg: Chroma Squad (nachfolgend Cs) ist kein Spiel welches Stunde um Stunde an den Bildschirm fesselt und man sich wundert wohin die Stunden verflogen sind.
Cs ist ein netter Zeitvertreib für Zwischendurch, Kameras auf, Spot an und mal eben eine Folge "abdrehen"
Allemal ein charmanteres Casualspiel als irrige Fremiumware vom Handy und Co und dafür ist es völlig ausreichend.

Story:

Fast so dünn wie die Brust eines Magermodels.
Eine Stuntcrew beschließt ihr altes Set hinter sich zu lassen und eine eigene, Powerrangers ähnliche, Serie zu produzieren.
So weit so gut, viel mehr gibt der Ausgangsplot nicht her. Es gibt im späteren Verlauf einige kleinere Einschübe in der Geschichte. 
Nicht wirklich unabdingbar wichtig oder unerträglich spannend.
Für ein Spiel dieser Art allemal ausreichend.

Gameplay:

Cs ist eine Mischung aus Management und JRPG

Management bedeutet, man sucht sich Werbeverträge aus mit unterschiedlichen, optionalen Perks die je nach "Fanpower" aktivierbar sind.
Ihr erwirtschaftet mit jeder Episode eine unterschiedliche Menge Geld. 
Die finanziellen Mittel errechnen sich aus der Zuschauerzahl, den optional erreichbaren Zielen jeder einzelnen Mission/Folge und den diversen Abzügen aus Studiomaterial und Mali bestimmter Perks.
Geld kann für besseres Studiomaterial (mit jeweiligen Boni) und Equipment für die Schauspieler ausgegeben werden.

Dazu gibt es ein Crafting System bei dem ihr, von besiegten Gegnern verlorene, Materialien in Equipment umwandeln könnt.
Altes Equipment kann recycelt werden, dabei spielt Glück aber eine gewisse Rolle. Einige Materialien lassen sich außerdem in Andere umwandeln.

Außerdem kommt später ein großer Mech ins Spiel, ganz ähnlich wie bei den Powerrangers persönlich. Dieser lässt sich auch mit Materialien aufwerten und dient bei Bossgegnern als Finisher.

Die JRPG Elemente halten sich allerdings etwas zurück. 
Jede Folge bedeutet Gegner vermöbeln, eure Helden wissen also das sie nur eine Serie drehen und machen gelegentlich auflockernde Sprüche oder beschweren sich über unangemeldete Setänderungen u.Ä
Eure Schauspieler können mit verschiedenen Rüstungsteilen und jeweils einer Waffe ausgerüstet werden.
Mit jeder Staffel stehen außerdem neue Perks zur Auswahl zwischen denen ihr euch entscheiden müsst.
Das Kampfsystem ist genretypisch rundenbasiert.
Ihr bewegt nacheinander eure Helden auf das gewünschte Feld und bekämpft eure Gegner, setzt Heilungssprüche ein oder ihr aktiviert die Teamwork Funktion und nutzt einen Helden als "Katapult" für die restliche Truppe.
Mit der Teamwork Funktion lassen sich außerdem taktische Angriffsmanöver ausführen z.B. wenn ihr einen Gegner umzingelt habt.

Besonders wenn alle "Rangers" sich samt eingeschaltetem Teamwork um den letzten Gegner versammeln geht schonmal die Post ab ;-)
Sollte die Energie einmal knapp werden, könnt ihr euch per Knopfdruck in Schale schmeißen und seht nun wirklich wie billig verkleidete Japano-Fernsehstars aus, die Energie ist wieder voll und ihr könnt mehr Fähigkeiten einsetzen.

Persönliches Fazit:

Ein charmantes Pixelabenteuer für Zwischendurch. Die taktischen Möglichkeiten würde ich nicht als tiefschürfend durchgehen lassen, sowohl im Management als auch im JRPG Teil.
Was unter dem Strich bleibt ist gediegene und lockere Unterhaltung für kleinere Spielsessions, der Umfang ist nämlich auch nicht sonderlich hoch.
Etwas mehr Tiefgang im Management und RPG Teil hätten dem Spiel definitiv nicht geschadet, so bleibt es unterm Strich ein nettes, kleines Casualabenteuer.
Der Standardpreis mag vllt etwas zu hoch angesetzt sein, dennoch bereue ich den Kauf keinesfalls.
Die Idee und die Präsentation samt Chiptune Sound reißen so einiges wieder heraus, dass man anderen Spielen wohl nicht so leicht verzeihen würde.
Powerrangers Fans sollten ruhig ein oder zwei Blicke riskieren.

30767209.review:
Chroma Squad is the indie power ranger, an strategy rpg like FF Tactics. Its a unique game that uses props as armors and weapons, its because the story is involving a movie studio. What I like about this game is a mecha fight or megazord fight. No problem with optimization, game run flawlessly, but it lacks of graphic options. 

Pros:
- Mecha fight, standard fight, 1 on 1, basically just hitting a def, atk, or skill button. Its repetitive, but still is a unique concept.
- Power ranger theme game, you can choose who will be the rangers from humans to dog. There are also space rangers that you can get when you pick certain choices in the game
- Story is OK
- Because the game is about making an episodic tv series, you can upgrade your studios, equipping your studios with new and high tech equipments, and ofc you can hire a marketing team, each team has their own perks, to activate these perks you need fans, yep sacrificing your innocent fans to the devil to gain some bonuses. You can gain fans in battle, every action you do will grant you a small amount of fans, you get more if you can fulfill the director's mission (sort of side objectives) everytime you go to do missions.
- Finishing move, there are 2 finishing moves here, both of them are executed by positioning your rangers around the enemy and use Teamwork command to finish their turn and the last ranger has to attack the enemy. Pretty neat. 
- Crafting system, you can craft weapons, armours and robot parts. Fortunately, you can buy materials from the crafting shop, but its randomize though. And unfortunately, you cant grind money or materials in this game. Its kinda hard when doing the challenging difficulty because of this. 

Cons:
- Graphic is bad, really bad. Because of lack graphic options, my rangers has become square rangers. 
- The weapon I equipped to my rangers are useless aside from the skills attack. I dont know why the dev decided that any equipped weapons cant be used to attack the enemies, but can use their skills. I dont know if its a lack of animation or this is how the game designed the game
- Battle system is too simple and unpolished, aside from skill attack from weapons and from level up, there is nothing more. So, battle will become boring after a while.And because I cant grind materials or money, with no means to upgrade your characters, I had a bad time a few times on challenging difficulty. 

Its not a bad game nor a great game, its OK game. So, I dont recommend this game. If you are a power ranger fan, you're good. If you're a casual, stay away. And if you're an achievement hunter, go for it.

30681106.review:
Chroma Squad is a nicely simple tactics RPG and a very cute parody/homage to Power Rangers and Super Sentai. Tactics RPGs can be hard to get into because they're often 100+ hour epics with large numbers of characters, classes, and items to sort through; Chroma Squad strips away a lot of that to create a tactics RPG that doesn't require the same level of commitment, while keeping enough elements to maintain a certain level of strategic depth. 

For the most part, beating the missions is relatively easy - the tricky part is usually trying to fulfill the optional objections to maximize your audience. This worked pretty well as a way of challenging the player without punishing them too much for the occasional failure. Unfortunately, the giant mecha fights are more difficult and rely fairly heavily on luck.

The character statistics are pretty straightforward, but some of the global boosts aren't as clear as I'd like. For example, how much is +10 Drop Rate? I guess the base Drop Rate is 100, but it doesn't seem to say that anywhere. +2 Fan Conversion Rate and +25% Crafting Rate are similarly unclear.

Fortunately, most of these concerns do little to take away from the game's solid core. Chroma Squad is a good fit for both newcomers to the genre and veterans who feel like taking a break from their attempt to 100% complete Disgaea.

30232624.review:
The "humble" pixel art of this game can catch you off-guard. It's a very funny game, much deeper than I expected (30h + on it), and overall it's very well done. 

You start with 5 stunt men, from a Power Rangers alike TV show, that get tired of doing all the hard work of the show and getting none of the credits, so they decide to create their own show where they can be the leading actors too. I won't talk about the rest of the story because that would be a spoiler. 

The combat is turn based, like XCOM or The Banner Saga. When you are not fighting, you are running the show and you have to deal with TV ratings, marketing, season budgets, etc. At the beginning it will be a very crappy and low-budget show, and it will be up to you to improve it.

The 95% of positive reviews are a good indicator of the quality of this Brazilian game funded through a kickstarter campaign. It's an homage to the Power Rangers / Super Sentai kind of shows from the 90's, so you'll probably find it more interesting if you were a kid during that time. 

The key feature of this game it's his humor. They managed to pay an homage but yet at the same time they mock every single cliché from those shows. The acrobatic jumps, the different colors of each fighter, the giant robots (Mechas) at the end of each episode, and much more, it's all there. It's a cliché mocking homage game.

30227638.review:
I really liked this.

I was never into the Power Rangers myself, nor a lot of the anime this game pays tribute to. But I don't think that's really required here to appreciate that this game is a love letter to cheesy TV and all the fun people have had with it. Everything in this game is so goofy and so fourth wall breaking wink wink, but it's done in a way I found really charming and sweet, as opposed to, say, Retro City Rampage which just bashed you over the head with how funny it thought it was every 5 seconds (hot tip: it wasn't).

There are about five million of these faux-16 bit games now, but here is one that actually uses that effect correctly and accurately. The target audience for this game is, at least in part, people like me that actually remember when 16-bit was real and spectacular, and tactics RPG's were just an emerging thing. There's just enough depth here to be interesting without being something overwhelming to work out, both in terms of the combat and the crafting system. The gimmick with the game is you are playing a fight scene in each episode of the show, and you can get bonuses for fulfilling director's instructions, things like "kill three enemies on a turn" or "use team attacks 4 times", these add enough spice for completionist types without, technically, being neccessary to advance the game.

The game isn't flawless, I hit a couple annoying but inconsequential bugs (there's an annoying one with one of the Space Sherrifs where his finisher doesn't actually count as a finisher). There are a couple spelling errors that aren't part of the on-purpose narrator gag (breath/breathe mixup happened at least twice). And I really, really wish this game had saving mid-chapter.

But on the whole, I had way more fun with this than I could have ever anticipated. It's cute, almost disgustingly so. But not quite. I got this in the Humble Freedom Bundle which was so large it was inevitable there were several indie games I'd never heard of there. This was the first of those I tried becaue the premise of "some stuntmen quit a TV show to start their own knockoff" is a hilarious, great premise. And I really did enjoy the game from start to finish.

Save earth with friendship instead of with ultraviolence? Well, why ever not?

The Mecha fights are pretty annoying. They are usually either impossible (If you didn't invest enough material into your mecha) or boring (If you have invested enough), and they don't really involve a lot of interesting decision-making.

Nos encontramos ante un juego de estrategia por turnos, basado en los famosos Power Rangers (aunque disfrutable por cualquiera que no los haya seguido) con divertidisimas referencias a la cultura geek de todo tipo (desde anime y  cine hasta otros videojuegos) 

A Chroma Squad se le nota de lejos lo Indie que lleva en la sange. Es un juego hecho con un amor a los videojuegos enorme, y con la imaginacion e innovacion que solamente le pueden poner los estudios independientes.
Posee un soundtrack de juego en 8bits que engancha cual melodia del 1-1 de Mario, una historia divertida e innesperada. y una jugabilidad muchisimo mas profunda de lo que parece en un principio.

En resumen, Chroma Squad es un juego completisimo, con una jugabilidad profunda, una historia rejugable (3 finales distintos de 13 preciosas horas cada uno, y si te olia a poco repetir todo para cambiar algo, tiene muchos actores distintos para cada rol del grupo, asi, si ya lo terminaste con uno, elige otro, y prueba combinaciones), Un soundtrack memorable y unos graficos acordes al ambiente general.

29857829.review:
I don't think I've ever said this about a game before, but the writing makes me want to punch myself in the face. It's not bad English, it's just supernaturally bland. Banal is not a word I've ever had cause to use before, and I'm using it now.

It's like...

You know how five year olds write? Maybe all the words are in the right places because the teacher helped them out a bit, and maybe their spelling's all been fixed with red pen, but the story still reads like a grocery list?

That's Chroma Squad. That's Chroma Squad in its excruciating, every-mission-is-a-plot-mission tedium.

This would be tolerable, I guess, but the gameplay is boring too. Even on the hardest difficulty, missions just take longer to clear, and most of that time is hammering away at putties waiting for something to actually threaten you.

There's a whole resource management/business sim back end to the game and that, at least, isn't boring, but it's grindy and obnoxious instead. You try to farm enough resources to craft new gear while deploying advertising bonuses to get new fans and increase revenue from viewership, while pumping your stats with a few small global bonuses, so that you can quickly and efficiently win the next mission with lots of style and max out your money gain.

That's not awful, but it ends with you playing the mission, which is.

If you liked Knights of Pen and Paper, you'll like this. It's a time-waster with bright colors and a surprisingly pleasant soundtrack. It has good design ideas but they're somehow lost in the implementation - like a cannoli and kidney milkshake.

I tried hard to enjoy Chroma Squad, and I recognize that other people may have quite different experiences with the game, but at the end of the day, it's still just...

"Once upon a time there was Teddy. He went to the store. Then he went to the beach. It rained there. The end."

0/10, Teddy. Wait a few years and try again.

29690341.review:
Chroma Squad is a little, cute game that has spend a fair bit of time just laying in my library. I liked the premise and got my hands on the game, but didn't feel the pressure to try and play it for a while. 

I have finally decided to give it a shot, and I honestly can't say that I regret that decision. The game is a tactical RPG with minor management elements - you control a squad of five (and later - six) characters, who will fight against sets of enemy minions and bosses. I am not going to discuss a premise, because it is very clearly stated in the description. 

What I will say, that gameplay-wise, the game is pretty good at what it does. Game is split in two phases - episodes (which consist of combat) and studio management. The combat system is simple, but enjoyable - your characters can use simple melee attacks, weapons and their abilities. There is also a teamwork system, which allows you to attack with a few characters at the same time. In some episodes you also get control of special characters which have some unique abilities of their own. 
The management part of the game is less robust and in many ways confusing. You can craft equipment for your squad, you can upgrade studio equipment which comes with different bonuses, and you can choose a marketing agency, which also provides you with a set of benefits based on your fans. That part of it all is, however, fairly simplistic and lacks any real depth.

The game makes good use of it's theme, and most of the game is enjoyably cheesy. If that's something you are not into, you will probably not enjoy your time with Chroma Squad. It does also take a bizzare twist half way through, but it only adds to the experience in my opinion. 
There is a single place where the story diverges. It isn't a huge difference, honestly, and happens very late into the game. If you are going to unlock all the achievements, you will have to play through the game three times - and about 80% of each playthrough is going to be identical, sadly.

There are some minor issues that I have with the game. The mech combat is extremely repetitive, and if you are planning on finishing up the game in short period of time (I personally did last 2 seasons in one sitting), you will have to do A LOT of mech fighting. A system which is a cool idea, but execution of it is rather lackluster, and you will always be doing the same thing. No matter who you are fighting, the enemy will always have the same pattern - either three basic attacks or one large attack. You just sit there and click the same button time after time, hoping for RNG to work out for you. 
Another issue right now is the scarcity of information - or at least information which is not being presented in a clear way. There are some terms thrown around without much explanation at all, and at other times information that you could need at any given time is not given to you in the right place. Sure, you could remember it - but you shouldn't have to. I didn't realise you could read buffs and debuffs on your enemy until the last season, because of how unintuitive it is.  

While the game has it's flaws, I would still recommend it. There is nothing that actively makes it less fun - the mech combat is a bit of a drag, and management could use more work, but the episodes themselves, with turn-based combat and abilities to use, can be really fun. 
It's a small and enjoyable experience overall.

29584123.review:
Go Go Power Rangers!

[i][h1]Что понравилось...[/h1]

[b]- Необычная идея с менеджментом собственного телешоу.[/b]
По сути вся игра это один большой сериал, а ваша задача как игрока, любыми способами удержать его на плаву. Для этого вам предстоит расширять фан-базу, пиарить шоу при помощи сторонних фирм, и самое главное - устраивать движуху во время эпизодов сериала, тем самым увеличивая количество активных зрителей и соответственно доход с каждой отдельной серии. В свободную минутку между сьемками можно потратить заработанные купюры на покупку нового оборудования для павильона, крафт или покупку оружия и экипировки для своих каскадеров, кастомизировать меха, а также всякие мелочи типа прочитки почты, хвалебных твитов, или распределения умений вашего могучего отряда. Ближе к середине этот процесс конечно-же набьет оскомину и превратится в рутину, но все равно останется в памяти уникальным опытом, выделяющим игру среди себе подобных.
[b]- Художественное наполнение.[/b]
Игра спешит отдать дань уважения не только целому жанру - токусатсу, но и лично сериалу сентай, который существует с середины семидесятых, имеет много подражателей и оказал огромное влияние на культуру Японии. Поэтому в игре огромное количество отсылок, камео гостевых персонажей навеянных иконами жанра, а также свойственный японцам дух эпичного, немного абсурдного приключения. Также слегка зацепили интернет мемы, высмеяли многие клише, вкупе с расизмом и сэксизмом. Короче, тех вещей над которыми пошутить себе могут позволить только инди разработчики.
[b]- Музыка.[/b]
Вот уж что действительно редко встречается в современном инди, так это запоминающаяся музыка, особенно chip-tune. В данном случае саундтрек продается отдельно совершенно не зря: штук пять композиций вполне достойны попасть в чей-нибудь плейлист.

[h1]Что не понравилось...[/h1]

[b]- Однообразие.[/b]
Если поначалу игра сильно доставляет своей свежестью и увлекательностью, то уже к середине у неё кончается запал и вплоть до самого конца нас ждет сплошное унылое повторение. Последний босс, конечно, оказался вполне не плох, но до него еще придется дотерпеть.
[b]- Планшетность и ленивый геймплей.[/b]
Я из того вымерающего типа людей, что до сих пор считают, что игры выходящие на ПК должны иметь соответствующее управление и интерфейс. К сожалению, так считаю только я. И проблема не только в огромных раздражающих иконках, а еще и в геймплее. Большую часть игры мы проведем на поле боя в пошаговых боях не отличающихся особой тактикой и интересом, и когда дело доходит до битвы Меха и огромного босса, ждешь как минимум чего-то эпичного, ведь собственно ради таких моментов мы в детстве смотрели сериал, но на деле бой ограничивается ленивым нажатием на пару иконок, да бегающую полосочку в середине экрана. Очень эпично! В итоге весь потенциал боевой системы слит в унитаз - планшетники не перетрудились, а для всех остальных нормальный геймплей просто отсутствует.
[b]- Графика.[/b]
Я с большим уважением отношусь к пиксельной графике, особенно конца прошлого века, когда кудесники геймдева при помощи всяческих технических ухищрений и таланта выжимали из слабых систем потрясающую картинку. Современные инди девеловеры на их фоне выглядят полными бездарями: имея все технические возможности и удобства они в большинстве своем не в состоянии подняться даже до уровня Nes. От того имеем очень креативные, но бесконечно отвратительные игры, но это сугубо мое мнение - глаз игра в целом не режет. [/i]

29575220.review:
Five stunt doubles quit their job and start their own sentai show in Chroma Squad, a turn based tactical RPG. If you’re not familiar with the sentai genre, it’s basically costumed people doing goofy acrobatics and occasionally piloting giant robots to fight space monsters and other wacky stuff, and this game features all of that. You even get to name your team (I picked Colorblind Crusaders to be ironic) and can customize all of their catch phrases.

Each of your team members has a role that defines how you will use them in combat. The scout typically runs ahead to stun groups of enemies or pick off individual monsters. Support heals and technician has a variety of useful skills and long distance attacks. Lead and Assault are for tanking and damage dealing respectively. All characters have their own skill tree that expands with new selectable skills every season.

This game features an assist system where a character ends their turn and becomes available for throwing other characters across the battlefield. If you put characters in assist mode while surrounding a monster and attack with a non-assist character, you will perform a team attack for additional damage. Finally, placing all five members of your squad in assist mode surrounding a monster initiates a special finishing move that does a lot of damage. 

A major underlying system in Chroma Squad is the audience meter. You gain audience by successfully completing levels. To keep things interesting, each level has director’s instructions that are essentially mini-quests ranging from “defeat the monster with a finishing move” or “attack the monster with lead 5 times”. Audience is turned into cash at the end of each episode and can be used with various marketing agencies to give your squad various different bonuses as well as additional cash. Cash is then used to buy armor or weapons or crafting materials to make specialized gear.

If I had to sum up Chroma Squad with one word it would probably be “cozy”, if only because of the soundtrack and overall graphic theme. Try listening to the OST on youtube and you’ll see (or hear rather) what I mean. I really liked the simplified retro-look as well, it has sort of a late-era SNES feel to it which fits perfectly with the game’s style. There are all sorts of little campy details like the characters doing different silly poses when they’re the focus of conversation or the omnipresent recording crew following you to every single battle and staying just out of harm’s way. 

All of this comes with a nasty catch though; there are some significant performance issues in this game. My rig is capable of doing VR games no problem but I still had loads of framerate drops at random parts of the game. The good news about this is that it typically won’t effect your playthrough due to the tactical nature of the game, but it will be a bit of a pain for giant robot fights where you have a QTE during the monster’s turn that requires you to click at a precise time to defend.

If you are in to sentai-style stuff at all, you will probably love Chroma Squad. Even if you aren’t though, this game is still fun for anyone who would enjoy a tactical rpg like Disgaea or Final Fantasy Tactics.

29505378.review:
I really want to like this game. I really, really do. I'm a huge fan of Tokusatu shows and I love Power Rangers and Super Sentai. I also love strategy games, business managers and RPGs. This game is based off Power Rangers, is a strategy game and has business manager elements. Sounds like a combo made in heaven, right? Well...I've tried to play through it over 3 times now and every time I just get tired of it. It's not a bad game, really, but it reeks of poor design choices. 

But I don't want it to seem like I hate the game, so lets talk about the positives of the game. 

The game looks gorgeous. Pixel art sometimes feels lazy, but this game makes it look really nice. Sprites are put together nicely and are animated well. The maps in particular look sweet, I especially love the city block with the toy store map.  The pieces of gear you can craft also look great, most end game gear even looks like cool Power Ranger suits. The animations your characters do when they fight enemies are also done really well and just feel like they really connected. The sound effects really help in making every hit feel like it landed too. 

The gameplay itself is also fun. It's simple, very simple, but fun. It's a basic SRPG affair. Units move across a grid map and punch enemies in the face. Some classes like the Tech Guy can hit enemies from afar and each class has their own skills to spice it up a bit. You only get 5 Rangers (missed opportunity for a dope 6th Ranger to join you), so the actual strategy element is a bit lite. 

Now for the bad...

The story...oh dear the writing. The writing in this game can range from just plain boring to borderline offensive statements that make no sense, but I want to avoid that can of worms so let's just talk about the other way the writing just isn't very good. 

First of all, the actual show you produce doesn't seem to have any sense of internal continuity with itself. You don't really see this unbelievably powerful alien king plotting his plan to take over earth in the show itself. That's like, a trait in Power Rangers since MMPR. Lord Zedd, Emperor Gruumm, Master Sledge etc, even the more fantasy ones had a similar antagonist. Almost every episode feels like a basic "Monster of the Week" episode. You only get to see the action elements of the show too, not the character development or world building Power Rangers is known for. The show you're running is boring and none of the episodes stand out. It's ironic because the actors you play as complain about the former show being all action and no substance. 

Next off, the monsters you fight all seem like jokes with no substance or personality. Yes, Power Rangers had silly looking villains (Diabolico still makes me chuckle), but most of them are still meant to be taken seriously, and to an extent, are. Some monsters in Power Rangers look downright [I]awesome[/i]. Lord Arcanon, Lord Zedd, Loki, Badussa, Koragg, Ransik, etc all look awesome and threatening. Meanwhile in Chroma Squad we get...that "has science gone to far" meme from a few years ago and a stop sign wizard...it's not very riveting. 

Your characters have no portraits for dialogue either, nor do they change expression at all, which makes the mood hard to read. It's hard to take a serious seeming role with a half naked boxer perpetually in a "1-2 punch" animation cycle. Those issues I listed, plus the fact that if you get down to it, the plot boils down to a basic "leader who got full of himself and has to get back down to earth" scenario (Man, Power Rangers SPD had that plot resolved in like, an episode...) that just isn't fun or interesting. 

When the plot actually does get going...it's just a typical villain arc with no flair or personality. The main bad guy is a joke in both literal and metaphorical senses. He has no menace to him. It's just a lady gaga parody. Imagine if we got someone like Lord Zedd, Octomus The Master, Emperor Gruumm or even King Mondo or Rita Repulsa to hijack the plot? That would've been 10 times more interesting then what we got. Heck, Power Rangers even had a similar villain to Lord Gaga named Heckyl...and they made him so much more interesting by giving him more depth then "he's feminine and girly". 

Now, the bad parts of the gameplay. The bosses just feel like they're tailored made to be as counter productive to a strategy game as possible. The first major boss teleports around every turn -- which makes gaining distance to regroup feel pointless, can scatter your units -- which makes positioning feel pointless, can attack multiple times per turn -- which is just mean and can stun your units -- which just removes an aspect of strategy. Not only that, but he constantly summons ranged units, which widdle you down while he attacks your units twice a turn. What makes this even worse is that you're healer in this game is borderline worthless. 1 heal per 5 turns? Are you serious?

And it doesn't get better...Season 5 is where I always just give up. It's just not fun in the slightest at that point. Stage gimmicks become bull and enemies have way to much health. The fact that you can't save in episodes -- which can take up to an hour -- is just painful. Theirs no check points, once you feel an episode, that's GG, gotta re-do it unless you want those major drawbacks. What makes this even worse are the mech fights. Oh god the mech fights. The mech fights have literally no strategy to them at all. No extra skills, no items, no techniques, just "punch" and "super move". Winning or losing is based off your luck with RNG. 

Character customization is also plagued with RNG. Getting crafting items is based off enemy drops or you can buy them in the store (Money is painfully scarce, mind you), so getting that piece of gear you need is up to chance. You think your characters are under equipped? Just got to live with it, I guess. You can't re-do episodes and theirs no way to grind reliably. If you're doing bad with drops, you just have to deal with it. Because of this, my squad always feels so lopsided, with my frail healer and scout getting all the good gear to cover their bad defenses, while my fighter and Red Ranger lack behind. 

Speaking of your squad. You can create your own Ranger squad with 5 classes. Pretty basic stuff, you got your Red Ranger, Blue Ranger, Black Ranger, Yellow Ranger and Pink Ranger, but you can customize the colors. Each has a different bonus and skill variety. My issue with this is the actual people you get for your Rangers. Most characters you pick just seem like jokes. I would've liked a variety of normal looking humans. In the words of the wise Zordon "Alpha, Rita's escaped! Recruit a team of teenagers with attitude!". 

That's probably just a nitpick on my end, but I just wish this game took something serious, you know? Everything feels like a joke. The characters are jokes, the mentor character is a joke, the plot is a joke, the monsters are jokes, the main villain is a joke. Theirs nothing to take seriously, nothing to really get into. Power Rangers had silly moments, but was meant to be taken seriously. This is just nothing but a joke. It's not a funny one either.

All in all, this game isn't bad, but it lacks substance, balance, depth and just fun.

29415296.review:
Tactical RPG fans interested in a Power Rangers parody should buy.
I would like to give it a thumbs up. However, while I personally enjoyed the game, it has far too many issues and bugs. Behold Studios can do better.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
* [b]The Teamwork system[/b]
The core of the battle system is the Teamwork system. I overall really like it. During a character's turn, you can end it by selecting "Teamwork". That character can then do one of two things: A. Join another team member's attack on an enemy.  B. Throw another team member to a further space.

* [b]You can fast forward through scenes by holding down Enter or Space[/b]
A lot of games simply have a "skip scene" option, but that's a very binary choice. With fast forward, I can selectively skip through parts of scenes.

* [b]Character models change as you change equipment[/b]
- In a lot of RPG's, the character models are the same regardless of what you've equipped. In Chroma Squad, the characters look different depending on what you've equipped!

* [b]Music[/b]
- The background Studio music got stuck in my head. In a good way.
- The music that plays in the Mecha battles is good and gives the appropriate feeling.
- Japanese theme songs are great.

* [b]Can choose the order you play Episodes in[/b]
- Each Season, there are 5 to 6 Episodes. Except for the first and last Episode, you can choose which order you play the Episodes in.


[h1]Mixed[/h1]
* [b]Story branches based on your choices[/b]
- Great to have branching
- But the branching is simplistic. There's only [spoiler]one minor branch and one major branch[/spoiler]
- If you want to see all 3 different endings, you have to replay from the beginning. And because the branching is so simplistic, you'll be mostly replaying the same content.


[h1]Cons[/h1]
* [b]Many game mechanics are not clearly explained.[/b]
- What's Crafting Rate? Fan Conversion Rate? Income Conversion? Skill Regin? None of these are clearly explained by the game.
- Some abilities boost Defense. Wait, how do I see my character's Defense stat? Well, you can't. They hid it.


* [b]Difficult to plan character movement[/b]
In Chroma Squad, you'll often want to use Team Acrobatics to have one team member throw another to a further tile. But this is tough to plan and I was often off by one.
- You don't get to see the member's throwing range until after you've already put them into Teamwork mode.
- The grid is only explicitly drawn as you're moving a character. And it is only drawn covering the area that that member can cover. 
The ability to undo actions that don't trigger RNG would be helpful. So you could undo movement or putting a member into Teamwork (exception: the Support class can heal neighboring members when put into Teamwork mode, which does trigger RNG). 


* [b]Crafting is problematic.[/b]
You can either buy equipment or craft it yourself. Crafting is neat in concept, but it has several issues:
- The bought equipment is unique from the crafted equipment. You'll often be asking yourself whether you should buy Equipment B or craft Equipment C.  However, the Shop and Crafting screens are separate, so there is no direct way to compare the two. I found myself constantly jumping between the two screens. (And you can't jump directly between them. You have to back out to the main Studio screen first. Bleh.)
- I generally found the Crafted equipment to be worse than the bought equipment.
- Some crafted items get random properties, which are basically boosts to one of the stats. But there's no explanation of what to expect. If you get Health +10 is that a good roll or a bad roll? Also, sometimes your rolls can be for the same stat. I found that a bit surprising at first and wondered if the game maybe failed to give me one of my random properties.


* [b]The story scenes have horribly slow pacing. Thank goodness you can fast-forward.[/b]
- In many scenes, the enemies are shown appearing one... by... one...  by... one... Why? No one want to see that.
- Do you like watching characters move across the screen with nothing happening?
- There are significant pauses between characters saying lines
- The fast forward system doesn't have an option to let you stop fast-forwarding at speech lines. That's what I really want. I want to read the dialog, but I don't want to have to wait through poorly choreagraphed scenes. 


* [b]Every mecha battle is the exact same[/b]
- Every monster you fight behaves the same way. And so you never have to change your strategy in how to fight them.
- The setting where you fight is always the exact same. (The game lampshades this, but that doesn't excuse it.) 
- This was a huge missed opportunity. Imagine monsters that attack in unique ways that require unique responses. Or unique environments that you can use as part of the fight.


* [b]The final bad guy is a huge letdown.[/b] [spoiler]He simply just shows up at the very end. You've never seen him before. There's absolutely no connection to the character. That's a big story failure.[/spoiler]


* [b]Tons of bugs[/b]
- About 20+ minutes into the final battle, the game wouldn't advance. I had to restart from the beginning of the battle.

- After finishing an Episode, I pressed escape while it was totalling how much Money and Fans I had earned. The game got in a messed up state and never gave me credit for the Money or Fans.

- For a game that fails to explain its mechanics, it compounds this by showing incorrect information around those mechanics:
-- The game often improperly calculates Expected Income. 
-- One Ad Agency gives you a bonus of 35 Fans per Episode. The game improperly shows that the Fan Conversion rate is increased by 35, instead of just a flat increase of 35 Fans.
-- The game is often incorrect about the number of Fans and Money you earned the previous Episode

- When defending in the Mecha battles, you basically have to time when you press your mouse. Unfortunately, this is exactly when the game would decide to stutter on me.

- Sometimes a character is attacked offscreen and the camera doesn't move to show you what's happening.

- If you click the upper right corner, you can submit a bug report, which is great. But, the form to report bugs has bugs! The arrow keys where you're writing text don't work.

29348503.review:
Have you ever watched Power Rangers as a kid? Well I didn't, but I knew of it, and even watched some scattered episodes here and there, but I always found it too hard to get into and really corny (And I know, it is part of the charm of the series, your hand is probably shaking right now to tell me that, but as a kid, that didn't grab my attention.), and well, this game surely nails on corniness, it feels just like the show, which I nowadays respect a lot, everything is here, the music, the silly costumes, the fights, the megazord, even Zordon is in it; and, in gameplay, this game surprised me, it's really fun!

In Chroma Squad, 5 stuntman for an lackluster action show get bored of their current contract and their director, so they decide to quit and make their own independent studio to film an action packed show, starting in a humble warehouse with Chroma Key and a text to speech giant brain prop, up to a real professional studio, and throughout the game you have to manage the costumes, the advertisement, the props, reply to fan letters, and of course, film the show. And it's all tongue-in-cheek and very corny, just like the original Power Rangers. It's amazing to see the big Mecha fights against a giant enemy, or the exaggerated moves, or EXPLOSIONS!!

The game has a really cool battle system, it is somewhat basic, but still fun. You watch over the battle field and you can either move or attack an enemy, you also have skills you can activate and a teamwork mechanic, which I think it's really well done. But that's just when you're filming, when you are between shoots, you can manage and improve your studio and show, by buying or crafting clothes and weapons for your rangers and improvements for your mecha, purchasing new filming equipment, signing contracts with advertising agents, and answering fan mail. Everything is really creative and well done.

The game looks really good, it has a wonderful 32 bit style to it, and sometimes there's also a 90s TV filter in the studio management screen, which sets the tone pretty well, all the sprites are really well drawn, and the enemies design is also fantastic, especially the bosses, who are a ton of fun.
The music and sound effects though, those are the best part, in the title screen, the game has an Japanese opening music playing, which already sets the mood to the game, and the rest of the soundtrack, is really good and somewhat catchy, I love it!

Overall, this game is great, I absolutely recommend it, it has the soul of the Power Rangers in it, with all the fun corniness the show had, the developers did a wonderful job! Now they just need to make 23 movies and iterations of it, and it truly will be Power Rangers, the game.

Read more video game reviews at cassus.org

Talvez esse seja um dos primeiros jogo brasileiros reconhecidos senão for o mais, fico feliz por uma ideia tão criativa ter vindo de nossas terras, Chroma Squad é a prova de que bons games não precisam ter gráficos de última geração e que a crtiatividade vai além disso.

Ao estilo sentai, as músias do game ficaram muito legais, porém poucas. As piadas e referências as séries japoneses assim como o uso da quarta parede são divertidas e inteligentes, o jogo tira onda até do jeito que as pessoas comentam nas redes sociais como o Twitter (#hashtags kkk).

Como ponto negativo eu achei a condução da história um pouco fora de foco, achei estranho que o jogo não deixa claro quando os personagens estão nas gravações e quando não estão, outros problemas também como a repetitividade fez com que eu enjoasse um pouco na metade do game, mas nos últimos episódios voltei a ter empolgação pra jogar.

Chroma Squad é simples, inteligente, criativo e do Brasil! Vale a pena ser jogado.

29283747.review:
Muy recomendable RPG de estrategia con ambientación de las series de Sentai japonés: Manejamos a un grupo de especialistas que deciden crear su propia serie, llamada Chroma Squad, aunque las cosas se complican. El guión es entretenido y está muy bien traducido al castellano, con 3 finales distintos en función de algunas decisiones que tomamos durante el juego.

La mecánica es sencilla, siguiendo las pautas marcadas por el nuevo XCOM (1 movimiento + 1 acción, o 2 movimientos), con un énfasis en la cooperación entre personajes. Las habilidades están bien pensadas y se le saca juego a todas, a la vez que dejan claros los roles de cada uno de los integrantes del equipo.

Falla un poco en los objetivos de misión, que siempre se reducen a "Mata a todos los enemigos" o "Aguanta X turnos" (que al final son básicamente lo mismo: Mata todo lo que puedas y procura no morir), aunque están las "peticiones del director" que añaden objetivos secundarios mucho más específicos y variados (gana en X turnos, no golpees al jefe hasta derrotar a los esbirros, realiza N ataques cooperativos, cura N puntos de salud...). En cierto modo es como los jueces del Final Fantasy Tactics, con la diferencia que no estamos obligados a seguirlos (aunque la recompensa de audiencia es importante).

Los enemigos son variados en parte: Por un lado los jefes son muchos y muy diferentes entre ellos, por el otro los esbirros/masillas los hay de sólo 4 tipos y no tienen apenas habilidades especiales, lo cual contribuye a que no haya demasiada variedad en la estrategia a seguir para las misiones.

Después tenemos los combates entre Kaijus, con nuestro Mecha gigante. Estos combates resultan bastante espectaculares y sus mecánicas apenas son más que un Stat Check (intercambio de puñetazos hasta que uno caiga), hay una ligera toma de decisiones respecto a qué habilidades usar y cuando dejar de golpear para defenderse, pero al final estas batallas se ganan en la tienda, no en el campo de batalla.

Entre episodios, conseguiremos fans en función de nuestra actuación, lo cual nos da ganancias y nos permite obtener mejoras o más dinero a base de usar las agencias de publicidad. También hay un sistema de crafting, aunque es bastante difícil conseguir los objetos que buscamos así que al final resulta un poco secundario (se pueden comprar objetos en la tienda con dinero).

Respecto a la dificultad, lo jugué en la máxima disponible y por lo que veo en los números creo que es la más adecuada (en Normal los enemigos tienen casi la mitad de vida y hacen la mitad de daño). No fue un paseo pero tampoco resultó especialmente difícil, tan sólo tuve que repetir una misión y una batalla de Kaijus.

El soporte con mando es regulero (manejas el cursor del ratón con el stick), mucho más recomendado un ratón o un Steam Controller.

En resumen, un juego de estrategia muy recomendable, ameno y con buena ambientación. Se hace un poco repetitivo en la segunda mitad, pero aun así tiene carisma suficiente para que no resulte molesto.

29261289.review:
It was hard for me to decide whether to recommend this or not. On the one hand, you've got some fairly smart Power Rangers/Sentai parody work, a fun storyline, and a great aesthetic. On the other hand, the tactical RPG aspect is... very unpolished. Even on medium difficulty, Season 3 really ramps up the challenge level, driven purely by poor design aspects. Unlike most TRPGs, there's no way to undo a move action if you realize you've gone to the wrong square. Healing is also ridiculously thin on the ground given how much damage enemies do the further you go in the game. I had one of my dudes (the scout, who has about average health) taken from full health to zero in a single round.

In the end, though, it's still pretty fun, even if the percentages on the material recycling in the crafting menu are complete BS.

29155401.review:
I really enjoyed this game. I started on "interesting" as a difficulty setting as I've played plenty of tactical rpgs. And, boy, did Chroma Squad deliver an enjoyable experience. Not accounting for times when I left to get food in my bidge-play of this game, you can complete it within a reasonable 10-12 hours, even faster if you skip the dialog on replays. 

But onto the important stuff, what was good?
+ Customization of characters, studio, and your OMEGA SUPREME mech. (eh, couldn't help it). 
+ Storyline does develop overtime but is slow in the first season.
+ Multiple endings
+ Quirky narrator
+ Crafting options for your squad and your mech
+ High level of detail (clouds hang from strings, cardboard backdrops, etc).
+ Multitude of bosses
+ Required episodes of annoying red leader being an annoying red leader
+ Character development(?), some people have stated that they didn't think the characters were developed enough, but I think part of that has to deal with being involved with your squad. By the end of the game I new what each team member's personality was, their flaws, and dislikes. (I.e. overzealous, not liking violence, etc). To get more out of the game maybe name rangers after friends or read the dialog out loud (oh, what a concept) to bring more life to them. Regardless I thought the charactization was good. 

Stuff I wished there was more of: 
- More characters to choose from. I'm on my third playthrough of the game and I do have favorites that I like to use, but there are other characters available that don't work well for the "challenge" level of difficulty where you need to spend money and upgrades for the studio and characters wisely.  This is not to complain about the difficulty, I think it is fine, but more characters would add more variety and depth to playthroughs. 
- Possibly less marketing partners.I know I just said I want more variety, but sometimes there can be too much of a good thing. I honestly only used 2-3 depending on my need for the episode. More options for other sections of the game could have been prioritized more instead. 
- Side-characters. I include this lightly as Chroma Squad does pay homage to other rangers coming to save our would be heroes by introducing different characters throughout different episodes, but some of them fall to the way side and don't re-appear (besides when you make choices that cause that to happen).

If it were a perfect world:
Keep in mind that this development team has been wanting to add more to Chroma Squad but, has been bogged down in bureaucratic nonsense due to licensing agreements with the Power Rangers franchise. I am sure that there is a lot more that they would like to add to the game. I look forward to more Chroma Squad in the future.

The price:
I bought this when it was on sale, that being said, I still would have paid the 14.99 to get the game. You can tell a lot of time was spent on settings, dialog, etc. That doesn't mean this game is entirely perfect, but the price is suitable to the experience I had.

LIGHTS, CAMERA, CHROMATIZE!!!! 9/10

29082590.review:
Chroma Squad is a tactical role-playing game, released for personal computers in early goings of 2015. It was heavily influenced by various Tokusatsu series, two of the chief inspirations being Saban's Power Rangers and Shotaro Ishinomori's Kamen Rider.

[h1]Go Go [strike]Power[/strike] Rangers![/h1]
Five professional stuntmen who've grown tired of the poor production values and tyranical director of their current television series decide to uproot and take their talent elsewhere. Soon after impulsively deciding to leave, the group begins developing an original Sentai series, and must work through a myriad of problems to ensure that the series is successful.

[h1]Out of the frying pan, into the casting department.[/h1]
Before the game rears into action, the player is given several options to tailor their experience: A choice between three difficulty settings, helping to accommodate players of all skill levels; selecting your squad and studio names, colors and transformation shout; and finally, designating the actors to the roles that you see fit.

Each of those actors have unique bonuses, which help to determine how they'll influence the team for the better. Several of these bonuses are especially beneficial with a particular role, e.g.; Skill Regen for an Assist character to improve the rate at which they can heal the rest of the group. Some actors go so as far as to impose combat penalties on themselves, so that they can provide a heavy boost in another area.

Branching paths are another feature that help to provide some elements of customization. The studio will occasionally receive an email with several options for replies. While most of these only lead to an audience bonus, others can provide weaponry that otherwise wouldn't be available. The largest branch in the game is accessed during one particular battle: depending on how one chooses to complete an objective, the game determines how the second half of the journey will play out. All of these add a great degree of value to subsequent plays.

[h1]It's Morphin' Time!​[/h1]
The foundation that the game is built upon is squad based combat, which plays out on a turn-by-turn basis in which the rangers move around on an isometric grid. The team use their varied skill sets to turn the tide of battle, in whatever way they can. Be they used for healing, or rapidly bursting down the health of nearby enemies, each member is prepared to put up a fight, whether they're alone, or working together. 

Should they choose the latter, teamwork is used as a mechanic that allow them to launch one another to distant locations, as well as attacking enemies as a group for higher damage. Still, sometimes even a team of powerful heroes need a little more help to defeat a daunting foe.

[h1]Megazord, Eat Your Heart Out​![/h1]
At times like these, our heroes call upon their Mecha to participate in Kaiju battles; essentially, giant robots fighting giant monsters. These also play out turn-by-turn, but here the objective is to create combos with your abilities, all the while paying close attention to a percentage representing you're likelihood of hitting the target. The significance of this is that combo-chains determine your damage multiplier, and missing an enemy breaks this chain, resets it to 0, and proceeds to the the next turn. While these sections aren't especially interesting on their own, they do add enough variety to keep the core gameplay relatively fresh.

[h1]A Heartfelt Tribute​[/h1]
Personally, I've never been particularly compatible with isometric tactics, as they tend to be very slow paced, without providing something that makes it feel necessary. That said, I found Chroma Squad to be a game that meaningfully improves the pace of the genre. Perhaps the kindest thing I can say about it in that regard is, while the gameplay is familiar, the time you spend in battle doesn't feel like it massively exceeds the amount of time allocated to plot and cutscenes, as it does in many tactical titles.

As a longtime enthusiast of the source material, Chroma Squad had an easy time getting through to me, as it shows an incredible amount of reverence for the style, and does a wonderful job of presenting it in a unique way. Going beyond that incredibly initial premise, there's an incredible amount of charm to be found here. From the moment you launch the game, the main theme mimics the vocal styling of many classic Tokusatsu themes, and perfectly sets the tone for the adventure. Something as simple as skipping through cutscenes is done as though someone was fast forwarding through a VHS tape, showing an immense amount of character for something that otherwise wouldn't be noteworthy in the slightest. Here we have an incredibly quirky game that makes for a very engaging experience and is absolutely worth the price of admission.

[b]Time Spent: [/b]132 Hours (Average game length: 15 hours.)
[b]Further Playing:[/b] Fire Emblem: Awakening (3DS), XCOM: Enemy Within (Windows, OS X, PlayStation 3, Xbox 360)
