29023840.review:
This game is wonderful.  It's self aware, funny, and one big homage to sentai, while playing like Final Fantasy Tactics and Disgaea in combat, and like nothing I have ever played in the management aspects.

Pros:  Combat.  You have team attacks, acrobatics, heals, buffs, stuns, and special attacks.  The studio management stuff seems a bit overwhelming at first, but you get used to it.  You can use marketing to increase your income, buff the actors in combat, increase your fanbase, etc.  You can choose to make all your costume pieces, or buy them instead, while getting rare items during episodes (missions).

Cons:  Might be a relatively short playtime.  I'm at 12 hours now, and that's just because I screwed up my first playthrough and wanted a fresh start, might have 4 more hours of play left.  Aside from the first few missions you get, and some emails you read in game, you kinda have to learn a lot of stuff on your own.  I'll give you an example, the game teaches you if you get all 5 actors next to an enemy, have 4 locked into team action, and then attack with the last, you'll get a finishing move.  What the game didn't teach me and I found on my own, you can have some attack from afar with others in range of the target, and get a finishing move with a mega laser gun where all the actors merge their weapons together.  All that being said, these are still minor cons.

I love this game and I recommend you get it if you enjoy some light to intermediate management gameplay and tactical rpg combat similar to Disgaea and FFTactics.  Also, if you like sentai and don't take it too seriously.  If you like playing these type of games on difficult, buy it no matter the price.  If you play on casual or normal (you'll probably finish a lot sooner), then I recommend waiting til its 10 or less.

Have fun.

28898750.review:
I love this game to bits.
Absolutely zero regrets about buying it.

I just finished playing through on the Normal difficulty. I wouldn't consider myself good at strategy games, and I found it to be generally rather easy most of the time (while trying to accomplish every Director's Instruction). I also never had to replay any of the levels, though I did put a good amount of thought between missions on what to purchase and upgrade. Anyone who often plays or enjoys strategy games should probably pick the hardest difficulty if they're looking for a proper challenge. It's there, though it probably wouldn't be the hardest game out there, by far.

There is so much to love about this game. Adorable and lovably drawn art, simplified but thought-out gameplay, and a very funny and self-aware representation of Indie Sentai filmmaking. You even get to pick your characters out of a good list of choices, choose their colour, and names. The costumes even change depending on what they have equipped, seriously.

It comes out as 'one-of-those-games-that-aren't-really-that-deep-but-it-really-doesn't-need-to-be' kind of games. It isn't the longest game out there either (it does have multiple endings though), so if you've only got a few dollars to throw around, you ought to wait for a sale.

You have to play this one and really feel the love and spirit put into it. If you even remotely enjoy the strategy genre or enjoy Sentai-style films like Power Rangers, Kamen Rider, or anything of the sort- this is practically a MUST-play.

28877665.review:
I followed the development of this game back from its Kickstarter campaign, and despite all the fanfarre it got, all I can say is that it was a letdown.

The gameplay in itself is somewhat enjoyable, if limited. Group battles are of a light tactical nature and play decently, but mecha battles are basically just contrived sequences of dice rolls.

There is some fun to be had in customizing your studio, Rangers and their equipment, but it all feels unbalanced, in such a way that there is just "one true way" of doing things, while the rest is filler.

The main issue, though, is the plot and flow of the game... or lack thereof. The story is rife with jokes that read like internal jokes of the dev team or obscure references. It's not even a cultural barrier deal, because even playing on the native language of the studio, the text just felt confusing, weak and generic.

That is compounded by the fact that every other mission counts with "support members" who contributed to the campaign. In summary, they are all dudes who are pretty much alike and have to make an introductory speech stating who they are, what they do, etc. and then be awesome. It gets annoying fast.

It's not that it's so bad that it shouldn't be played, but really, with so many other options out there, why bother?

"OMG! It's GODZILLA!!!" - Squad, Meme.

Se você gosta ou já gostou de tokusatsus (Power Rangers, Jaspion, Ryukendo, etc), este jogo foi feito para você!

Imagine que algúem misturou Final Fantasy Tactics e Disgaea com todos os super sentais já criados, e adicionando o estilo "new 8-bits" que apenas a Behold Studios consegue fazer. O resultado é Chroma Squad.

Você cria seu próprio estúdio e seu programa de Super Sentai, e as coisas começam a sair do controle. Até mesmo um plot simples como esse conseguiu ser muito bem desenvolvido, com missões muito boas, cheias de referências à cultura pop e outros tokusatsus, e muito desenvolvimento de personagem.

Uma customização extensa dos personagens, do estúdio e, principalmente, do Megazord (ou o nome que você quiser dar para ele (como, no meu caso, Godzilla Sarrador)), somado aos seus 3 finais diferentes adicionam um fator de rejogabilidade enorme ao jogo (considerando que o jogo possui uma campanha por volta de 12h).

Claro que existem seus problemas. Por mais que a customização seja grande, ainda sim, é meio limitada, principlamente pelo final do jogo, quando você consegue facilmente ter todos os upgrades e os melhores equipamentos, passando aquela sensação de "e agora?".

Em resumo:
Jogue Chroma Squad. Mesmo se você não gostar do estilo, do gênero Tático, ou da história, o jogo ainda sim consegue ser extremamente divertido. 8.4/10

Die einzelnen Missionen sind die Folgen der Serie, durch die man sich rundenweise mit Gegnern anlegt, wobei aber auch Taktik gefragt ist. Bonusziele (im Spiel „Regieanweisungen“ genannt) bringen zusätzliche Zuschauer und somit mehr Geld ein, mit das man das eigene Studio verbessern oder neue Ausrüstung für seine Schauspieler erwerben kann. 

Egal ob man nur kurz Zeit oder einen längeren Zeitraum zum Spielen hat, Chroma Squad bietet eine tolle Unterhaltung. Wie bei einer richtigen Serie verschiebt man schnell alles andere und denkt sich: „Nur noch eine Folge!“.

28705411.review:
Ahhh Chroma Squad, where to begin... I know!
TL;DR
Chroma squad is a fantastic action startegy game with an in depth, self aware story. With a well written set of dialogue, and a surprisingly deep combat system Chroma Squad is sure to please strategy fans... even if you haven't seen power rangers!





Chroma Squad, in an depth action strategy game that never ceases to amaze me! With large a (and albeit, very obvious) inspiration from Sabans Power Ranger. Chroma Squad is a game that will make you want to relive your childhood... and at the same time want to destroy it. You see Chroma Squad's difficulty system can be changed on the fly for those of you who don't want to think... If you do enjoy a challenge however, play the game on hard mode (warning! PLAN ABOUT THREE STEPS AHEAD ON HARD). This game can, and will kick you in the rear so hard you won't remember what you planned to do afterwards.
Chroma Squad has a very (from what I have played) unique system called teamwork. This system allows your teamates to perform double, tiple, even quadruple attacks (similar fire emblem fates), but there is a catch... teamwork is the only way to use your finisher (a vital tool later on) , and can allow your team to move further on the set! Now you may be wondering what can make this game so difficult, IMO I believe Chroma Squad is one of the few games that got difficulty right. It doesn't just swarm you with hundreds of cheap, or extremely powerful enemies, atleast not in the beginning. Chroma Squad has a real sense of growth meaning that as you get stronger the game can and WILL adapt.
Mecha battles, this feature surprised me. when I had my first mecha battle I was pleasently surprised. Though simple the mecha battle can really make you question your "startegic genius" and really mke you pull your hair out if not careful.




To sum it up, this game seems very simple, and easy on your first run. That fact can be a lie, the game can be very challenging to the extreme on the harder difficulties, and the AI can be very ruthless and capitalize on every mistake you make. The premise is great, and the game has this atmosphere that I find hard to explain, but enjoy. The mecha battles are a nice break from the normal gameplay. Worth a buy. if you watched Power Rangers for sure!

My score: 5/5 (6/5 if you enjoyed Power Rangers as a child)

Chroma Squad, a parody on Japanese Sentai TV series, is an amazing turn-based strategy game. Think of Final Fantasy tactics with Power Rangers.

The story is pretty fun. It's nothing special, but it's definetely not bad either (considering this is a parody) and the dialogue cracks me up from time to time. Some jokes might go way over your head if you don't watch Sentai series, but it doesn't ruin the experience. 
The gameplay is really fun as well. The Final Fantasy Tactics-esque gameplay is a good point in my book, although it might get repetitive for some. The length of the game and the "guest stars" that appear from time to time make up for it, in my opinion.
I think the visuals are really great, really digging the pixel art.
The soundtrack is superb. The chiptune-ish background music fits in perfectly, and makes every battle a little bit more fun.

So if u liked Final Fantasy Tactics or if u are a Power Rangers fan, you ought to try this game out!

28234153.review:
Si os gustan los juegos indies y tactics este es tu juego sin pensar lo dos veces, ya estas tardando, ¿Por que?, pues yo te lo explico:

Chroma Squad mezcla lo mejor de los juegos estilo tactic (Xcom, FF tactic, Vandal Hearts...) con juegos de controlar una empresa, si, ya que tendremos que llevar nuestro propio estudio de televisión de una serie al estilo Power Rangers. ¿Y como se come esto?, pués fácil.

La historia va de un grupo de dobles de acción de una serie de televisión que deciden dejar su trabajo para montar su propio estudio y serie de televisión. Empezaremos grabando en el garage de uno de los tíos de los protagonistas y de ahí iremos mejorando mientras grabamos capítulos nuestros trajes, armas y estudio a base de comprar o fabricar. También tendremos contratos on empresas de publicidad y cada vez que acabemos un capítulo recibiremos cartas y twitters de los fans.

Aquí no es solo pegar tortas, si no hacer acrobacias y seguir las instrucciones como que todos derroten al enemigo final pegando a la vez o que no muera nadie, hay infinidad de posibilidades, si lo hacemos bien la audiencia mejorará y eso significa más dinero.

Pero si todo fuera eso solo sería un juego de llevar tu empresa, aquí hay algo más, aquí hay una historia que se irá narrando en cada capítulo grabado, nuestros personajes quizás se conviertan en algo más de lo que pensais.

Como buena serie al estilo Power Ranger no faltarán acrobacias, golpes especials, monstruos divertidos e incluso tendremos nuestro propio robot de combate, Kaijuuuuuuuu!!!!!!!

Quizás si abusais jugando muchas horas seguidas (que puede pasar fácilmente por que es adictivo), puede volver se un poco repetitivo, pero de verdad que merece y mucho la pena.

Para mí es un juego diferente a lo habitual y eso lo hace especial.

Lo recomiendo gente, poned lo en favoritos y a la que haya un buen descuento aprovechad!.

28211492.review:
[h1]Chroma Squad – Go, go Pixel Rangers![/h1]

Das Spiel entführt dich zurück in die Zeit der 90er, die Zeit der trashigen Talkshows und anderer überdrehter TV-Unterhaltungsprogamme, wie den Power Rangers.


[b]Was dich erwartet...[/b] 

Nach einer kleinen Auseinandersetzung mit dem Regisseur, entschließt sich deine Gruppe von Stuntmen/Schauspielern die Sache in die eigenen Hände zu nehmen. Hierfür gründen sie kurzum eine Produktionsfirma und fangen in einer alten Lagerhalle an eine eigene Serie zu produzieren und zu vermarkten.

Deine Aufgabe wird es sein die Beliebtheit deiner Serie von Staffel zu Staffel zu garantieren, viele neue Fans zu bekommen und die Einschaltquote zu steigern. Dieses erreicht man, indem man Regieanweisungen durchführt, im Teamwork zusammenarbeitet, spezielle Fähigkeiten benutzt oder einfach nur die Gegner umhaut.
Dein Team besteht aus 5 verschiedenen Schauspielern, die du Anfangs noch ändern kannst. Jeder Schauspieler verfügt über Boni oder Mali, die durch ihre Filmrolle noch weiter spezialisiert werden. Schlussendlich hat man dann 5 Spezialisten mit unterschiedlichen Fähigkeiten, ähnlich wie man es aus dem klassischen Rollenspielen kennt.


[b]Aller Anfang ist schwer...[/b]

Denn steht man zum Beginn des Spiels noch vor einigen Startproblemen. Das Studio ist klein, die Outfits und Requisiten bescheiden, von Marketing kann keine Rede sein und irgendwie fehlt es an Spezialeffekten.


[b]Kommt Zeit, kommt Rat...[/b] 

Im weiteren Spielverlauf schaltet man zusätzliche Funktionen für deine Produktionsfirma frei, die dir helfen werden, deine Serie noch erfolgreicher zu machen. 
Einerseits gestatten sie dir coolere Outfits und Requisiten herzustellen oder zu kaufen. Hergestellt wird natürlich stilecht mit Dingen wie Plastik, Klebeband, Glitzer etc., wie es sich halt für eine richtig trashige TV-Produktion gehört. Man kann allerdings auch einfach Outfits und Requisiten im Shop kaufen, dieser steht von Anfang an des Spiels zur Verfügung. Diese Outfits wird man dann in einer spektakulären Squad Transformation anlegen, nachdem man innerhalb einer Folge genug Einschaltquoten gesammelt hat.
Andererseits hat man das Marketing und die Abteilung Mecha, die dann in den ersten Folgen freigeschaltet werden. Das Marketing kann zum Beispiel für mehr Geld, bessere Einschalt-quoten oder mehr Fans sorgen. Geschenkt bekommt man natürlich nichts und um diese Erweiterungen freizuschalten musst du deine Fan-Power einsetzen, welche die Summe deiner Fans ist. 
Mit der Mecha-Abteilung kommen dann die ultimativen Spezialeffekte hinzu. Das ist die Funktion, die dich deinen riesigen Kampfroboter modifizieren lässt. Verbesserung werden auch hier, natürlich stilecht, anfänglich mit Pappe und Klebeband hergestellt.


[b]Die Folgen und Staffeln...[/b]

Die Staffeln sind in Folgen unterteilt, wie man es aus TV-Serien kennt und folgen meistens dem gleichen Muster. Trashige Sprüche, Minions besiegen, Squad Transformation, Trashige Sprüche und den Boss besiegen. Gekämpft wird rundenbasiert in einer isometrischen Perspektive. Sobald der Endboss der Folge besiegt wurde, folgt noch ein weiterer Bosskampf mit dem selben Boss, bloß in seiner vergrößerten Form gegen euren Mecha. Dieser Kampf ist auch rundenbasiert, er-innert von seiner Aufmachung her aber eher an ein beat em up.
Die Orte, an denen die einzelnen Folgen spielen, wiederholen sich ab und an, aber wie es scheint, war es wohl Absicht der Entwickler, denn es wird sich selbst ein klein wenig auf die Schippe genommen.
Mit der Beendigung der Staffel bekommen deine Serienhelden immer weiter Eigenschaften, deine Produktionsfirma mehr Geld und weitere Werbeverträge im Marketingbereich werden angeboten.


[b]Klingt langweilig?![/b]

Ist aber dank der Story, die durchaus unterhaltsam ist und ein paar unerwartete Wendepunkte aufweist, auch mehrfach spielbar. Denn es gibt insgesamt 3 unterschiedliche Storyendings. Außerdem ist es auf dem einfachen Schwierigkeitsgrat ein Leichtes bis zum Ende der Story zu gelangen und bleibt dennoch bis zum Schluss eine spaßige Angelegenheit.
Die verschiedenen Bosse und Minions mit ihren schrägen Designs und die Gute-Laune-Musik tragen dazu bei, dass einem nicht langweilig wird. 


[b]Fazit[/b]

Chroma Squad ist sicher nicht jedermanns Ding, aber für Liebhaber des Trashs, Kinder der 90er und Pixelromantiker durchaus ein Blick wert. Mich hatte vorab der Preis abgeschreckt, doch habe es dann günstig erworben und war sehr überrascht von den Inhalten und der witzig gehalten Story, obwohl ich die Serie als Kind nie geschaut habe! Dennoch kam irgendwie das Kind in mir hoch und hätte jemand mitbekommen, wie ich voller Begeisterung „Go, Go Chroma Squad!“ gerufen habe... da hätte ich bestimmt nicht nur einmal einen Vogel gezeigt bekommen!
Für mich war es also ein toller Spaß und das Geld sicher wert und die alternativen Storyendings werde ich sicherlich auch noch versuchen zu erspielen!

The premise is interesting enough. But it's long, and the characters and their dialogue are VERY stupid, even considering the game itself is a parody. It was sometimes trying to be witty or funny, but it was just crap. 

Also, there are only a few environments you can battle in, which is strange, considering how low-res everything is. 

I wanted to play it through to the end, just to tick it off my list; and it wasn't all bad, when I played it on a lazy evening while listening to an interesting podcast, or something. 
But when I got to the REAL real last mission and saw how long-winded and boring it looked, I just quit. I tried watching it on YouTube, noticed it really is about 50 minutes long, gave it a minute of skipping and was done with it. 

I also wanted to read the entire dialogue of the last mission, just to see how the "story" turns out, but I just couldn't - that's how crap the dialogue was. 

All in all: if you get it for two bucks, to spend a couple fun hours with, go for it. After the novelty wears off, you'll probably get bored - but still, that's not all bad for a game you got for two bucks.

27876264.review:
Chroma squad caught my eye early on since it revolved around old sentai shows and good ol' turn based grid combat.  It only kept getting better as the game continued on.  
So this game let's you assemble/hire your own team of sentai heroes for their new show, and pit them against increasingly challenging battles and goals.  The partial end-game leading up to a big robot battle in your giant mech.  
Take note as this game is relatively difficult, but nothing so absurd it feels unbeatable but later missions will have you carefully planning your next move(s).  
As you progress you'll have to manage your money, crafting resources, which upgrades to purchase between studio/mech/characters, while the game gives you a wide range to customize how to generate and use your resources.  
The plot is also surprisingly well drawn out and more concrete than I was expecting; it's still super cheesy though.  
If you have a fondness for grid based combat, transformations, and giant robots, this game is well worth the time and money.

27599931.review:
[u]What I liked:[/u]
[list]
    [*]The combat, yet simple has some depth
    [*]The music and the charming yet cheesy story
    [*]The whole TV management gameplay aspect
[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know:[/u]
[list]
    [*]Yes it's similar to Power Rangers, but this game is good on its own not for being nostalgic (I’m didn’t watch the shows as a kid)

    [*]The combat is turned based, luckily the animations are fast and you’re not bogged down waiting for the enemies turn even when a dozen are present. Each ranger is a class with special abilities that grow in number with each season.

[*]The game is based on a TV of these fake rangers, but the story gets weirder as what’s real and fake blur the line. Each episode you play has optional objectives that when completed give you lots of fans(this is your way of making more money and getting better marketing perks). The first 3 seasons these were important to get as many as possible. But still missing some of them is ok and still not be crippled later on, plus a lot of them are easy.

    [*]But some bosses spawn mines or spores by the dozens each turn which I did not like. But that was only 2 out of the 30+ bosses you fight.

   [*]The game has a funny/corny story; I never skipped over it because it was entertaining enough to me. If you don’t like it you can skip it all very easily. There is no voice acting, so you will read the dialogue. It even has choices you make by email which will give you either in game rewards, like money, fans, materials or weapons or just the satisfaction of responding to a fan or person in need. Some even choose what bosses you fight so you won’t fight all the game’s bosses in one play through.

[*]The game even has 3 different endings where the last season of the game changes depending on your choice; you have different rangers you can pick at the start of the game (which you can name) along with the email choices above give a good replay value.

[*]Now the TV show management side is very easy and isn’t hard to understand. You have marketing team which you can pick from a lot with new ones each season offering different benefits, like more money, fans damage, item drop and more depending on who you pick. 

[*]You have crafting which is cool, offering more variety of armor and weapons that the shop doesn’t have. The shop and items you craft are both viable with neither being the obvious op choice. 

[*]Next are the mech battles, you customize your mech by the 5 parts of the body (head, torso, 2 arms and legs). These you craft and once start leveling up your parts to high tier it’s going to be hard to get the materials to swap if you want to. Now the battles themselves are simple, your main attack with every hit you gain a combo but lose in accuracy, so there is some luck involved there. You get abilities depending on the parts you picked for your mech. Overall these battles are short, flashy and fun to mix up the fights

[*]I played the game on the middle difficulty and failed about 3 episodes (there is a penalty for doing this). So it’s not that hard. Playing on the easy mode would be a cake walk if you’re worried about how difficult the game is. The game even though it’s simple does require planning and synergizing your team’s abilities and timing when played on the higher difficulties

[/list]

[h1]My Score:[/h1]
[b]A[/b]

[b]Paid:Included in $1 Humble Bundle[/b]
[b]Completed in:14 hours[/b]

27550583.review:
I received Chroma Squad in the Humble Monthly Bundle earlier this year.  Having never heard of it, I decided to give it a chance.  

This is a turn based game where you control a team of five stunt actors who decide to start their own power rangers show.  Every 'battle' is one episode, so you go through the setup and fundraising for the studio and costumes and such, and then enter filming, which is essentially the episode.  Failing to win the battle causes you to get bad ratings on your show.  

If you have positive feelings towards Power Rangers from your childhood, and you like lighter-side story centered RPG strategy games, you'd probably like this.  

Its strong points are numerous; it has item crafting, a good story, challenging but not overly brutal strategy, combat is fun, good humor, likeable characters, nostalgia (without leaning on it too heavily), etc.

Weak points might be that some mechanics can be a little tedious.  Kaiju battles never got boring for me (there's like 8 or so in the game) but they're all pretty similar.  Also, some people don't like pixel graphics, so if that's not your thing then move on.  Also, the game tries (and succeeds) in capturing the campy nature of power rangers style shows, so if that's going to make you cringe then you could consider it a weak feature.

PONTOS NEGATIVOS: NÃO JOGUE DEMAIS (ele pode acabar enjoando e vai ficar parado por muito tempo na sua biblioteca) - Mesmo tendo 3 finais, eles não são tão diferentes assim, oq acaba se tornando meio repetitivo - O URSO DE COLIN (pior vilão, é sério eu fiquei quase 1 semana sem jogar por causa dele....) - O craft de itens

SPOILERS SE N JOGOU Q QUER TER EXPERIENCIA PRÓPRIA, PARE DE LER POR AQ E PULE PRO FINAL ONDE EU DOU A MINHA NOTA PARA O JOGO!!! (n é sério, eu vo da uns spoilers pesados aq q podem acabar com seu jogo)

A história começa assim: Tinha 5 nego q eram dubles de um programa de "Super Sentai" (Pessoas normais q ativam seus poderes quando usam roupas coloridas e coladas, tipo Power Rangers ou algo do genero), mas seu chefe era um vacilaum, e só queria luta, luta, luta, luta, luta E MAIS LUTA nos episódios. Ent eles ficam de saco cheio e vao embora de seu estudio tentando criar o seu próprio. Eles vão para uma garagem onde eles encontram uma coisa coberta com um lençol, ent eles descobrem q aquilo é um cerebro satanico gigante com cristais saindo dele. Mas eles n sabiam q aquilo era realmente um ET Bilu e acabam achando q aquilo é só uma decoração. Um pouco mais pra frente no jogo, o seu antigo chefe te da 1 proposta (Ver ele no tibunal - Pagar pelos direitos autorais de sua antiga série - Deixa-lo ser seu chefe novamente. Vc é obrigado a fazer uma escolha e isso ira intervir nos finais do jogo). Mais um pouco pra frente no jogo, um cara chamado Gaga (Ou Lorde Gaga, como preferir), te pergunta se vc quer uma máquina q aumenta audiencia a cada episódio (Vou explicar para q ele qeria a audiencia dps), mas vc n tem como recusar, vc é obrigado a aceitar. Ent vc luta contra uns cara e vai terminando o jogo. Mas chega um momento no game em q Gaga (Ou Lorde Gaga) se rebela contra vcs e vcs tem q tentar para-lo, mas vcs são apenas dubles e n conseguem nem toca-lo direito. Ent vc destroi a máquina que dava audiencia para Gaga para ele chamar seu exercito de ETs/Aliens. Ent Gaga sequestra todos os seus amigos e só resta um no time. Vc acaba lutando contra alguns caras até chegar na luta final. E APARTIR DAQUI EU N VO MAS FALAR NADA! ENT VC TERA Q COMPRAR O JOGO PARA SABER OQ ACONTECE! :^D (ou sla ve video e.e)


NOTA FINAL: 9.6/10
Esse jogo é incrivel, porém enjoativo. Mas ele tem seu charme. E essa foi a minha analise :^D

27455423.review:
Great game. I think it really helps if you're a fan of Super Sentai shows. Even a reasonable knowledge of Power Rangers will do. But even without that, I think what really shines through with this game is how self-referential a lot of the writing and humour is. Fake emails from viewers asking when the Kickstarter backers will get their copies, sidelong references to how similar all the enemies look, pokes at bad spell-checking of the narrator.

And the pop-culture references go beyond Power Rangers. If you look closely enough, there are littered references and parodies of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Teletubbies, Robocop - even The Devil's Advocate!

Behind all this is an extremely solid and varied strategy game. Chroma Squad comes in for a lot of criticism for being shallow - and I think this was my first impression, too. The first "season" of the game provides very limited flexibility and differences between characters and especially on normal difficulty it's easy to simply punch your way through most battles. But the action is driven by the Director's Instructions which push you to complete battle with a certain style and a certain way, which makes a difference to audience size, fans and of course studio income. Characters get an additional ability slot unlocked per-season, so by the third or fourth set of missions it's possible to really customise your squad's abilities and maximise your performance. 

Arguably the weakest element is the Kaiju fights, in which you take turns trading blows with a giant enemy. I personally like them and I think they're a really satisfying end to an episode, from a narrative point of view. BUT, if you choose upgrades which give you boosted attack and hit % then there really isn't much to do apart from gamble with the decreasing hit % and occasionally defend. However I recently went for a Mecha build which game me a choice of four special abilities to choose from and this gave me a lot of flexibility, expression and interest in these fights - but that route is optional, so the devs may want to consider what needs changing for these in - dare I wish!? - a sequel.

But it's definitely one of those games where I think "ahh, one more episode" and before I know it, it's two A.M. Really fun turn-based combat, great humour and stories and I love the low bit graphic style.

27370312.review:
Well,its chroma squad. And guess whos back to make crap reviews. LET'S A GO:

Postives:

Musics pretty good, although if your expecting instruments, look somewhere else. Its Bit-Music, but its very catchy regardless.

The gameplay is Similar to Fire Emblem and whatnot. You have a few skills to choose from, and you get 5 classes:Lead,Tech,Scout,Support,and Strength. You can choose who has what role, and each character has Boosts, and disadvantages to some fields. 

The story is similar to Power Rangers, execpt with a pretty decent twist at the end. Why would i say who it is? :3

Not many glitches atleast that i saw, so its polished.

Now for some Bads:

GOOD LUCK. This game is HARD sometimes, brutal even. Some bosses are just ridiculous with how hard they are,dare i say unfair. Although this usually isint the case,so thats good.

Tammy is broken to hell n back, trust me.

The crafting system is a little meh, its hard to get the materieals you need for some stuff. Once you play a stage its gone, so thats why its difficult to say good about this. However you can get boxes of the materieals you need, but thats random with whatcha get.

The games Mecha battles,while you have a Crutch, are still sometimes INSANE with unfairness. Go watch NicoB's lets play for example. But heres one from me:Multiple times, i have missed the second punch. Its a luck-based thing, where the higher the combo,the lesser the chance of it hitting. There is nothing like this outside Mecha,so dont worry.

The upgrades to your studio should be a One-time buy, and not allways cutting into your paycheck. I belive thats how it works, but i could be wrong,it wasent explained very well.

Overall,its a 4/5. (Its because theres 5 party members. Hahahah-Killmethatslame.)

Great game with only two notible flaws:
1) Normal mode is a bit too easy, and hard mode is a bit too hard. It was difficult to find a satifyling balance.
2) Crafting can be very annoying seeing as you aren't able to grind money and resources and the outcome is randomized. This means that, on hard mode where equipment is very important, you'll be stuck returning to title screen and reloading your save to re-craft weapons and armor until you get the stats you want. It can be very time consuming.
Despite these things, it is still very fun with equally fun writing.
Plus three endings, who doesn't love that?

26964499.review:
Epic Super Sentai Sendup!

This is a fun (if simple) SRPG with a story that's a hilarious parody of every live action superhero show.  The narrative unfolds just like the inner monologue that anyone of a certain age would have if their younger siblings watched Power Rangers.  It's spot on in terms of the humor, but it's also apparent that the creators enjoyed Power Rangers and their ilk.  There's enough strategy to keep things interesting, but it isn't so difficult as to turn of novices to the genre.  SRPG stalwarts will find the game to be pretty basic, but the storyline is entertaining enough for the game to be a solid recommendation for fans of SPRGs and Power Rangers alike.

Gráficos: 10   -> Estilo 8-bit
Som: 10 -> Músicas nostálgicas, encaixam bem com a proposta de resgatar os sentais das décas de 80 e 90.
Gameplay: 7 -> Meclando um gameplay de managemento do estúdio, RPG tático nas lutas dos sentais e as batalhas de robôs vs monstros usando um sistema de sorte. As batalhas dos sentais podiam ter uma maior complexidade, usando diferentes níveis de terreno invés do terreno sempre plano.
História: 9 -> A possibilidade de finais diferentes acrescenta muito, contudo alguns diálogos são clichês demais, até mesmo para a proposta de sentais.

As diferentes dificuldades, vários personagens, mais de um final, estes são fatores que vai levar você a repetir o jogo todo novamente. A Oficina podia gerar equipamentos mais úteis, na Loja sempre vão existir os melhores equipamentos.

26641538.review:
The game is very repetitive. It started becoming a chore after the 1st season.

The abilities are lackluster.

There are quite a few imbalances. For example:
-The hard mode is stupid difficult in the final mission in season 1 due to the lack of various base abilities. Perhaps it becomes a bit reasonable after season 1 but still..
-Normal mode is just way too easy. There is no middle ground.
-You can mainly obtain cash OR items for crafting as the game is setup to make it difficult to obtain both at a reasonable amount. This makes you miss content.

While the script is tongue on cheek, it starts getting boring, silly and predictable after season 1.

Basically this is a very dumbed down version of X-com tactical fighting. If you are between the ages of 5-80 yrs, I recommend trying X-com 1 or 2.

I understand it is an indie game but I just felt I'd save some players the time wasted here. There are way better games out there and X-com enemy unknown is pretty cheap atm.

You control the finance, the studio upgrades, the costumes, and everything in between, as well as participating in the actual fights. If you're a fan of turn based RPGs and the Power Rangers, this game is perfect for you. It took me 24 hours of gameplay to beat the whole game on the hardest difficulty, though I had to switch it to medium at the very end becasue the final fight was so brutal.

+Good Music
+ Nice animations
+ Customization
+ Wacky bosses
+ 3 difficulty levels, and the hardest one is actually challenging
+ 3 different endings
+ Good progression through the seasons. (There are 5)
+ Fun Story
+ Mech battles
+ Cute dialog

- Combat gets a little stale occasionally
- Mech battles are decided mainly on chance
- Not very many enemy types
- looking at the achievments spoiled the story

26591062.review:
In this game, you play as a team of stuntmen who play Power Rangers on television, and they've gotten fed up with their director and open their own studio doing the exact same thing instead. The plot is rather tongue-in-cheek and "dorky," but with a fun tone and some pleasant music along the way. The gameplay is a bit like the Shadowrun turn-based strategy games on PC if those were all about melee combat instead of ranged. You might say "oh, like Banner Saga?" but I would reply "No, this is actually kinda enjoyable, so it's not that much like Banner Saga." As with Shadowrun, you have abilities with cooldowns that give you a nice edge in combat, and the further into the game you get, the game shows you that there are higher tiers of skills to unlock, making things more interesting than just "run over and punch a dude" each turn.

The game has three difficulty levels: one intended to just get through the game without challenge, one to get through it with a little challenge, and a tough version. I played the middle of these three options and found it to be a nice experience that does a good job of teaching you the basics. In between missions ("episodes"), you can buy new equipment for your team, as well as upgrade your studio to incur running costs that give you bonus attitbutes on missions (worth it, from what I experienced).

I personally lack the interest in the narrative and the gameplay hasn't fully hooked me in enough for me to want to really continue, but this game has the rare condition of being one I'm stopping playing that I would actually recommend. I could totally see myself playing it through to completion and liking it if I had more time to spend on games that don't pull me in strong. It commits no grave offenses against the player, seems well-balanced, has a lot of heart, and seems fully intended to be a fun and different experience for gamers. If turn-based strategy, goofy/dorky plot, and/or Power Rangers put a smile on your face, this could be a good buy for you, especially on sale or Humble Bundle.

26517849.review:
Décevant.

Un tactical RPG très moyen, pollué par son interface. En combat c'est assez mou et sans enjeu, malgré les quelques bonnes idées de mécanique (la chromatisation, les objectifs du réal'...) qui ajoutent un intérêt. En dehors des combats, l'interface de gestion des upgrades et du crafting est elle insupportable. C'est moche - le pixel art n'excuse pas tout - et c'est surtout très mal fichu: allers-retours entre des menus pas clairs, visibilité limitée sur les armes et armures équipées. Ce n'est pas mauvais, c'est parfois rigolo à jouer, mais je n'ai pas plus de temps à y consacrer.

Par ailleurs, une chose avant tout me fait abandonner: la narration. Narration qui prend un côté lourdingue à force d'insister sur l'aspect meta du jeu, qui partait pourtant d'une idée excellente à laquelle j'adhérais à 100%. Les dialogues sont inintéressants, les blagues tombent à l'eau, et dans le pire des cas on a droit à de petits coups de pied au tibia pour nous dire "hé hé hé regardez on est trop intelligents, regardez les références qu'on arrive à placer!". Les emails, parce que courts, sont en revanche un petit plus au tableau. J'ai aussi été très déçu par l'histoire, qui au lieu de nous laisser nous amuser à gérer ce petit studio de sentai, suit une trame linéaire qui s'embarque dans des intrigues metas WTF, qui auraient peut-être été utiles si elles avaient réussi à être drôle.

J'aime les jeux drôles et parodiques, quand ils sont réussis et proposent aussi des mécaniques de gameplay captivantes. Ce n'est pas le cas de Chroma Squad. J'ai le sentiment de bien comprendre ce qu'il tente de faire, sans adhérer du tout au résultat final.

26510094.review:
Chroma squad is power rangers meets Xcom with pixle art. Yes it is as good as that sounds to the ten year old inside you thats been bludgoned to near death by the cynical you of today.

The plot of the game is simple. Five stuntmen quit their job at a sentai tv series studio and decide to make their own. From there, the plot thickens in the same way watery milk turns into tasty cheese. In other words, the plot starts out weak, but gets stronger the further on you go, just don't expect anything other than pure cheesy sentai goodness.

The game is split into two parts, base management and combat. The base is your studio, from here you can buy new gear for your heros, craft new stuff for them, build new parts for your mecha, view your heros and change their equipment and abilities, upgrade the studio, check emails, and lastly, hire a sponsor. Upgrading your studio gives benefits in and out of combat, from HP boosts, to shop discounts. None of the upgrades are Game changing, but they are all useful. The sponsor however does change things up. Each sponsor can be hired, and you can only have one at a time. Each one offers various benefits, with additional benefits being added on top of those by spending fans (i can only assume its their tolerance your expending). These can have positives and negatives. for example, one of them will cost you alot of money each episode, but give you a big conversion boost. Overall, you want to check what kinds of episodes you'll be shooting during the season before you hire them on. The emails are also worth checking, as you make choices in them that can effect the game. some of them provide no options, others allow you to possibly change the plot or gain more fans and items.

Combat is square grid tactical turn based. during your turn you can move and do one of four things with each individual hero. Attack, weapon attack, activate an ability, or engage teamwork mode. Each hero has an entirely different skill set and should be used appropriately. For example, the techie is good at long range combat and a solid support, while the lead is the guy you use to set up team moves. Each ability has a certain amount of cool down time, that can be decreased by using specific bits of equipment. Weapon attack is exactly what it says on the tin, your hero attacks with the weapon they have equipped instead of their fists. Certain weapons can only be used by certain cheracters, and once used they go on cool down. The ability to use teamwork abilities is what makes this game different from others. When you set a character into teamwork mode, their turn ends, but you can still move your other heros around. You can do three things with two team members when one of them is in teamwork mode. Joint attacks, acrobatics and joint weapon attacks. attacking an enemy that is next to hero in teamwork mode causes both of you to attack at once, causing a greater amount of damage. Weapon attacks do the same thing, but both characters must have their weapons off cool down in order to pull off. Acrobatics are a little different. Each character can only move a certain amount (unless you equip them with gear that increases the distance), but, they can extend the distance by being thrown, allowing them to reach beyond their movement. They do this by walking over to a hero in team mode and then getting thrown higher than a crack addict on a spring board.

The combat is simple at first, but after each season it gets more and more complex, adding on new abilities, new gear and new options at the base. This prevents it from getting stale, always adding in something fresh. 

Visually the game isn't all that impressive, certain areas are reused several times, the sprites aren't extremely detailed and you can really see each pixle. But, the number of different sprites there are for the heros is impressive, as it changes with each helmet you wear and each outfit you put on. There are in total about five basic enemy types, two of which get three different sprites. However, the game has alot of bosses, each one is rather different and challenging, save for a few who were rather lacking. The final bosses are really challenging and require you to really plan out your moves, they don't feel unfair though, more like a reward for getting that far, given how much fun they are to fight. The music of the game is limited to a few tracks, none of which are particularly memorable, but they aren't bad by any means and serve their purpose well enough.

The game does allow you to change the names of your characters, your studio, your mecha and pretty much everything else that your in game studio owns. Nothing felt better than seeing my dudes yell "taste the rainbow motherfucker!" before shooting a guy with a traffic cone on his head with a laser powered by crappy special effects and friendship. 

That little moment sums up the game, its charming, and it allows you to add your own spin on it to an extent. Its obvious this game came from a place of love and it really does shine despite its flaws, the few complaints i have with it don't outweigh the number of good qualities this title has and i would recommend anyone who loved, or loves power rangers get this. Anyone who likes Xcom, but wants an easier experience, this is for you. Hell, if you like turn based rpgs, this is worth checking out.

26498284.review:
Chroma Squad is an amusing romp through sentia silliness - a bunch of sentia (re: a show in the vein of the Power Rangers) actors, fed up with their poor treatment, set up their own studio and follow their dreams...with a tongue firmly in cheek the entire way. And Then Things Get Weird. The game itself plays out through 5 "seasons," each containing 6 episodes - an opener, a closer, and 4 stages that can be done in any order. Each episode consists of one or more turn-based scenarios with several optional conditions - for example, your goal in a stage might be beating the boss, but you get a bonus if a particular character hits them every turn. People familiar with the Disgeae series will be pretty comfortable here. Outside of battles, you spend the income you earned thanks to your legions of adoring fans to buy upgrades for your studio, actors/costumes, and the mech suit, hire advertisers, and respond to fanmail. 

The controls are nice and solid, though you will be occassionally frustrated that a throw doesn't pan out the way you want (the rules for when one person can assist another by catapulting them across the field aren't clear, though they are consistent). There are also a few occassions when there is a mechanic that isn't well explained - for example, during a giant mech/monster fight, your audience can save you if you run out of life - but nothing mentions this effect. 

The graphics are fun and clear, with a pleasantly pixelated presentation, and while the results aren't exactly spectacular, they are very firmly in line with the source material.

The music and sound effects are pleasant if not particularly memorable.

The story is interesting, if incredibly silly, and not terribly written (or, rather, it's terribly written in the way sentia series are, so, good/bad writing). 

There is some replay value - there is clearly a fair number of alternative routes to take, for example, and multiple levels of difficulty. I will certainly play through at least twice more.

TLDR: 8/10 light fun turn based strategy with a solid sense of humor and a nice degree of self-awareness. It isn't trying to be an epic blockbuster AAA, and it certainly doesn't need to be. Some of the elements are a little iffy, but nothing is "badly done," and, if you like the source material, there are a fair number of places and nods to keep you amused.

26468109.review: Third game in the series (after Knights of Pen and Paper and KoPaP2) is definitely an improvement. Nonetheless, the pacing feels slow, the character customization limited, and upon succeeding I rarely felt like I'd been particularly clever, but more that I had exploited poor AI and strange mechanics. The attempt at a humorous plot line is also incredibly painful -- as much as I wanted to like it, the writing is abysmal. That said, there are some well-done elements. Acquiring points by piling on certain mechanics (rather than by being brutally efficient in dispatching enemies) to unlock power-ups lead to some of the more interesting tactical decisions, and the crafting system occasionally presented a tough choice. In another couple games, this dev team could be the talk of indie gaming, but not yet.

26464803.review:
CHROMA SQUAD - EXCELENTE - 10/10

1 - Definição do Jogo:

O jogo simula  o ambiente da industria de série de tv no estilo "power rangers". Aqui você vai ter que se preocupar com os inimigos ao mesmo tempo que administra o dinheiro para upgrades e custos e busca agradar a audiência dos episódios para conseguir mais fãs.

2 - Gráfico e modo de jogo:
O gráfico é retro, ficou muito bom. O estilo do jogo é rpg tático, semelhante ao Dofus.

3 - Resumo do que você vai encontrar o jogo:

Pode criar sua própria equipe de heróis, com habilidades diferentes.

Customize o nome da equipe, grito de guerra, cores, nome do estúdio

Uma loja  para comprar items e um sistema de Craft elaborado para criar novos equipamentos. Os recursos para craft podem ser encontrados nas fases ou comprados em pacotes sortidos na loja. 

Uma variedade de inimigos e fases.

Várias referências , humor e diversão

Responda emails, contrate uma agência de divulgação para melhorar o programa

Lutas de robô gigante ! YEAH !

4 - Dicas:

Faça as missões indicadas para ter mais audiência, dinheiro e fãs.

A cada temporada seus heróis descobrem uma nova habilidade, use elas sabiamente.

Busque uma agência de divulgação compatível com a sua quantidade de fãs, assim você aproveitará 100% da agência.

Faça upgrades no robô, ele é importante  e fundamental para zerar o jogo

PENSE ! Não saia batendo aleatoriamente.

5 - Opinião.

Eu já conhecia  o jogo e consegui agora pelo Humble Bundle. O jogo é be divertido, me identifiquei muito com os meus heróis. Inclusive eu gritava EAGLE LASSO (habilidade que laça o inimigo e puxa pra perto) junto com meu ranger branco.
É um dos poucos jogos que eu jogaria novamente :)

Recomendo que você compre, se tiver desconto fica melhor ainda :)

26458674.review:
It's an easy to pick up tactical RPG inspired by super sentai themed shows (aka Power Rangers, if you're in the USA). The premise is light-hearted and often lends itself to some enjoyable comedy. The balance between RPG and TV studio management at first might seem like a chore, but growing both sides turned out to be enjoyable for me. Struggling to get a leg up and gradually improving your team's costumes to get more fans to get more stuff for your studio/cast is a rewarding cycle of endeavors. I hadn't even heard of this game until I got it in a Humble Bundle with some other things I wanted. I am not disappointed so far!
One thing I didn't like was that the mech battles seem to be driven by RNG in the worst possible way. 75% chance to hit = you will miss 90% of the time. Just a heads up.
update: if absolutely awful final bosses are a pet peeve of yours, you should avoid this game. 99% of it is *sooo* good. And then the final boss is a teleporting enemy with the worst arena layout. Get close to attack, he teleports and then it takes your squad like 4 turns to reach him. 2 hits, then he teleports across the arena again. Instead of being strategic, it's just unnecessarily drawn out and boring. The game still gets a positive rec from me, but I don't know what the devs were thinking when they made the finale.

26441786.review:
Aunque desde la pantalla de título dice que es un juego de rol táctico, «Chroma Squad» comienza de forma engañosa, haciéndote sentir más bien en un juego de gestión. Y esa es la parte más divertida que ofrece. Cuando tienes que personalizar tu equipo, nombrarlos, elegir sus colores y las frases que dirán en combate al llamar al robot gigante o atestar el golpe especial. Todo tiene un aire de gracia e ingenuidad muy encantador.

Pero como decíamos, el juego mismo te avisa que no va de eso. Y de lo que va, pues no es tan bueno. «Rol táctico». Pero de táctico nada, el juego tiene opciones, armas, equipo y demás, pero no sirven de nada porque el juego no presenta, al menos en la dificultad normal, reto alguno que requiera estrategia, y el combate de tablero no explota siquiera elementos básicos del género como cambiar el ataque dependiendo del lado por el que uno ataque. Y de rol también nada. Los personajes tiene personalidades determinadas, uno no decide el devenir de nada, salvo el orden de los episodios, unos pocos correos con una opción u otra, todos sin consecuencias.

Más allá de eso, «Chroma Squad» tiene una narrativa rara, de querer ser más inteligentes u originales de lo que por su propio bien hacía falta. La trama va tornando de una simulación a una batalla real, pero sigue filmándose como si de episodios se tratara, y lo justifica de formas muy pobres, sin saber cómo salir de un problema que no hacía falta ni que existiera. Los personajes no tienen nombre mas allá del seudónimo del héroe que caracterizan, durante los episodios no hay guión, sino que hablan del propio episodio, poniéndose más meta de lo sinceramente necesario.

Sus primeras horas son excelentes y se va desinflando por no saber identificar y explotar lo mejor que puede ofrecer. No deja de ser, no obstante, un juego diferente hecho con amor y clara admiración al género que le inspira. Vale la pena.

26433867.review:
A tactics game where you play as a Power Rangers TV studio. Game is split up into episodes (where you do battle) and in between episodes you spend your cash/craft upgrades. It has a silly story with silly enemies and plot. Story is mostly told through dialogue so doesn't get very deep. A lot of 'just because' reasoning so you have to go with the flow. Things that happen outside dialogue are often just quickly summed up by the narrator to set the scene. Graphics are good enough and sound fits well.

Episodes are often split up into 1-3 tactics battle segments and sometimes finished off with a mecha battle. The tactics system is pretty standard and simple. There are only damage and status effects, no damage types (no physical vs magic attack, no elemental resistance/weakness). The mecha battle is a regular RPG slugfest where you take turns attacking each other. You can do multiple actions in your turn and each action builds up your combo meter (which increases the effect of your next action but decreases the accuracy). In normal mode, the enemy mecha usually just does 3 regular attacks one special attack. You reduce damage taken through a timing minigame (there's a bar that fills up, stop it at the right time and you block more damage).

It feels like you want mecha battles to be over as soon as possible so it feels better to go for as many 50%+ accuracy attacks as you can rather than ever defending. It seems like enemies usually do 3 attacks of ~5k damage each and defending (maybe unless you go for max defense) only blocks a total of ~5k of that. It feels like a race against the clock so the less turns you take to defeat the mecha, the less turns the enemy has to deal 15k+ damage.

However, it does get a little frustrating when you miss your 2nd attack (~85% accuracy) twice in a row, which is brutal because of your missed damage output (especially if you're holding onto your finisher for a high combo) and it means you take free rounds of damage. But I guess that's why there's the mecha audience meter (DBZ spirit bomb-esque gathering the energy of your fans). When you lose all hp in a mecha fight, your hp meter refills with audience points (though losing hp from then on doesn't seem to affect audience score later). Assumably, the more fans you have the more HP you get.

In tactics battles, your performance is calculated by an audience meter which goes up through combat actions and by following the episode's director's instructions (which are bonus objectives like 'win in 5 turns' or 'keep all members above 50% health). In normal difficulty, clearing missions wasn't too hard but clearing them while following the director's instructions was sometimes pretty challenging. However, you don't need to do every instruction to max out your audience meter and it doesn't seem like failing them matters if you fill the meter anyway.

Boss enemies sometimes have line attacks but they feel unpredictable. The attacks don't hit a standard grid-based area (not clean 45 degree directions) so it's more realistic but you can't tell what it'll hit. One boss has a burst aoe (starting from himself) that usually hits allies hidden behind other allies but there were rare times where it didn't (only the one in front got hit). Sometimes the cubes served as cover, sometimes his attack hit despite the cube being in the way. Maybe there is no such thing as cover and it just randomly misses without showing the 'miss' text. He burst twice in the same spot on one turn and hit 2 on the first and all 5 on the second.

The only real indicator I could see of how much damage you'd do is the enemy health bar (which shows how much remaining hp would be left after the attack). It can be a little tough to see if an attack really finishes it off or if there's a pixel left. It would've been nice to see an obvious indicator (like the bar turning gray) to show the attack should finish off the opponent.

Alternatively, you could check your attack stat for how much damage you'd do (only for single attacks; I'm not sure how teamwork attacks affect damage).

Seems to let you retry missions relatively easily (via abandon mission) so if you like to retry there's no need to quit/restart the game. If you don't, then you can personally choose to make your own hardcore mode by accepting whatever result you get. It's pretty nice for me because you go into episodes without knowing what you're really up against so you can abandon and customize/upgrade as necessary so you can beat the mission. Also, some director's instructions (mission goals) can be ruined by unfortunate events outside your control.

It allows you to fast forward through cutscenes which is very nice. However, it sometimes speeds through the first text bubble even when I didn't intentionally click or skip through. It may have captured a click several seconds before during a cutscene or something. It would be nice to also have animation speed options in settings to make quicken actions and be able to fast forward in-battle quips.

[Side note: why is 'go' and 'fas' blocked by steam? Wanted to type 'go' and 'faster']

Other thoughts:
[list]
[*] One tactic is to pull back and give a turn to let the enemies chase you, often clumping together for aoe skills.
[*] Audience bonuses from marketing may not count towards the audience meter cap (meaning if you max out the meter it still counts as a bonus towards the cash/fan conversion). Would be nice to have that cleared up in-game.
[*] Mostly polished but there are some quirks. Dialogue bubble gets cut off in one sewer scene, breath->breathe typo.
[*] Seems like some e-mails don't deduct the right amount of cash? I know some options say they'll cost a certain amount but are reduced but those mention it in the reply.
[*] At hotdog stand battle, it feels like there's a minion that comes in on the left side that doesn't get placed on the map?
[*] When you have a flat +fan modifier at end of battle, it still shows as per 100 in the tooltip (you have +175 fans per episode but it shows as 175 fan conversion per 100 audience)
[*] Seems like you're supposed to lose audience when a party member is downed but it either doesn't work properly (audience bar visually is reduced but actual number isn't) or there's a hidden buffer you get by overfilling the audience meter.
[*] Seems like [spoiler]Tammy[/spoiler] is supposed to get into the mecha (and sometimes she teleports with the rest) but they didn't make a new cockpit image, still only 5 people.
[*] Although normally fine, sometimes I had a little visual lag/frame skips when blocking in a mecha fight, making it hard to time blocks properly.
[/list]

Worth a try if you like the theme (a studio making episodes of Power Rangers) and are fine with simple tactics games. I don't think I would like it as much if it were a generic tactics game (the combat system isn't very deep) but I think they play up to the theme very well. Reminds me of Punch Club (silly story, good-enough game) though I think I enjoyed this experience more.

26426672.review:
Chroma Squad is a turn-based, tactics RPG from Behold Studios. Let’s get rocking.

The Good

The Power Rangers were a huge part of my childhood. I’m not talking about the newer, crappier Power Ranger series’, I’m talking about the original that started in 93. The Red Ranger was on of my idols as a child. Chroma Squad has all the same Power Rangers vibes in all the right ways.

The story is not what I expected it to be. While I was ready to dive headfirst into a tactical, turn-based Power Rnagers styled game, I was surprised to find that I was diving into a tactical, turn-based you’re playing as stuntmen filming a Power Rangers styled show game. Total curve ball. That’s what I get for not watching the trailer beforehand. I’m still trying to figure out how I missed it.

Gameplay is simple, but not too simple. There’s the right amount of everything for you to take into consideration while you’re in the heat of battle.

The music is great and the dialog is actually pretty funny.

The Bad

I’ve got nothing here. Move along, please.

The Meh

It’s not actually the Power Rangers.

Verdict: Yea

Is this a game you should get? If you like turn-based tactical games, then yes. If you watched Power Rangers at any point in your life and enjoyed it, then very yes. If you can get it on sale, even better.

I love what the game is trying to do, but I feel that it fails. 

The combat is very shallow for a turn-based RPG and too much of it comes down to random chance (particularly the mech scenes). It varies between frustratingly easy and frustratingly difficult, and never really feels like a rewarding challenge.

The writing would be a lot funnier if they didn't call attention to every single joke and reference that they make (Seriously, they throw in a "see what we did there?" at least once per cutscene, and it feels like a laugh track.) 

And for a game that is supposedly about running a studio, it really doesn't do anything original with its combat. I think it would have been a lot more interesting if we could choose the extras for them to fight and increase the challenge level on our own, and get more audience points for having a dramatic battle. 
Instead we're only rewarded for winning the fight, and that's no different from every other tactics RPG in existence.

Wow, all I can say is "Wow!!"

This game appeals to the part of me that remembers almost missing the bus often in 2nd grade trying to stay inside to watch as much Power Rangers as I could.

It's a bright, more simple version of games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Ogre Tactics, etc.  You play as stun actors who after dealing with an insulting, arrogant director realize they have the passion and talent to make their own show instead of being doing the hard stunt work and letting actors soak up the screen the rest of the time.

From there, you manage your own studio, making decisions about fan interaction, marketing, managing crafting materials (used for building your own costume parts as well as eventually creating your mecha suit, yeah, it's as awesome as it sounds)

The game's story is clever anc cute and as of Season 3, seems to be building to more of an interesting story than I would have ever expected from what was seemingly a simple game (sure, it's got the basic tropes you've seen before, but they're done right and they provide a context that serves it's purpose and frames the fighting well)

I get it. I get why the reviews are so good: great game, great exectution, interesting concept that appeals to something that was likely a part of many of our childhood's.

Grab it.  I got it free from a good buddy who had an extra key from a bundle, but had I known what a true gem this is I'd have bought it up already.

Seriously, get it, get it, get it, get it.  Manage your studio, prepare your mecha, and CHROMATIZE MOTHAFUCKAS!!!!

26333038.review:
[h1]Basic Information[/h1]
[b]Title:[/b]  Chroma Squad
[b]Developers:[/b]  Behold Studios
[b]Publisher:[/b]  Behold Studios
[b]Genre:[/b]  SRPG/Economic hybrid

[h1]General Impression[/h1]
Perhaps I’m just nostalgic about those simple and happy times I used to watch the Power Rangers on TV as kid. For me, Chroma Squad really shed a new light on what a modern pixelated video game can achieve. The title I’m reviewing today is a far cry from your run-of-the-mill 2D Simulation Role Playing Game (SRPG, for short) since it incorporates a well planned economic component to it. You have to supervise  a team of stunt actors looking to promote their own studio and projects. And that is no easy task, given how cutthroat the show business is in general terms. You control everything from the production of the shows and even the advertising and human resources department of your firm. It’s not just a faux Power Ranger simulator in which combat takes center stage. 

You need to carefully manage your total funds and some compromises shall be made when hiring actors or sacking older ones which contrary to their skill sets, lack any appeal towards the audience. And you will certainly have to entertain your public. That is where the core tactical side of the game, comes alive. You have a surprisingly complex turn-based battle system that relies on literal teamwork between the squadmates you control, since boss fights are never easy. This really is a rare case of a title that can be used to demonstrate independent creativeness and show the gaming industry that you don’t require an overinflated budget in order to create a fun and captivating game.

[h1]Strong Points[/h1]
+ Beautiful pixel graphics and equally pleasant soundtrack.
+ Clever use of pop culture references and humor.
+ Unique type of gameplay.
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.

[h1]Weak Points[/h1]
- Some elements get repetitive over time.

[b]Rating 9/10[/b]
 
[quote]This review was submitted for [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews]Imperial Reviews[/url] and [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Cubbes]Cubbes[/url].[/quote]

26327175.review:
An overhyped mess. It rides on the nostalgia train but crashes ingloriously when it comes to gameplay.
This is written after haven finished the highest difficulty.

In essence it consists of 4 core elements: Tactical RPG, economy / money management, crafting, and bugs.
-On the tactics side we have a squad of 5 actors / heroes fighting enemies in turn based combad on a planar field. During the first few levels it works perfectly. You have your classes like assault, support and scout who each do different things. But the more you play the more a mess it becomes. Suddenly everyone has heals, buffs, damage, etc. It lacks imagination. This is even more emphasized when it comes to enemies. You have to face melee, ranged, healers and coloured variations with more hp / damage. Even the bosses play the same way (almost) every level. They each mainly use the same attacks / abilities. It makes for a very tedious gameplay experience all the way to the end.

-Economy. The better you do the more money you get. That's the premise. It falls apart very early in the game when it becomes clear that it's almost impossible to miss the mark. Probably due to the very easy difficulty even on the highest setting. Same with director instructions during missions. Basically sidequests that make you do something. Mostly it doesn't even affect the gameplay and furthermore the boost they give becomes negligible the further you progress.

-Crafting is a big part of the game. The more this hurts. It is horrible and completely missed the point of crafting.
You get materials from slain enemies or you can buy random packs in the shop. So good so far. But crafting is a lottery. You pick your base and it adds random properties. That's not crafting, it's lottery. When you want a defined outcome. That's crafting. It makes sense very early in the game pretending that your actors are improvising. But when you suddenly deal with high tech components the immersion falls apart. It doesn't hel either that most of the game the shop sold items are just far superior and don't have you hurt yourself through the atrocious interface.

-Bugs. This one is really dissapointing. We are talking on an Ubisoft level of bugginess. Nothing so far has been gamebreaking, but considering this whole thing rides on tropes and the passion for the genre one would think the devs would put more effort into this. Originally I would list the bugs here, but I simply lost track of them and at one point didn't bother to write them down. From economy, to battle, loot drops. Hell, even the basic text bubbles have a minor word wrap bug. It really becomes a joke when you realise there is a permanent bug report button on the top right.


This is a very sad case. I really tried to like this game, it's not bad, but it is below mediocre. It became painfully obvious during the game that all they cared about was the athmosphere and design. They got that perfectly and then stopped doing anything else. Don't get me wrong, most of the things I mentioned are very minor, but they are so numerous you wouldn't believe the devs actually played their own game (and those peeves are not even all).
For the price tag of 15€ I cannot recommend this game. Too short, lackluster gameplay. Even fans of the genre are better of just buying a DVD of their favourite series.

26326140.review:
S'il était sorti en boîte il y a une quinzaine d'années sur Playstation 2, Chroma Squad aurait été un jeu adulé des gens qui alors s'autoproclamaient [i]de bon goût[/i], l'os préféré d'une niche, balancé comme un missile dans tes gencives au milieu d'une liste de tirets prouvant que le jeu vidéo mérite d'être joué sur ma console et pas sur la tienne. [i]Tu vois, il n'y a pas que Disgaea et Phantom Brave sur ma bécane.[/i]

Coloré et idiot, Chroma Squad détourne les codes du jeu de rôle à la japonaise dans le but de nous amuser de sa loufoquerie plus que de nous passionner de son gameplay. Son game design simpliste, bourré de petites idées sans conséquences mais assez nombreuses pour nous donner l'illusion que ce squelette a du corps, a juste ce qu'il faut de muscles pour porter l'enthousiasme du joueur pendant les dix à quinze heures de jeu que nous coûteront son aventure. S'il avait été plus long, on aurait pu s'en rendre compte et s'en ennuyer. Mais les meilleurs des mensonges sont ceux qui savent quand s'arrêter.

Il faut dire que dans Chroma Squad, tout est fake, jusqu'aux affrontements qui ne sont que des chorégraphies de cascadeurs. On s'y affronte pour de faux, sans rien prendre au sérieux, le sourire toujours aux lèvres, pas vraiment désolé d'avoir frappé un peu trop fort le pauvre bougre dans le costume d'en face. On s'amuse beaucoup de l'originalité de son concept (on incarne une bande d'acteurs ratés qui ont décidé de prendre en main leur avenir et de monter leur propre show télévisé inspiré des Power Rangers et autres Bioman) qui a des conséquences directes sur le système de jeu : un peu comme dans La Porte Millénaire mais en beaucoup moins bien (TOUT sur cette Terre est beaucoup moins bien que La Porte Millénaire), il faudra combattre avec la manière pour gagner le coeur des spectateurs ; on se bat pour séduire le public plus que pour vaincre son ennemi. Les cascades, les attaques spéciales et les combos à plusieurs sur le même vilain-pas-beau seront récompensés par des bonds d'audimat. Il faudra aussi se soumettre aux exigences du réalisateur (sous formes d'objectifs annexes) pour optimiser l'impact visuel de nos combats et faire grimper en flèche la popularité de la série.

Chroma Squad a un autre atout dans sa besace : son rythme. Il est rare que les scènes de bagarre durent plus de vingt minutes - aussi, on les commence souvent en denim jean et en t-shirt, ne se battant qu'avec de simples coups de poings et de pieds comme des civils émeutiers ou des zadistes en colère. Il faudra attendre un ou deux tours pour se transformer en guerriers sentai, marquant ainsi une rupture et une progression dans le combat, en régénérant nos points de vie et débloquant les armes et les attaques spéciales de nos personnages. Les scènes de Mechas qui viennent conclure les affrontements dans la démesure la plus carton-pâte, pas super intéressantes à jouer, ont le mérite de renforcer cette sensation de progression et de variété des combats, pas très riches tactiquement mais, du coup, jamais lassants.

Pour s'aérer l'esprit, ces batailles sont toujours prises en sandwich entre deux dialogues, jamais très bavards - et c'est tant mieux car au-delà de son aspect parodique, le jeu n'a rien d'intéressant à raconter. Après et avant chaque épisode, on retourne au studio d'enregistrement, le camp de base depuis lequel on s'achète de nouveaux jouets. On s'en servira plus tard comme d'armes et d'armures, aussi on s'adonne aux joies du crafting pour en fabriquer d'autres, répond au courrier des fans, change les costumes et les coups spéciaux de nos acteurs chéris, enfin on gère le marketing de la série en se satisfaisant de voir grossir notre fanbase. Débloquer et acheter des améliorations pour addicter le joueur est une astuce vieille comme le monde mais toujours aussi efficace - et totalement justifiée dans le cadre de la montée en puissance d'une série télévisée tenue par un petit groupe de jeunes adultes qui démarrent la vie sans-le-sou jusqu'à la conquête d'Hollywood.

Entre ses costumes sentai, son style graphique fluo et ses attaques spéciales en étoile, Chroma Squad a une petite odeur de Super Mario RPG métissé avec Viewtiful Joe. Sans jamais vraiment atteindre le génie ni de l'un, ni de l'autre : si son gameplay a su maquiller ses défauts aussi efficacement que cette jolie fille qui cache ses volcans de pus derrière des tartines de fond de teint, Chroma Squad a du mal à nous faire oublier qu'il est un jeu un peu vain qui n'a rien à dire. C'est un copain attachant mais léger qui n'a que des blagues pas toujours géniales qui lui sortent de la bouche. Maladroit quand il essaie d'être l'allégorie de l'indépendance dans le jeu vidéo, il est carrément lourdaud quand il passe le plus clair de son temps à s'auto-référencer en tant que jeu Kickstarter. S'il est marrant de briser le quatrième mur et de voir un jeu dire "je suis un jeu" une ou deux fois, on commence à saturer à partir de la dixième occurrence. Aussi, les backers les plus riches seront sûrement très heureux d'être incrustés dans l'histoire d'une façon si appuyée. Pour ma part, j'ai juste émergé de l'aventure à chaque fois qu'un nouveau guest à la peau blanche albinos, au bidon rond et aux lunettes énormes apparaissait de nulle part en me récitant son nom. Ces [i]invités[/i] sont non seulement trop nombreux mais aussi, comme il n'y a pas de quêtes annexes dans lesquelles ils pourraient vivre, envahissent la trame principale. Si bien qu'on retrouve en moyenne un mécène toutes les deux ou trois missions.

A trop s'auto-référencer et se féliciter d'être passé par le crowdfunding, Chroma Squad donne parfois l'impression d'être plus une blague entre potes qu'une oeuvre autonome. Rien d'assez gênant pour nous gâcher ce très bon tactical RPG drôle, coloré, assez malin pour en avoir l'air sans l'être. Une excellente façon d'user sa souris ou sa manette. Il est juste dommage qu'un jeu si sympathique, passé l'adolescence de son développement, ait oublié d'être autonome une fois venue l'heure de l'âge adulte et de la release. Chroma Squad, avec des dialogues qui ont parfois l'allure d'une newsletter pour backers, a juste oublié d'apprendre à marcher tout seul et à exister par lui-même loin de son nid.

26325837.review:
As a tokusatsu fan, Chroma Squad is amazing. 
I was worried that, much like many other Power Rangers inspired media, this game would be ashamed of it's roots. Making fun of the source with a "look how stupid this is" attitude.
That is certainly not the case. Chroma Squad is very self aware, but is a celebration of the genre! It's light hearted, tongue-in-cheek humour, and most importantly: fun.

The gameplay may be basic when compared to other tactics based RPGs however the dressing (for lack of a better word) more than makes it up. Perhaps I am biased, but the idea of running my own Sentai production company, with control over the costumes and props, and studio, and marketing etc. coupled with the absolutely charm of the writing... I can't describe how happy it made me.

I feel exteremely bad for waiting this long to pick up this game, and through a humble bundle no less. The developers of this game deserve full compensation for doing such a magnificent job.

I don't think you NEED to be a tokusatsu fan to enjoy this game. The writing makes it very accessible. But if you are a fan, or have knowledge of the subject, there are a ton of little nods and easter eggs to be found.

I'm going to recommend it, with a few caveats.  Keep in mind that the game mostly gets by on charm and style.  As a tactics game, it doesn't do any of the things I'd like it to.  

My favorite Tactics games, like Final Fantasy Tactics and Tactics Ogre, let you recruit a handful of named characters with personalities.  Other games, like XCOM, let you fully recruit and customize your own squad.  Chroma Squad does neither, you can choose 5 from about 15 different characters at the very beginning of the game, and they're all interchangeable with no discernable personality.

So without interesting characters the gameplay has to be compelling (like XCOM) but it's pretty simplistic and does a poor job of explaining itself.  That being said, you get to make your own Sentai team.  So, you know.  That goes a long way.
