26236998.review:
It's been a while since I last properly sat down and played an SRPG, and I was honestly weary to a degree with the whole Super Sentai's Powers Rangers theme Chroma Squad employed. Needless to say fact I beat it in under three days after I actually began playing should tell you I was way off that mark.

You create and assume the roles of your five-strong Super Sentai group, process which is done through choosing which character will assume each role (Lead, Assist, etc) and there are quite a few cameos ranging from actors to pop icons you may recognize. I had fun naming my totally-not-Weasley-Snipes “Eyes-Open”, but that's beside the point. After that's done and over with you find out they're disgruntled stunt actors on a related show who decide to create a new studio and show of their own. These are the humble beginnings game presents you with and it's customizable down to Ranger colors, studio name catchphrases team will employ. Far be it for me to say that's ALL there is to this story, and oh boy does it escalate, but it never loses that sense of “we're running a show here” which is further enforced by character's comments, episode setups and constant camera crews on the set. 

This illusion is never broken because no matter what happens you're still making a show which nets you fans and money. Both are important for keeping your studio successful because it lets you craft gear from materials your enemies drop; things like tape, cardboard and glass, or straight up buy new stuff from the store. You will also want to invest in your studio for things like HD cameras which net you more audience per-episode, better health insurance for HP bonus, etc. It's definitely sensible and tongue-in-cheek with the mood of the game. As befitting a Super Sentai team you will also acquire a wise MENTOR and Mecha at your disposal, latter which also gets its own separate upgrades and is used in 1v1 fights against giant opponents. 

As far as actual meat of the game goes, that being combat, you'll quickly discover your team of five is constantly outnumbered usually 3-to1 if you're lucky and keeping your gear up snuff is a good idea. As each of the five seasons go by your characters unlock another tier of skills you can choose form so you're not just brute-forcing it. In fact, I'd argue game is somewhat on the easy side unless you really want to do all of Director's Instructions aka specific set of objectives in each episode which may be on the tricky side but are also a great way to get more audience, except in the very last part when that difficulty spike becomes too real. It does make for a fitting conclusion, but also drags down what should've been a way more intense end game. I will say that send off itself is amazing and no game that plays the theme track can do wrong by me in that regard. It turns out your show is pretty radical and watched worldwide. 

If there are any negatives they are very few, mostly on the side of some Unity engine shenanigans like some scripts not being timed correctly which leads to some delays, hang ups when game has to display things like a ton of audience bonus gained from healing and alike, but I would probably point out overused Mecha fights in the last episode or so as the worst offender for me. You don't have to end each episode like that and especially not because you'll notice hit percentage is still RNG-driven so it'll eventually turn on you. I also wish game was longer, but you can also have too much of the good stuff.

So, did I like Chroma Squad? I loved it. Really got me motivated to play some more SRPGs when I get the time and had me grinning like a maniac at times. You gotta accept it is, well, episodic at times because that's the source material it draws from, but stellar soundtrack really kicks in at times and does wonders for overall impression. If you're even remotely interested in these games give it a go and remember to GATTAI at your earliest convenience.

Chroma Squad is easily summed up with: "If power rangers and Xcom had a baby, this is that game." If that sounds like fun to you then you don't need to read the rest of this. Pick it up and have some fun.

For those who are interested in getting a little more indepth, I'll provide what I can by way of a review (but I don't have a huge amount of time devoted to the game so take what I say with a grain of salt).

Pros:

Aesthetically really nice. Meaning the visuals and music are basically perfect for the game.
Fun and funny storyline (from what I've experienced so far)
Gameplay is like a simplified Xcom. Mechanically I'd be ok with letting my 8+ year old nieces and nephews to play. They'd figure it out after some trial and error.
Family friendly (so far)

Cons:

For some people they might not like the pixelated aesthetic. I can undersand that point of view, even if I don't agree with it.

For a slightly longer review. I had fun playing this game. When I saw it first appear on steam I was intrigued enough to pick it up when it went on sale. Even though I don't have a lot of playtime, I will say that it was worth the sale price for sure and would be worth full price too. There are hours of entertainment that can be pulled from this game. It's light enough on the processor that it makes it perfect for gaming on the go if you don't have a great laptop and/or just want to "film a quick episode" (mission) when you are waiting for class to start or stuck in the airport. If all this sounds good to you, consider giving it a chance.

The game is amazing but due to multiple game breaking bugs; I cannot reccomend it.

The major bugs are all lumped into the final episode - where you can soft-lock your game or just outright crash. This has apperently been fixed; while it still clearly persists.

Also, the hub system could use a massive rework. Because of the clunky design you end up having to click 10 times to get what you want accomplished. 

Example 1: Rather that put the crafting system alongside where you need crafting - you have to leave what you're doing and go craft that thing (which unnecesarily takes time to complete; even if you have all the materials.)

Example 2: You cannot compare stats with what you have equipped unless you are buying it from the store. If you're crafting something; prepare to go back and forth several times with lots of clicking involved to manuever between the two screens.

Overall: It's great but... The last bit of the game is a buggy mess and the menu design on the hubworld is terribly clunky. Avoid it until a much-needed overhaul is made.

Chroma Squad is a fun and cheeky tile based strategy RPG.  I like that it incorporates the gameplay styles of games like Game Dev Tycoon and those other "build a franchise" type games.

The gameplay isn't too complex for a tile-based SRPG, but there are some fun ways to make your characters interact.  After you win the first segment of a battle, oftentimes a boss will show up and you fight it in your giant robot - those sections I found to be tedious.  Pretty much 100% RNG based, which was disappointing, as the buildup makes it seem like those sections will be the most fun part, unfortunately, they're the least amount of fun in the game.

Definitly worth playing, it's not a serious game but for a casual title that you can play if you don't want to invest yourself too heavily into something I would recommedn Chroma Squad.  Unfortunately I wasn't drawn in enough to finish the game, but definitely had some fun with it.

25643132.review:
Forse uno dei pochi giochi sviluppato con Unity degno di nota.

Chroma Squad è un RPG tattico in cui impersonerete un gruppo di 5 attori che dovranno salvare il mondo lavorando in squadra. Il gioco in se è MOLTO piacevole.

La grafica anche se di bassa qualità offre diversità ed è ben pensata, dando la possibilità al giocatore di non cadere troppo nel monotono.

Il comparto sonoro è magnifico: suoni ben fatti e musiche bellissime (ne avrei aggiunte altre).

La storia, come ben si può capire e come descritto nella presentazione di questo titolo, riporta ad anni addietro, per chi come me, è cresciuto un pò a pane e Power Rangers.

La gicabilità risulta ottima, veloce e l'aggiunta di oggetti equipaggiabili, skill addizionali, contratti con gli sponsor e modifiche per il nostro Mecha, renderà la nostra esperienza di gioco ancora migliore.

Onestamente ho trovato un pò inutile il sistema di crafting, in quanto in generale, data la scarsa difficoltà del gioco, avrete a disposizione abbastanza soldi per modificare l'equipaggiamento semplicemente acquistandolo, invece di andarvelo a craftare; avrei cercato di rendere il crafting più complesso, fornendo al giocatore oggetti addizionali senza avere la possibilità di acquistarli nello shop.

E' un gioco che fa passare il tempo, che intrattiene e che diverte allo stesso tempo; lo avevo sott'occhio da un pò di tempo, ma dopo l'uscita di un bundle l'ho acquistato e non me ne pento per nulla. Consigliato.

Voto 7/10

25627278.review:
Chroma Squad is a decent turn-based tactics parody RPG that might not be complex enough for some people. It probably helped that I grew up on Power Rangers so my appreciation for the setting and tolerance for its issues might go a bit further than some. You can expect around 12 hours of playtime on the normal difficulty if you engage a bit with the crafting system and take time to equip everyone optimally.

I’ll start off by going over Chroma Squad’s problems. This game is weighed down by its boring mecha fights and gameplay repetitiveness. The mecha fights are 2D encounters where you take turns beating each other up instead of taking place on a grid. Imagine missing attacks with 80-90% accuracy against monsters that need to be KO’d three times and you have the early mecha combat experience. The fights become more tolerable later as you can equip different mech parts that increase accuracy (a must), other stats, or grant new abilities. Still, they’re too long and not mechanically interesting. I also didn’t enjoy the timing mini-game when you defend. 

The gameplay repetitiveness comes from the pacing of acquiring new abilities and the common enemy variety. The bosses are fine and some of them have interesting gimmicks. New abilities are unlocked at the start of a new season which felt too long since you can only have one active out of the two or three choices at that tier. Some choices felt obvious, but I did do some switching around later in the game. What helped me was playing in short bursts of 1-1.5 hours. Otherwise, the gameplay might wear you down since you’ll often be using the same strategies against the same baddies. I noticed areas being reused often too. I recommend deliberately setting out to acquire the Rider path for season 5 to experience some very interesting gameplay changes relative to the rest of the game.

Chroma Squad allows for some silly customization. Since the theme is that you’re running a TV studio, you’re able to select your actors, name their characters, name the studio, customize catchphrases, name the mech, and more.  I highly recommend personalizing everything to have more fun with it. I went with Friendship Squad and named the mech Big Friend. The power of friendship can overcome all, don’t cha know.

The gameplay itself involves recording episodes (going out on missions) and managing your team in-between shoots. Episodes involve combat and following the Director’s Instructions as best as you can since you want to have a high audience rating for more money and fan conversion. The combat involves you making squad members move twice or move and then attack (attacks end the character’s turn). You can use certain abilities that count as free actions so that you can still attack and/or move. The Teamwork ability that any class can use lets you gang up on an enemy or toss teammates around which lets them move farther. The gameplay becomes more interesting later with more abilities unlocked while the start is a bit slow.

An example I can give is the having the Assault use Teamwork to toss the Lead away from danger, then using the Lead’s Join Up ability (free action) to gather everyone without making them use any actions, followed by the Support’s AoE heal, using the Lead’s Lasso ability to rope in a weak enemy for a kill, and then making the Scout cloak for something sneaky-sneaky.

The team management aspect involves crafting gear with materials found in episodes or from crates, deciding on what studio upgrades to buy, deciding which marketing agency to hire (income buffs, combat buffs) so that you can spend fans on even more buffs, buying gear from the shop, deciding on what abilities to use, and reading fan mail. Crafting can be a little time consuming considering that some stats are RNG which leads to multiple attempts if you have a poor roll.

Well, that’s it. I liked the game overall, but it does have some problems. I think it’s worth a look.

25392191.review:
A light RPG about not just defeating your enemies, but about looking cool while doing it.

The mechanics of this game are most certainly simple and trimmed down enough that it will be coming out on mobile.  Still provides enough fiddling with equipment, marketing choices, upgrade options, and whatnot to give you something to do.  You are to gather Audience during each Episode (mission), so alongside trying to make sure you win (which on the medium difficulty I never felt too pressured about), you are also to coordinate team attacks and acrobatics, fulfilling the optional objectives of that mission, trying to get the last blow on the boss to be a Finishing Move, and whatever else will excite your audience, and thus gain you Fans and Money.  You can customize your super group down to their respective color themes, names, catch-phrases, and so forth.  The songs fit the mood of the moment splendidly, and I'll likely be buying the soundtrack later.

Seeing as I usually prefer more complexity to my RPG's, it's hard for me to indicate exactly what drove me to like this game as much as I did.  Maybe it was just fighting an obvious reference to Barnie to Dinosaur in my Mecha as we towered over the city, combo-ing fists and lasers before I miss and lose the initiative.  Maybe it was the progression of starting as a low-budget series fighting a guy with a traffic cone on his head, up to a full-fledged studio.  Maybe I'm just vain, and desire as many Fans as I can get by being Cool Guy in front of a camera, with a charisma and acting talent I could never attempt in real life.

The point is, I got genuinely excited during some of the pivotal battles in this game, and that's deserving of praise.

25373408.review:
Kurt Vonnegut said that anyone who has attacked a piece of written work with genuine loathing is being ridiculous, that they are behaving as someone who has "put on full armor and attacked a hot fudge sundae". 

What I'm about to do is kind of like that, but imagine me duct taping pink polyester all over my body and wandering into a public park to hunt down an anthropomorphic version of a video game called Chroma Squad, a tiny freckly kid with jubilantly blue eyes, offering me an ice cream cone, his diminutive hands aquiver with timid goodwill. I will proceed to karate kick that child in the face, and as he reaches for the ice cream again (mint chocolate drizzled with galaxies of cake sprinkles), I will remove my plastic helmet to let him gaze on my dreadfully expressionless face as I level a long gentle stare into his brilliant, innocent eyes, grinding his delicious confection into the pea gravel with the heel of a nylon boot.

I came to Chroma Squad for obvious reasons. Chroma Squad begins with what we are to take as the stunt actors from the actual Power Rangers set staging a revolt and opening their own studio to shoot their own martial arts children's show, or in other words, to do everything exactly as before but with a rigorous simulation of creative control. The thing that really drew me to it, though, was the rumor that it was a Final Fantasy Tactics-esque Tactical RPG with a splash of XCOM flavor, full of cheek and wit and heart-warming hilarity to bring home to the whole family.

I'm going to have a total XCOM-snob conniption right now, so be sure to click the 'not helpful' button if those words don't mean anything to you at all. This game's combat is wearing tactical RPG clothes for what appears to be no reason apart from the fun of having made a game that aesthetically resembles a turn-based tactical RPG ala Disgaea or FF Tactics. Battles are much more comparable, however, to those of Diablo or Torchlight, in which you click somewhere on the screen, your little fellows amble (or here, cartwheel and cheer-lift one another) in a direction, swing their fists around, and that's it. This, of course, places Chroma Squad on the tactical combat spectrum nearest to "something you idly click through."

It's all about positioning your team just right so they can perform the same finishing move again. And again. And again. All for the entertainment of the type of children Chroma Squad must think we all were at a certain age: the kid who got up early every Saturday morning to sit at the TV with eyes pressed directly to the glass. Combat is shockingly boring, special abilities don't really synchronize, and there's basically no reason to attempt to play "tactically," because the experience is much closer to being babysat by a kind teenager who thinks she's way cooler than she is. You are given a laundry list each mission of little hoops to jump through, such as "defeat 3 enemies in the same turn," "keep all your heroes alive," or "attempt to figure out how to do that same team attack again," but all of these come off as suggestions on the level with "wouldn't it be really cool if you brushed your teeth and went to bed at exactly 8 PM per your parents' instructions? We're really on the same side here."

I found myself cranking the difficulty down from its highest setting midway through, not because I felt particularly challenged, but because I just couldn't bear the thought of spending more time seeing this thing through than I had to. Yes, sometimes you'll get so bored watching each reskinned enemy type spawn in one-at-a-time and run into positions that will have no effect on how you'll fight that you phase back into paying attention to learn that your healer is dead, and things get a little bit tricky. Then you can halfheartedly attempt to survive the mission or suffer some consequences featuring a number that represents your supposed fans, who have opted, instead of watching your onscreen incompetence, to get stoned and watch Godzilla vs Megalon again, which is about 1/4 as stoned as I'd need to be to enjoy this game or find it compellingly difficult, a state of I mind imagine as a hypothetical level of brain-myopia in which I lose the ability to read or control my bowels.

What you'll never see in Chroma Squad, at any rate, is any indication that the AI knows that it's supposed to try to win. Chroma Squad is every bit the tactical RPG that Battletoads & Double Dragon was way back when.

The game's interface is by far the worst enemy--not much is communicated clearly, and features stand a very real chance of remaining hidden in plain sight well into late game. The explanations of some abilities don't make sense--one has you dealing damage to enemies along your traveled path, but the ability doesn't path through enemies, so I never figured out what the hell that ability is supposed to be doing.

One could argue the game is challenging given that you'll feel underpowered most of the time. But I'll counter that by saying that making a sloppy, unresponsive mess of a studio management screen does not tactical gameplay make. Your resource management screen seems wilfully designed to confuse you--you'll spend money in an attempt to get at least one aspect of your television enterprise functioning competently, but little seems to help. You cannot sell equipment and are instead forced to reduce items to scrap materials you'll probably never use. Everything is a one-way street to a sort of long suffering.

Somehow, the novelty of the game's customization options wears off extremely fast, and even turning your heroes' "morphin time" catchphrase to HAIL SATAN fails to drum up much enthusiasm when you know more deadening combat is coming.

THAT'S THE WHOLE JOKE, you say. It's all LOW RENT and also DID YOU NOTICE that EVERYTHING IS A REFERENCE. Yeah. And it's extremely hilarious or something. Don't get me wrong, there are some sensible chuckles strung throughout in the form of a draconian director barking Backstreet Boys lyrics as stage prompts, an anonymous "biggest fan" innocently emailing the studio to ask if Halliburton had any involvement in the design of the Megazord, or the sudden run-in with the star of Colin's Bear Animation, who unaccountably transforms into a send-up of Yakra and Heckran from Chrono Trigger.

But when I start to sense that the game's wit is wringing itself raw with the exertion of transmuting "Nick Fury" to "Rick Anger", or naming a large sentient iPod enemy DOPi, or reaching -just- -one- -more- -time- for another Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles shoutout, I start experimenting with how much mileage I can get out of the handy fast-forwarding key. I swear to god, nothing tells me more about how quick this game's lights and camera went up around its ramshackle production than having a character recite the Taken monologue verbatim and the villain responding with "Hey Sentai fans, did you catch that that comes from somewhere else? Thanks so much for playing our game, guys, and HEY MACARENA, AHA."

Best of all, I watched the everloving SHIT out of Power Rangers as a kid and got into my share of schoolyard trouble for it, and I don't know if it's me or the developers of this game who are supposed to be more pissed off that the fact alone does not make this game good. It is all heart, goddamn it, all heart through and through, stuffed with beautiful art and infectious music, and for all those elements I will certainly place a crisp gold star at the top of this game's construction paper project plastered with hot glue and macaroni.

Pure flavor, bad content, like a Fruit Roll-Up or a new season of Full House. Buy it as cheap as you can.

25204434.review:
The pros:

The game is quite fun and very addictive. It's a strategy RPG with a unique concept that is pulled off extremely well. It's the perfect application of crafting mechanics, too. The graphics are beautiful, and the music is impressively good. The concept of going from small-time to big time is a brilliant idea for a game of this manner.

There is a lot of attention to detail in the game, with secret things to find both graphically and plot wise. It's easily worth the MSRP, and is one of those things you don't know you want until you have played it for yourself.

Protip: Don't try hard mode on your first playthrough. It's really unbalanced hard.

The cons:

The programming is so glitchy the game feels like a beta version. The textboxes overflow when people are talking and transitions are often jarringly abrupt, just cutting out and flickering when a level ends instead of having a proper "you win" screen. The controller controls need major work as they just operate the mouse cursor instead of having true controller support.

The writing is mediocre, with very poor grammar that could have used major proofreading. Some of the scenarios are sort of nonsensical due to the writing. The appearances of numerous Kickstarter backers break the immersion of the game, it would have been better if they didn't have to awkwardly say their full names every time someone appeared. The backer characters all look like the same nerdy white guys, and dont make sense in the setting.

With the lack of characterization you'd think there'd be some kind of character creation for your team, but instead there is very little in the way of choice if you want a decent team, I wish you could choose from more diverse appearances and just assign certain personalities to them, instead there are kind of obvious "best characters", so if you didn't want a cartoon beaver on your team youre flat out of luck.

25158535.review:
Jednoho dne se na křižovatce objevil záhadný Semaforník. S oranžovým kuželem na hlavě a semaforem v ruce sázel strach do motorových srdcí všech hodných a laskavých řidičů, jelikož zcela ovládl značení dopravy. Naštěstí netrvalo dlouho a Semaforníkovy zlé plány se vydala zničit skupinka obyčejných lidí, kteří dělali ale neobyčejné činy. Ne, nemluvím o policii, ale o Smečce.

Smečka, skupina složená z pěti lidí, kteří se rozhodli bojovat proti hnusným zlosynům. FireWolf, chrabrý a nejvíce sexy vůdce skupiny, jaký tu kdy byl. Rohlík, jenž byl expertem na různé vychytávky a nebál se použít proti nepřátelům i střelné zbraně. Shiranui, krásná mladá blondýnka, která držela skupinu pohromadě a v případě potřeby neváhala a vyléčila jejího člena. Lovely Black Sheep, další mladá žena, která byla svižná a rychlá a její vyhýbání útokům protivníků se stalo pomalu legendárním. A posledním členem jest Bargud, promiňte, Bobrgud, který sice vypadá jako bobr, ale zasazuje tak tvrdé rány, které protivníky pořádně zabolí a co teprve jeho pověstný kop, jenž složí více nepřátel najednou!

Tato skupinka se postavila Semaforníkovi a ukázala mu červené světlo. A pak, další den, je čekalo vše nanovo. Tentokrát dělníci hlásili tvora podobného bahnu, který otravuje na stavbě a vyvolává zombíky... Porazí i jej naši neohrožení hrdinové? To se dozvíte v další epizodě seriálu Smečka!

[h1]Epizoda 1 - příběh[/h1]
Ano, takhle nějak vypadá tahle hra. Nebere se moc vážně, je hodně vtipná a obsahuje hromadu easter eggů. Když se na ni podíváte, první vás napadne inspirace Power Rangers (Strážci vesmíru). A je tomu skutečně tak. Ve hře se chopíte pěti postav, vyberete jim barvu oblečení, jméno a jdete potírat zlo. Zpočátku to je jen pouze jako televizní seriál, kdy je hra rozdělena na 5 sérií po šesti epizodách.

Časem se však vše změní a hra dostane na hloubce. Můžu říct, že děj pěkně odsýpá a užíval jsem si ho. Nepřátelé jsou originální, bojujete proti televizi, medvědovi, který vás svým tancem dostane do tranzu a podobnými originálními nepřáteli.

Dalším kladem jsou bezesporu konce hry, které jsou tři a každý nabízí jiný zážitek. Na konci čtvrté série na vás čeká rozhodnutí, které rozhodne právě o tom, jak bude vypadat poslední série.

[h1]Epizoda 2 - hratelnost[/h1]
Hra nabízí primitivní tahový systém soubojů, kdy se zpočátku bojuje bez schopností, ale pokud to uznáte za vhodné, můžete se přeměnit na "Strážce vesmíru", kdy má každá z postav unikátní schopnosti. Bohužel zde přichází první chyba, kdy ony schopnosti jsou vázány na sezónu, takže každou sérii se vám odemknou dvě schopnosti a vy  musíte vybrat tu, která vyhovuje vašemu stylu boje lépe.

Samotný systém tahů je také jednoduchý, máte tu jen přesun, speciální útok, klasický útok a pak pomoc příteli, kdy pomůže daná postava jiné postavě skočit dále nebo společně zaútočí na nepřítele. Není tu bohužel žádná obrana ani "overwatch" (známé ze série XCOM), ale to je dáno tím, že tahle hra je především pro co nejširší skupinu lidí.

Každá z epizod je jiná, máte hlavní úkol a pak i vedlejší, díky kterým získáte body do audience navíc (vysvětlím dále). K tomu si přičtěte, že dost často bojujete na konci epizody jako robot proti nepříteli anebo že sem tam máte o postavu méně nebo více, takže každá epizoda je skutečně jiná a nenudí vás.

[h1]Epizoda 3 - fanoušci a vylepšování[/h1]
Ve svém studiu můžete také kromě vylepšování postav vybírat a vytvářet oblečení, díky kterému budou odolnější a silnější. Také můžete vylepšit svého robota. No a pak tu jsou úpravy vašeho studia, kdy za získané peníze koupíte třeba lepší osvětlení nebo větší studio a to vám dá určitý bonus.

Jakožto tvůrci seriálů se samozřejmě kromě peněz snažíte získat i co nejširší základnu fanoušků. A ty získáváte právě díky spolupráci hrdinů během epizod nebo plněním vedlejších úkolů. Pak tu také můžete vybrat jednu z agentur, která vám poskytne určitý boost k určitým věcem. Já například dost využíval služby agentury, díky které jsem měl jisté zvýšení fanoušků u každé epizody a tím se mi i zvýši zisk. Samozřejmě i zde jde prohrát. Na začátku každé série dostanete kontrakt a pokud jej nesplníte (například pokud se základna fanoušků sníží na určitý počet), prohráli jste.

K tomu se váže i prohrávání epizod, což ale není problém. Prohrát můžete, oddálí to vydání další epizody a sebere vám to trochu peněz a i fanoušků. Pokud ale budete hrát na první dvě obtížnosti, tohle není vůbec problém. První projdete s prstem v nose, druhá je tak akorát, i když v poslední sezóně hodně stoupne obtížnost a třetí je... peklo. Tvůrci nedokázali dle mě vyvážit obtížnosti, takže ta poslední je o několik levelů výše než střední. I proto doporučuji hrát na druhou obtížnost, která je většinu času férová a strávíte díky ní s hrou zhruba dvanáct hodin.

[h1]Epizoda 4 - grafika a hudba[/h1]
Audiovizuální zpracování je úžasné. Grafická stylizace se mi líbí, i když to jsou kostičky a hudba je taktéž skvělá. Po čase se možná někomu ohraje, protože tu je jen pár témat, ale já osobně jsem s tímhle problém překvapivě neměl.

[h1]Epizoda 5 - bugy[/h1]
Jak jde asi poznat z textu, hra se mi hodně líbila a užíval jsem si ji. Bohužel ji dost sráží bugy, kterých tu je požehnaně. Například se mi neodemykaly achievementy, ale to není až takový problém, že. Horší bylo, že se mi stalo, že v poslední epizodě jsem nemohl pokračovat dále, protože se mi dveře k finálnímu bossovi neotevřely. Bugů tu je bohužel vícero a strašně moc kazí, jinak perfektní, požitek z hraní.

[h1]Plusy[/h1]
+ pohodová atmosféra
+ vtip
+ hratelnost
+ tahový systém soubojů
+ příběh
+ tři konce hry
+ vtipní bossové
+ vylepšování vlastního studia, hrdinů a robota
+ jednoduchý systém vytváření předmětů
+ audiovizuální zpracování
+ hromada easter eggů
+ délka hry

[h1]Mínusy[/h1]
- opravdu hodně bugů, z nichž některé rozbijí hru a vy nemůžete pokračovat dále
- souboje s roboty se po čase ohrají
- nevyvážené obtížnosti

[h1]Konečný verdikt[/h1]
[b]Mé hodnocení: 9/10[/b]

Pokud milujete strážce vesmíru, budete milovat i tuhle hru. Mezi tahovkami patří k těm jednodušším, to ale krásně kompenzuje vtipem, zajímavým příběhem a zábavností. Největší pihou na kráse tak je přítomnost většího množství bugů.

24946757.review:
Starts strong, with an amusing story and good base mechanics.  By season 3 or 4, the scarcity of new and interesting mechanics turns the combat into a dull grind, full of reskinned enemies that you've fought again and again and again.

I played through the end of season 4, on the highest difficulty.  The game balance seemed reasonable but not overly challenging at first, but by the end, it felt like I was constantly underlevelled and underequipped.  Even though the game has no concept of experience (season number does function as a sort of "level") and my gear was the best on offfer.

As a result, the game became a tedious slog of repeatedly sending 2-3 people after each enemy (for multiple turns, if it was the defensive type), keeping everyone's health up, and the occasional weird "because the director told me so" goal to get more audience.  The strategy varied *slightly* depending on the exact configuration of enemies, whether you could hit a few with an AOE, and if there was a boss.  For bosses, the standard procedure was to ignore them until you killed the enemies, then repeatedly wail on them with 2-3 people and heal up from their inevitable "knock one or all nearby people back, move, attack again" attack pattern.  And with a boss in most episodes (stages), even that became completely routine.

The end boss of season 4 was particularly dull.  Every few turns, he summons two enemy-summoning portals.  The portals have about as much health and defense as a normal enemy, and they spawn an enemy every turn (except the turn when they are spawned).  So you spend half or more of your time cleaning up the portals, rather than handling the boss.  The boss also has an assistant, who (for plot reasons) the game suggests not killing.  The assistant heals the boss periodically.  I ended up killing the assistant eventually, because it was taking far, far too long to win when I kept having to go kill portals and watch the boss get healed.  I had even tried letting the portals spawn for a few turns and just focusing on the boss, but had to regroup and clear them out, as the ever-spawning enemies were threatening to overwhelm me.

The mech battles similarly stagnate.  The first one is neat, and the next few are also cool as you customize your mech.  But by the end of season 2, you're mech has basically reached its final form, and it's just a matter of making numbers go up to try to keep pace with ever-stronger enemies.

I liked the game.  It had charm, an amusingly-cheesy plot, and solid mechanics.  But while the plot progressed and got better, the mechanics didn't,  I don't regret buying it, but I do find myself saddened and disappointed that it couldn't follow through on the solid experience it started.

24416356.review:
This game is a great little indie title. Their omage to Power Rangers clearly comes from a place of wanting to laugh with the fans, not mock source material. The turn-based battles aren't the most complex system around, but there are some choices you can make towards your actors skills that can certainly allow for differing strategies. I think the part that made it so good and easy to get into for me is how the game is paced. It's wisely broken up into seasons and episodes, which really solidifies the setting, and the episodes themselves never take a huge amount of time to complete with most coming in at 30-45 minutes. It makes it really nice and easy to play a small portion and then come back to it later. The one aspect of the game that doesn't deliver as well as the rest is the Mech vs. Big Monster battles, but they don't happen every episode.

Great game with great humor and well designed gameplay, definitely great for fans of strategy RPGs and a good trek down memory lane for watchers of shows like Power Rangers.

24398199.review:
That was 20 hours that I don't regret. 

Creating your own "power-rangers"-team, and playing them through meta-scenarios while making a studio and buying plastic swords was a great ride. Because I named all my characters after friends, the banter ended up being eerily similar to if I had written it myself, which was great. 

Tactical turn based fighting is fun, and the added focus on teamwork and stunts on partners made it even better. 

I would have loved even more characters to play through the game with, and even more weapons and gear to craft and buy. I guess it's not too negative that I want more of what's already in the game. 

The pacing of seasons is a great idea and works well, allowing the game to be played in episodes or seasons if you want. I rarely complete games, but this one was fab, and I'll probably play it through at least one more time.

Had been 8/10, but because the price point is what it is, given the production values, I'll put this at a 10/10. 

No game is perfect, and everything can be improved, but if 10 is an obtainable number, and considering the price, then yeah. One of my favourite new games.

24090069.review:
If you haven't figured it out already, this game is essentially Power Rangers. With a bunch of comedy, hilarious dialogue, memes and 90s pop culture references thrown in for good measure. That is to say, it's a lot of fun to play, especially if you're old enough to remember the 90s.

Fundamentally, the gameplay is a tactical turn based RPG. You pick your squad members at the start of the game (and use them for the entire game) and upgrade them along the way. There's no levels, you can buy new equipment and unlock new skills as you progress through the story.

Unfortunately, this game is not perfect and I have a few issues with certain aspects of this game. Hopefully the devs can address some of these issues at some point.

1. Tutorial
The tutorial is very light on details and skips over certain fundamental game mechanics entirely. It doesn't provide any information on what the Chromatize button does, or that you need to use it to use your finisher move. Additionally, there is very little information on what the different audience stats and numbers mean in terms of gameplay and what the different stats from the advertising agencies actually do to affect that.

2. Movement and combat
Each character can generally perform two actions per turn (outside of certain free action abilities marked as such). This is fine, but the implementation is quite annoying at times. You first move action, regardless of whether you moved the full distance or not, takes up a full action. So if you moved closer to use a ranged ability and found yourself one tile too far away but still had enough movement range to do it with your first action, you have wasted the turn since to move the one additional tile will take the full second action and you will not be able to use your ranged ability.

It's also hard to see where to position squad members to use abilities and teamwork without actually moving them and seeing what they can do next, compounding the frustration from the abovementioned issue. I would like to see some kind of move planner that lets you plan out all the moves for a turn (with an undo) to queue up all the actions, and when you're done setting it up, it all happens at once when you end the turn.

3. Crafting
Random item drops might sound good on paper and work alright in a game with infinite random monsters to farm to eventually get what you need, but in this game it pretty much means that you'll generally be buying most of your equipment, especially since crafted items have random stats that may or may not be what you actually want/need. Save your resources for upgrading the mecha.

3. Snowballing failure
Because of the story structure of this game, if you don't have the right equipment to do a mission and don't have money to afford it, you're stuck. If you do poorly on an early mission, you'll be short on cash for later missions, leading to a snowball effect of frustration with no solution other than starting over. The game is long enough that this could become rage inducing, especially given the difficulty spike at the very end. Thankfully on casual difficulty the game is easy enough that this isn't an issue at all, but could become a major problem on higher difficulties.

Related to this is the major difficulty spike for the last mission, especially the final mecha battle. Tactics and equipment that worked just fine earlier in the game suddenly become useless since you're now faced with lots of new enemies and abilities. The final mecha battle has no rounds where your mech can recover, so if you didn't equip your mech with an active heal ability, you will lose, even on casual since you won't be able to heal at all, but the boss can and has a lot more health than you.

Overall though I had a lot of fun playing this game in spite of my enthusiasm being dampened by the difficulty spike of the final mission. Easily recommended, especially if the devs keep working on this game and address some of the aforementioned issues.

24066548.review:
Hah! This game is too much fun. For anyone who enjoys turn-based strategy RPGs, with plenty of customization, cheesy chiptune music and intricacies that are easy to learn but difficult to master... Pick this up, even at full price.

Here we have a game where you manage a crew of actors/actresses of your choosing, filming a television show with a brand new studio. The two big elements to this game are when you're in the studio (business management mode), and when you're recording (combat mode). Both are fleshed out quite well--when you're in the studio, you *will* spend a while making tactical decisions as to what agency to sign with, what to craft/buy and for whom, and how to gear up your mech for the upcoming fight.

Combat is a whole 'nother beast. It isn't *terribly* complicated on the surface, but the addition of being able to enter a "Teamwork" state where you can either combo with others or, more importantly, catapult off them to gain some extra movement and set yourself up, that's where it gets interesting. It's a little reminiscent of throwing people around in Disgaea (similarly, the whole game has a Disgaea-ish feel to it). In fact, if I didn't know any better, I'd think this was a direct offshoot of the Super Sentai-esque characters from Disgaea, but that's just because this is also a tactical RPG and it's a common trope.

In addition, adding a layer to combat, in each scenario you have a pair of "Director's Instructions," which net you bonus points (referred to as "audience"). These are tallied at the end to give you money and "fans" (which are effectively points that allow you to benefit from more of your chosen agency's bonuses). 

PROS:
* Though it's not for everyone, and can get a little repetitive, the cheesy, chiptune, over-the-top music is great. 
* Also subjective, but I find the combat to be just plain fun, and hard difficulty will provide no small amount of challenge for the perfectionist. Mech combat is no exception.
* Very deep game overall. Seems like something I'd give another playthrough.
* It's funny and cheesy without pushing either of those too far.
* Nicely animated for 2D sprites.

CONS:
* Some of the stats are a little unclear, and there seems to be no in-game explanation for most of them. Some of them are self-explanatory, some aren't. This might not really count as a con, but the UI could have used some cleaning up.
* Can't undo accidental misclicks in combat. In fairness though, that can be chalked up to human error, it's not like it's easy to misclick.
* No toggle to see the tactical grid, which has led to some poor choices in gauging how far away I've been from an opponent (another reason I wish there was an undo function).
* This may just be me, but my computer stutters at least one or two times during those crucial timing-based defense moves in the mech battles. Probably just me since I run so much in my background, but the game continues and I'm left only to guess when to click. I've run much higher graphics games with zero issues like this still running everything in my background, but I will say the game is otherwise technically sound.
* My last minor gripe, I wish I could fire an actor and replace them. So fair warning, you can't change your characters mid-game.

Pick this one up if any of that appeals to you, it definitely put a smile on my face.

24007122.review:
Já vou avisando logo de cara: se você ainda tem preconceito com jogos nacionais, é melhor abrir sua mente e dar uma chance à esse título! 
Chroma Squad é um RPG tático dos mesmos criadores do excelente Knights of Pen and Paper, que simula um seriado de Super Sentai, bem aos moldes de Power Rangers. Aqui, um grupo de dublês se cansa de atuar e receber ordens de um diretor mandão a troco de nenhum reconhecimento e abrem seu próprio estúdio para gravar seus próprios episódios de Super Sentai. E assim começa a "jornada" dos cinco amigos rumo ao estrelato, em uma verdadeira montanha-russa de metalinguagem. 
Um lance bacana é que seu esquadrão é totalmente customizável. Você pode escolher a cor da roupa de cada integrante, que tipo de integrante irá desempenhar o papel, o nome de cada um e isso apenas falando de escolhas meramente cosméticas. Fora isso temos tudo que um bom RPG tático oferece e mais um pouco. 
O modo de combate é bem interessante e há um sistema bem legal de cooperação entre os membros do grupo, sendo possível realizar acrobacias para atingir lugares do mapa mais distantes, ataques em conjunto que amplificam o dano e é claro que não poderia faltar a gloriosa Mecha para finalizar algumas brigas no melhor estilo possível. Outro detalhe bem bacana é que cada membro do time, por mais que sejam parecidos (com exceção da cor de cada um), se movimenta de forma diferente, uma sacada bem legal, pois você acaba criando um apego por cada um. 
Chroma Squad é a prova concreta de que nós brasileiros estamos cada vez mais engajados na cultura gamer mundial e que podemos criar muita coisa maneira. Super recomendo!

23875517.review:
A spunky, cool game featuring a squad of stuntmen and -women who set out to make a POWER RANGERS-style series. 

As far as the gameplay goes: It's a mix of isometrical turn-based tactics and one of those management games where you get to buy stuff and outfit your office. Stuff like MAD TV. If you remember that one, then you're an old fart like me and you probably just missed the super sentai-craze of the mid-90s, because you considered yourself too old and prefered mature stuff like those XTREME era IMAGE comics. You know... the ones where superheroes hat 5000 pouches. But I digress. Gameplay-wise, CHROMA SQUAD is really nifty. There are three difficulty levels and the middle one is just right in my opinion. I'm too old to get really good at any game - once you pass the magical 30, you come to find that life won't allow you to play video games for ten hours a day. And when I say "life", I mean "spouse", you know what I'm sayin'? Not that I'm complaining! Just saying it like it is, yo. Droppin' knowledge. Yo, yo.

The thing I like best about this game, is its sense of humour, though. Really. Usually, I find games that try to be funny annoying. There is something so endearing about CHROMA SQUAD that I just can't bring myself not to chuckle. You can see that the makers are not trying to make fun of POWER RANGERS and the like, they are paying hommage, but in an oddball way that really has heart. As referential as the game is, its references are never ham-fisted and they don't pander to geeks moe-stlye. They're actually quite cute.

So. There you go. If you were to ask me "Gaston, shall I buy this game", I'd answer: "Go for it." And then I'd add that if you remember MAD TV, you should google it, because there is an online version of it that you can play in your browser.

Peace, out.

23848914.review:
This game is adorable and feels like a SNES classic that flew under the radar. The pixel graphics are clear, well-animated, and bold, the soundtrack is super catchy, and the gameplay is fun. Most of all, it oozes flavor from everywhere, from the item descriptions, to the post-level "tweets" as a scorecard.

If it has any flaw, it's that it's a bit shallow for a tactical RPG; there's a lack of class customization and enemy variety, though they cover all the bases. The mecha battles could be better, too. The difficulty curve is a bit wobbly as well, though I enjoyed having some easy stages to "cooldown" with following the tough ones.

Unless you're looking for a deep tactical game, none of these rough edges are enough to pull the game down. The game is a love letter to sentai shows and 90s childhood, without any cynicism or irony. It looks back on it with modern eyes, pokes fun at it's own expense, but completely embraces its nostalgia. I loved it!

23820745.review:
TLDR:

Gameplay - 10
Music - 10
Story/Writing - 10
Nostalgia - 10
Chance for Enemies to Dodge Attacks - OP
_____________________________________________________________________

Still in "Season 1" and this game is great. My only complaint is that their hardest difficulty is too hard. 

There are objectives to fulfill in each mission, for example: Kill all enemies in 4 turns
And it feels like the enemies dodge more often on round 4 than they do the previous 3.  I've had to restart more than a handful of times because of this.

Another objective might be: Kill the boss with a finishing move
Which requires all 5 party members to be alive, so if one of your members gets KO'd then tough shit. Which is especially hard when the Season 1 boss has 2000HP and you hit for 60-100 each person. You can team-attack for about 400-600 but that requires all party members to be right up next to the bad guy, which sounds easy enough, but as you get hit your players get knocked back depending on where they get hit from so your players will fall out of range of team attacks.


Oh, and the healer can heal allies but can't heal itself? 

It feels like I just have to keep restarting the mission until I get lucky enough to finally pass, which to a certain degree I can understand because I don't want my wins to be handed to me, but my tactics (in a tactical-RPG) should not be undermined by something as whimsical as fucking RNG-dodging.

23677088.review:
This is a fairly straight-forward tactical RPG. It has an interesting twist where you run a TV studio filming a "sentai" style action show. For those unfamiliar, that means it's a Power Rangers style show. You get to make a few personal touches as far as Squad name, transformation name, Mech name, and a few other options. You're also in charge of upgrading your studio, some basic marketing options, as well as purchasing or crafting new equipment.

If you've ever played a tactical-RPG, you know what to expect. You get a movement and an action, or two movements. There are free actions which are the exception. There's also a teamwork feature. A member of your squad can throw you further increasing your initial movement. If they are adjacent to an enemy and you attack with another member, they combine their attack and do increased damage. There's also a finishing move if you have 4 members using teamwork and you attack with the 5th. 

The pixel graphics are actually well done. Most of the sets look very nice. The details in the character models are nice, as well. Some of the suits look cool. The retro soundtrack is also nice, but you can mostly just play it with the sound off as it gets rather repetitive. Of course, graphics and sound aren't the important part of a game like this so I'm sure you won't be drawn to get this game just because they're not amazing.

This game supports a controller, but it thinks my Xbox controller is a Playstation controller. A minor complaint, but a little weird. Also, and this is annoying, you can't use the controller for the Mech fights. Pretty aggravating to have to use the mouse.

So, if you're interested in the genre, and the theme appeals to you, go for it. Especially if it's on sale.

23410711.review:
Excellent tactical RPG with a surprising amount of depth.
It's a bit of a business management sim on top of the RPG side, but they mesh very well together.
The game play works well, with plenty of options in combat to choose how you want to approach things, and a wealth of customization in the pre episode/fight setup.
A silly and offbeat story line with enough genuine comedy to make you laugh occasionally helps to spruce up the quality game play as well.

It starts off simple, so it's not difficult to learn but gets progressively deeper, and I can tell there is more to come. I'm genuinely looking forward to each new "episode" of the TV show you play in.

Difficulty wise, I'm playing on hard and it's just right for me. Hard enough I have to pay attention to what I'm doing and think out my actions, and most episodes I'm barely scraping through. Can't comment on how that would fit for others of course, but as someone pretty accustomed to this style of game hard difficulty has works nicely for me.

I'm not finished the game so I can't comment on length, but I'm a long ways from finishing and have put in about 11hrs on this save so far. So I'm confident there is a surprisingly large amount of content to play through.

I've heard tons of love given to the sound track for the game but... honestly I don't see it. It's not bad by any means but it's more decent and fits the game well, then anything truly memorable.
The visuals I really appreciate however, it's simple retro pixel graphics but the combat animations, movement, and even the special attacks are all very well animated and look quite nice. Lots of extra frills like a fast forward effect reminiscent of an old VCR on a CRT TV fit perfectly with the atmosphere.

I can happily recommend this to anyone who wants a lighthearted RPG, or just looking for something unique and different. Not much else out there like this.

9/10 and a genuinely excellent game. Easy recommendation.

This game is absolutely adorable. The art, writing, music -- it's all just too damn cute. I really love it.

It's not deep -- the strategy is always fairly simple, and towards the end, somewhat repetitive. If you're looking for 90+ hours of customization and grueling, meat-grinding tactical battles, try Wasteland 2 or Xenonauts. But if you're looking for an extremely light-hearted game with nostalgia and adorableness oozing from every pixel, this is a really fun way to blow some hours. The battles ARE occasionally somewhat difficult, too.

I hope these guys go on to make a sequel, and add some depth, additional content, and better crafting/skill balance.

But despite its flaws, it's really worth a play if you've ever been a fan of giant robots, Power Rangers, or simple turn-based strategies.

23098101.review:
I have never been a huge Power Rangers fan. I only watched the first 2 or 3 Power Rangers seasons as a kid and I have ignored all other super sentai shows. This game made me regret that I missed out on so much.

+ Solid turn based tactical combat (think XCOM / Banner Saga / Disgaea / etc.)
+ Tongue in cheek humor that will dig its way into your heart
+ Awesome music
+++ Supreme commitment to its theme

- Mecha fights are kind of dull
- Later stages of the game can make side objectives frustrating


It's wacky, it's silly, it's fun, it will remind you of your childhood, the value of friendship, playing around with cardboard and wood back when your imagination had no limit. It oozes so much personality and it manages to both pay tribute to and satirize the super sentai genre and all sorts of other aspects of pop culture. It's a product of deep love and understanding of an entire subculture that most of us are barely aware of but the passion placed behind it transcends the limit of your knowledge and even personal taste to the point where it is impossible not to appreciate what you're seeing before your eyes.

The only reason not to play this game is if you really dislike turn based tactical combat. It's a really good game and an amazing experience overall.

22773942.review:
Je ne m'attendais vraiment à passer autant de temps sur ce jeu la première fois que je l'ai lancé.
Chroma Squad vous met dans la peau de 5 cascadeurs qui décident de lâcher leur série de sentai actuelle pour lancer leur propre studio.
Le soft prend alors l'apparence d'un jeu de stratégie/gestion dans sa forme la plus simple. On alterne entre trois phases qui constitueront le coeur de votre partie : on gère son studio pour améliorer ses personnages et rajouter différents bonus, un épisode se lance sous forme de stratégie au tour par tour et sur certains épisodes, un combat de mecha est lancé pour clôturer l'épisode.
Il vous faudrer gagner un maximum de points sur la deuxième phase pour pouvoir les utiliser pendant la partie gestion et pour cela il faudra accomplir certaines actions spécifiques comme par exemple battre le boss avec une attaque en coopération ou bien battre tous les ennemis avant de battre le boss.
Un des gros points forts du jeu est sa BO qui est bien maîtrisée : de la musique 16-bits remastérisée au goût du jour avec des influences disco/funky très plaisante à écouter.
Les succès sont simples et se débloquent au fur et à mesure de vos parties mais il faut quand même s'accrocher pour le succès basé sur la difficulté "Corsé" qui vous demandera pas mal de patience.
Le jeu n'a pas beaucoup de défauts à moins que vous n'aimiez pas le "pixel'art" ou encore le côté redondant des missions qui s'enchâinent. D'ailleurs le jeu se finit assez rapidement (j'ai du mettre à peu près 5h pour finir le jeu une première en difficulté normale)
J'ai vraiment passé un bon moment dessus et je le reccomande vivement.

22715827.review:
🌟 Review [b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/26778369]4u[/url][/b]

Chroma Squad was one of the big surprises of 2015, impressive as a simple game can be so fun and interactive. Take so long to play it, but I've played it with the same feeling of a goty release.

🎥 Gameplay
2D game based on fighting in shifts. Chroma Squad has a unique and fun structure. At first it is even a bit overwhelming with the amount of attributes and differences that each character has, to summarize, you command a studio that is producing a superheroes serie, each actor has their skills and has something to more. It can be played only with the mouse and the gameplay with the control is a little hard to adapt.

🎥 Graphic
Pixelated, needless to comment on it. The market of games has proved that a game can be amazing even with simple graphic. Chroma Squad is no different, full pixel graphic is purposely nostalgic, with a palette of bright colors, the game reminds older movie titles, drawings and heroes series.

🎥 Plot
You and your friends are stuntmen in a studio commanding by a terrible director, he explores your services, don't give the deserve value to you and block you creatively, where the actors are just watching you work. Tired of it you decide to create your own studio. The fun on Chroma Squad is that each "episode" can be seen as a stage in the game, in the episodes you fight with several enemies through shifts, combining strategies, individual or cooperative attacks with the other members.

🎥 Soundtrack
Impressively nostalgic, they had success producing original tracks without losing the essence of the old songs. Hit that childhood longing to hear the opening song, the rest of the songs refer to 8bit style, they are instrumental and made an incredible treat. I leave here the link of the opening song, which was the most striking to me:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkrfCSyugnM

✔ 10/10 - Flawless game in all aspects, you feel quality in gameplay, graphics, music and plot itself. Behold Studios shows that the brazilian market has everything to compete with veteran companies in this business. Chroma Squad it's a mandatory title for nostalgic players.

Loin d'être un fan des tactical-rpg, les trouvant trop difficile pour moi, j'ai commencé Chroma Squad sans grand espoir, j'ai été attiré par son humour et sa mise en scène.

Et je suis resté tenu en haleine jusqu'à la fin, le scénario est vraiment interessant, avec de bons rebondissement, on retrouve tous les elements d'une série de sentai classique, avec beaucoup de reference et d'humour.

Le gameplay est vraiment top, on gère d'un côté son studio, de l'autre l'équipement et les compétences de ses acteurs, il y'a du craft qui reste négligeable, pas assez mis en avant. Le tour par tour marche super bien, les arènes sont bien faites.

Le seul défaut du jeu est les moments avec le mécha, vraiment répétitives, ils ont tendances à gacher le rythme, c'est dommage.

A part ça foncez sans hésitez, la bande son est excellente, une des meilleurs, ce jeu est un énorme coup de coeur et je le recommande. Depuis la dernière mise à jour il est dispo en français pour ceux à qui l'anglais rebute un peu.

Von Menschen in Gummiklamotten, die auszogen um die Herzen der Zuschauer zu erobern.

Eine geniale Mischung aus Power Rangers, Taktik RPG und Wirtschaftssimulation mit einem Schuss Casual Game in ansprechender Pixel Optik.

Wer früher Power Rangers mochte, kommt an diesem Spiel eigentlich nicht vorbei. In jedem Pixel steckt ganz viel Liebe zum Genre mit all seinen tollen Sachen aber auch mit seinen Albernheiten.

Man übernimmt ein Filmstudio und dreht eine Sentai Serie. Durch tolle Kämpfe bekommt man mehr Zuschauer und Fans, was einem genug Budget verschafft um aus Monstern in Pappkartons zu einem professionellerem Look verhilft.

Und nach und nach erstrahlt die Sentai Truppe immer mehr.

Sehr unterhaltsam und kurzweilig und mit ganz vielen kleinen Anspielungen auf die tollen Serien der 90er...

22448342.review:
Comme prévu, je modifie mon évaluation après avoir pu voir la fin du jeu. Pour info, j'ai été victime d'un bug qui m'a empêché de continuer le combat final. La phase étant très longue (sans être difficile), j'ai décidé de passer en facile pour réessayer et voir si le bug était encore présent. 
Après quelques mises à jour dont celle des langues ajoutées, j'ai pu voir une des fins. Le jeu est simple à comprendre avec un niveau correct d'anglais. La VF a l'air assez bonne pour le peu que j'en ai vu ( La fin en somme).

Pour en revenir au jeu, c'est un tactical RPG avec de la gestion dans un univers sentaï par le biais de la parodie. Un groupe de cascadeurs décident de monter leur propre studio pour faire une série type Power Rangers. Le scénario est bourré de références, souvent drôle même si je trouve qu'il se perd un peu quand le côté cheap et série télé s'efface pour un propos un peu plus "sérieux".

Le gameplay se décompose en deux parties : La gestion et les combats. La gestion suppose de s'occuper de son studio, son équipe et son mécha. Il y a du craft, des possibilités d'acheter directement de l'équipement et prendre une agence de marketing qui offre divers bonus. 
Cette partie est assez simple et permet de customiser pas mal de choses. Je conseille fortement de miser sur l'agence qui vous donnera le plus d'argent par épisode.
Les combats sont du tour par tour assez classique et facile d'accès : des pouvoirs, du cooldown (temps d'attente pour certaines attaques) des cases et de la coopération pour se déplacer plus loin ou faire des super attaques.
La partie en mécha est la moins réussie même si sympathique. Le fait d'appuyer au bon moment pour encaisser les coups en prenant le moins de dégats possibles est trop redondant. Sur cette partie, les développeurs sont tombés dans la facilité et le trop grand respect du genre empêche ses phases d'être intéressantes sur le long terme (La première ressemblera à la dernière). 

La durée de vie du jeu est d'une dizaine d'heures et la difficulté va en s'amenuisant parce que les Chrom Squad deviennent surpuissants rapidement. Pour pallier à cet écueil, les développeurs ont eu la très bonne idée de mettre des défis à chaque épisode (Le jeu est découpé en saisons qui contiennent des épisodes) pour gagner de l'audience (donc de l'argent pour les améliorations). Les défis consistent à respecter les consignes du réalisateur ( Dans chaque niveau, on peut voir l'équipe de tournage). Ils ne sont pas toujours simples à réaliser, mais apportent un vrai plus.

Graphiquement, c'est du pixel art de très bonne facture et la direction artistique respecte les codes du Sentai. En plus, ça tourne sur des configurations très modestes.


En résumé, Chroma squad devrait ravir les amateur de Sentai qui pourront s'amuser à customiser leur équipe et sourire voire rire devant les références disséminées dans le jeu. Pour les allergiques au genre, le délire est poussé trop loin pour adhérer même si le gameplay est très bon. 
Je regrette un peu que le jeu ne continue pas sur sa lancée du début après la moitié environ. Je ne peux pas dire qu'il se prend au sérieux, mais j'aurais aimé que le pitch de départ soit assumé jusqu'au bout (C'est pour chipoter).


P.S. : Il faut insister à la fin pour avoir droit à une petite surprise (prévisible, mais dans l'esprit du genre).

22392408.review:
A group of stuntmen of a sentai series decide to go indie after they get too annoyed with their boss' arrogance: starting from a small warehouse and using cardboard costumes you''ll be following their story in this tactical RPG.
Chroma Squas is not only a love letter to the sentai genre but also a very fun game to play thanks to its humourous story and gameplay straight out from the series it took as a model.

[b]PROS:[/b]

-quirky pixel art

-spot-on sentai-inspired soundtrack

-amusing plot backed by dialogues filled with references and humour

-story offers three branching paths that'll change scenes, bosses and even who joins your team

-the tactical combat is fun and offers a decent challenge, same goes for boss fights 

-studio management, crafting, a shop and a few unlockable skills all give a fair sense of progression

-nice length, took me 11 hours on Interesting difficulty

[b]NEUTRAL:[/b]

-the actual studio management options are pretty light on content

-gameplay stays basically the same and can get a bit trite

[b]CONS:[/b]

-mecha fights get dull after a bit

-could have used an "undo last move" button and an animation speed option

-randomness in crafting is annoying

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=664180217

The sentai genre is everywhere in the game..it's in the costumes, the moves you pull, the mecha fights against kaijus and the over the top dialogues: but Chroma Squad also breaks the fourth wall by letting you see the cameras and green screen or by chatting amicably with the extra in the boss costume before you fight them. Eventually you'll realize that maybe not everything is just a special effect but the game rarely abandons its humour and will keep throwing references your way. You'll also have to manage your studio by buying upgrades and deciding which contracts to sign for marketing: while studio upgrades are a straightforward "more is better" story ad agencies all provide different bonuses to fights/ audience/ money gained letting you customize your experience a bit.

Most fights feel fair and some can be easy as long as you upgrade your equipment and play decently but, at times, you might end up making a bad decision due to not being able to see whether an enemy'll be in range of your rifle or how far you'll be able to throw teammates before you actually move: this is where an undo button'd have worked wonders in case you misjudged a distance-which is not as hard as it sounds- or just misclick. Mecha fights are enjoyable at first but they get dull quite fast as you're basically just chaining a combo, doing the "click to defend" minigame on enemy turn, and unleashing a special move when needed: it's not bad per se but the number of fights and the repetitive gameplay make the novelty value fade fast. Last but not least the crafting system is a bit of a chore as you'll be using materials dropped from fights or bought to build new costume pieces and weapons, sadly they come with random properties so it's mostly luck based whether you'll be getting something decent or useless: in the end you can either reload your save and try again or just buy some all around decent stuff from the shop directly.

Chroma Squad offers a good amout of fun, if limited in variety, gameplay enriched by an amusing story and narrative: it's good entertainment made even better if you have even just a passing knowledge of the sentai genre.

22295474.review:
Bom como começar a falar dessa obra de arte? 

Chroma Squad é um jogo onde você controla 5 personagens (no meio do jogo você pode ou não, dependendo de sua decisão, ter 6 personagens) criando seu próprio estúdio de super sentai, onde você tem tudo customizável, dos bordões como trocar morfar por digevoluir, até o nome do estúdio. Essa é a premissa do jogo e com ela que você deverá fazer sucesso como estúdio, digo, salvar o mundo dos monstros.

Sempre curtia assistir super sentais quando mais novo (hoje em dia assisto de vez em nunca mais pra dar aquela nostalgia com a qual esse jogo soube brincar com maestria :D ),  eu também nunca me interessei por jogos táticos e não tinha jogado nenhum até então, e foi assim que conheci chroma squad numa stream da twitch.tv, de cara o jogo já me chamou muito a atenção pela arte, trilha e tema e quando descobri que era feito por brasileiros fiquei louco para jogar.

Agora depois de jogar todo o hype que eu tinha colocado no jogo foi atendido e superado, os easter eggs são dos mais variados tendo tantos que provavelmente vão ter alguns que vão passar despercebidos por você, ou por falta de conhecimento em algum tema não vai reconhe-lo, o sistema de batalha é bem simples e o jogo é bem fácil no fácil (parece uma piada mas no easy o jogo estava tão fácil que até eu que nunca joguei nenhum RPG tatico estava ganhando sem esforço, mudei a dificuldade até por isso) se quiser algum desafio joga pelo menos no médio, no hard ele é bem complicado no pouco que tentei, possui um sistema de gerenciamento bem simples mas bastante divertido te dando o controle do estudio para gerenciar, trilha sonora sensacional sempre te deixando no clima do jogo, artes em pixel art sensacionais, história "simples" porém empolgante como todo bom super sentai e personagens muito carismáticos, um dos melhores se não o melhor jogo brasileiro já desenvolvido.

Prós:
Gráficos (pixel arte muito bem feito) 
Trilha sonora
História (não é a melhor história do mundo mas ela cumpre precisamente seu papel)
Personagens
Gerenciamento 
Bem amistoso com novos jogadores de RPG Tático

Contras:

Único contra realmente que tenho é com um pequeno problema de queda de frame na hora da batalha de zord, como você precissa aperta na hora certa para defender, a pequena travada que ocorre as vezes faz você errar e tomar dano a mais por problema no jogo. Fora isso não vi mais nada a reclamar. 
 
Se você gosta de Super Sentai ou gostava quando menor, se curti um RPG tático ou quer experimentar um que seja amistoso, ou mesmo que não preencha nenhum dos requisistos sitados você tem que jogar essa delicia rsrsrs. Vale o valor cobrado (se tiver apertado espera um sale que se consegue ele pelo menos com uns 50% de desconto), se você não sair fazendo tudo apressadamente o game dura entorno de 20h. 

E é isso ai, jogo 10/10.

22279924.review: Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG where you use power ranger esque characters to fight monsters. so right off the bat it sounds awesome right? Well it is, it's really awesome but is it perfect? No. When the game is on the ground using its awesome sentai inspired battle system it sparkles like the sea. However each stage ends with a mecha fight, that is cool in theory but in practice it becomes a nightmare. Stages in this game usually take about an hour so after an hour of immensly satisfying tactical comabt where victory is decided by skill alone you are thrust into a situation where you could randomly lose all your progress and need to entirely restart the mission. This can leave you entirely dishearted as an hour of very intense gameplay can be thrown out the window. Aside from this however, the game is outstanding. looks great, sounds great and can lead to some very satisfying gameplay. You really should play this awesome game, but be ready from some seriously salty rage quits at the meccha battles.

21994269.review:
[h1]Go, go, Chroma Squad![/h1]

Chroma Squad is Power Rangers plus Disgaea. If you like one or both of those, I am 99% sure you will like this. If you do not know of either, then that is what the rest of this review is for!

I confess, I never watched Power Rangers or any sentai shows as a kid. But I do know the tropes quite well and have heard more than enough about them to get the gist. Chroma Squad is a love letter to those shows, and you should expect them to follow those standard formulas. I found it to be an absolute blast, especially as an SRPG lover. Take a look below to see all the reasons why.

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*]While I like SRPGs in general, this one hooked me and wouldn't let go. The gameplay is addicting. Every episode has different objectives and maps, and it is a lot of fun to figure out how to best impress your audience while winning the fight. It keeps the core gameplay strong while adding enough variables to make the on-foot fights fresh.
[*]There is a crafting system that  works well. You can make some nifty equipment with materials that randomly drop. Sometimes the shop equipment will be better, and you always receive gold after each level. So even if you bomb during a crafting session, you have good resources to fall back on.
[*]Grinding does not exist. There is no experience present, and the only thing you can earn from each level is randomly dropped items, which cap off at eight per level. I approve of the levels all being scaled by equipment per season, rather than by level. You can even mix up the order you play groups of episodes in!
[*]You have a lot of freedom with your characters. You can select different designs for the squad of five, name them, choose their skills, equip them accordingly, and make some great set-ups while utilizing a "role" structure. As a bonus, you get to name your studio, catch phrase, and robot, among other things.
[*]The story starts off a bit standard, but it evolves into a fun plot. The build-up is excellently done, and the development your characters get helps a lot. I grew very fond of my squad and was sad to finish their story, though happy with how it ended.
[*]There are three endings, and while I have only gotten one of them, I get the feeling they are each very different. Along with this, some choices come up throughout the plot that have an impact on the battles and story overall. It is great to have a reason to replay it beyond simply wanting to play it.
[*]Very good graphics all around! The characters look distinctive and have well-done designs, the giant robot and enemies look hardcore, and the TV screen openings/endings/loading screens are nice touches. It is a colorful game that is pleasing to the eye.
[*]The music is fan-ta-stic! The opening theme alone made me go, "Oh heck yes," and the rest of the game kept that quality. You can buy the soundtrack for $3.99, which is more than worth it. I know I'll pick it up when I have some more funds to spare.
[*]Of course you get a giant robot to fight in. Why wouldn't you? I like the way it works overall. Defending requires precise timing with your clicks, which is of a fair difficutly. But trying to hit the kaijus multiple times is problematic. I missed far more 70% opportunities than I hit with. Bad luck? Most likely, but it can be frustrating. I still call the robot fights a plus due to their epic feel and most of their mechanics, yet unlike the on-foot fights, there is not a whole lot of variation. The developers mentioned they want to strengthen this part of the game, which would be great.
[*]Speaking of the developers, they are very friendly people who take fan comments and suggestions into account. They are constantly striving to improve Chroma Squad. Having people like them as the creators of this game makes me think it will become even better. That is incredible to consider, given that they already have produced an amazing piece right here. Their tribute to sentai shows is masterfully executed, and I love their dedication to that.
[*]There are 43 achievements that you can get, and most of them are not too difficult. As a bonus, if you beat the game on a higher difficulty level, you get achievements for that level and all of the ones below it. I wish more games would do this instead of insisting you play on easy mode after beating hard mode, all for the sake of an achievement.
[*]Okay, look. You control a group of people in colorful suits fighting evil cupcakes, lawyers, irons, badgers, and television sets with martial arts, wacky weapons, and a giant robot made out of cardboard boxes. What else do I need to say to get you to buy this?[/list]

[b][u]Neutral:[/u][/b]
[list][*]The analog stick movement with the PS3 controller seems a bit floaty. I am not sure how it is for other types of controllers. Using the mouse keeps the movements sharp. Thankfully, this is not a game that requires quick analog movements, so it is not a big deal.
[*]Speaking of controllers, you can't use the controller for the kaiju fights. Again, not a big deal, especially since there are not many commands used in them. It is somewhat bothersome to have to set the controller aside, but the store page does say it is only partial controller support. My PS3 controller actually worked in every other situation (besides typing out the names for my heroes/studio,) so that was a pleasant surprise given that I wasn't sure how well it would respond.
[*]There is no New Game+. Some games are not suited for New Game+, but this one begs for it. The good news is that the developers have acknowledged the lack of a New Game+ and are trying to implement it. I would be very happy with that addition!
[*]What this game does have are multiple save files. I like this feature. The problem is that there is nowhere in the game that makes it obvious this is possible. I thought I would be erasing an old file when I started a new one, and only then learned it keeps multiple files.
[*]This game does have trading cards. They look nice and are a good addition for collectors.[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*]If you have more than a certain amount of weapons or armor in your inventory, you can only see a handful to equip. You can't scroll through them to get an older item if you want it. Since I like to have one copy of each item in most of my games, this drove me bonkers. You can still recycle the old items, you just can't get to them on the equip screen. Ugh!
[*]When using the keyboard controls, the mouse pointer shows over the game pointer. I don't know if there is a way to disable that. If there is, I couldn't find it. That is the main reason I used a controller, as when you are using the analog sticks instead, the mouse pointer vanishes.
[*]There are some spelling and grammar errors scattered throughout the game. Most of them are not that noticeable, and they do not interfere with the story, but they are worth mentioning. The oddest one I saw was weapons that you craft saying "any role" can use them, when in truth some are limited to certain roles.[/list]

[b]Overall experience:[/b]

I was excited to play this game, and it surpassed even those expectations. It satisfied me not only as an SRPG, but as a stand-out tribute to a great genre. It is charming, fun, and has fantastic spirit. I've beaten it once, but I plan to play it at least two more times. It's too good not to!

[b]Rating:[/b]

9/10. I was leaning toward 9.5/10, but there's a few issues that drag it down a little too much for me to give that precious half of a point. That being said? This game is awesome and playing it will make you feel more awesome as well. Join in on the sentai love and pick up Chroma Squad now!

21954935.review:
It isn't perfect, let's be honest there. It's not a perfect game.

It's got issues with difficulty, it's either a bit too trivial or a bit too hard. The mecha fights are too formulaic. There are rarely any real choices, usually just some very obvious right or good decisions, rather than alternatives. 

But despite all that, it's really fun. It hooked me in for the first playthrough, and I'm going back for a second and third because there are alternate endings(though the lack of any option to keep multiple saves DOES mean you need to replay the entire thing... which is kind of a shame). The soundtrack is unbeatably enjoyable and a lot of the jokes are just plain good. 

It's clearly a first-time product from an indie studio, it has rough edges, but you can feel that it's full of love despite it, and that makes you love it too. A definite buy if you like goofy humour, bright colours, good music, feel-good stories and isometric tactical combat.
