21848644.review:
Normally I'm fairly good at knowing which games I'll enjoy, and this is one of those rare exceptions that I was completely wrong with how I'd react. Halfway through the third act, I found myself floored, how could I not know that a tiny top down team tactics game would be drastically improved with the guise of recklessly cheap 90s nostalgia? 

For me, this game is like a restaurant, that I ate at for years- to the point where I got physically ill anytime you thought of it. It is this eatery, but years later, when I found out the chef has been indicted for serving criminally poor quality meals, and in some robust campaign I found myself back there, with a free meal coupon, and the new chef personally going out of their way to try and regain my patronage. 

It takes content from my childhood and under the guise of pointed satire, allowed me to appreciate the beauty of chintzy theatrics.

21756446.review:
The story certainly feels like a sentai, and I loved every minute of it. Gameplay was both fun and interesting. The "TEAMWORK" command is a wonderful unique feature that makes Chroma Squad stand out amongst tactical RPGs. I feel like they spend too much time with meta dialogue, but it doesn't affect the story in any way. 

My biggest problem is with the difficulty settings. There's too much of a difference between Easy, Medium, and Hard, and the difficulty shifts in weird ways between episodes. Medium was surprisingly effortless at times whereas Hard felt straight-up impossible during certain episodes. There's no grinding in the game, so to do well on Hard mode you need to be making the correct decisions at your studio (the management portion of the game) at all times. 

All in all, it's a great short RPG that is sure to bring fire to your soul. Also you get to customize your character's names, catchphrases, and battle moves so every time my team did a finishing blow they said "GANG UP ON THEM!" Which was nice.

21735961.review: While it's not the Power Rangers game of my dreams, I found a lot to like about Chroma Squad. I was originally turned off when I found out it was about running a TV show and not actually being Power Rangers, but it actually works. It's full of all the cheesy lines and scenarios fans of the old Power Rangers seasons will like, and people who have stuck with the show can appreciate the love and knowledge of the franchise and it's tropes went into this game. I'm not particularly a fan of strategy games and I'm not really good at them, so I found this game pretty difficult on normal, but fans of the genre might find it too easy. Still, I really enjoyed all of the customization, the multiple storylines, and found the game overall to very enjoyable.

21598695.review:
TL; DR: If you like X-COM style tactical RPGs, this is a pretty fun and light spin on it.  The game has some rough edges, but is a solid all around tactical RPG.

Long Version:

If you're into tactical RPGs like X-COM, then this is a fun 10-15 'light' experience.  The angle (you're stuntmen from a Power Rangers-esque TV show that get in a fued with the director and decided to start a new show) is original and can be pretty amusing.  For better or worse, you can fast forward through most the story.  I wish there was an in between, where you could read the cupious amount of story text quickly without reverting to warp speed, but it's either painfully slow or hyper speed.  The other thing holding the game back is a bit of UI/tutorial polish.  The game, especially in the beginning, rapidly unlocks new features, but never really even tells you they're there, let alone what everything means.  It's not a deal breaker, but I could imagine going through significant chunks of the game without realizing some suped up ability or item was available.

The other drawback of the game is the QTE Mecha mini-game that ends many of the episodes.  You basically are given a % chance to hit on a punch, to continure your combo, and have the option to switch to defense or lay a power move on.  Needless to say, you will feel the burn of the RNG when you miss 3 or 4 consecutive ~75% swings, each time taking massive damage because you can't properly defend when you miss.  You thene have a little bar that you have to click when it's in the right zone to deflect as much damage as possible.  I only 'lost' 3 or 4 times playing through the game, and every time it was in the mecha game.  Kudos for trying to mix it up with a different paced bit, but it's too rough around the edges, especially compared to the relatively tight tactical RPG play.

Speaking of the 'RPG' aspect, they are definitely on the lite side.  No XP, you just unlock the next level of the skill tree when you complete each season.  No mana points either, everything is done on a x-com style cool down system (also, there is no ammo, everything can be used as many times as it cools down).  There is crafting, though it's not very well explained.  The advantage of crafting is that the gear has a few set attributes, plus a few random attributes to it that MAY make it better than the items you just buy outright.  But you never know until you craft it, and you can't compare a craft item to your current gear until you actually make it.  You also have to combine lower craftable items into better items, and then better items again, to be able to craft the good stuff.  This, again, is never really explained and buried on a submenu - I didn't know I could do it until Season 5 (of 6), and until then, I was confused on what the point of a crafting system was when you never got the materials you needed to craft.  Turns out, I had plenty, but I had to combine my 75 rolls of regular tape into 15 rolls of silver tape, and then those 15 rolls into 5 rolls of gold tape...which I could then use to buy the pimp stuff.

If tactical RPGs are your thing, this is a nice light experience.  I imagine it has pretty low system specs, so it would probably be good on a laptop, though the Unity engine chugs occassionally, especially during the mecha scenes.  Definitely worth picking up for a few bucks or in a Humble Bundle.

21574757.review:
I friend gifted me this game so I just wanted to shout out a big thanks to him!

This game... is awesome. I love the concept. Created by Behold Studios, Chroma Squad is essentially a Power Rangers management sim. You get to make your own squad and customize your team to fit your desires of having one of the best or lamest Sentai teams ever!

The story is that a bunch of stuntmen quit their old job because they believe their director lacks creativity and want more creative freedom. The plot really goes off the rails later on but it's fun to watch. The dialogue of your team is super corny but I loved it however if that's not your thing then it might be something to consider if you're planning on getting Chroma Squad. The dialogue is filled with puns, references and enough fourth wall jokes to make Deadpool blush.

Visually it looks nice, it's some nice pixel graphics. I don't think they use it as a lazy excuse since it's nice good to look at and there is detail in the game. Not the heaviest but enough to distinguish everything easily. The music is personally one of the best parts of the game. This is some really good chiptune music, it has some great soundtracks that get you pumped up for a boss battle and my personal favourite "This is Cerebro" is so campy and so catchy. 

The gameplay itself, when fighting is a tactical RPG. A pretty fun one, the game has an emphasis on team attacks which is pretty cool and works with the theme. You got abilities and cool weapons for the different classes to play around with and a cool chunk of bosses. You also get finishing moves for them which is pretty sweet as well. One thing that does bother me a bit is that a lot of the time the game can be too easy but then there is a huge difficulty spike in the last level. What is that all about?

When not in normal combat you're doing one of two things. The first is managing your studio, it's fun as you have to upgrade the studio, buy or craft new gear, hire agencies to promote your show, check emails and all that managment sim stuff. The other is the mech combat. It wouldn't be Power Rangers without a giant mech battle in almost every episode. It can be fun but really it just comes down to chance whether attack or block attacks. It looks cool but it's pretty shallow.

To conclude my mad ramblings I of course like this game a lot! It's one of those games I wished I played earlier when it came out last year. If you understand the basic core material you'll have a lot of fun with it.  If you've never heard of Power Rangers AT ALL or know exactly ziltch about it then I wouldn't reccommend this to you. Otherwise you should definitely get it! It's a game that's about having fun rather than being amazingly unique or difficult (for the most part). I give this an 8.5/10

21287751.review:
Simple Turn-based tactics RPG that brings in a few unique mechanics to the genre.

Gameplay straddles a fine line between making things intuitive but not too simple while giving you just enough but not too much stuff to play around with. The crafting system is multiple layers of RNG buggery and it leaves me with a sour taste in my mouth sometimes.  You can work around it but meh.
The pacing is fairly on point and the game never really overstays its welcome.

There are Super Robot Fights, though it's easily the weakest part of the game currently.  They're also gathering feedback and have announced an overhaul, so this point may become moot in a couple of months.

Aesthetics are colorful with a strong indie feel (it's an indie, kickstarted game so yeah).  16 bit and the like.

The writing assumes that you've watched at least 2-3 episodes of power rangers and have a passing knowledge of certain internet memes that came out within a specific timeframe (I had to google a couple things).  I enjoyed it.  It has the right kind of corn and ham that'll get me to sensibly chuckle most of the time.
and again, the pacing is pretty strong despite the source material.

I highly recommend configuring your super sentai team away from the defaults to fit your preferences as it can greatly improve your gameplay experience.  My team was called the Rude Rollers, they Rolled Out, and my robot was named Pablo Escobar (he shanked giant monsters).

A single run may take like 6-8 hours and there are multiple endings.

21185547.review:
The game far exceded my expectations.
I don't need to tell you about the graphics, either you like the chosen style or you don't. FWIW I think they did a great job of having consistent high-quality pixel art. 
The sound track is great too!
Story is good, has multiple endings (and the game play is good enough to go through and get them all), good humor, and if you are there just for the tactics, there is a fast-forward though the dialogue.
Game play is excellent.
When I first recieved this game my expectations were that it would be good, but not great, but I figured I might as well give it a try, since I got it.  My intent was to play for just half an hour before bed, since I had to get up early the next day.  The next time i had bothered to look at a clock, nearly four hours had passed. I'll take the old addage about time flying as objective evidence that the game is fun as heck. Since building my new gaming rig, I have actually played it more than any other game.
The game is not perfect.  I have encounted a few bugs (nothing that made it crash, and any complicated software will end up with at least one small bug.)
The games i play over multiple times is limited, this one easily made the short list.
You don't have to be a fan of any of the tv shows that inspired the game, or particularly fond of turnbased strategy games to find the game enjoyable. 
The hard difficuly offers a challenge and rewards a strategical approach, medium is more forgiving. It is a game that i think is accessible to a wide audience. For its target audience it offers nostolgia, but It is not inappropriate for younger audiencies and gameplay is approachable to anyone.

Esse jogo foi minha introdução ao Steam. Comprei por indicação de um amigo, que havia indicado a outros 3 (cujos viciaram). Após muito esforço, consegui enfim comprar meu primeiro jogo e me impressionei.

Esse simplesmente é um dos melhores jogos que já tive o prazer de jogar. Um RPG tático/em turnos com história profunda, personagens incríveis, vilões fodas e muito mais. A trilha sonora remonta as musiquinhas dos tokusatsus nos anos 80 e o gráfico totalmente 8-bit simplesmente é um deleite.

Admito que esse jogo me introduziu aos tokusatsus (meu amigo é fanático, mas eu não me interessava muito) e consegui perceber uma nostalgia imensa. Eu imaginava os episódios da série Bioman como episódios que um dia gravei em Chroma Squad... é tudo tão parecido. Os vilões, as trilhas, os heróis, os diálogos. Esse jogo simplesmente é a representação perfeita de como um tokusatsu real deveria ser: um tesouro no meio de tantos jogos brasileiros desconhecidos. Temos episódios variados, batalhas de Kaiju, vilões alienígenas, referências sem fim, enredos hilários e muito mais.

Em resumo, Chroma Squad é uma relíquia indie brasileira e deve ser jogado não só por todos que se interessam em tokusatsus (Ultraman, Super Sentai, Power Rangers, Sharivan, Gavan, etc), como por qualquer um que gostar de um bom e divertido jogo.

Excerpt:

After enough grief from their director, five talented stunt actors decide to take matters into their own hands, starting their own studio and action-packed TV show. Where Millennials like myself had the Power Rangers back in the ’90s, Behold Studios gives us Chroma Squad, a tactical RPG where you control this quintet of do-gooders in their rise to glory–or at least television fame.

Packed with a ton of tongue-in-cheek, fourth-wall-breaking humor and its obvious impersonation of Power Rangers, Chroma Squad is all about nostalgia in its style and delivery. With its pixelated sprites and loading screens that “warm up” and adjust like an old tube television when you’re starting a new episode, this is the kind of game that would go great with pajamas and a bowl of cereal on a Saturday morning.

21012108.review:
Wonderful little tactical RPG game where you control a team of actors with their own show where they fight monsters, which starts coming true as time goes on.

The meat of the game is the tactical turn based combat, and as someone who really enjoys this type of gameplay this is right up my alley. There are also some RPG elements outside of combat, such as allocating skill points, crafting and buying upgrades.

After completing most maps you join together and go into a giant mecha to fight the boss of the map again, with a different combat style which is focused on timing the hits and using a limited number of different abilities. This is a nice addition for the first few times, however it is not nearly as fleshed out and feels like an after thought. And seeing as how you have to do a bunch of these fights I'm quite sure everyone will get tired of them before the end of the game.

The story is reasonably entertaining, although it can become tiresome to follow since it is delivered solely through text boxes of the main characaters, and you have to wait for each one to finish scrolling in order to move on to the next one. So if you read much faster than the game scrolls then you're going to have to do a lot of waiting. There is an option to fast forward through everything, however it is not really useful if you still want to follow the story since the fast forward skips everything.

And the game does go a little overboard with the pixel artstyle, I certainly would have liked more definition and fluid animations. Also the overall design starts to become stale with time, especially since this is quite a long game.

I would easily recommend Chroma Squad to any fan of the tactical turn based combat style.

7 / 10

20999807.review: Ótimo jogo. Bem uhumorado, com elementos clássicos de RPG e com a história que agrada qualquer fã de Super Sentais e Power Rangers.

20984370.review: Chroma Squad is a Tactical RPG game made by Behold Studios, creators of the mobile game, Knights of Pen and Paper, an RPG that is more pressing buttons that movement. Now you'd think that this would make it hard for them, seeing as they're pretty much doing nothing the same. If you do, get out. This game is packed with humor, references, and breaking of the fourth wall. And while most people hate breaking the fourth wall, it's done in a way where if you literally are paying no attention, you will not see it. And if you're going into this game using the internet for the first time, the references to pop culture and video games will definitely fly over your head, but if you know the internet like the back of your hand, every reference will make you laugh, and there are a lot. The game play is simple, you have two actions you can do with every character every turn, and you can switch between who you're using by clicking their box, or using both of the above player's actions. Each "class" has their own unique set of skills, with customization diverse enough so that there is very little repetition. A lot of this game's achievements can be accomplished on the first run, but to get them all you will have to play the game at least three times. And if you get stuck, the community has already figured them out. After you beat the game, I reccomend sticking around after the credits for each run, and you will be pleased by what comes after, but stick around until you get forced out of them to get information that will complete the story more and more. Now buy the game and get to playing. #FrendshipIsForever

It’s a tactical RPG with base-building strategy elements that follows the story of five stuntmen who leave their second banana positions to make their own martial arts TV show. Like Knights of Pen and Paper, Chroma Squad has retro-inspired graphics and music, and spends a lot of time breaking the fourth wall and poking fun at pop culture tropes.

I personally felt that Knights of Pen and Paper, while it had some charm, went on for far too long without shaking anything up, ultimately weakening what might have been a charming experience by overstaying its welcome. And while Chroma Squad sometimes suffers from a similar affliction, I feel that Behold Studios learned a hell of a lot, tightening and producing an RPG that is just plain fun to play.

20811506.review:
Pros:
[list]
[*]Customize your team with various actors, each with their own strengths and weaknesses.
[*]Further customize your characters with various stat-increasing gear choices and weapon types.
[*]Responding to emails seems to provide variation in the storyline, or just give you goodies or fans.
[*]Upgrade your base to provide various buffs to your team.
[*]Optional crafting system; just buy from the store if you can't be bothered.
[*]Winning the fight is only part of the game; try to maximize audience, fans, and income as well.
[*]Light-hearted, otherworldly story with plenty of comedy.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]Only five party members and predetermined classes limit team customization.
[*]Unable to cancel your movement action, even if you haven't taken any other actions; annoying if you misclick a location, or misjudge distance for a ranged attack.
[*]Characters don't level up, only gaining skills and stats from equipment and progressing through the story "seasons"
[*]Since characters don't level up, and you can't rerun past content for money or crafting components, you can't grind to level up and make the game easier on yourself even if you want to.
[*]You can only see tile markers on tiles you can move or attack to, sometimes making it difficult to judge positioning for ranged attacks.
[*]You cannot customize whether UP is Up-Left or Up-Right if using a gamepad; you just have to get used to it.
[/list]

A goofy, lovable Turn-based Strategy that reminds me of Disgaea. A type of game all too rare on PC. Definitely recommend to fans of Turn-based Strategy games such as Disgaea or Final Fantasy Tactics.

20762810.review:
A light tactical RPG for people who appreciate making robots out of buckets. Not terribly difficult, but also not very deep.

The game starts very slow, but picks up considerably about seven hours in. This game scratched an itch, but might be too little, too late for some people. I'd recommend waiting for a sale.

More in depth, I'm a little disappointed with the tactical depth of combat. There aren't many ways to mitigate damage during combat. It feels like enemies can attack at arbitrary ranges and move across the map at will. All-out attack is usually the best option, tempered only by the games scoring system, which encourages drawing fights out longer. Even seven hours in, I only have access to one crowd control skill, and very limited area attacks.

The crafting system seems expansive, but the game is very stingy with crafting materials, which is a problem for the mech combat minigame. I found myself buying items from the shop just to try breaking them down into spare parts. I really wish there was a way to buy the materials you need from the shop. Collecting drops from enemies seems contrary to the theme of the game--why am I making the lead's costumes out of scraps from the extra's costumes? Where are the extras getting their costumes, if I have to craft the main characters'?

20625906.review:
Chroma Squad é uma bela homenagem aos sentais que muitos assistimos quando crianças e hoje não se vê mais. Parece que até o detalhe do gráfico ser "16 bits" acaba remetendo a essa nostalgia. O jogo é bem colorido, cheio de vida e piadas realmente engraçadas. Tudo tenta ser bem único e com aquele estilo e detalhe próprio.

A trilha sonora, que excluindo a música do menu, não conta com músicas instrumentadas ou cantadas. Tudo remete a uma decada onde os poucos bits forçavam os desenvolvedores a trabalhar em sons com "ritmos digitais". De certa forma, a trilha do Chroma é muito show, a musica do vilão, principalmente, gruda como chiclete... ^_^  O detalhe gráfico do jogo é muito bacana, por mais minimalista que tenta ser, os detalhes em coisas que muitos nem ligariam estão lá. Acho que o pecado só fica pela roupa do Squad, que independente se o personagem for mulher, homem ou "ser", o sprite do herói fica igual. A história é muito boa, sem dar spoiler, você começa achando bem boba e engraçada, pra não dizer uma paródia completa dos sentais, porém da temporada 3 em diante o caldo começa a engrossar e o tom fica mais sério, não abandonando o humor completamente.

Das coisas que não gostei, foi a diferença de dificuldade. No modo Fácil, as coisas vão seguindo naturalmente sem esforço até o chefão final. No Normal, só dificulta mesmo na última temporada. O Difícil é extremamente injusto. Eu fiquei com a sensação que o difícil do jogo é a continuação do normal, porque a dificuldade já começa mais elevada que no Normal, o que dificulta a curva de aprendizagem significativamente. Senti falta também de episódios que ficam de fora conforme a dificuldade. São poucas mudanças, mas que acabam deixando o jogo mais curto. Tratando-se de um jogo tão divertido, chegar ao final sem ver tudo é um pouquinho frustrante.

O jogo realmente cativou meu coração, a nostalgia foi acertada em cheio. Acho que Chroma Squad tem tudo pra receber continuação, a criatividade os desenvolvedores tem, só faltam polir mais a experiencia para ela ser mais divertida e nada frustrante. Comprei por 17 reais, na época era um desconto de 50% se não me engano, e valeu cada centavo! Foi um dos primeiros jogos que zerei na Steam e até fiz a análise, mas relendo achei bem abaixo do que eu poderia falar sobre a experiencia. kkk  Enfim, compre sem pensar duas vezes se você curtir um pouco de RPG tático, a experiencia deste aqui foi a melhor experiencia no gênero que eu tive. Espero que quem venha a jogar tenha a mesma experiencia!

Joguei no Linux, Ubuntu 14.10 e 16.04, e o jogo ainda hoje conta com bugs nas roupas e em algumas falas, que ficam pretas do nada e ficam em inglês, mesmo em português, respectivamente, porém não estraga o gameplay.

20572272.review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Chroma Squad is a turn-based action RPG game that revolves around a group of [strike]Power Rangers[/strike] stunt actors, who are acting Power Rangers. They are unhappy with their director and with the studio where they are taking the show, so they make their own, Chroma Squad! The story might have few surprises for you but the main thing are the references and jokes, you'll find many of those.

Gameplay is classic for turn-based action games, with exception of acrobatics - a character can hold a position so another character can ricochet himself farther (closer to your target enemy). You can expect about 30 levels (split into 5 "seasons"), with repeating basic enemies but original bosses, which will make you laugh and, some later ones, might make you a little angry. You have to try hard.

But I don't want to scare you, I've played on "Interesting" difficulty (take it as normal) and I think it was perfectly balanced experience. I had times where I've almost didn't beat the level (last [strike]man[/strike] Power Ranger standing!) and I've never felt the game was too easy, so I always felt motivated to do my best.

Anyway, Chroma Squad would totally suck if they weren't able to form into a huge mech. And guess what, you will have a mech action too! But don't get too excited for that, mech fights have completely different fight rules, there is no positioning strategy and your attacks are based on your luck.

Visuals are presented in neat pixelart style, combined with nice sound effect and soundtrack, which contains even a Japanese theme song! Everything gets you to the right mood pretty fast, so you can enjoy everything developers made - and there's a lot of content to see.

Chroma Squad is definitely worth recommending, I've enjoyed it for more than 10 hours and might even try to play it later again on higher difficulty for another endings. If you are looking for  turn-based RPG, pixelart and want many pop culture references, you'll love it!

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- [b]Extensive system of skills, upgrades, items and crafting[/b]. You'll spend minutes in management windows between fights and you won't mind it at all! 
- [b]Well-made turn RPG and strategy gameplay[/b]. 
- [b]Funny dialogues[/b] that perfectly fits into the silly story of stuntmen running a TV show, that changes their lives.
- [b]Specific unique tasks for every single battle[/b]. So if you think it's too easy, try to do something more and complete them - you'll be more popular, if you can do it.
- [b]Fair pixelart graphics[/b].
- [b]Doesn't get repetitive[/b]. There are many mobs that are getting reused pretty often but you can (on most levels) expect a new and original boss with his unique skills. Also, every season, each of your characters get a new skill!
- More difficulties, more endings.
- Good sound effects and soundtrack.
- Steam achievements.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- [b]Kaiju fights[/b]. They are too much based on luck, you just see your % chance to hit your enemy... and hope you'll hit it.

20489646.review:
Decided to grab this game since I liked Tactics RPGs, and wanted something bright and colorful. Came into the game with pretty "meh" expectations and was blown out of the water.

As someone who watched Power Rangers when I was little, this game is an absolute nostalgia trip, while at the same time parodying a lot of the tropes of the sentai genre. The game starts with the protagonists getting a tutorial from their overbearing boss before quitting to form their own sentai studio. You get to name all your rangers, choose their colors (Even if the palette is rather limited), their mecha, their catchphrases, etc. Though this has no impact on gameplay whatsoever, it adds nicely to the fantasy of running your own show. 

Gameplay is a relatively simple TRPG where you can only have one of each class, Assist, Tech, Assault, Scout, and Lead. This prevents a lot of the cheese strategies that are common in TRPGs like Fire Emblem and Final Fantasy Tactics. This game's difficulty in actual fights is usually pretty low. Instead the difficulty comes from getting your Audience meter filled up and then keeping it filled. The best way to fill it up is by doing flips, team moves, special attacks, and Director's Instructions, which are special submissions that can range from "Don't lose any of your team members" to "win in 5 turns" to "Defeat the boss before defeating any minions." The gameplay, despite being turnbased, really does a great job of showing how a sentai show usually plays out, and its very easy to see how cool everything would look to the eyes of a child watching the show at home. The only major gameplay flaw is that my scout always felt useless. Next to the rapid-fire skills of the Tech, the massive healing from the Assist, the raw damage and acrobatics bonus of the Assault, and the tankiness of the Lead, the Scout... moves an extra space every turn. This would be alright if his damage were anything special, but either my choice of actor or gear for my scout meant that he was consistently doing less damage than the healer. Though the scout does get several crowd control abilties, they all require him to be in the midst of battle, and the Scout's frailty means that these are very risky to use past Season 3.

Graphics are psuedo 16-bit, bright colorful and cheery graphics with some great sprite art. Not quite on the same level as Undertale's sprite art, but its all still very appealing. Boss designers are all unique and, with a few exceptions, creative. Though you'll be fighting in th same 7 or so locals a lot, I'm willing to write that up as part of the parody. Besides, the locations are all great looking and have enough functional differences from one another to keep you on your toes.

That's not to say the game is perfect. While the game is generally humorous, there are more than a few spots where I felt as though the game was expecting me to laugh and I didn't. Mecha fighting is pretty boring and one dimensional, and is usually the worst part of any mission its included in, which is a shame since a lot of its moves and parts are references to Mecha anime like Gurren Lagann and NGE, references I would appreciate a lot more if it wasn't part of the most boring part of the game. There's crafting, which is already a very played out mechanic that seems to pop up in every game nowadays, but at least here it fits the fantasy of everything on a sentai show being handmade and crappy looking. There's also multiple things that seem to ride the line between satire and unironic crapiness. When you reach Season 3, most of that season's plot revolves around your Lead growing an ego, which is a trite and boring plot line used in every sentai show ever. Are you trying to make fun of these trite and boring plots, Chrome Squad, or was your plot for Season 3 just trite and boring? Or did I just answer my own question?

Despite those flaws, I'd be wrong if I said this game was bad. The game just has so much heart and dedication put into it, the gameplay is fun, the visuals were colorful and the plot is meta-tastic goofiness. While the game didn't make me burst out laughing or bawl my eyes out, it was just so delightful I can't help but recommend it. If you love Tactics RPGs or Sentai shows, consider it a double recommendation.

20483956.review: I was iffy to buy this game based on the theme and trailer. Next thing I know it's 1 AM and I wonder where the last three days went. The developers did a really fantastic job on story, design, concept, and gameplay. My only complaint is the big mech battle scenes can be choppy sometimes.

20483204.review:
Eu já me interessava bastante por esse jogo antes mesmo dele ser lançado, pois eu sou um amante dos dois típos de gameplay que esse jogo engloba.

Chroma Squad é uma união perfeita entre os jogos de estilo "Tycoon" onde o jogador ao invés de ser um personagem no jogo, é um manager, que apenas organiza tudo, com os jogos de RPG estratégico, onde o gameplay de batalhas se torna uma versão um tanto avançada do Xadrez.

Além disso, o jogo vem carregado com uma carga enorme de nostalgia, pois a história do jogo remete aos seriados de Super Sentai que fizeram parte da minha infância e de muitas outras pessoas. Como eu tinha dito, metade de Chroma Squad é um jogo do estilo Tycoon, onde você se torna responsável por organizar e controlar um estúdio indie de um Super Sentai. Isso envolve desde reunir materiais como massinha de modelar/fita adesiva para "craftar" os equipamentos dos personagens, a fazer upgrades no estudio, como comprar lanternas melhores, fazer contratos com agências de publicidade etc. e tal.

Quanto à outra metade, Chroma Squad é um jogo de RPG Estratégico. Você tem controle de 5 personagens de um Super Sentai, cada um com suas próprias habilidades e estilo de jogo. As batalhas ocorrem em torno de um sistema de audiência (afinal, é um seriado), onde as ações dos personagens aumentam a audiência do episódio, que no final entram como fãs e lucros para o estúdio para compra de equipamentos e upgrades. Como o mesmo visa emular um seriado, o gameplay é dividido em episódios, e assim como nos Super Sentais, quase sempre terá um "Boss Monster" no final de cada episódio. 

Em alguns episódios também haverão as Mecha Battles, nas quais os heróis "pilotam um robô" para lutar com uma versão gigante do monstro. O robô em si também é uma parte do estilo Tycoon, visto que você pode equipar diferentes "partes" com diversos efeitos nele. Apesar de ter uma boa proposta, é uma parte do jogo que ficou um tanto mal executada, pois é altamente baseada em RNG e se o jogador não tiver sorte pode acabar tendo mais dificuldade do que deveria

Além disso tudo, o jogo também segue rotas. Em vários momentos do jogo o player terá que fazer escolhas e essas escolhas podem afetar negativa ou positivamente o estúdio, e inclusive alterar a história do jogo. O jogo em si tem 3 finais totalmente diferentes os quais os jogador pode conseguir, de acordo com as escolhas, apesar de que não dá pra considerar nenhum deles "Good Ending" ou "Bad Ending" pois todos os finais são únicos a sua própria maneira.

Chroma Squad além da óbvia referência ao mundo dos Super Sentais, também possui vários easter eggs e referências sutis (ou não tão sutis) ao universo da "cultura pop", tornando o gameplay um tanto mais divertido pra o jogador que as entender.
O playtime apesar de tudo não é muito longo nem muito curto. Uma run na dificuldade normal, onde o jogador provavelmente não tem que refazer nenhum episódio, raramente passa das 20h, o que dá por volta de umas 60h se o jogador quiser pegar os 3 finais possíveis.
Também vale mencionar que o jogo como se espera de um Tycoon, é altamente customizável, de forma que você pode escolher quem serão os personagens que irão compor o time, os seus nomes, o nome do esquadrão, o nome do golpe finalizador do esquadrão e até mesmo o nome do "MegaZord". Na minha opinião isso incrementa bastante o replay value do jogo.

No geral
Pros
-Gameplay estilo Tycoon
-Gameplay estilo RPG Estratégico
-História envolvente
-Escolhas que afetam o gameplay e a história

20398824.review:
Juego homenaje al género sentai ( las series japonesas rollo Power Rangers de toda la vida ) en que llevamos la carrera de uns especialistas de acción que deciden emprender su propia serie. Cada capítulo es una misión que se juega en formato tactics RPG. Aquí no hay niveles de personajes, sino audiencia. Cuanto más espectacular de las batallas, más audiencia, más dinero, más posibilidad de mejorar nuestro equipo técnico ( plató y demás ) y el equipo de nuestros guerreros. ¡ Y además tienes un mecha !

Lo malo, es que aunque todas las mecánicas del tactics RPG habitual estén perfectamente integradas dentro su propuesta paródica, el humor de sus diálogos y situaciones no suple unos combates repetitivos y faltos de profundidad. Lo que parece divertido y simpático las primeras horas, acaba por convertirse en tediosa rutina, sobretodo los mal balanceados combates con el mecha. 

Esperaba divertirme mucho más, bien fuera por los combates o su humor, pero a poco que avanzan las horas, pierde toda la chispa y se queda en una mera curiosidad para la posteridad.

20377615.review:
I wanted Final Fantasy Tactics in Sentai suits and was not disappointed!

No seriously, I'm calling [b]Chroma Squad[/b] a must-buy in terms of tactical RPGs. At worst, the scenarios get kinda samey, the mecha battles are more luck-based than anything, Scout class needs work in terms of role within the team and the meme-based humour might get under some delicate skins. Never mind the details; as a tactical RPG, Chroma Squad gets everything right and even dares some neat ideas concerning character statistics, combat and the money/audience system.

What I'm saying is there's a deepness to the game despite the apparent simplicity of the setting, with clear character roles and a certain leeway in how you want them optimized. The love for the genre is genuine and goes a long way in enhancing your experience; it's more than just shooting aliens as in X-Com. Building an audience to gain money and better toys is a welcome change from XP grinding. The grid movement can be unforgiving what with the inability to take back a move but I feel as this just adds to the challenge factor.

In short: the core of the gameplay is great and the further you get from the tactical RPG, the worse it gets. I can't fault a game for false notes when it's just being overly ambitious. An original backdrop for an RPG, multiple story paths, clever insertion of Kickstarter backers into the story and the fact I've encountered no game-breaking bugs despite a Report button makes me want to heavily endorse this product. An example for other Kickstarter-funded game developers.

20133082.review:
I wanted to like this game. The concept of former stuntmen making their own TV studio that you control mixed in with strategy RPG combat was a fresh idea in a landscape full of zombie survival games and minecraft clones. But having just finished the game, it failed to deliver on so many levels.

PROS:
- Great overall concept.  Run a TV studio while having your stuntment meet certain criteria in strategy RPG battles.
- The art style is interesting and has character.  The costumes pay homage to the various costumes seen in shows like Power Rangers.
- The music works well enough for what it is.

CONS:
- The studio management aspect of the game is very under developed.  Most of the choices, from the type of camera you use to the marketing agency that you hire, are shallow and don't offer more than slight bonuses here and there.  For example, you can have your marketing agency put up your actors for an award, but all that will do is increase your fan power, which is used to activate marketing agency policies.
- Objectives in battle could have been more varied.  As it is, there are 3 primary objectives that you'll see:  1. Kill X amount of enemies, maybe with Y time; 2. Kill the boss with a team member/team attack/finishing move; 3.  Keep everyone alive/above 50% health.   This is disappointing because, being a TV show that you make, you could have gone with more interesting objectives, especially if you the player could set them.
- The writing is not very good.  The story seems to be unsure on whether it wants to play a particular scene straight or comically, and so flip flops between the two extremes awkwardly.  In addition, the story progression is very clunky and poorly executed.
- The game is unfunny.  Most of the "humor" comes from blatant references to pop culture outside of the genre (such as a Robocop/Tiger hybrid.  That's it, that's the joke), with a smattering of poorly constructed puns to tie it all together.
- The localization is not very good.  The game was clearly translated by somebody that does not have very good command of the English language, as much of the text and dialogue just reads wrong to a native English speaker.  Getting a decent writer would fix this and some of the previous issue.

20075580.review:
Chroma Squad es un RPG táctico delicioso visualmente. Consigue un estilo retro-pixel adaptado a las resoluciones modernas, de forma que no veremos horteradas como sprites feos y estirados debido al redimensionamiento.

Nuestros personajes son dobles de acción de una serie rollo Power Rangers que un día deciden montar su propio estudio. Así el juego gira alrededor del subgénero Sentai (famoso en Japón y, por alguna razón, Brasil). Para mejorar las stats de nuestros personajes equiparemos armas y ropa de atrezzo que irán mejorando en la calidad de sus materiales. El dinero lo obtenemos a través de la audiencia, que a su vez aumenta cada vez que seguimos las instrucciones del director o realizamos acrobacias.

Tal vez la mayor pega sea que el combate no es todo lo profundo que podría ser. No existen elementos como el nivel del terreno, la posición de tu personaje ni las armas a distancia excluyendo habilidades que puedes usar cada X turnos. Echo de menos una mayor variedad en las habilidades y una mayor diferenciación entre las clases. 

Sin embargo también ofrece elementos únicos, como las peleas de mechas y el comando de Teamwork, que permite realizar acciones de colaboración para hacer piruetas y saltar más lejos o combinar fuerzas para lanzar un ataque más poderoso.

Chroma Squad entra fácil, se digiere bien y deja un fantástico sabor de boca.

Chroma Squad é um jogo brasileiro que veio do Kickstarter com seu estilo memorável em 32 bits, nele você terá o controle de 5 atores/dublês que após se irritarem com um diretor, todos se demitem e resolvem juntos abrir um estúdio e criar eles mesmo uma nova série de Tokusatsu, com lutas contra monstros fantasiados e tudo mais. 
O Destaque do jogo está em seu gameplay que se divide em duas partes, a primeira parte, você deverá controlar os 5 personagens numa esquema tático em turnos (tipo Xcom/Banner Saga) para derrotar os inimigos, e a segunda parte, você deverá controlar o orçamento do estúdio, pois com seu dinheiro ganho através dos episódios filmados, você poderá comprar iluminação do estúdio e outras melhorias que dão bônus nas batalhas, porém também terá que se preocupar com os equipamentos dos seus personagens. A Música combina muito com todo estilo do jogo, animado e cheios de lutas. 
O jogo avança em sua dificuldade sem frustrar ninguém, as batalhas exigem mais estratégia e o controle da finanças fica um pouco mais complexo, o que realmente decepciona é o desenvolvimento da história que é lento mas nada que tire a diversão do jogo.

19932905.review:
Combining pros and cons, because you should know what you like in a game and what you would rather not want to see.

[u]Go:[/u]
[list]
    [*]It has 8-bit graphics.
I myself have gotten quite weary over retro-pixely graphics. But I also know that graphics shouldn't be a reason to determine whether to buy/play a game at all. The worst that can happen with a good game of which you don't like the graphics is that you might think "well, it could look better". And as we all know, if you have to say that it's just [i]the worst[/i], right?
    [*]It has an 8-bit soundtack.
Well, technically it's not 8-bit at all. Ultra fakebit, I'm telling you. Everyone who's ever listened to chiptune should notice immediatly. Noobs.
For me it was the same as with the graphics at first - I just can't hear it anymore. And still, the soundtrack is super catchy + fits the game perfectly, although I feel like it could contain a few more tracks. Then again, the theme song is not just catchy, but also funny.
    [*]Speaking of which, the game itself is pretty punny.
Yes, it's definitely one of the funnier games you'll see. Not necessarily the funniest, because it's not Portal. However, although I've always been looking forward to seeing new boss monsters, because of their funny names or puns they came up with, I felt like the humor was innocuous. Of course humor doesn't always have to be ironic/sarcastic/critical - I just feel it wouldn't have hurt sometimes.
Oh, hold on, there was this one situation where they were directly referring to Anita Sarkeesian's Tropes vs. Women in Videogames series, which I found absolutely hilarious, very well placed and well executed. [b]Good job Behold Studios![/b]
    [*]Although it's not a very long game in and of itself, it felt unnecessarily prolonged after around season 3 in the game. It was basically the same thing over and over again, until the game ended. Most episodes you make go like this:
Fight minions, fight minions and boss, fight mecha battle against same giant boss.
That's probably the weakest part about the game and the one thing I would personally hold against it. Still, I managed to beat the game just yesterday and right now I'm actually in the mood to play it again, with different actors.
   [*]The fighting system is tactical and has it's own profundity, while remaining simple. It's really a good balance.
Although, of course, I personally would put the fighting system and the game itself into the more casual corner with the other more casual fighting systems and the other more casual games.
[/list]
[b]
tl;dr

When trying to summarize my experience, I would absolutely recommend anyone (meaning all of my friends and you) to buy this game and at least play the first two to three seasons (the game progresses in seasons) of it, to see if you'd like to continue or stop. I'd also say that it's worth it's regular price. But hey, you can always wait until it's on sale. And if it is on sale, you should definitely get it.[/b]

19740425.review:
Pros

 - The general look of the game is top notch. It's very appealing to look at.
 - The soundtrack is decent, albeit forgetable.
 - Changes in armor and weaponry are actually shown on the sprites, which makes equipping new gear feel much better.
 - The Teamwork function is pretty neat. It allows for some pretty interesting tactics in combat. Having one character toss another character in order to move them closer to an enemy is a cool way to move around the map. I just wish it was more fledged out. I feel like this would be a great feature if it was just developed a bit more.

Cons

 - The game is very easy. I'm playing on the hardest difficulty and I'm having no trouble so far.
 - Customization feels pointless. It doesn't matter what you call your crew, your show, your attack names, etc. It's just there for the sake of having it as a selling point.
 - The writing is terrible. It actually has smileys - :) - written in speech bubbles. As though the characters are somehow able to pronounce ":)". Furthermore, not an hour in and the game blatantly tries to push an agenda down your throat by (poorly) criticizing the "damsel in distress" trope. A character mentions that his sister would like to appear on the show in respone to them needing someone to play the role of hostage, which another character immediately says they cannot allow, and they find a male person to play the role of hostage instead. It's never explained WHY having a woman in that role would be bad, they just say it's bad.
 - You cannot influence the episodes in any way. How you take out enemies, how many of your crew members go down in battle, how long it takes, etc... All of that only influences how many fans your show gets, and it's all completely arbitrary. (A hero falling in battle for any reason will cause you to lose viewers, while something as simple as moving a hero around on the map can cause you to gain viewers.)
 - Mecha battles are insultingly simple. You have the option to either attack or defend. You can attack as many times as you want, but your chance to hit decreases with each succesful strike. Defending ends your turn and gives you a bonus to defense, which increases the more times you've hit your opponent this turn. On your opponent's turn, you just click the mouse button at the right time to reduce damage. Eventually, you gain access to a finishin move, which deals high damage and ends your turn instantly. That's all.

I came into this expecting something like Agarest mixed with Game Maker Tycoon. I have to say, I'm very disappointed. Even if you're a huge fan of Sentai shows, I imagine the cringy dialogue, boring story, and shallow gameplay will start to rub you the wrong way eventually.
I cannot recommend this game to anyone, and it is certainly not worth the asking price. I doubt I'll ever finish the game, so I don't even consider it worth my time.

19718109.review: This is a great game. I recommend. Remeber Final fantasy Tatics.

19713602.review:
This game made me glad, than I'm subscribed to Humble Monthly Bundle ;). It's simply awesome. Fun, light-hearted, cute, self-aware and full of references - most of which I probably didn't get, but hey! How fun this game must be for people who love Power Rangers and similar TV series! But fear not! Even if you know almost nothing about this sort of stuff, you'll still find something for yourself :).

Pros:
+ choose your own team - Want to have all female squad? Here you go! Or maybe men only (men dressed as panda by any chance...?). Why not! But how about... A robot? Or an alien? Or maybe even a beaver? 
+ crafting, managing your own studio, buying upgrades, fan mails... Don't you have a feeling that sometimes game developers give us just "naked" game, without any substance besides main action? Well, you won't have this feeling here.
+ graphic - I cannot imagine better graphic style for this game.
+ music - simply awesome. I think Lord Gaga's theme will stay in my memory for pretty long time. 
+ tons and tons of references! 
+ funny, self-aware, full of intended cliches. If it won't make you laugh, it'll at least make you smile.
+ awesome, hilarious enemies.
+ challenging but not frustrating - I finished game on medium difficulty. It can be pretty challenging when you try to fulfill all goals, but still it's not that hard that you want to throw your PC out ;).

Sadly, there are also cons:
- too long fights. Not all of them, of course, some are very quickly, but there's tons of fights that just take too much damn time and it's not because player don't use proper strategy. No, no. It's because there are fights with tons of enemie's minions and each one of them need to make a move, EACH turn, and sometimes it really takes forever. And if you add mines/sprouts to that... It's just hell. And I don't think there's a way to skip it. There was a time, when I literally step away from my computer for a few minutes and when I get back, last enemies were still moving.
- mecha combat - it breaks my heart, but it may be one of the weakest points of this game. Of course you need to have huge robots and huge monsters with the game heavily inspired by Power Rangers. And don't get me wrong, crafting upgrades for your Mecha is pretty interesting, but fight itself... Boring and repetitive. If Mecha battles were reserved only for final episodes/bosses then maybe I wouldn't have this opinion, but they are a regular part o game. And they look exactly the same. You make combos, that ends with special move/defense or just because you didn't manage to do another attack. Then your opponent attacks - always three times (and sometimes there's a special move). You defend yourself by clicking in the right moment. And then the process continue. Regular fights are fun (if they don't take too long), because you have different enemies, with different skills, minions, attacks, goals etc. Here, no matter who your opponent is, fight ALWAYS looks the same. There's no much strategy involved.

19692887.review:
TL;DR版：
总体来说，游戏算不错。一开始会让人眼前一亮，但中后期会让人十分疲倦。
为了感谢他们拯救了地球，我就暂且给个好评吧。

我在开始玩以后注意到它是Knights of Pen & Paper（KPP）的同门师兄弟，如果我入之前就发现了的话多半我这手就不剁了（（（

背景：KPP作为PC游戏而言超级垃圾，虽然作为手游来说还行

Chroma Squad继承了KPP的一些缺点，包括：
[olist]
[*]比较无聊又故作幽默的对话
我就是在读对话的时候感觉他们是一家的
[*]麻烦的成就
比如要你在战役中拍100集，[spoiler]我打的6th Ranger线[/spoiler]一个周目应该只有31集可以拍，所以大概三周目多点吧
[/olist]

其他缺点还包括：
[olist]
[*]垃圾mecha战斗
[i](Edit: Jul. 7 2017年发布的扩展补丁重做了mecha战斗部分，因此这段将不再适用。)[/i]
这点甚至连dev都承认这确实是最无聊的部分了。
战斗系统是这样的：你的机甲有两个基础能力，攻击和防御，以及至多四个由装备决定的技能。
基础命中率是90%+装备命中率，每次攻击都会降低命中率，当你miss或者用会结束回合的能力（如防御）后换对方攻击。
对方除非用技能不然的话必然攻击你三次，防御动作跟南方公园差不多的类似QTE，但无聊透顶：一个箭头在一个条上滑动，滑到白色部分的时候你点鼠标就可以了。而且无聊到这样的程度：箭头的移动速度和条上的白色部分无论你打谁都是一样的，所有mecha boss的区别只有sprite和数值了……他们那可悲的技能完全可以无视，防御方式和普攻一样的
[*]Update：“关键选项”没啥影响
在第四章结尾的时候有一个关键选择，选择的结果有三，1）得不到新队友；2）得到新队友A；3）得到新队友B。
目前我打了第二和第三个选项，结果发现区别只有第五章第一关和大结局的少量对话有区别，其他的地方除了新队友能力都一模一样喔……
就连对话都是，只是同样的话换个不同的sprite来说而已，真失望啊……
等我把选择1打了以后再看看吧……
[*]垃圾unity引擎
[*]太过重复
整个游戏里一共就几种不同的敌人，几个场景反复用
[*]浪费潜力
后面展开说
[*]剧情缺乏深度
同样后面展开说
[/olist]

好，先抑后扬，接下来是中评：
[olist]
[*]音乐
Theme和ED让人眼前一亮，整个游戏里音乐最棒的部分就是主菜单的Theme[spoiler]最终战的时候再次放出来超燃的[/spoiler]。
但总体而言，音乐曲目过少，游戏流程中就那几个曲子翻来覆去放还是让人有点厌烦
[*]缺乏RPG元素
游戏里没有经验值系统，加点是每到新的一章就可以解锁一个新技能；装备基本是制式装备，有一点点随机数值；同时角色之间实在太缺乏互动。本来这对我而言应该是妥妥的差评，但考虑到这是个策略游戏……
[*]bug不多
有时候人物进场和敌人进场的时候位置有点问题，但无伤大雅。我在第四章还是第五章卡死过一次，问题不算大
[*]不是很有策略游戏的深度
战斗中teamwork还算有点意思，利用队友的特技动作把你抛到远处挺重要的，但总体来说缺乏深度
[/olist]

接下来，不错的地方有：
[olist]
[*]画面
很漂亮的8比特人物，虽然sprite的动作不多，但看着挺舒服的，背景画得也很好。加上有些地方会加上老电视弧形屏变形滤镜，还算挺带感的
[*]很多neta，非常多
虽然因为故作风趣的对话让这些neta没那么让人开心了
[*]像模像样的特摄片战队
包括队长红，阿宅蓝，凶暴黑，软妹粉，神速黄
[*]一些可以自定义的小细节
虽然这点还蛮不值一提的……但把战队的名字取作奥特曼赛文，成员的名字都用来打的名字，然后mecha取名叫Shin Getter，召唤mecha时大喊FINAL FUSION真是超爽的……
[/olist]

我实在感到很遗憾，因为这部作品有成为一小撮人心中的神作的潜力，却被Behold Studio浪费得干干净净。从KPP和Chroma Squad来看，他们不是缺一个靠谱的编剧就是根本没有编剧，因为这两者都有一个了不起的母题：虚构和现实的交错。

若是没玩过KPP，它的故事是这样的：你和几个朋友在跑团（Role Play，不懂的朋友请见兽人与饼），一路做任务啦农怪啦还打了各种boss，直到你老妈看你们整天在这里又吃又玩不知道搞什么鬼很愤怒抄着擀面杖冲了进来，于是你们就要面对大boss你老妈……

Chroma Squad则与此相反。首先，你们是一群替身演员，在一个摄影棚里拍特摄片，然后你们被导演骂得不想干了，就愤怒地辞职去开了自己的摄影棚，自己拍特摄片。你们是一群穿着卡纸和胶带做的特摄服的英雄，打的是同样穿着戏服的演员，mecha战斗则是你们自己搭建场景在里面用纸箱做的机器人来打。在一些说了就算剧透的事情之后，整个事情越来越不对劲，你们的“敌人”的“戏服”越来越逼真，最后你们发现你们要对抗的是真正要侵略地球的怪人军团，你们真的成了[请输入战队名字]，你们的友情和意志也真的能驱动（那无聊得要死的）mecha……

看起来也没有特别棒？如果读过卡尔维诺或博尔赫斯，或者，嗯，看点漫画吧，看过格兰特·莫里森写的动物侠，或者野蛮人乔，或者神力肌肉男之类的超棒作品的话，你应该可以意识到这样的一个故事有多大的潜力，能够成为多么了不起的东西……

但开发者不打算这样做！

他们想要的是轻喜剧！

Chroma Squad的剧情虽然大框架上没啥问题，但小范围里bug多多；虽然有几句对话让人眼前一亮，但绝大多数时候都在自作聪明，自以为风趣极了，到处插科打诨。或许你会说这个作品的篇幅完全不足以写成一个感人肺腑令人深思的伟大作品，那你可就错了，它的情节展开算是相当拖沓……说真的，随便多读点书的人都能把这个剧本改成像样得多的剧本，如果我手下有几个码农有几个美工我早就自己做游戏去了（？）

好，那我把要求放低一点，如果他们按照特摄片或者老式萝卜片的标准写个剧本，也足够我感动得热泪盈眶了，但他们也没有！这个标准其实已经挺低了……他们真的只是想要轻喜剧！

或许这和他们预算有关，KS上他们仅筹到了不到十万美元，而他们决定先弄点不错的音乐，然后好好把sprite画得漂亮点，然后再把内涵装进去，结果发现没钱了……虽然这个可能性太小了，看看他们KPP的剧本，我觉得他们真的是喜欢这样玩……

同样在故事中，不知dev有没有意识到（应该是有意识到的，Chroma Squad里还有个成就就叫So Meta），都有若是稍微认真发挥一下就让整个作品散发着光环的伟大的元叙事……却仅仅被用在了插科打诨上。

假如老天有眼，祖坟冒烟，他们进了KS百万美元俱乐部，他们会不会好好请几个大拿来写剧本？

我觉得不会，因为他们喜欢自己的风格。他们可能会把故事做长几倍（或者做几个不同的剧本），然后开发自己的引擎而不是用垃圾unity，把游戏的战略深度做得更了不起，加入更多的RPG元素，提高sprite的分辨率，增加sprite动作，然后顺便解决他们面对的侵权问题，然后扩展一下摄影棚的经营管理，使得战斗外的部分更加有趣，更加费脑，同时多做一些曲子，好让人不觉得整个游戏里就三四首歌来回loop，然后请人全程配音……

就做成了一个很棒的轻喜剧。

也就这样了。

This is a nice little game that will keep you busy for about 15-20 hours. I really liked knights of pen and paper (my avatar is from that game) for its graphics and casual game style, and also enjoyed the overall foreign feel with bad grammar and jokes that don't always translate perfectly. This game is sort of the same, but is more linear and less compelling to replay.

As someone growing up watching the power rangers I wanted to go back to some of those cheesy moments and the game really delivers, including the repetitive unispiring boss fights in the form of a minigame. The plot is overall nice and somewhat reminds me of their other work, and there's a nice fast forward effect to skip through the story. TBH I skipped through most of the ending just to finish playing.

I will probably return to this game when a major update is declared and overall don't regret buying it on sale. Thanks Devs for the time put in to writing and styling this!

19627733.review:
[b]tl;dr -> I finally got to create my own squad of Power Rangers, OMG![/b]

I was fortunate to receive multiple review/press copies from the developing team, and I was very excited to play as a squad of television stars acting as super heroes akin to the Power Rangers. I was thoroughly satisfied with my gameplay experience.

If you enjoy retro pixel graphics, role-playing games (RPG), squad-based tactical combat, superheroes, kaiju, and management mechanics (television studio), then you will absolutely adore Chroma Squad.

The aesthetics are fantastic - the amount of detail in every model and object is very high. The sound effects and music are good and add a lot to the retro feel. You can even fast-forward cutscenes and it will appear like a VHS (if you were alive to remember what those are lol) tape. The story is funny and decent, and there is a very good twist that recaptured my attention. Admittedly, near the end-game I would just fast-forward through any of the cutscenes. There are a number of choices you will encounter, changing the story and encouraging multiple playthroughs. I love how equipping different armor (helmet, boots, etc) and weapons actually changes the look of your characters - I have always been the biggest aesthetic whore. A nice detail is how newer seasons introduce better equipment (like transitioning from handmade/cardboard equipment to plastic) - and the appearance of each item reflects the quality level. You also have a giant mech, and end-game mechs look so much more badass than the starting one. These aesthetics accurately capture your gameplay progression from a low-budget mom & pop company to a AAA brand.

Controls are easy to learn and typical of turn-based tactics games. The tutorials are very informative and every element of the game is explained well enough so that you won't have to look up guides (unless you want some extra tips). The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with turn-based tactical games - the most challenging part of the game is maintaining your entire studio (specifically, your equipment) properly match the enemy's prowess after each episode. Each season is split into multiple episodes, and new seasons introduce new enemies, equipment, and other things.

Gameplay begins in the studio, where you can craft/buy equipment for your actors/mech to use, upgrade items in the studio for bonuses, and purchase marketing teams (which provide further bonuses). You can customize your actors and actresses' names and the catchphrases they use - like when they transform or summon their mech. As you progress through the TV show seasons, you will unlock more items to craft, buy, and upgrade. There are crates you can buy that provide random crafting materials in different tiers - crafting your own equipment is better in most cases because you also gain random attributes to your new items. Marketing teams you select will grant you bonuses depending on how many fans you have (gained after each level/episode depending on how well you perform and if you complete secondary objectives). Emails are answered in the studio hub, and some of your choices will affect future storylines and opportunities.

When you are finished outfitting your team, you can select from different episodes to act out - some will feature mech vs. kaiju battles, others may have a guest ally appear. Secondary objectives may include defeating x enemies before transforming (once you select "transform," your team will move close together and switch to their Power Ranger-like forms), executing x team moves, or winning in x turns. Completing these tasks will grant you a bonus to fans, but missing them will not deduct anything; however, you lose fans whenever a squad member is downed (brought to 0 health). In order to transform, you need to gain enough audience power (think of it as active viewers) to fill your "transform" gauge. There are marketing companies that give you a starting boost to this gauge, accelerating how quickly you can transform.

During combat, you will issue orders one-at-a-time for each member - once you are finished, the enemy's phase will begin, followed by the next round. You can have your characters use "teamwork," which allows you to chain together team attacks and increase the movement range of other actors/actresses. You will execute a special attack if every member of your squad attacks the same target, and you will perform a super attack if every member uses a weapon. Episodes are usually split into multiple parts, and subsequent parts will have you continue with refilled health. For some episodes, you will end with a mech battle mini-game.

The mini-game is my most favorite part - you and the enemy kaiju take turns attacking. Whenever you attack, it reduces the accuracy (but increases the damage multiplier) of the next attack. Furthermore, chaining a long attack increases the multiplier for anything you decide to do, so a good idea is to balance offence and defence - if you "defend" with a high multiplier, you will negate much of your opponent's damage. Your multiplier also affects any special attacks you have. If you get greedy, however, your turn will end once you miss an attack. When the enemy attacks, you have to defend at right moment, and your timing will determine how much damage you receive.

At the beginning of each new season, your characters will level up, gaining a new set of skills (you may only choose one if two are offered, however, you can swap them at will in the studio). Build/role types (ex: full healer, crit scout, glass cannons) help immensely if you plan accordingly, as the equipment you can buy/craft (and the skill types) really encourages focusing on specific playstyles for each character.

Crafting - at least until the mid-game - presents an interesting challenge because the materials required to upgrade your mech are usually a higher/different tier than the items needed to upgrade your squad. There have been many times where I had to choose between upgrading all/most of my team or my mech. When you craft, you can also combine lower-tier materials to create better ingredients, however, the recipes are different depending on whether you are focusing on your mech or characters. I noticed that in the end-game this wasn't as much of a problem because I had a lot of excess money and could just buy a bunch of boxes (or items from the store).

Overall, the gameplay is a lot of fun and replayability is high due to possible character builds/roles and branching storylines. If you are interested in turn-based tactical gameplay and transforming into superheroes, then you must try this game. You will love it.

ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!

Cheers,
DJSF [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/djsfsroguereviews]@DJSF's Rogue Reviews[/url]

[url=http://theroguereviews.com/]My Website[/url]

19573076.review:
[h1]What I found was something in between a tycoon style game, like Game Dev Tycoon and a 8 bit top-down tactical RPG.  Hmm.  So does the concept work?[/h1]

Growing up I liked power rangers - it was such a cool show.  As I grew older I really liked RPG games on my Gameboy Color.  Pokemon Yellow, Zelda, and then on our home PC FFVII.  So when I saw this game, I thought I would really enjoy it.  But it just failed to catch my attention, I never felt engaged or interested in what was happening in game.

[b]Pros[/b]
[*]The theme is great.  You are making “power ranger” episodes and gaining more viewers/money depending on how well you perform.
[*]The genre is unique.  As I said, somewhere between a tactical RPG and a business sim game.  Very unique, and indeed a good idea.
[*]I think the 8-bit style (or is it 16?) is appropriate as the game is a throwback to the ‘90s.
[/list]
[b]Cons[/b]
[*]Ultimately, I just couldn’t get into the gameplay, progression, or the story. 
[*]THe only real technical complain I have is that I found the interface odd and uneasy.  Sometimes it's difficult to tell, according to the character selection bar on the right, which avatar correlates to various characters on the map.  Setting up the vital teamwork moves is also a little awkward and inconsistent

19541876.review:
This game is fantastic.
 Lots of nostalgia for anyone growing up watching power rangers. There isnt much strategy to the game but just enough to make it enjoyable though you wont be smacking your head against the wall because it is difficult. Sometimes completing all the director's instructions can be a chore but if you dont care about that and just want to 'win' than it will be a piece of cake...unless you play on the hardest difficulty, where you will need all the fans you can get to generate money and keep your studio floating. 
There is definitely replayability because you can get a couple of different endings but it feels like most of the choices you make are small scale, it is a pretty linear story with some variations in my opinion.
Also, dont pay any attention to the gamergate types that complain about feminist tropes. There is one episode that has a guy kidnapped instead of a girl in the very beginning and it doesnt have any bearing on the rest of the plot, just the game creators making commentary on overplayed tropes.
Overall I would highly recommend this game to someone who loves strategy, RPGs, power rangers, and a few corny jokes.
10/10

19507739.review:
[h1] I got this game through Humble Monthly. What that means is I didn't go out special to find it and buy it.[/h1]

I hated the Power Rangers. I really and truly did. To this very day they make me cringe. I'm not sophisicated by any means; but I enjoy being entertained like the next person does; and watching robots continue to fake explode for like three minutes at a time simple isn't my cup of tea. The Power Rangers are so fake, so chinsy, and generally awful.

But if you make a game about dudes aspiring to be them with an 8-bit art style and tight controls; what you get, is an enjoyable experience.

I like to imagine this is what the team behind Power Rangers had to actually go and do. Like, at one point, they all were just wearing rain boots and could craft plastic and stuff together to make a spiffy top hat; and then they all did shots of vodka and did an episode.

Its got a crafting system that'll allow you to make better weapons and costume parts; thus improving your stats and killing the dudes faster and easier.

This game also takes a few pages out of recent Fire Emblem game's playbook in a good way and will let you use teamwork to get farther ahead in the map; or you can use them to pummel foes. Its just a bit annoying having to constantly tell them to use teamwork; and it  can ony be used once per turn. Also the game is kinda like a game of chess where you can move all your dudes and attack maybe in one turn; which again; takes me back to FE. I know FE isn't the only game that does this; but its the only one I can think of.


The Story is basiclly what you'd expect; its not lack-luster but its not awful; the battle system isn't creative but its also not overused and they do it well. They give you objectives that can provide bonus' if completed; and you gotta complete them. Cuz if you don't you'll just run out of money.

You can change actors for certain benefits if you want, it tries to be funny and doesn't succeed for me, everything you buy will take money from you after you buy it which I feel is quite needless; why not just let us have the buff.

So.
Is it fun? Yes.
Should you get it? On sale, yes.
Will I beat it? Eventually.
Rating: 7/10

19450271.review:
I was interested by the premise of a power rangers-esque tactical RPG, but this game had everything it promised and more!

The best part of this game is the fun and satisfying gameplay. The tactics you implement in fights like the team acrobatics and team attacks are true to both this genre of game and the TV shows Chroma Squad draws inspiration from. There's so many different play styles you can try thanks to the no-penalty selection of skills. By no-penalty I mean that if you want to change a character's skills alter their strengths and weaknesses you can do total 180s. The freedom to experiment with different strategies really add a lot of replay value to this game. 

The crafting is very thought out with different tiers organized so that there are no useless crafting items and none of them are too hard to get. The studio upgrades, mecha upgrade, shop, and agency stuff are all great inclusions that all players to go wild with improving and powering up their characters. I also love being able to make my own power rangers  including their names, colours, catch phrases, and all that other cool super hero stuff.

The visuals are pixelly, but in a good way. Behold Studios did a great job using an old-school graphics style in a cinematic and modern way. Even though everything is a clearly made from little squares, there is detail involving perspective, lighting, and various other aspects that gives this 2D world a bigger feeling. This style is similar to games like Hotline Miami and Party Hard, if you need an example.

The music is awesome, once again capturing the vibe of those 90's shows we all remember so fondly, but being modern and pleasing to the ear. The theme songs for specific characters are all tailored quite well to who they are paired with. The story at first made me think "meh", but after a couple episodes I was drawn into being a squad of stuntmen trying to make their way in the world independently of The Man. And even more drawn in when the stakes get raised and the stuntmen squad must become genuine heros.

There are minor quirks here or there, but none worth mentioning since they've probably already been fixed as I'm typing this. 


TL;DR: if you like incrediby well made tactical RPGs and have a nostalgia scratch to itch, then you should really play this game.

18983609.review:
Chroma Squad
There is alot going on with Chroma Squad but I'll keep it short...some areas of the game are very very very good...and some awful.
Let's start off with the good, Chroma Squad is a hybrid between simulation and turn based strategy. It sounds complicated, but they kept those two elements at the simplist form. So,  the developers pulled it off nicely.  I played on the easiest difficulty because I am atrocious at both genres, but this title kept me interested.  There are a few branching storyline choices to choose from, so that's a plus as well.

The storyline is hit or miss...so I'll try to keep the spoilers to a bare minimum. Note the word try:

If you read the description, if Chroma Squad, the player runs its own Super Sentai studio/show.  The actors who decide to start their own show are all best friends who got tired of their former show's director. So the player runs the studio, and the action(Turn based strategy) is the episode being filmed. 
I wish it was that simple.  It begins to get confusing, because everyone begins breaking the 4th wall(from the show to their audience), sometimes the actors don't know if what's happening while on set is scripted or really happening, and then soon they begin to 'Morph'/Transform for real and fight real battles while its still being filmed.(In other words, the actors became real super heroes and saved the world). I sometimes got mixed up with what is real or what isn't real.  At one point, a developer comes on screen and tells the actors its all just a game and he made a glitch by mistake, is that the 5th wall being broken????
The gameplay was fantastic, and the retro style graphics were beautiful too.  I liked the idea of naming my studio and all the catch phrases, so the only thing I didn't like was the story, I pretty much hated it.  I wish it was either one or the other, either a Super Sentai game(Where I name the characters, catchphrases, customize colors/armor), or the same studio simulation/turn based strategy where it was kept JUST A TV SHOW without a confusing storyline.

6.5/10

I know alot of people love the story, and that's okay.  It just wasn't for me.

- Le scénario est original et les anciens comme moi qui regardaient les powers rangers qui nous étions petits trouveront les situations plutôt amusantes (tellement elles sont vraies). De plus l'umour omniprésent permet  de garder le sourire tout le long du jeu.

- Petit bémol au niveau de la difficulté : à savoir qu'on nous en propose 3 : une très facile, une simple, et une plutot dure... Heureusement il est possible de la changer dans les options.

Bref Chroma Squad n'est pas le jeu de l'année mais il est, à mon humble avis, un vent de fraicheur pour tous les amateurs de TRPG ayant envie de passer un bon moment.

18437476.review:
An amazing game with noticeable flaws that tarnish the gameplay depending on the player.

Pros:
Nostalgic soundtrack and gameplay, balanced difficulty, loads of content/replayability, and creativity. Many games this generation are essentially creatively bankrupt, but Chroma Squad realizes this and challenges the standard of games today. A tycoon game with rpg gameplay and tons of customization has been completely unheard of. Fun humor and fun character designs, the game doesn't take itself seriously at all and knows its limits. It is literally self-aware of the tropes and cliches it uses. For example, in one point of the game, a girl needs to be rescued. One of the squad members questions if it should be a guy just to avoid using sexist tropes. The game knows the stupidity of generic hero-saving-the-day tv shows and utilizes it to bring out the fun that is in them easily. 

Also, if you are a fan of super sentai, you will laugh your ass off at these references. I promise you.


Subjective:
It's obvious just from the start of the game how much customization there is. You can customize everything- from your squad name, the names of your members, the attributes of the members, the weapons of the members, the abilities of the members, your mecha, your mecha's name, your transformation name, and way more. In theory, it sounds great, but when you get right down to it, it get's annoying. Have you ever felt the feeling of, "Ugh, I can't choose between these great abilities/weapons! I wish the game didn't even give me an option!" Well, half of the game is like that. It's so customizable to the point where it may ruin the enjoyment factor. Should I craft this? Should I buy this? Should I equip this? There's way too many choices. Me personally, I had only a few problems with this, considering how much I love customization in games. This is a pro or a con depending on the player.

Cons:

Repetitive. Incredibly repetitive, to the point where you say to yourself, "Really? This again?" The game is oozing with creativity but unfortunately the gameplay is designed so that almost all of the fights are entirely the same. Some enemies are different, the map layout is sometimes different (and other times copy pasted), but the game throws at you the same fights over and over again just to reach the conclusion. This is easily noticeable after getting through the start of the game. 

No effect on overall plot. Nothing you really do changes where the game is going. Sure, occasionally you get fans praising you for doing x or shunning you for doing y, but it doesn't really do much in the long run from what I've seen.

Little strategy. Unless playing on the hardest difficulty, you only need a bit of strategy to complete the levels. 

Dialogue. The dialogue is sometimes humorous and creative, but really? It can be written by 5 year olds and probably be the same. The writing is pretty awful and the characters have little depth. This I get it; that's the whole point of the game. It doesn't take itself seriously and is SUPPOSED to be immature. It isn't that big of a deal, but the game could easily be better with more engaging dialogues and more clever jokes.

Mecha fights. Fun the first time you launch it and the first time you use a new ability you got, but otherwise? Not engaging at all, and anti-climactic a lot of the time. Incredibly repetitive. 

Overall though? Do I have to go through a bit of repetitiveness and subpar dialogue to enjoy a game with tons of replayability, nostalgic design/soundtrack and a unique experience? Definitely. This game is fun as hell.

18428883.review:
I had a great time playing this! With that sweet, sweet 90's pixel-art nostalgia and the general "have fun" attitude of the game, I couldn't help but enjoy it! Not to mention that awesome music. The Nintendo/Sega-esque 8-bit style battle music is soothing to my soul.

For a Tactical-RPG it's pretty minimal in its actual "tactical" gameplay. That was something I personally loved, but I could easily see others hating. Differen't strokes for differen't folks. If you were looking for a hardcore, strategy heavy game... then this game most likely isn't for you. If anything, as far as strategy goes it's mainly about what you [i]build[/i] more so than what you actually [i]do[/i] during the battle sequences. I played on intermediate difficulty and not once did I have to consciously think about how I was gonna move/attack 'X' turns ahead like a game of chess. But I did have a moment where I consciously thought (and was surprised) at how captivated I was into what's basically an 8-bit power rangers rip-off with a "behind the scenes" twist. I think it's because of factors like the minimal strategic gameplay (as well as the storyline) that I was able to just relax and have fun with it. If you want something a little more hardcore then you'll definitely want to turn the difficulty up.

The story is easily where this game shines the most. A story that really makes you feel like you're progressing from the point of being stunt actors playing fake super heroes to becoming actual ones that [spoiler]end up saving the entire planet (and I think universe?)[/spoiler]. Another thing to note about this game is it's very satirical, emphasizing mainly on the process that goes in to shooting the episodes and production in general. The bosses are sometimes pretty ludicrous in design (and name) but this game's humor is just that, ludicrous and out there- So it fits the theme nicely. There's also multiple endings- something that I was unaware of until randomly checking out the achievements (lol). That's a pretty big bonus and adds a good bit of replayability. The story is also much longer than I expected it to be, so thats a huge bonus

The dialogue became... interesting... at times. But the rest of the game as a whole easily makes up for the questionable dialogue. When it's bad dialogue- it's intentional. It's not like it's bad because it was an earnest attempt at something that just came out wrong in translation, or something that just flat out didn't work at all. It's definitely all intentionally placed bad dialogue. Things like the game's [i]constant[/i] breaking of the fourth wall was forgiveable... but intentional typos for a laugh and putting emoji's into my game dialogue?! NO. Just, NO!

The music was fantastic and hit all the right spots. I'm considering buying the soundtrack for $5 just to make a good review for it that would probably rival this one in length. Nuff said.. It's probably what hooked me the most (next to the story) being how important music in general is to a guy like me, but I digress.

[b]All in All, it's a fantastic game. I highly recommend if you enjoyed anything 'Power Rangers' related when you were younger, and just feel like having a few laughs with it now that you're older.[/b]
