18400444.review:
Well that was a good game, but not all that long, on casual if you don't muck up, about a dozen hours. I just finished it as I type this review, their were very few things ultimately that bugged me however, nothing really that bad that I'd give it a negative recommendation, but still it bugged me.

First you don't have one of each pieces of armor and each weapons at 'Legendary' quality, you got a pistol & a sword, I guess so those can be wielded by everyone however if you got used to wield class specific weapons its a let down that you can't have a unique Legendary weapon for each classes, also while you got one armor and two helmets for your characers armor, I found it lacking that you couldn't have boots and make a full Legendary armor, which would have been nice for the finale, but from what I seen you can't sadly, it would have been really a great idea for the very last mission at least to be able to have all your team in full Legendary.

Next is New Game +, I saw the narrator after the credits mention that, it would have been great to finish your game on a level than be able to New Game + to the next difficulty level. Now the game has been out for a few months and still no  sign of that sadly. If not for a New Game + one thing that would have been great would have been to be able to replay any mission after the end or after having done them, so that you could fight again any battles, sure their might not be able to alter the storyline path you took, but just replaying the missions would have been a pretty good idea, give the game a bit more longevity. Right now the game feel limited in what you can do, since ou can't continue into a New Game + with your stuff or you can't continue in that game either , when its over its over, whatever you like it or not. I did see their is a mention of some sort of 'Episode Editor' program that would allow us to create custom episodes for endless gaming, I can't wait for it to come out.

Otherwise maybe the selection of potential characters is a bit limited too, I went for a all female team and I was just able to do it, you have barely enough characters of each genders to fill in a full team, without accounting I think for the backers special characters which are... peculiar... one is an weird animal thing, one is a robot, another looked like a lazy bum, and the last is some guy with a shop discount.... but it would have been nice to have a few more picks, if I want to play a new all female team I'd be forced to go with the exact same team and the only way to change things up would be to shift whom is what... so yea, a bit lacking on that part.

Still when all is said and done, this game is great, it was worthwhile for me to get it and I hope it will be expanded upon, maybe get a sequel in time, since the scene at the very end imply their could be a sequel to it, I really want it to be true, hopefully one that would correct the few issues and build up to a even greater game, but that is something we'll have to wait and see about, I really wish for it to happen, if not at least another Tactical RPG of that quality would always be welcome.

18126782.review:
Do you like dying because your attacks missed and there was nothing you could do about it? Do you like chasing gun-wielding birds across half the map? 

A few quirks kept me from enjoying this game as much as I wanted to. I will never understand what goes through a designer's head that says "You know what might be fun? Setting up 3/5s of your team for a combined attack that will miss". Or just accuracy in general. It's not fun, it detracts from strategy, and it's incredibly frustrating. Similarly, gunmen in the game can and will kite you endlessly to the very edges of the map. It's not fun, it's not interesting, and it just makes you want to chuck something through a window. They will do this on every single turn, and if your teament that can catch them isn't at hand you're SOL. 

The art is amazing, the themes and writing are really cool and well used, and you can tell the creators are huge fans of the Sentai series. Its just that the game is an exercise in incredible frustration. 

If you can stomach these awful design choises, the game is fantastic. But for me few things piss me off more than accurasy where it absolutely is not required.

18050253.review:
[h1]Chroma Squad[/h1]
[b]Developer[/b]: Behold Studios
[b]Publisher[/b]: Behold Studios

[b]Note[/b]: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased informative review. No other compensation was given.

[b]Introduction[/b]
==========
Back in the old days there were a flood of Sentai TV series: Power Rangers, Sailor Moon, Beetle Borgs, Tattooed Teenage Alien Fighters from Beverly Hills, Samurai Cyber Squad, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, etc etc. The list goes on for quite a while. Sentai translates to "Task Force" or "Squadron" and is usually a team of heroes wearing color coded outfits or uniforms. Basically superheroes...Japanese style! Generally they come with a range of personalities/roles that usually follows some variation of the Five-Man Band. Known for their synchronized posing; also, a standard powerup pose is often used in many Sentai works during the transformation sequence. A key concept is that the collective team are more important than the individual, and that more can be achieved by working together. Chroma Squad is directly inspired by Saban's Power Rangers, and capitalizes on most of these concepts from the Sentai genre but takes it a bit further in that you are actually managing the studio shooting the TV series!

[b]Gameplay[/b]
==========
Starting up the game you are introduced to your team of actors/heroes, as they are in the middle of a shoot for a TV show, taking a lot of crap from their director in the process. By the end of the shoot, the actors decide to ditch their jerk of a director and start their own TV studio and sentai hero show! One of the actor's has an uncle that lends you an old warehouse where you setup your new studio. 

At the start of your new career, you get to customize your team of actors, choosing what color their suit will be, the actors themselves, and change their names. You are then able to choose your studio's name, and some various phrases that will you used throughout the game, such as when your actors "morph" into their hero suits ("Chromatize!"). As a studio manager, it's your job to choose which episodes get aired and in what order. At the main screen, you can choose to buy equipment/props for your actors that boost their stats in battle scenes. You can also check yoru fan mail, which you will recieve regularly and are able to choose differents responses to. Sometimes depending on your responses you will lose or gain money and/or items. Items can also be crafted using materials you find in combat, such as duct tape and cardboard. 

The main draw of Chroma Squad is in the action scenes - combat. Chroma Squad utilizes a very simple tactical RPG system in which you can move your team across a grid on the battlefield. During your "Phase" you can direct any of your actors in any order you choose until they've all had an action, then it's the Enemy's "Phase". Each character has access to a limited set of skills, and the number of skills you can use increases as you shoot more episodes and as you wrap up more seasons of the show. Your team is able to use special "Teamwork" actions, which can be very, very useful in dealing damage or traversing the battlefield. For example, one actor can toss another one, enabling them to cover more distance. Another example is having 2 or more adjacent actors attack the same enemy in a team attack. Lastly, if all 5 of your actors are adjacent to an enemy, you can use a Finishing Move, dealing massive damage to your target! FEAR THE POWER OF TEAMWORK! Each scene also has special challenges in the form of Director's Instructions. These can range from reaching an objective within a specfied number of turns, or defeating a certain number of minions before attacking a boss. Completing these orders rewards you with extra points that are converted into fans and money at the end of every episode. Most sentai shows had giant mech suits...such as Power Rangers' MegaZord. Chroma Squad has a similar feature! 

Perhaps one of the best things about Chroma Squad is the enemy designs. Early on you meet a fellow named Transitmancer -- a mage wield a staff with a traffic signal attached to the top of it. You will also meet enemies like "The Boxing Box"...which is literally a cardboard box with arms, wearing boxing gloves. There's way more creative ones and even some cameos, but I don't want to spoil too much of the fun!

[b]Graphics[/b]
==========
If you have played Behold Studio's previous game, Knights of Pen and Paper, you will be familiar with the art style used here. It's slightly more advanced than KoPaP, with even more details on each sprite. Combat animations, movement, and even the special attacks are very well animated and look really nice. Props look great, and like I said before character designs and enemies look amazing.

[b]Sound and Music[/b]
==========
This game has one of the most amazing soundtracks I have heard in quite a long time. The best tracks are the battle tunes by FAR. Just let a battle start and leave it there for a few to take it in. They really get you pumped up for any challenges you are faced with! I have added most of it to my YouTube playlist reserved specially for great game music! The soundtrack is available for purchase on the Store Page for $4.99. Well worth it! Seriously, just give this a listen:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oYnd0uRCkCk

The sound effects are pretty minimal, but they do their job. I can't fault the sound direction here, as it's pretty well done despite being fairly minimal. The soundtrack more than makes up for any shortcomings!

[b]Performance[/b]
==========
Chroma Squad runs like a dream. No crashes, stuttering, framerate drops, or any weird glitches were encountered during my playtime so far, and I really don't expect to see any. Behold Studios is usually really good about the quality of their games, as we've seen so far. I didn't think to test the game with my controller, as mouse and keyboard worked extremely well. Probably best for this type of game anyway.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
==========
If you are looking for a fun tactical RPG that's a bit different and has a ton of humor, Chroma Squad fits the bill perfectly. Such a great little title, and a complete joy to play. You should not hesitate at all in buying this, it's quite the gem! The soundtrack alone is enough to justify the purchase. 

[b]Gameplay Demo[/b]
==========
https://youtu.be/XMmY3uRXmvM

[b]Nerd House Verdict[/b]:
==========
[h1][b]Highly Recommended[/b][/h1]

Amazing game spoiled by a poorly balanced ending.  I do reccomend this game, especially if you're a fan of sentai, but there are a few cons I need to point out.

- Game difficulty settings are worthless; game is too easy on hardest difficulty until the last two episodes, where you can only win on Casual mode, a mode so easy it practically makes the rest of the game not worth playing.  Changing difficulty settings also ruins which ending achievement you get, if you care about that.
- You can't lose the last boss fight.  It's incredibly lame and kills all tension.
- One of the early episodes has some highly forced writing.  It's out of place and obnoxiously preachy, but thankfully it's the only one I really noticed.  If you're ok with being lectured about sexism, disregard this.

Overall I enjoyed the game, although all my excitement to see it through to the end was ruined by the difficulty balance of the last two episodes.  7/10 until the ending, 6/10 overall, YMMV.

Great brazilian game inspired by the Super Sentai series like Changeman and Power Rangers.

You are creating your own studio to produce your Super Sentai serie, so you have to contract the actors to perform in the show, manage the money and audience on each episode and do the costumes and buy the equipment.

The gameplay is a turn based combat system, where you must perform the instructions by the director to win more money and get more fans to watch your show. If you are more a RPG-person, your can see the status of every weapon and equipment for each member of the team. And if you don't care about these numbers you can just pick the most expensive and high level item and you are ready to go.

So if you liked any Super Sentai serie when you were a kid (or still watching these series) you should play it now.

This is a strategy game where your characters become more powerful by either (The long way...) crafting equipment you gain from various enemies, or (The easy capitalist way) paying for equipment at a shop. This game also has a few different possible endings, so that gives it some replay value, and since this game lets you choose different characters at the beginning as well as have your own play style, you shouldn't really be bored out of your mind replaying the game like I usually am with some other games. The price isn't really too much compared to what you get out of it, because there are a lot of ways you could customize your team to work with your play style (At least 3!.... Probably more, though...). Chroma Squad really gave me a lot of nostalgia, especially since I grew up watching Power Rangers, but I think I could really recommend this game to anyone who really likes any sort of strategy game or any sort of game where you can make important choices to decide what happens. Soooo.... This is a pretty good game, and, as a plus, the soundtrack is awesome!

17552622.review: I feel rather disappointed in that I was unaware of this game until long after the Kickstater was met. I'm a fan of sentai series, both american and japanese versions, and I see a lot of genuine love and effort put forth in the game to show off the themes, corny messages & jokes, and tropes that those shows fall into. With that, however, a love of those fanchises is felt through the effort and minor details scattered in the stages, dialogue, and backgrounds. For instance, the statue of JAKQ's 'Big One' in the convention stage or the reference to Doggie Kruger in one of the post-stage tweets. What about the game play? Well, it plays like the tactical RPGs I love (FF Tactics, Disgaea) while still have it's own take and original elements to it. I do wish there was a big more clarity in know what can and can't be done. For example, I didn't know until Episode 3 that I could customize more then the chest of my mech by clicking on the seperate parts. There are some small nuances in the game like that that take me out of the game for a moment as I may have spent my materials differently. Better explanation on fan or income conversion may be nice as well. Overall, I'm very happy with this game and pray the studio learn from this and make their next game bigger and better.

17134455.review:
Buy it. You don't need a review from me. Wait, you do? Well... alright then.

Pros:
+The dialouge: It's just amazing how many jokes they can state considering the setting is litterally being an indie studio group filming power rangers.

+Stradegy: There's a good amount of it. I'm basing it off of just finishing Season 1, but basically you are given director tasks to appease audience, such as defeating X amount of Y monsters in Z amount of turns, or pulling off finishers on bosses which are very satisfying (when you Chromatize)

+ THE MUSIC: My lord is this the best soundtrack I've heard in a long time. Kudos to the music makers for making such an amazing soundtrack (looking at you A little break from saving the world)

+ Graphics: The graphics is a very vast and colorful pixelated style, and it's very appeasing to the eyes

+ Fan System: Considering it's about an indie group trying to run a show, fans play a major role. They determine how much money you get, and that money goes to upgrading equipment which is the only way (as far as I can tell) to increase your stats.

Cons:
-Crafting Equipment: I'm not knocking off the crafting system, I like it. The only thing that pesters me is that you don't get to see the stat increase or decrease until after you craft it, and once you craft it, you have to hope it does increases with hopefully small decrease in other stats, otherwise you have to recycle it and so far my rng of recycling has been pretty poop.

-Options Menu: Totalbiscuit would probably sue me for doing this since that's his thing.. but the option system is kind of lacking. Sure the requirements would allow even my pc which is viewed as being powered by a potatoe could play it, but the resolutions are kind of hard to navigate and change.. for some reason, you have to let the game go full screen, change the resolution (for me I had to click alot to figure out how to make the slider work), then uncheck full screen, and then it'll save the resolution you want (though for those that play full screen all the time it might not be a problem). But hey at least it has a seperate audio slider for both volume and sfx. ^^

That's about it. The cool thing is that the company is now doing the long task of fixing many bugs... so it's good that they'll keep updating this game. Heck there's even a button to report bugs. So because of that, so will this reveiw if more changes for the better (or worst) occurs.

17114593.review:
Good game - the isometric combat is fun due to the characters having not just different abilities, but such different abilities that it feels good when you figure out a way they can co-operate to take down a monster. For example in one of the later levels I had to kill the boss with a certain character ("A") - 4 of the 6 team members were knocked out, the 2 survivors only had a few points of health left and were surrounded by powerful enemies - but the medic was *just* able to run inbetween A and the boss, so that A could leapfrog across the screen and give the boss one last punch, which was enough to win. The game is entirely set-piece scenarios, but the whole thing was like that: if someone scores a critical hit in a round all the tactics have to adapt. The other good thing is that the combat system rewards you for using sentai-hero logic, rather than X-Com logic. It's not about finding a weakness and exploting it, it's about trying and failing and returning again in a stronger form.

There are some downsides. Only 1 gamesave. There aren't any random levels which I think is quite a bold decision: the bosses and stage layouts are little works of art: I can see that just bashing randomly-placed waves of minions would get dull. But I'd still have liked to try it - some games have a horde mode where you survive as long as possible, even if it didn't work in practice it would have made me appreciate the scripting more, I think.

A side effect of everything being tightly scripted (except what actually happens in a battle) is that you can't build up or replenish resources (money and crafting materials) so if you wanted to go back and try a different character build then you couldn't (not that there are many, it isn't RPG-ish, just that you can select a couple of types of equipment for each of the 5-6 set characters). The writing is a bit odd: the overarching plot is somehow *even more* disjointed than Power Rangers, and they have tried to make *every* *single* *line* into a joke: but the layer of abstraction inbetween and the way they set each episode up to satirize the genre is ingenious - almost worthy of Charlie Kaufman at points. The stunt actors are on the way to film a scene, but monsters kidnap one of them, and when the others rescue her the first thing they ask is whether she has brought any food back (on the story's logic she was off the set).

The mecha battles are both disappointing and an excellent rendition of kaiju battles. Round 1: you win. Round 2: they win. Round 3: it's really close but you power attack charges up again just in the nick of time. The mecha's abilities upgrade, the monsters' abilities change, but the traditional pattern is honoured. They're only short, so it isn't annoying - but a tiny bit more mechanics wouldn't have gone amiss like choosing which weapons to take into which fights. In a real super-robot series they would have occasionally had the kindly scientist invent a jetpack so it could fight a flying monster, or something - just for variety.

Overall great fun though.

17040434.review: Pelotão Croma é um jogo de estratégia por turnos com visão isométrica. Já digo que o que mais se destaca é que tudo neste jogo respira Power Rangers! Os personagens tem características bem distintas entre si (e você pode escolher quem eles são e quais suas posições e cores) e os monstros são marcantes, sendo alguns até bem ridículos, como é neste tipo de série. A história começa com uma equipe de dublês que pede demissão de um estúdio para formar uma série super sentai independente. Ou seja, além de lutar, o objetivo do jogo é administrar o novo empreendimento deles, comprando equipamentos para as gravações e para cada ator (ou fazendo-os por um sistema de crafting), respondendo e-mails, planejando ações de marketing e estratégias para o público se interessar cada vez mais no seriado. O jogo traz diversas referências, não só ao universo Power Rangers, mas a outros jogos, filmes, pessoas famosas, etc., além de fenômenos bem atuais, como financiamento coletivo, redes sociais, entre outros. É repleto de cenas hilárias e nunca se perde uma oportunidade de fazer um trocadilho. O sistema de batalha é simples de aprender, sendo que os ataques em conjunto são normalmente mais poderosos (com o uso do Teamwork, que também serve para acrobacias, as quais levam os personagens para distâncias maiores), mas tudo vai ficando bem desafiador com o passar dos episódios (fica ainda mais interessante se você fazer um esforço pra fazer as Director's Intructions, que nada mais são do que metas paralelas em cada fase). O visual tem um charme legal de pixel art e a trilha sonora é sensacional. E ainda tem três finais hein! Taí um jogo que merece ser apreciado não só por ser brasileiro, mas porque é uma baita obra, excelente nos mínimos detalhes.

17004476.review:
A creative tribute to the Tokusatsu genre that many have grown up to or still enjoy. Having team work and acrobatics effect audience levels was an interesting mechanic that allowed to the player to decide on how much of either to do to maximize the attendance to gain more fans/money per episode. The attendance machanic in general seemed a bit easy to abuse to an extent, should have a negative factor if either is overly used.

Having different characters to choose from at the beginning for each role is a really nice touch. It allowed to add in variety to characters with the abilities that affected the gameplay. This allows the player to choose how they would like to play their games, and not have a stagnant gameplay with fixed characters for the storyline only.

Storyline progressed at a decent pace and was well thought out in respect to what Tokusatsu's usually revolved around. But also adding in a bit of flare by blurring reality with fiction.

One thing that was unimpressive after a few levels would be the minion's designs. During a level that had a Boss Mob, could have had the minion's designs centered around that particular Boss in the later stages. It's understandable at the beginning since it is representing the beginning stages of a starter company.

16990935.review:
WOW.

I just finished Chroma Squad and I loved it. I am gonna explain with a couple of keywords what kind of game this is (for those who are considering to buy Chroma Squad):

- Tactical RPG, the tactical form in this game is centered in how you skill your characters (more than positioning).
- Mech fights, YES MECHS.
- Game time, I completed the game in 20 hours.
- Difficulties, there is easy, interesting and challenging. Hardest difficulty is a real BITCH!
- Managing, beside the tactical RPG side of the game, you need to manage your characters by crafting, teching their skills, upgrading your mech, marketing, responding to e-mail where choices matter (not heavily), upgrading your studio and buying items.
- Achievements, well done compared to most indie games.
- Comedy & awesomeness, this game gave me laughs and goosebumps. Comedy is based on parodies of modern memes, Power Rangers and other silly stuff. I got goosebumps in the final fight, where I just got blown away by the story and momentum of it.
- Story is well done and original.

TL:DR
Chroma squad is an original indie game which has two sides of gameplay: tactical RPG and managing your party. The story is wel done and takes around 15+ hours to complete. I had ALOT OF FUN completing this game and I am happy I bought it. You need to understand the mechanics, but the moment you do its fun as hell.

P.S. Don't craft anything until the later seasons, buying items is the way to go.

16902764.review:
This game is exactly what Kickstarter should be about: interesting idea, fantastic development team, and, most importantly, delivery of a finished product. 

The game itself blends a business management simulation on the macro level and a tactical RPG for an episode of the TV series, played for greatest theatrical effect. The animation is simplistic and minimized, but that's okay. This game oozes nostalgia, and coming off as "Mario Brothers-esque" is not an insult. Music and graphical interface are smooth, but some small issues have arisen with different computers. The biggest selling point is by far the writing; snark and self-referential humor make reading the dialogue part of the experience rather than a chore. As an added bonus, there is a fast forward option via pressing the enter key. It's one of the many little details that says this studio cares about the fan experience. 

The only real downside I can think of is the menu system: clunky and no real way to make transitions between the various sub menus easier, but perhaps that is just the nature of a game that puts you in charge of so many details. That being said, the positives outweigh the negatives by several orders of magnitude. Pick this little gem up; even at full price, it's a bargain.

16847271.review:
It's a fun, light-hearted game! It's got good (not fantastic) music, a decent set of strategy mechanics, a fun and mostly light story, giant mechs, and an engaging, but lightweight TV show budget simulator

It's a jack-of-all-games. It's a turn based strategy, 2-D mech fighting, TV show simulator. 

Though, by the end of the 4th season (out of 5), money management ceases to exist because your set is bankrolled enough to fund the wildest expenditures with ease. Combat is also too easy, with some straight up OP characters and pants-on-head AI. The enemy will spread out it's attacks amongst your team rather than congregating together to fight a single weak enemy, thus losing is almost laughably hard. That being said, team acrobatics, team attacks, and finding the sweet spot with AOE attacks are honestly delightful.

It's not super strategic, but it's a genuinely fun and widely appealing indie game.

16845760.review:
As a huge toku fanboy, I was excited to see a video game based on Super Sentai. One that kept in the spirit of sentai by parodying it, and at the same time, paying tribute to it. I've been following this game since Kickstarter, but only more recently got a chance to buy it with the Steam Sale.

As far as the gameplay goes, it actually managed to exceed my expectations. Everything is controlled by mouse and things like the the teamwork mechanic and skills you can switch out are things I've seen in other games, but this is one of the better ones in recent memory. Teamwork is more than just an extra person to help you attack, you can also use teamwork to get to spaces much farther on the field and pull off specials using it. This really helped me when trying to accomplish the special requirements. The game never felt imbalanced, too, which is awesome because it's the easiest trap to fall in with strategy RPGs.

When you start a new game, you're given the option of picking your team. While I wish there was more options for party members (DLC/Chroma Squad 2?), what characters they do have are very diverse and I think they have just a right amount of options for character selections. The plot itself is the exact same regardless of who you pick, so the main reason to do this is to decide your character's starting stats and which ones you would like to see for the rest of the game, which I really like a lot. The easy way out would have been to just always have them in the suit and choose their stats, or just have your five chosen for you. It even allows there to be a possible lesbian romance later on in the game depending on what gender you pick a certain ranger. Your main five are completely customizable.

As for the story itself, it's not like a mind blowing story or anything like that, but it does it's job of feeling like the power ranger/super sentai shows the game is based on. The end goal is defeating a big bad guy, and on the way, you defeat a ton of different monsters ranging from ridiculous to...well, more ridiculous. There's also trophies, multiple endings, storyline branches, and three difficulties to add some replay value.

There's one place this game falls flat for me, and I don't think it's major, because it only really started to bother me nearing the end. The humor in this game can be funny at times, and then at other times can get a little groan worthy with the memes. I don't mind a lot of the refernces. The non-comedic ones for sentai fans in the weapons/equipment/skills that referenced a bunch of different sentai series all made me smile when I realized the references, and certain jokes work really well. At one point, they reference the "What has science done" image with the Seagull with massive biceps, and jokes like that and the backstreet boys/lady gaga references work really well, but when it's just meme, after meme, after meme, it starts to get a little grating, not unlike being in the presence of an middle aged person who goes on Reddit.

Still, I would recommend this to anybody looking for a fun and quirky little RPG. It's definitely worth the price. I still have two more ending paths and minor storyline branches to get, so I may update this in the future, but having just completed my first playthrough, I just wanted to share my thoughts on it.

The customization of your characters is subtle enough to streamline the gameplay but involved enough to make things personal, and give you a reasonable amount of input.  

The plot is cheery and interesting, and it even has a quite a few unexpected turns up its sleeves.  Once you hit the turning point things really escalate quickly, and in the best of ways.

There is tribute paid to so many legacies that the banter alone would make this game worthwhile to a diehard fan.

If you're a fan of Tactical RPG's, it's worth every penny-- and if you're a fan of Super Sentai? It's worth so much more.

16822743.review:
O que dizer de Chroma Squad? Excelente!
É daquelas experiências que você não está preparado para passar, achei a princípio que seria um jogo simples mas divertido, até por seu tema e visual nostalgicos. 

Logo de cara me deparei com um jogo de mecânica muito bem elaborada e divertida de se jogar, com inúmeras possibilidades de estratégia nas batalhas, que se mal usadas acarretam na derrota certa de seu esquadrão. Cada personagem possui suas habilidades únicas que os tornam impressindíveis para que os objetivos sejam alcançados, use cada turno com muita inteligência!

Além da excelente mecânica, o fator customizável do jogo o deixa entretido por horas, você deve escolher o figurino mais adequado para seu esquadrão, bem como melhorias no estúdio que afetam diretamente a jogabilidade na hora das batalhas. As lutas dos MECHAS (robôs gigantes) também são divertidas e requerem além da tática um certo timing para que se obtenha sucesso.

O visual do jogo é muito bom, bastante simpático com animações muito bem feitas, personagens extremamente carismáticos e engraçados e o design de monstros bastante inspirados.
As músicas são gostosas de se ouvir e não enjoam nenhum pouco, aliás é dificil tirar o tema principal da cabeça, melhor escolha impossível.

Veredicto, Chroma squad é um RPG tático de primeiro escalão, recheado de referências e cum uma história muito divertida, tudo feito com extremo capricho e uma grande dose de humor, um produto de alta qualidade vindo de terras tupiniquins! Parabéns a Behold por seu fantástico e inspirador trabalho!!!

16820489.review:
I am an incredibly lazy and therefore never write reviews even though I play so many video games. I had to take some time out today to write a review for Chroma Squad, though, because this game is pure awesome. This game is a 75 on metacritic and thats a clear under-rating.

Yes, I'll acknowledge that Power Rangers/tokusatsu fanboyism is strong within my heart, but you do NOT have to love Power Rangers to love this game. If you can appreciate a creative tactical RPG with fun, geeky dialogue and story lines, you'll be happy with whatever they are charging for this nowadays. Oh, and choices matter!

Gameplay
The combat system is inventive and really lets the player decide how the battles will go. It's not very complicated, but its still satisfying. Think X-com. You can play with a very basic, methodical approach to the fights, or you can open up and fully utilize all the various weapons/skills in the game. Each of the characters has a particular specialty (like most RPGs) and sunergy is key. Between fights, you'll work on upgrading your characters, equipment, base; this aspect of the game isn't particularly deep, but the developer has adjusted to make it more interesting, in terms of viable options. I would say the Mecha fights are lame, however; good thing there isn't really many of them.

Graphics/Music
I'm not really a fan of pixel graphics and all that, but many people seem to love the pixel art. These are easy to judge for yourself. For this type of game, the graphics aren't important to me. But to be honest, if the game wasn't so much fun, I would probably complain about the character models. I think the environments looks pretty great, though.

The music is pure excellence if you are looking for a fully immersive experience. I tend to turn off music on games and listen to my own stuff, but this is one of the few games that I rolled through using the actual game music.

Story
If you are a Sentai/Power Rangers fan in search of nostalgia, you don't even need this section- it's epic.
If you are not as obsessed with sentai as myself, you will still enjoy the hilarious dialogue and story overall. There are some complaints in this aspect because of the imperfect English (dudes are Brazilian), and also because some of the jokes are dated internet-meme jokes, so if that would annoy you then I suppose you'll need to skip through some dialogue? People who complain about the dialogue have maybe forgotten what the dialogue was like in the shows this is modeled after. The plot will surprise you, even if you don't care about sentai at all.


TLDR
Simplified X-com + Power Rangers + loads of content + multiple storylines = FREAKING AMAZING


Best $15 I have spent this year, and I'm about to buy gift copies for some friends even if they don't wana play it.

16762446.review:
I was never a real fan of the whole sentai/power rangers stuff, still the theme was enjoyable on a '90s nostalgia level. I guess a lot of jokes went over my head but I didn't overly mind much.

This game describes itself as a tactical RPG, and it couldn't be more accurate about that. It's not particularly strategy heavy, but the tactical play and the between missions team building feels great. The crafting system is a bit clunky and some of the studio upgrades seem very oddly priced, but that doesn't ruin the fun. The game did feel a bit easy on the medium difficulty setting though.

Alll in all, I feel it's good enough to recommend provided you like tactical play and the theme. The rough edges can be forgiven because you get the real feel that this was a labour of love.

[spoiler]This game does commit the capital sin of making you feel irrelevant during the final bossfight. They tried to go for an epic ending and succeeded, but all your choices and perfect tactics don't contribute to it. It doesn't ruin the game, but it's a beginner's design mistake they shouldn't have made.[/spoiler]

16543347.review:
Chroma Squad é um jogo que me deixou um pouco dividida sobre comprar ou não. De um lado, graficamente falando, eu sou encantada por jogos com esse estilo de bits/pixels. De outro, eu nunca havia experimentado um RPG Tático e, por isso, fiquei naquela dúvida se ia curtir mesmo. Porém, o tema do jogo em si (caraca, criar seu próprio time Super Sentai, me diz se você não quer jogar algo assim e sentir uma boa nostalgia de assistir Power Rangers ou qualquer outro Super Sentai) e a vontade de prestigiar um trabalho feito aqui no nosso bom Brasil me deram um empurrãozinho a mais para comprar. Olha, não me arrependo nem um pouco. 
É um jogo muito divertido, com uma jogabilidade fácil, com uma história boa, cheia de humor, de descontração (os tweets que aparecem no fim de cada episódio gravado e os e-mails que eles recebem são particularmente as minhas coisas favoritas nesse quesito), de referências e, claro, de Sentai (sobre as lutas de Mecha: 10/10). O trabalho em equipe nesse jogo realmente é importante (e cativante). As habilidades de cada personagem do esquadão e o sistema de craft também são coisas que eu gostei bastante. Além disso, a OST é simplesmente espetacular (8-bit music lover here). Mais do que recomendo!

16487433.review:
It's a good game the combat is fun and the story is interesting. 
Pros -
 - Fun boss designs
 - Flashy combat that gives a feel of power rangers style rather than effective combat tactics
 - Interesting story plot

Cons -
 - Cringy "social justice" pandering writing. (you expect cheese moral points but it's feminism and diversity with a rich Californa valley vibe to it)
 - Terrible character selection, if you want to make a themed team after your favorite shows squad you can't. Pick a animal, robot, or fat guy.
 - Poor upgrade system crafting is heavily RNG based and overall doesn't feel very rewarding. It's also annoying to get your squad to match
 - Pixal art
 - Really annoying filter whenever you enter a new area or screen that gives me a massive headache after a couple times with no way to disable it. 

I'd give the game a 6/10 if you want to play a stragety based power rangers game but keep in mind the writing is pretty poor and character selection sucks. 

If you're just wanting a strategy game and you like this games theme maybe get it but it's a 4/10 as far as tactical rpgs go. Not very innovative and loot isn't that rewarding

I bought this game on a whim, and I don't regret it.  I really enjoyed the fast paced combat, the crafting, and studio upgrade system.  I thought I'd have an issue that the squad really only levels up through gear you equip, but it didn't actually bother me that much.  You get a new ability every season, so that in its own, felt kind of like progression.

I didn't care for the mecha fights so much, it was cool at first, but got boring fast.

I played on the hardest difficulty, having little experience in Tactical RPGs, but I ended up have only a few issues until the final boss, where the difficulty amped up big time.

If you like fast paced Tactical RPG's, you'll like this.

Im giving this a positive review because it has deserved it.
The only reason you should not buy this game is if you absolutely HATE tactical RPGs.
Otherwise get it.
+Fluid and well done Pixel Art
+FANTASTIC Music
+Fun and simple tactical combat. But not easy peasy if you let your guard down!
+Enjoyable if somewhat predictable story that, if you dont take it too seriously, is a great experience all the way. Plenty of 4th wall breaking too
+Massive quantity of customization. From outfit colours, to the actors inside the suits, to the effing Catchphrases to transform and the one to call your Mecha. 
+Lots of items to craft and buy to outfit your characters and give them different attributes. RPG veterans will spend quite a while in the room outfitting


-You won't get too many abilities in this game overall for your actors. And the classes are set. Just a little thing that might just be me nitpicking.
-If you fail an Episode, or decide to restart it, getting to the point you were at, skipping all the text is a bit tedious. I did feel like I was being punished for restarting the mission, instead of going through and failing it and taking a hit in my fanbase. But its the same for failing.
-A few hilarious but present Graphical glitches, which luckily did not harm my gameplay. The most common one for me were my actors greeting clone version of themselves in the studio interface.

LIGHTS,CAMERA,CHROMATIZE!

16468158.review:
A power rangers inspire strategy fighter. The pixelated artstyle is fantastic, the humour is brilliant, the music is so very fitting.
The story is about a group of disgruntled stunt actors forming their own studio to produce a power ranger/ super sentai series without network interfierence. The story is played out in episodes and seasons, with the studio inbetween for upgrades, equipment, ability management and mecha construction. 
Each customisable character has their own abilities and personality, fights have a big reliance on team-work and the more stunts and team attacks and director instructions you pull off, the bigger audience you get, which nets you more money, more marketing and a bonus later on.
I highly recommend it to anyone even vaguely interested!

16375272.review:
Talk about a hidden gem!

I wasn't sure of what exactly I was expecting when I purchased Chroma Squad, but I liked the combination of tactical RPG and Power Rangers references enough that I had to give it a shot.  I was impressed right out of the gate as the game incorporates several different genres very well and even adds several new elements that I have not seen before.

The tactical combat of the game is very enjoyable and there is much more to it than I had initially assumed.  Each episode begins with your heroes arriving on the scene and battling their enemies in their plain clothes.  While in this form you don't have access to your equipment and abilities, though you are formidable enough to go toe-to-toe with the villains all the same.  Once you transform, however, you get your costume and the previously stated abilities unlocked and you can really do some impressive things.  

The aspect of combat that really caught my attention and made this game stand out, though, is that your goal is to make every fight as cinematic as possible.  For example, every battle has two Director's Objectives that give a massive boost to the points you earn for putting on an exciting fight, your Audience.  You also gain audience for performing special skills, defeating enemies, using teamwork to give a teammate a boost (the boosted character performs an acrobatic maneuver to move additional spaces that turn), and most of all for performing unified 'team attacks' where you set your squad up in such a manner that they all focus on and attack the targeted enemy at once,

The music is enjoyable, the battles challenging and fun.  Did I mention that you get to customize the look of your gear, colors of your outfits, specializations of your stats and skills, and actors who you use for your squad?  Oh right, and you get to customize and do battle with your own mech!

I can not put into words how highly I recommend this game.  Truly a hidden gem and one of the best games I've come across in awhile.

16337607.review:
It’s not often that one show can take control of an entire generation. For my childhood it was Power Rangers… This multi-cultural love-letter to nostalgia took over many homes in the 90s with force. Its flimsy morals and clunkily scripted acting were apparently exactly what most of the world was looking for, as we stumbled out of the cocaine-fueled haze that was the 80s. There are very few shows today that manage to galvanize fans in such massive numbers. Maybe Spongebob comes close, but he’s a crossdresser who lives inside of a fruit. Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG about a tokusatsu show similar to Power Rangers. Each character has a specialized role, but are able to be slightly customized to your liking depending on the actor/equipment you choose. Chroma Squad does have a few blemishes, but is an overall amazing experience. Will it hold up for those who aren’t wearing nostalgia goggles? Let’s find out as we look deeper at Chroma Squad.

Fantastic retro style coats Chroma Squad, from the graphics to the music. While the gameplay starts out feeling extremely simple, it quickly deepens as the odds are stacked ever-higher against you. After moving you can attack, move a second time, or prepare for teamwork. Teamwork is an awesome aspect that allows your characters to toss each other around in fantastic acrobatics, or prepare a combo attack on an adjacent enemy. Teamwork attacks are an absolute necessity, as later enemies take multiple attacks to defeat. Aside from fantastic agility and teamwork, the Chroma Squad doesn’t have much in the way of firepower when they’re in their 28-year-old-teenager form. However, once per fight though, you can Chromatize. Transformation not only fully heals all your characters, but also unlocks a variety of special abilities. Every season you will unlock a couple of new skills to pick from, and this extends the replayability of Chroma Squad greatly.

The fights take place in a variety of sets. Some are fantastic to look at, with a variety of hazards. Others are completely stark with nothing on display except for a couple lighting guys and key grips using their bellies to knock bowls of mac’n’cheese off of the craft service table. At least that’s what I like to imagine. The gameplay grows even deeper as you realize there are a variety of director actions you will need to follow during the combat in order to maximize your audience and gain new fans. Chroma Squad isn’t all about high-flying action though. Between episodes you will need to craft equipments and gear up your heroes, choose between a variety of marketing agents with tons of different boosts, and assemble your mecha to do battle when your enemies go super-size. The management aspect is extremely interesting, and while praying to RNGsus while crafting for a decent upgrade can become a bit frustrating, it again does wonders to extend the replayability.

I’ve sung so much praise for Chroma Squad that I am loathe to point out the low points, but it is about that time in the review. The majority of the controls are point and click, which can be a bit of a drain when sitting for extended play sessions. The less-inspired set designs seriously break my heart, as there is much more potential than a big empty room. The story does alright, aside from some pretty blatant SJW messaging in the beginning. It might be tongue in cheek. I can really only hope. Overall I think Chroma Squad is an experience worth having, especially if you were raised on Power Rangers or Big Bad Beetleborgs or VR Troopers. There really were just a plethora of these shows on in the 90s. This is why it’s pretty obvious to me why this game was so easily kickstarted, and I am positively overjoyed that Behold Studios was able to bring Chroma Squad very close to its full potential. I really do hope to see a sequel sometime in the future.

Gameplay:

    Controls- 6/10
    Fun Factor- 9/10
    Difficulty- 8/10
    Replayability- 7/10
    Innovation- 10/10

Aesthetic:

    Graphics- 9/10
    Music- 10/10
    Sound FX- 8/10
    Story/Lore- 7/10
    Level Design- 6/10

Final Score: 80/100 for innovation, graphics, and fun factor.
Summary: Fantastic tactical RPG infused with humor and deceptively-deep gameplay.
Verdict: Amazing fun. Not as replayable as something like Final Fantasy Tactics, but still worth a look.

Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-chroma-squad/
Full review video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J5JHWQLc0zo

16301147.review:
Aaaah! After 10,000 years I'm free! Not only from the infernal hellfire of school, but from that god awful writer's block! Time to conq- write; write a review. Sorry. It's on Chroma Squad, so strap in.

REVIEW
Chroma Squad

GENRE
Tactical RPG

STORY
The year is 20XX probably. Five stunt actors with attitude are recording their parts in the most recent episode of the hit sentai show sensation: Super Rangers! The show stinks though, and so does its director: Dr. Mi Ah. [More like MAMAMiAh, amirite?] No cool monster fights, no struggles against the higher ups, and most of all; no giant mecha fights! Our heroes are fed up and, immediately after finishing the recording session, quit Super Rangers to start their own sentai show. The gang sets up their base of operations in Blue's uncle's warehouse; unsure of where to begin. However, in the center of the room stands a large object obscured with a large bedsheet. Pulling the sheet off, our actors find the start of their new journey,  and after signing a contract or two; they're ready to Lights, Camera, Chromatize!

GAMEPLAY
Chroma Squad is very unique in its gameplay, fairly simple, but unique nonetheless. You control your units on a grid, taking turns moving your units and allowing your enemies to move. Simple. You can utilize a teamwork mechanic to not only group up on an enemy, but launch your rangers to spaces they couldn't normally reach. Unique. Each of your units has specific passives and abilities tailored to their class. Simple. These abilities may come into play for completing 'director's instructions'; secondary objectives that will give a healthy boost to your audience. Unique. Every mission features a big boss monster that has its own special attacks and abilities. Simple. Just like in Power Rangers though, the monster becomes gigantic after you beat it; bringing you into a risk-vs-reward kaiju fight minigame. Unique. You get the jist. 

Outside of combat you can upgrade your gear, improve your studio, answer e-mails, sign marketing agencies to your show, and upgrade your mecha. Upgrading your gear not only increases certain stats, but visually changes the look of your heroes for hire. Improving your studio provides you with an advantage while recording your episodes; though you really shouldn't think too hard about them. I'm not rally sure how upgrading your light fixtures makes enemies less likely to dodge attacks, but I also don't get how so many people burn their meals while watching my show. E-mails range from heartfelt to crazy and everything in-between Sometimesyou get fan-mail about aliens and tinfoil hats, and other times you get companies asking you to buy a 'sword enlargment kit.' Marketing agencies provide temporary bonuses in and outside of combat depending on which agencies you sign your brand to. Personally, I always chose Toys-R-Fans because I like money having money; lots and lots of money. Upgrading your mecha simply gives it small bonuses during the kaiju fights, such as increased hit chance or a chest beam. Y'know, little things.

VISUALS
The visuals are nice, not too complex, but very charming. The pixelated aesthetic compliments the game nicely; and this especially shows in the exemplary boss design. You'll start out fighting monsters like Boxing Box; a cardboard box with boxing gloves. [You're on a tight budget okay?] Eventually however, you'll be fighting intergalactic evildoers such as Tengu, a Japanese demon with cloning capabilities. Either way, the game was pleasin' to my eyeballs and I think it'll please yours too.

SOUNDTRACK
Hot diggity dog, this is a good soundtrack! Featuring 31 unique tracks composed by a variety of artists; you couldn't ask for anything better to accompany your multi-dimensional misadventures. Each track fits its respective scene beautifully, with the timing on some of them being downright god-tier. [That might be a bit of an exaggeration, but you get the point.] Personally, my favorite track has got to be the main theme. I can't tell you how much time I've wasted on the main menu listening to it. I probably need help.

FINAL THOUGHTS
It takes quite a bit to make me buy a game based off of impulse alone, and Chroma Squad happened to have that special something. It was charming, enjoyable, and just challenging enough from start to finish to keep me wanting more consistently. In a way, I got hooked on Chroma Squad the way you get hooked on a show. My first thought after beating an episode was 'Man, I can't wait to see what happens next!'. Being able to choose my actors and their names was a great touch, and the ability to modify the catchphrases and names of aspects of the show took it to the next level. I don't think I'll ever get tired of a wise, robed monk yelling 'Prepare for dank justice!' before turning into a spandex clad superhero. The gameplay is simple, but brings a unique twist to just about every aspect. The dialogue is... cringe-worthy at times to say the least. At the same time though, it reminded me of the horrible dialogue in my favorite shows as a kid. I love the look of it, and I don't think I'll ever quite get over how fantastic the music was. This game is by no means perfect, but for what it's worth; I'm willing to say that this is everything that I've ever looked for in a videogame. It panders to my inner-child, it indulges my unhealthy addiction to customization, it scratches that tactical gameplay itch, it gives me goosebumps when I listen to the music, and most of all; it makes me remember why I love video games. Thanks Behold Studios, I needed something to get me outta this rut.

16266912.review:
8/10
"Great gameplay along with nostalgic references, couple of tweeks to mecha combat needed and more diverse storylines wouldnt hurt"

I picked this game up based on the theme and overall design and i am so glad i did! Brilliant references to 90's culture and an interesting tactical RPG combat system make this game very enjoyable. The scenario is you are stunt performers of a super sentai show who decide to make it on your own by kickstarting your own, the plot then twists from what is a tv show with stunt actors to then turn into something alot more real. The game gives you full control over your cast, studio and many other things which makes this game very interesting and different from the norm. With your team of 5 unique classes you can take down foes with a variety of unique moves or work together and form devastating combo attacks. The fact each character is a certain class is a great idea keeping you thinking about what form of attack you will make that will benefit the battle in the long run. Your characters strengths can also be upgraded with an interesting upgrade system, with a shop you can spend program revenue with to buy stronger equipment or a crafting system in which you can create equipment with drops or purchased materials to help make your characters or mecha stronger. As far as the mecha is concerned it is perhaps the weakest part of this brilliant title, although it feels incredible the first couple of times it happens the tactical tile RPG suddenly turns into a 2D fighting mechanic that feels as though it relies on luck far too often. Your accuracy ratio reduces the number of successful hits you make in the same turn, there were times however where i would hit once have an 85% hit chance and miss finishing my combo. i understand it can happen sometimes but it happened alot more than it probably should have. It made it more frustrating given the fact the enemy monster had the same attack pattern which never missed and then could also do a super attack every few turns made some of these duels long, repetitive and rather frustrating. I feel if the mecha combat was still a tile combat system where you fight in the city it could be made a lot more interesting, whats to say your viewer rating could go down based on the number of detroyed buildings via combat, or using the environment to your advantage. It would certainly make the currently bland mecha combat into something a bit more interesting. The story structure is set in a number of series in which the goal is to increase your fanbase and revenue by putting on an awesome show. You are also in charge of advertising and the studio which can be upgraded to help with the show. The idea of seperate series is great and makes the game into more bitesize chuncks that open up possibilities of extra content later on. With multiple endings the game does have replay value and the episodes in each season can be played in any order desired. The enemy designs are fantastic and some of the stories are great but perhaps more of a mixup with different scenarios would only benefit the game more, party members could be missing or sub objectives could be more diverse with perhaps saving civilians or dealing with environmental scenarios. This does happen sometimes but maybe not enough.
The soundtrack is a pleasure to listen to and keeps the tempo going. it plays very well along with the artistic style of the game.

Overall the game is a great experience, especially if you are a power rangers/super sentai fan with some great story and combat design and an interesting yet simple upgrade system and tle based RPG combat. More diverse storylines and some work on the mecha battles would only do this game good! If they bring out more content as well this game could be played long into the future.

Chroma Squad is a turn-based rpg, where you essentailly run a Sentai show. I personally love this game, it has some great mechanics, and the dialogue is rather impressive and witty. You control most aspects of the "show" from the name of the squad, to the catchphrases that they yell in combat. The story, yes there is a story, is simple and funny. It essentially follow the typical story that you'd expect from any sentai show.

It's not a terribly long game, as I'm on 8 hours of gameplay and in my 4th season out of 5 seasons. Each season gradually gains more episodes with various conditions that will gain you more audience/fans. These conditions vary from survive 10 turns to use teamwork acrobatics 5 times. Their simple conditions that give each episode a nice flavor, and occasionally make you play with a different strategy.

Overall, it's a fun game. Simple and easy to pick up. Sure the graphics aren't the best, but it fits very nicely with the theme of the game.

16235734.review: This game is fantastic and I cannot stop playing it. You're tasked with running your own TV studio in order to produce a Power Rangers-esque show. Your path to stardom will not be easy, as a plethora of monsters and baddies must be fought to attract the larest audience possible. I'm usually not a big fan of games with a turn-based combat system, however Chroma Squad knows how to make it fun and interesting. Team attacks, finishing moves, acrobatics, and skills are all at your disposal while fighting the hordes of enemies thrown at you. To my surprise, the game also implements a crafting system. Enemies will drop loot that can be turned into gear. In addition to this, you may recycle old gear to gain some parts, which in turn can be crafted into nicer materials to make better gear. There's a shop too, and a place to buy studio upgrades. All in all, there is a lot to see here, and the funny dialogue and refreshing gameplay make it a great experience.

16156911.review:
Em meados de 2013, estava eu circulando pelos sites de games, quando uma notícia explodiu minha cabeça: A Behold Studios, estúdio brasileiro responsável pelo incrível Knights of Pen and Paper, estava angariando recursos no Kickstarter para o desenvolvimento de um jogo chamado Chroma Squad. O vídeo promocional deixa claro a proposta do jogo: administrar um programa Sentai, aqueles seriados japoneses de grupos de super-heróis fantasiados que ficaram populares aqui no Ocidente, principalmente por causa dos Power Rangers. Na mesma hora eu pensei: meu corpo precisa desse jogo. Mas como lados de dois imãs de mesma polaridade que se repelem, cada dia que passava, o jogo se afastava de mim. Antes previsto para o final de 2013, o jogo foi adiado para o final de 2014, sendo somente lançado em abril de 2015. Parte do atraso se deu por um bom motivo, pois com o lançamento do beta para quem comprou o jogo na pré-venda ou para quem o financiou pelo Kickstarter, os desenvolvedores puderam receber um feedback dos jogadores e assim aprimorarem o jogo. Por outro lado, o estúdio teve que enfrentar uma situação delicada com a Saban, detentora dos direitos de distribuição da marca Power Rangers no Ocidente, que ameaçava impedir o lançamento de Chroma Squad, em virtude de direitos autorais. Por fim, ambas as empresas chegaram a um acordo e o jogo pode ser lançado. \o/

A jogabilidade se divide em três etapas:

1) Gerenciamento do estúdio: Nesse ponto, cabe a você a administração do programa que consiste em  várias ações como contratação dos atores, compra de melhorias para o estúdio, marketing e aquisição de uniformes e armas. Neste último quesito, existem duas opções: comprar os itens na lojinha ou fabricá-los utilizando diversos materiais como caixa de papelão e massinhas de modelar que são dropados pelos inimigos durante os episódios. Essa improvisação nível cospobre,nos lembra muito os seriados sentai/tokusatsu em que tudo era ou parecia ser de baixo orçamento. Outras situações que emulam esse espírito mulambo são as caracterizações de muitos vilões, como o Boxing Box, ou a conversa dos personagens durante a história. Com o passar do tempo, o estúdio vai melhorando, tornando as coisas mais profissionais. O jogo possui dois medidores: Dinheiro e Quantidade de Fãs que são diretamente influenciados pelas ações durante a gravação dos episódios e pela quantidade de audiência conquistada, bem como pelas políticas de marketingadotadas.

2) Gravação dos Episódios: As fases são organizadas em temporadas que por sua vez são divididas em episódios (Ah, antes que você pergunte, tem episódios gravados na pedreira). Durante as fases, deve-se lutar com uma onda de inimigos e um chefão, seguindo a orientação do diretor para ajudar a aumentar a audiência. O combate possui o estilo RPG de estratégia em turnos como visto em X-com e Final Fantasy Tatics. Uma novidade trazida por esse jogo chama-secooperação em que permite coordenar a movimentação e os golpes dos rangers. Caso todos os cincos ataquem ao mesmo tempo, uma animação surge na tela e nos lembra aqueles ataques finalizadores executados nos seriados. Cada ranger possui habilidades diferentes e, à medida que as temporadas vão passando, há o desbloqueio de novas. 
3) Luta  de robôs: Após a derrota do monstro-chefe,um bom e velho clichê dos sentai ocorre: o monstro aumenta de tamanho e o Mecha é invocado. A jogabilidade muda novamente, passando a ser de RPG em turnos em que a cada golpe desferido pelo robô aumenta o multiplicador de dano, mas diminui a chance de acerto e, se errar um golpe, o turno passa para o monstro e incube ao jogador a defesa no momento certo. Apesar de simples e rolar um fator sorte, planejar bem os golpes torna-se importante, combinando golpes simples com os especiais. Se porventura a vida do mecha chegar a zero, o jogador recebe uma segunda chance chamada “Poder de Fã”, em que ganha-se uma nova vida baseada na quantidade de telespectadores.
A história do jogo é simples e divertida, com algumas reviravoltas e três finais diferentes, pois, em certo ponto, dependendo da escolha tomada, um determinado personagem é desbloqueado e a narrativa segue um rumo diferente. Os gráficos são belos e pixelados e a trilha sonora impecável, apesar de um pouco repetitiva. 
Caracterizar o jogo como somente “um jogo inspirado na série Power Ranger”, tradução livre do subtítulo exigido pela Saban, é subestimar a carta de amor que esse jogo escreve para as séries tokusatsu/sentai. Além disso, notamos influências de outros elementos da cultura nerd e pop que rendem grandes risadas, momentos WTF e explosões de nostalgia. Jogo recomendadíssimo para quem gosta das coisas boas da vida. Parabéns a Behold Studios por esse projeto maravilhoso.

16148006.review:
More or less an in depth review
-Pros
~This game brings you back to your childhood (or lets you experience a childhood), bringing me back to the days where I proudly watched series like Power Rangers. Not many games that want me to feel nostalgic can do it like this game, the next best thing for nostalgia would be Shovel Knight, but this takes the cake
~Simple , yet extremely fun RPG mechanics. Ok lets get this down, 5 base classes, the lead, support, techie, assault, medic. Each class is equipped with each special ability of course, but then there becomes another layer, with the inclusion of different characters with each their own respective stats and weaknesses, this can dramatically effect the way you can fight a boss. An example would be, my lead, who i chose to be the Panda Guy (Forgot his name!) has reduced movement speed, because of this one of the episodes required me to kill the boss with my lead (This is also known as Director Instructions, although not required, it gives you a boost in "audience" which helps you use a few Studio options which will be explained later) My lead was way too far from the boss and there was no way to get to him before the boss dying from my techie's amazing counter-chance. Thus causing me to feel the want to restart the level and do it again to 100% it, and I did, I had to dramatically change the way I play by having the Lead always stay close to the boss while the others protect him. Now I would explain the skills to you, but they are fairly simple and standard RPG mechanics (Use them and then you have a cooldown, the usual)
~What it wants to introduce to you though is it's "teamwork" mechanic. This mechanic allows you to have one of your well....heroes...can sacrifice their turn to say instead of using a skill to kill an enemy they switch to teamwork mode so that another one of your team can go to them and be launched farther than they can usually move, you could also do a teamwork attack. Which consists one or maybe even all of your team to attack a single opponent, which does become very useful against harder minions.
~Music- Goddamn the music is so nostalgic, it literally brings the heart of 8-Bit RPGS and Super-Sentai series and puts them together to make just an amazing soundtrack
~Story - To me, the story is the important part of a game (If it offers a story, it better be damn good *cough cough Call of Duty Ghosts cough cough*. Now at first the story may seem pointless, but after maybe the 2nd season if i recall, it gets just a huge jump in drama and everything just starts to mold into place. Each character is given their own little "arc" or little segment focusing on them and their personal problems, and by the end of them season you feel satisfied and you just want more. Although I won't spoil much of the story, I can tell you that the dialouge includes many pokes and jabs toward internet memes and commonly uses smiley faces (Which too me is very refreshing) Now in terms of story itself, you start off as very ticked off actors that leave the studio they are hired at and buy/create their own. As you progress you are given "choices" through "fan mail" which people send you, although it may not seem significant, these fan mail choose the path you will be taken on and how your fans will react, also be warned there is no voice acting so get ready to read.
~Bosses- Each boss is super memorable and actually are pretty damn funny when intended, each skill set makes sense for each boss and are actually pretty fun to figure out how to fight against. Now after certain fights, you are allowed to what some people may call MECHA FIGHTSSSSS!.....now these are simple but are actually pretty fun and poke fun at the *ahem* Power Rangers mecha fights.
~Stuio/Crafting Etc. - In the studio you can buy stuff from the shop or look and change the skill sets of your characters. Inside the shops you are given the ability to buy Armor and Weapons. Now most of these items are basic and the best usually come from crafting (DUH) but are still useful. Now crafting, simple, yet not the best or even my favorite, so ill explain my dislikes of it later. You can also go to the "Studio" options which allow you to spend money generated from episodes to upgrade certain attributes (Health Care gives your actors +Health and HD Cameras give you better Audience Conversion Rate). Next up is the Mecha Screen, basiclly upgrading the parts of the mecha to make it better as the story progresses. Not too overly complicated, but could be a lot better.
-Cons
~Crafting- Because you cant replay episodes, you better hope you get those crafting items by luck OR you can spend considerable ( A LOT ) of money from episodes you did to buy Material Packs and because of this you may be out of luck for the first few seasons or you force yourself not to buy better Armor/Weapons/Studio Upgrades. 
~Agency Buying- I held off talking about this because I'm more or less biased toward this, but as you progress thorugh the story you can hire agencies to promote your show, this gives you special boosts to a certain amount of episodes (1 or 3) and of course it tells you the boosts but it doesnt tell you how much fan power it costs (You earn fan power during episodes) which left me bummed out because although there were 4 boosts I liked on the agency, I could only get 1 of them for 3 episodes because I didnt know the fan power was so high. Leaving me a lot of money down the drain.

~All in all this is a great game, it achieves what it wants and does even better than certain rpg's. I would give this game the Indie Game of the Year if i could

9.4/10

16123298.review:
Отличная игра, особенно если вы в детсве любили смотреть Power Rangers. Позитивная и немного наивная игра которая оставила кучу положительных эмоций после себя. 

Суть, вы открываете свою собственную инди-студию чтобы снимать свой собственный сериал аля "Power Rangers". Выбираете членов команды, их цвета, имена и даже фразы которые они выкрикивают перед трансформацией или вызовом гиганского робота. 

Ваша задача снимать эпизоды (уровни) в которых вы деретесь в несложнм но интересном пошаговом бою, в течении которого вы должы не только победить всех врагов, но и выполнить указания режисера чтобы под конец сезона у вас было достаточно фанатов, зрителей и соответсвенно денег. На эти денги вы покупаете картон и изоленту из которой собираете новые [strike]ведра[/strike] шлемы, костюмы мечи и запчасти для робота, но или просто покупаете в магазине.

Все сезоны связываються сюжет в котором вам в будут навязывать силу дружбы и равенства, прямо как в Power Rangers. Сюжет забавный, нелепый и нелинейный, судя по всему в игре есть 3 концовки (пока что прошел только 1 раз).

Единственное НО, без знаний английского или партугальского игра потеряет весь свой шарм и смысл, так что если не знаете один из этих языков семь раз подумайте перед покупкой. Лично я не пожалел потраченых денег и выпавший из жизни день.

16109818.review:
If you had even a passing interest in Power Rangers as a kid, you'll get a kick out of this, even more so with the fact that you can tweak your team from the start by changing their names, appearances (or even, in some cases, race) and suit color to add your own personal flavor. I spent a good ten minutes trying to come up with my own team name and catch-phrases. The tactical RPG aspects are simple and enjoyable, and I like a more streamlined approach to gearing the squad. What I really love about the game, though, is its consistent charm; from my characters yelling my ridiculous catch-phrases, to the Assist character constantly using emoji's in dialogue, to some of the ridiculous bosses you face (shout-out to Transitmancer), I often had a wide grin on my face while playing.

As for gripes, well, the Kaiju battles got repetitive; spam Punch until you were at about 60% accuracy then pop Defense, Defend self against enemy's attacks, repeat. It'll probably be harder on higher difficulties, but I found myself getting somewhat bored during a battle between a GIANT ROBOT AND A GIANT MONSTER. Also, there were a couple bosses who kept doing knockback abilities that kept me from doing a Finishing Move, which happened to be a side-objective for that Episode, so I spent maybe twenty minutes trying to get into the correct position.

That said, though, this is perfectly viable nostalgia fuel that manages to be fun, engaging and lets you have a beaver on your superhero team. Sheer brilliance.

16048501.review:
Chroma Squad is, as it says, a tactical RPG that was inspired by the many Sentai series such as Power Rangers, Kamen Rider and many, many more. What is the story, you ask? Well, essentially, the story of the game goes like this: You have a bunch of stunt people who recently quit their jobs because of a director who was, shall we say, demanding and is overall being a complete douche and they all decide to start a studio of their own! From the beginning, they don't have much to work with, using cardboard, duct tape, and third-rate costumes to get by, eventually, they start having an audience to work with.

The gameplay is quite fun, you kit out your actors in the best gear that cardboard and duct tape can buy and record new 'episodes', essentially maps, for the season, each with their own bonus objectives that don't punish you much for failing them but the extra fans and cashflow you can get from maxing out your audience each episode is a nice incentive to do them. Every actor has their own special abilities that are accessible as soon as they suit up which can be sometimes impossible to do at the start of the episode as you need to build audience power first before chromatizing. The phrases said throughout the game such as "Chromatize" and "Mecha Power, Activate!" can be modified in the studio to your liking. Yes, this means you can be as silly or as creative as you like... or creatively silly.

The difficulty of the game is strange at times, some episodes are easy, others are pretty difficult, even with the best gear for the season's tier equipped, and others still are fairly difficult. You'll end up curbstomping half the time if you're playing on the normal difficulty if you know how to play tactical RPGs, well, tactically, and I'm fairly certain hard mode is pretty challenging but I can't quite say that for myself. I'm not going to say that this game is too easy but it feels too easy at times, especially when you have an assault one-shotting everything they touch that isn't a boss monster or a shielded enemy.

However, despite the odd difficulty curve, I absolutely adore the presence of the game and I absolutely love the feel and the gameplay of Chroma Squad, it kind of reminds me of XCOM, in a way, with all the aliens but minus the permadeath. Oh, and the music's damn good too, I will admit that the title theme may have dug deep into my brain and has implanted its melody into my brain and it won't get out. Although, there's not really much replayability in this game apart from the acheievements and, well, I can't say all that much without spoilers.

In short? Fun game, even if you're not very familiar with the subject of the game, although most references may fly over you since this is an homage game, after all. Worth a buy? Sure. It's a good game for its price although it tends to be lacking a bit in the replayability department, it's fun for what it's worth and that is what matters.

16032780.review:
I was really hesitant at first to purchase this game because of the lackluster look to combat but damn, the power rangers/super sentai theme just won me over. I've watched every episode of power rangers and most of super sentai. With that said, the thematic elements are spot on. The way the dialogue is corny and the team up moves are all taken from power rangers and i love every single second of it.

As for the turn based strategy, the game is pretty fun. While other games like Fire Emblem or FF tactics have more interesting and robust systems, the combat elements in this game are still fun. Complexity doesnt always mean fun game play. 

The RPG elements are also very interesting. I was surprised to see that this game has a development strategy portion similar to that of the kariosoft games. Overall, highly recommend this game if your a power rangers/super sentai fan. For rpg/tactics fans, I would say it's less complicated and interesting the other games in the genere , but the combat is still fun.

16027911.review: A really well made yet simple. Yet has a few annoying bugs. Overall 9/10. The story is good and can give you a laugh.

16027712.review:
Summary: The game is great only hindered by some difficulty issues and minor bugs. The games story and graphics are fantastic. Upgrading is satisfying and also takes a lot of thinking. Combat takes strategy and is near flawless, for the most part aside from the Mech battles difficulty spike.

Lengthy-er Review: Combat is great, it takes a lot of strategy of what combinations of teamwork, and skills to boost your audience meter. The game lets you customize what your squads name is, transforming motto, and actor names. This makes the game feel way more your own and adds a lot of depth. The story is silly and over-the-top enough to feel very Sentai-like. The "hub" where you buy upgrades and items is another fantastic aspect of the game. Buying new items and mech parts, along with buying new marketers who can bring you special benefits depending on which person you sign a contract with. Replying to fan emails was also a joy to do. Now onto the cons. Mech fights are incredibly challenging even on normal mode, it took me NUMEROUS times to defeat most makes in the final 2 seasons. Mech fights also lack strategy and ends up mostly being dependent on luck. For example, for each punch you start off around 90% chance to hit, then goes down to around 80% for the next punch, and so on. Problem is healing skills require you to get around a 4x combo of punches to do any real healing, and so does the +Def move. It is nearly impossible to get consistent 4x combo, myself rarely even getting 3x combos. Even with that decent sized flaw it doesn't take away too much from the game, it is still fantastic and charming. All the pro's easily out weigh the cons.
Rating: 9/10
