15984642.review:
Chroma Squad é algo que espero há muito tempo!
Um jogo simples que supreende. Cheio de nostalgia e referências aos seriados japoneses que só quem cresceu assistindo vai tirar total proveito da história e dos diálogos. Dei muita risada durante todo o jogo e fiquei como uma criança de 10 anos que vai na locadora todo final de semana para alugar o mesmo jogo até zerar. 
É um jogo feito por pessoas que viveram aquela infância de Changeman, Jaspion, Power Rangers, aqui no Brasil. Então você se sente em casa o tempo todo. Tudo é uma referência, uma lembrança. 
A jogabilidade em si é muito simples, você só precisa usar o mouse. Algumas fases são fáceis, mas outras podem realmente dar um desafio de horas. Joguei logo de cara no modo mais difícil e zerei assim. Confesso que a vontade que eu tenho agora é de fazer tudo de novo, de forma diferente. A customização possibilita que tudo seja bem diferente. Tem até final alternativo...

Definitivamente o melhor jogo Indie de 2015. Vale o preço inteiro.

15978789.review:
For 15 or even 30 bones, you really can't do much better than Chroma Squad. Even if Power Rangers (or Super Sentai if you INSIST) isn't necessarily your jam, it hits all the right notes for making a good gaming experience through that Triple-A seems to have forgotten; It's fun. Fun. You remember that? You know, when you get giggles or smile? When you get drawn into the experience not because of the spectacle, but because the game directly involves you and lets you make it your own, that's how you make games fun.

Throwing down on some details, here's some specifics of why it's already made my top ten for 2015 -

-Turn-Based strategy, not RPG. Think XCOM: EU, but with goddamn Power Rangers.

-Customisation and upgrades for pretty much EVERYTHING.

-Resource management that's more give-take than just your standard subtraction. It reminds me a lot of how the economy worked in Mechwarrior 2: Mercenaries, a type of economy system I feel got left by the wayside in favour of simpler/easier things that don't add any weight to your decisions.

-Crafting, a system that is notorious for earning my ire by basically being utter bullshit roughly a million per-cent of the time, actually makes some sort of sense in how components are named/what goes into what. It's also not needlessly complicated, which is a gigantic tick in my "yes" box.

-It's got good moments of humour in it. It's not a comedy game, per se, but it knows not to take itself too seriously, and the humour it employs has a nice spectrum, from subtle pointing out of tropes, tongue-in-cheek, to bad puns, to breaking the fourth wall, and even some nice.... "meta" moments.

-The art is nicely done, and consistent. While I can't say I have any particular love for the "retro" style that just about every indie game is doing, this one has really nicely animated sprites with a lot of good character to them as well as fun and well-done environments.

In conclusion, if you're one of those indie-game wads that just can't get enough of retro-styled graphics, crafting and whatever, you should have already creamed your free-trade, locally sourced shorts just by looking at the game's trailer. But even if you're not, this is definitely a game worth playing if you just want to have some goddamn fun playing games for once.

15930846.review:
This game may have been released too soon. Once it's fully bug tested and no longer freezes during the interminably long last mission (which I finished after 7 attempts and two weeks), this game is a 4/5. As it stands, with these glitches, it's a 2/5. 

Positives:
- The idea is well thought out and utilized. 
- The main RPG game is fun and entertaining, and fairly deep. 
- The fourth wall breaks and overall sense of humor are fun. 
- Customization- you can change your team's name and their various battle cries. These make the in game dialogue awesome at times. (No, Bill, of course you're as important as anyone else in Sakura and the Rest!) I'd like more costume choices, but what's there is fine. 

Negatives:
- The mecha missions are incredibly dull, since it always comes down to the same exact fight (punch punch punch punch special. Click to lesson damage. Click to lessen damage. Click to lessen damage. Punch punch punch punch block.) A few of the enemies have very slow animation that makes the battles even MORE interminable, especially the Barney parody. I changed the mecha summoning catch phrase to "Let's Get This Over With!" I seriously dreaded them every time. 
- Glitches. These are the game's current biggest issue. They seem to be clearing up, but they kept me from finishing the last mission for two weeks, which destroyed the game's momentum and my interest in pursuing the other alternate endings. Buyer beware. 
- The last mission. There's a plot twist in that last mission that changes who the villain is that makes it less satisfying. I didn't get the final battle I REALLY wanted. 

Overall, this game is a lot of fun and incredibly imaginative. Once it's fully polished, I recommend it. Just check out the community board before buying and make sure that things have been cleared up.

15918410.review:
Watch our review on our channel Steam Punks! 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_gwizmWdkYU

Who didn’t have at least some fascination for Power Rangers when they were a kid? Sure the effects were cheesy and the plots formulaic, but there was a special magic when you were younger to seeing a team of colourful heroes take down hordes of nameless aliens and monsters. Hell, Marvel Disney seems to know what’s up. With the help of Kickstarter, Behold Studios launched their tactical RPG based off Saban’s hit franchise with amazing results. Get your suit ready, it’s time to Chromatize.

For such a lighthearted tone, the storyline is legitimately captivating. In what almost seems like a metaphor for the formation of Behold Studios, the 5 stunt actors that do most of the work on their past Sentai show decide to quit out of frustration with their director’s lack of fresh ideas. While building a studio from scratch, our heroes need to shoot episodes quickly and establish a fanbase to turn some revenue so they can keep the lights on, the actors paid, and the new season contracts coming in. The entire game is framed around this television production point of view, with missions gradually blurring the lines of reality into the realms of fantasy and superpower for the characters. Setups for conflict are playful with these ideas; an episode may require multiple reshoots due to on-set power outages, and other times you could be joined by unexpected ally rangers with their own personal vendettas against the alien baddies. Each level ends with tweets from your followers either praising or criticizing your work, and a fun email system helps to make you feel like you’re actually interacting with your niche crowd. The brief tutorial on combat helps succinctly explain the flow of fighting without dragging down players with over-explanation, and it does a great job to tie into the introduction of the story. The whole game carries a consistently fun tone that’s easy to enjoy. It’s a cheerful and self-aware romp through the experiences of being an independent studio and crafting something meaningful to both the creators and fans.

For veterans of the genre it may feel slightly basic and on a smaller scale, but every element you’d want in a tactical RPG has been incorporated here fantastically. There are 5 separate roles for each party member to fill. There’s the lead that acts as a tank, support as a healer, a stealthy and mobile scout, an assault character as your heaviest damage unit, and a techie that specializes in ranged combat and item use. Each class has distinct capabilities and limitations for moving around boards and dispatching enemies, making your choice of team member just as important as what you want to do with them. Audience is gained by performing skillful moves and combos, and this metric dictates your overall fan count and income. Just like most Power Rangers episodes, the squad usually has to engage in some out of costume combat before having enough audience power to Chromatize and activate your powerful suits and abilities. Skilled players can be rewarded with bonus audience by following special director instructions in each episode shoot. Trying to setup tactics to fulfil every side goal can be challenging, but other times the objectives sort of complete themselves.

Players can employ a variety of tactics to clear levels; strategies don’t simply involve just hiding weaker units behind tanks. There are two phases to each character’s turn, allowing you to creatively set up attacks with special weapons, abilities, and a unique gameplay element called Teamwork. Activating this ability sets up the character to help gang-attack enemies with subsequent Rangers, or catapult teammates across the board to reach distant foes. Setting up a Teamwork attack with all 5 members results in a satisfying finishing move that deals massive damage, but players who aren’t careful to use this maneuver appropriately are punished with a loss of audience interest.

Of course many bosses take on a second life after defeat, becoming Kaiju beasts to destroy with your giant mecha robot. These sequences handle similarly to piloting a World of Warcraft vehicle, but unfortunately for how common these parts are they lack the same amount of strategy that can be found in the rest of the game.

Players that put in the time will find it easy to see the inspiration taken from the source material in a loving way, and the thoughtful game behind it. Your experience feels totally customizable from the start. You choose from a large variety of actors; characters with specific stats to fit into the game’s 5 main roles for your squad. You can set the colour for each member as well, fully immersing your interest in your team. If you want the pink ranger to steal the spotlight with the lead role you can totally do that here, or maybe you don’t want a red ranger at all, there really are no limits to team assembly. The unique T.V. production management system to your team’s growth is a wonderfully creative way to explain the game’s action and provide a narrative backbone to the accumulation of player wealth.
   
Rather than gaining experience and levels, characters boost their stats through buying and crafting new gear. Creating new items from dropped material makes outfitting your team to be a more involved endeavour than simply spending money at a shop, and it motivates you to defeat just a few more foes in each stage to get those extra drops. Quirky item descriptions help keep a smile on your face while you click through these menus. There’s a good emphasis on needing to understand how to get the most out of your cash and saved up materials in order to make your team the best it can be. There’s also an interesting balance between managing your budget to buy your team these upgrades and to also spend on studio expenses, such as better lighting and healthcare, each adding their own statistical advantages. A variety of marketing companies can be hired for different perks in order to gain a larger audience and more income, and just like the items more of these are unlocked as you progress through the story.
 
The game’s broken down into 5 seasons, with each stage acting as an episode shoot. Starting a new season unlocks the next tier on each character’s ability tree, giving exciting progression to each of the distinct classes. Players can set their team’s abilities to their preference and go back to tweak them later with no penalty, giving a level of freedom to experimentation on these trees that isn’t in most role playing games.

The level of detail in the presentation truly creates a vibrant world to take in, all accompanied by a soundtrack that’s honestly one of the most enjoyable we’ve ever found in an indie game. Little touches like the plucky upbeat signature jingle complements the rest of the perfect retro groove that the music carefully weaves with its effects and scales. Seriously, they’re some of the best bit-style tracks this side of Megaman. Art is so fine-tuned as to even include bent corners on menu screens to make you feel like you’re watching from your tube TV. The familiar pixel art style is done expertly; there’s a real level of character given to the sprites by the careful expressions and animations. The isometric perspective works extremely well for both the gameplay and the artwork.
 
Behold Studios really hit all the right notes, giving us a great tactical turn-based action title that’s a perfect game for fans of the genre or anyone looking to try it for the first time. You might spend some time wading through some new gameplay elements, but it quickly clicks and with enough skill you’ll soon be taking down monsters just like they do on TV. There’s no doubt that you should take up your offer to join the Chroma Squad.
SCORE: 9.0

15910950.review:
http://niveloculto.com/analisis-chroma-squad/

Temporada 1: ha nacido un nuevo equipo de rangers

A estas alturas te estarás preguntando si nos hemos equivocado de temática en Nivel Oculto o qué demonios. No, se nos ha ido la pinza porque estamos muy locos, pero esto es Chroma Squad, el videojuego del estudio independiente brasileño Behold Studios y la mejor carta de presentación es la que te has encontrado: una ficha de IMDB. Porque con esta oda a los archifamosos Power Rangers de Saban es como estos chicos han querido rendirle homenaje al género, el que específicamente en tierras niponas se conoce como sentai.

Como muchos proyectos independientes, Chroma Squad nació en Kickstarter y consiguió el doble de financiación de la esperada (casi 100.000 dólares de los 50.000 que necesitaban). El que en su día se planteó como un RPG táctico de corte sentai donde el objetivo era crearte tu propio equipo de rangers vería la luz con un poco más de retraso del esperado: el título saldría finalmente a la venta el pasado 30 de abril de 2015 (pese a que la fecha inicial era finales de 2013).

Temporada 2: real e irreal como en la vida misma

El juego es un soplo de aire fresco porque, tal y como habían prometido, lo primero que haremos será elegir el nombre, atributos y color de cada uno de los rangers de nuestro equipo. Está cargado de humor y de sátira a todo lo que es el mundo del sentai, con edificios de cartón pluma, enemigos copia-pega, argumento muy pero que muy absurdo y explosiones de bajo presupuesto. No obstante, no hay que perder nunca de vista que esto es un RPG táctico al más puro estilo XCOM o similares.

Voy a tratar de presentarlo de la mejor forma posible: hazte tu propia historia de rangers. ¿Por qué digo esto? Porque creo que como mejor se disfruta este título es metiendo a tus conocidos en toda esta vorágine de estupidez tan terriblemente divertida. Tú, como líder, tienes que montar desde cero un estudio de grabación donde, temporada a temporada y si tus finanzas lo permiten, deberás ganar audiencia para poder sobrevivir y firmar nuevos contratos de renovación año a año, hasta un total de cinco.

Como en todo sentai que se precie, cada episodio es autoconclusivo y tus propios compañeros de equipo irán construyendo la trama de cada uno sobre la marcha según las circunstancias de sus propias vidas van dando pie a ello. Por ejemplo: el secuestro de uno de tus rangers cuando en su vida real tiene que ir al dentista. ¿Cómo no iba a ser un motivo excelente para grabar un episodio? Pues básicamente en esto consiste Chroma Squad.

Temporada 3: el tablero de juego

Como ya dije unas líneas más arriba, es un RPG táctico de lo más simplote, pero es aquí donde radica precisamente toda su belleza. No es un juego terriblemente complicado, lo que permite que puedas centrar tu atención en todas las tonterías que van surgiendo capítulo a capítulo. Pero tiene un par de peculiaridades que lo hacen único. Lo normal (salvo excepciones) es que empecemos cada episodio vestido de calle. Tenemos un medidor de audiencia que, según vamos realizando ciertas acciones o derribando masillas (los enemigos copia-pega, vaya) se irá rellenando. Llegado a un punto podremos elegir (si queremos) transformarnos. Cómo no, luces, efectos de sonido y mucha explosión chapucera y ¡voilà!, equipo de rangers preparado para darlo todo sobre el escenario de lucha de turno (croma verde del estudio, azotea, el parque de al lado o en la propia calle).

Tenemos cinco clases (con alguna que otra aparición estelar) y cuatro acciones básicas: atacar, utilizar una habilidad especial (solamente una vez transformados), movernos o colaborar. La acción colaborar, la peculiar en este tinglado, es que servirá tanto para ejecutar ataques conjuntos como para catapultar a otro ranger más casillas de las que podría normalmente. Esta acción es la que le da el punto de estrategia a todas las batallas, ya que según la situación podremos aprovechar para tomar una posición más defensiva u ofensiva. Sumado a que cada batalla tiene un plus de bonificaciones si cumplimos determinados objetivos (mantener a todos los rangers vivos, eliminar a todos los masillas, etcétera) la diversión está servida. Además, si ejecutamos un ataque conjunto sobre un mismo enemigo con todos nuestros rangers, le asestaremos el típico golpe final (el cual también tiene nombre, como podéis ver en la ficha técnica) que nos asegurará la victoria sobre la batalla.

Temporada 4: el estudio y los contratos, de algo hay que ganarse la vida

Nuestra base de operaciones, el estudio de grabación, juega otro papel fundamental en Chroma Squad. De una forma progresiva, para no soltárnoslo todo de sopetón, podremos gestionar los contratos con la compañía de grabación, mejorar los elementos del estudio, comprar equipo para nuestros rangers, fabricarlos manualmente con los objetos que sueltan los enemigos cuando mueren y, cómo no, mejorar nuestro robot de combate. No me gustaría detenerme demasiado porque hablar de estos puntos es destripar un poco la propia trama y las mecánicas del juego, pero de la misma forma que la base del XCOM Enemy Unknown jugaba un papel fundamental en la forma de enfocar nuestros combates, aquí el estudio de grabación realiza una función parecida, salvando las diferencias.

Cada temporada se divide en una serie de episodios que, aunque sean obligatorios, pueden grabarse en cualquier orden que nos convenga (salvo el prólogo y la season finale). Además, cada episodio puede a su vez estar subdividido en varias “fases” o combates, vaya, según la trama lo requiera. Y, cómo no, llegado el momento nuestro jefe final cambiará de tamaño y para poder enfrentarnos a él en condiciones el estudio pondrá a nuestra disposición nuestro propio robot de cartón y cinta adhesiva totalmente modificable. De la misma forma que en los sentai el combate del robot era espectacular, aquí no se quedan cortos y dando un cambio de género casi, casi de 180º, nos plantan en un escenario con dos barras de vida (la del robot y la del enemigo) donde tendremos que darnos toñas hasta hacer explotar al bicharraco rival casi como si se tratase de un juego de peleas (salvando las distancias).

Temporada 5: conclusiones y semejanzas con las series de verdad

Chroma Squad es un puntazo de juego y me lo he pasado como un enano. Me he reído mucho no, lo siguiente, y aunque en líneas generales es un juego sencillo tiene momentos donde lo pasaremos francamente mal para cumplir los objetivos o acabar los episodios. No obstante, de la misma forma que algunas series por motivos puramente económicos se alargan innecesariamente, me han sobrado un par de horas de este fenomenal título de Behold Studios. Ojo, porque jugando a mi parecer bastante a saco, me ha durado la friolera de trece horas. Una vez llegamos a la temporada 3 ya se nos ha desplegado todo el abanico de posibilidades que nos da el juego y, bajo mi punto de vista, habría sido más inteligente cortar en la temporada 4 en lugar de alargarlo una temporada más innecesariamente. Lo cual resulta irónico y te hace pensar si el propio estudio hizo esto a propósito o es otra de esas simpáticas jugarretas del azar.

En definitiva, si eres un amante del género, Chroma Squad es todo un acierto y un must have en toda regla y si encima estás familiarizado con toda esta movida de sentais, pasará de ser un must have a un juego que recordarás con muchísimo cariño porque todos y cada uno de sus detalles (como por ejemplo tuits de los fans con comentarios y hashtags al final de cada episodio) se han programado con muchísimo mimo, empezando por el botoncito de la esquina superior derecha de la pantalla que te permite avisarles de cualquier bug mientras estás jugando.

15896478.review:
I really wanted to like this game. There's some really good ideas and bit and pieces that work well together, but then the game quickly remembers it's an indie title so it immediately breaks the fourth wall with some dumb meme joke and poorly placed rants about sexism. It wouldn't have been so bad had the dialogue actually followed what sentai/powerranger shows were like, but it isn't ; it's completely about these random, pre-made characters that always spew the same lines regardless of their gender/race/species. Why even let people choose the visual appearance of them if you've already created characters for them? It would have been better just to create a premade team that apes the original show's archetypes rather than blandly change the visuals.

The game also suffers in that there's too much fluff and not enough depth. You have weapons, crafting, a store and various upgrades - but they all feel meaningless. Nothing really excels and feels like it was tacked on because all rpgs must have crafting now, rather than it was something important to the game play.

Lastly, the art can be downright confusing or poorly imitating at times. For some reason my blonde female support character won't stop rubbing her nipples in her idle animation. It's kind of disturbing and is weirding me out. Just, standing there all day, rubbing away. Did nobody notice this ????

15864861.review:
Chroma Squad is full of style with its fun writing, simple yet engaging gameplay, and so close to copyright infringement for all its references it's not even funny. In the game you control a group of people that run a live-action power rangers rip off show where they fight evil baddies and have huge mecha fights. 

Before you start one of these levels though (referred to as episodes in game), you have to micromanage your money at your studio (It is a t.v. show after all), in this section you purchase upgrades for your studio and purchase equipment for characters and such and it is surprisingly engaging how much thought I personally put in to figure out where to put my resources, did I want to put more money towards purchasing materials to craft cardboard box equipment, or did I want to invest in marketing agencies to increase my fanbase and reap extra benefits for a few episodes? It gives you enough to manage without overwhelming you. 

The combat is your typical tactical rpg with skills and classes and such,however there is a nice little temawork mechanic where if you set a character to teamwork mode you can assist other teammates in team attacks and acrobatics for more movement adding a little extra depth to the combat. Mecha fights play differently as when you're fighting bigger monsters you play a sort of risk-reward turn based game, you basically have hit chance and damage multiplier, whenever you attack and hit the monster you get to keep combo-ing them with attacks and other abilities and as long as you land hits, for every successful hit your damage for the next attack goes up, however it has a lower chance of hitting and when you miss it becomes the monsters turn, this also employs a decent amount of strategy but can ultimately feel like luck sometimes, its still enjoyable and doesn't detract from the main game

When it comes to customization this game handles that aspect very well allowing customization of not only characters, but even the customization of the company, you can name the super hero squad whatever you like as well as the mechas and what they shout when they suit up, heck if you wanted to you could even theme the whole thing around butts! Butt Squad! Mecha Butt! Butter up! There is a great amount of customization in the game!

Overall it comes down to this:
Do you like Power ranger esque tactical rpgs with funny parody writing, lots of customization, and fun gameplay, while micromanaging your own butt studio?
Then Chroma Squad is for you
8/10

15823381.review:
Back when the Power Rangers were a big deal in 1995, my parents wouldn't let me watch it. They deemed it too violent. Mind you, they're telling this to a guy who is chronically addicted to Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles and tuned in every Saturday to watch the Spiderman and Batman cartoons. Power Rangers were much too violent though. When my folks finally gave up on controlling my viewing habits Power Rangers quickly became a guilty pleasure and I watched it until Wild Force. Enter [i]Chroma Squad[/i], a retro style turn based tactics game that puts you in control of a squad of power rangers. It is every bit as fun as going round your parents' back to just watch cardboard robots beating up rubber monsters.

[i]Chroma Squad[/i]'s premise is very catchy hook to begin with. A group of disgruntled stunt actors are fed up with their boss and quit their current Ranger season to start their own series. With buckets, old shirts and cardboard boxes your crew assembles a set of costumes and backdrops and the battle against evil can begin. Along the way you'll find that there is a little more to playing Power Rangers than just making cool poses.

The game's real kicker is the ability to create and assemble your own team. You can possibly recreate every Ranger team down to the letter with the game, or engineer a squad entirely your own. Did you like Mighty Morphing Power Rangers? Just pick the five colours, three boys, two girls and be on your way. Fed up with the patriarchy? Pick five girls, colour them all in shades of purple and kick some ass. Feeling grimdark and edgy? Pick five depressed kids, paint them black and act like Batman. Everything is up to you. Each Ranger has its own role. Lead is in charge and gets additional hitpoints, while the tech rangers does bonus damage with weapons. The colours are up to you, so you can make the Pink ranger be the boss this time round and let the snooty Red bastard be the butt of the Megazord this time. 

After you tune your squad you record your episodes. This is a turn based tactics game where you fight minions and monsters on a grid. The real selling point here is positioning and teamwork. One ranger can kick a mook for sure, but positioning your squad in such a way will allow you to vault your rangers straight into the bosses face on the first turn to deliver a juicy team attack. It is key that master the acrobatics and abilities to chase down the shifty bosses, or that you weaken and wear out the brawlers without losing a Ranger, because no one likes it when the good guys lose.

You performance isn't measured in money, or experience; it is measured in audience. Since you're recording a TV show your audience is your life; and you cannot survive without loyal viewers and fans. Every episode gives you a hand full of objectives to clear to make your episode a bit better. More audience, means more fans, means more money, means better suits, means better TV, means more audience, etc. It is a simple, yet fun system, because it invites you to think of other ways to approach a problem, rather than to look for the one tactic. 

The entire game is booming with references to the Power Rangers and its Japanese original: Super Sentai. Finishing moves, focus on Red, giant robots, believing in your friends, mystery helpers, talking jars, it's all part of the experience. During your downtime you have time to craft new weapons from arts and crafts materials as well as answer fanmail and hire marketing groups to propel your show to the next level of hype. You'll quickly fall in love with the familiar and sometimes cliché traits of the series that round out the experience.

All in all, the game presses so many right buttons, it's hard not to like. Though the sometimes lazy writing rips you out of the game, the desire to know what kind of crazy thing the devs have cooked up for the next episode will have you coming back soon. The branching storyline also helps to draw you back in after beating it once. [i]Chroma Squad[/i] is a precious gem that should be play by anyone who ever watched even a single episode of Power Rangers.

15808524.review:
Chroma Squad is an amazing game where you delve into the makings of a Super Sentai studio. It's like a business tycoon, a tactical RPG, and a customization rainbow stuffed into an amazing masterpiece of a sandwich!

I honestly can't remember how I stumbled across this gem, but when I saw it, I fell in love with it and I had to have it. I'm glad that I did stumble acorss this, 'cuz I've had the funnest time playing Chroma Squad, the most enjoyable game I've come across in a while. In the first week of owning it, this game was what I'd play every night if I wasn't busy. It's extremely addicting, and while the story seems to start out at a good pace, things escalate quickly later on, providing great plot twists that keep the story immensely interesting.

With those opening comments out of the way, let's list the pros and cons.

Pros:
~A great level of customization with a plethora of actors, colors, and equipment to choose from, heck, even the mechs have a good level of customization.
~A great soundtrack. I persoanlly am a big fan of the 8-bit/chiptune style of music, it reminds of the days of arcades and gameboys. Any chiptune lover would listen to the soundtrack over and over again. If you like the music, get the reasonably priced soundtrack. Not only does it help support the devs, but you get to listen to your favorite groovy tunes from the game anytime you want.
~Cool graphics. if you like these kinds of pixely games or pixel art in general, this is a game for you.
~The storyline. I've said it before: It's interesting with a great pace.
~The play time. It took me about 22 hours to get through my first playthrough of the game, on the normal difficulty setting. And that's just for one of 3 endings that the game has to offer. Depending on the difficlty level you're playing and the time spent jamming out to the music, the time to get all the endings can range from 50 hours to 70 hours. Great amount of gameplay.
~The achievements. There's not hundreds of them like their are in other games, and most of them are pretty easy to get, you just need to play the game accordingly. I got over half the achievements on my first playthrough. (Though I guess they could add some ones in the future that require DLC.) If you're not an achievement hunter, that's all right, it could just be a fun side quest. This game has enough play-achievement balance that you don't need to dedicate hundreds of hours to get all of them.
~Difficalty settings. This is always a great feature to have in a game. The difficulties are casual, interesting, and challenging, ehich translates to easy, normal, hard respectively. If you're new to this type of game and/or want to focus on the story, play the game on casual. If you've played these games before and like a nice balance of story and challenge, interesting's your cuppa joe. If you like a challenge, like good planning, and you aren't afraid to lose a little to win a little, challenging is just the right fit.
~Nice balance of battle and management. Not only do you fight with your heroes, you need to check and maintain their gear in order to beat the enemies that get more difficult as time progresses, as well as answer emails from fans, manage production companies, and upgrade your small warehouse studio as time goes on.
~A great price. This game is relatively well priced, and will provide hours of fun and enjoyment that for most of you will be the best entertainment you've had in a while. At 15 American dollars for the game, with 5 additional for the soundtrack DLC, 20 dollars is a great price for this game. (Without DLC, the game is about 10 British pounds, 13 with DLC, for those of you in the UK)

Cons:
~Though the customization is great, it would be a little better if there was more actors to choose form to play your characters.
~Though it has a great storyline, playing it for the second time, at first, can seem kind of repetitive, and I found it hard to emotionally invest myself into the second set of characters. If you feel the same way, I advise taking a break for a month or two, so the shine of this game doesn't get burnt out.
~Dr. Mi ah

Otherwise, this is a great game, and if you were a fan of the Power Rangers when you were a kid, you're going to love this, although prior association is not required for this to be a great game. I personally thought ths was an amazing game.

I give Chroma Squad a 9.7/10

Happy Chromatizing!

TL;DR

Pros:
+Fun and flashy combat that does a nice job replicating battles from popular super sentai shows
+Lighthearted and humorous writing that is appropriately cheesy and over-the-top
+Bright, expressive pixel art
+Overall oozes charm and nostalgia; better than the sum of it's parts and a must play for anyone who grew up watching shows like Power Rangers

Cons:
-Combat isn't particularly complex, especially the mecha segments
-The same environments and director instructions are reused a bit too often; not enough variety in "episodes"
-Still a number of bugs to work out

Ultimately, your enjoyment of the game really comes down to how much super sentai you've seen. The game relies a lot on Power Rangers nostalgia and poking fun at the genre's various quirks and tropes.

15789437.review:
TechRaptor Review by Mark Richard

After a development cycle interrupted by looming threats of legal action due to copyright issues, Chroma Squad, a a Kickstarter turn-based isometric tactical strategy with Super Sentai spices, created by Behold Studios, has made it across the finish line after reaching an amicable agreement with Saban Entertainment. Thank goodness for that, because it’s every bit as charming as the developer’s previous game Knights of Pen & Paper, only without those pesky micro-transactions.

Despite a few questionable design choices and small bugs, Chroma Squad is an enjoyable experience. The customization makes all the difference in the world, and it has an infectious innocence that evokes fond childhood memories. The campaign goes on for a solid ten hours, plenty of time to use the framework’s potential to the fullest. If that doesn’t appeal there’s also a branching story, talk of adding multiplayer, and the end credits promise an upcoming New Game+ mode.

Overall Score: [b]6.5/10[/b] - [i]Good[/i] - A whimsical love letter to Super Sentai and a must have for a fan, though far from perfect in design.

Read the full review at: [url=http://techraptor.net/content/chroma-squad-review-spandex-warriors]http://techraptor.net/content/chroma-squad-review-spandex-warriors[/url]

15788034.review: A rare PC member of tactical RPG family. Challenging (on highest difficulty) and interesting, thought the story sometimes feels like its TOO simplistic.

15783715.review:
TL; DR This game is very fun, very easy to pick up on, and incredibly witty.

I've played Knights of Pen & Paper (which I would highly recommend as well) so I knew this team from before.  They take old ideas, revamp them, and put fun twists on them.  And they come out great.  The 8-bit graphics are awesome, so if that's a concern for you, don't let it stop you with this game.

The game is basically about your team, who are stuntmen, making their own TV studio to make a Power Rangers-esque show.  You have the 5 roles, and you pick which "person" is in each role, all with their own bonuses, so there's a lot of customizability in that. You pick colors and names, too, but that's pretty simple stuff.

And then the fun starts.  The combat is turn based, grid strategy, and your characters get powers (more as they progress into each "season") so you start of with not a lot and end up with a plethora.  You can use teamwork to add to actions (like throwing a team member at the end of the movement range to get that guy who's JUST too far away or comboing for bonus damage on the same target).  It takes some time to fully understand, but it adds a level of depth that's VERY enjoyable.

There's a lot of customization, but I won't spoil that part, as it's hysterically funny once you find what you can actually change.  The gear is cool, too.  You have a shop, that you can spend money upgrading occassionaly, that sells gear.  It's pretty basic, but you know what you're getting.  You can also craft your own, but that leaves the effects randomly generated, so you could get something awesome (like a pair of boots that give you crazy high dodge and counter chance, fuck yeah!) or something absolutely terrible (like a helmet that gives 2% dmg increase to pistols, which you stop using pretty early).  You don't sell gear, you break it down for crafting components, which I feel was on the devs part a way to motivate you to craft stuff.  It does actually change the characters looks, so fun lil bonus there.

The story is pretty awful, but in a fun way.  At first you're filming episodes just to get viewers and fans, and no, they're not the same in this game and they have very different effects on your studio.  It gets downright hilarious, and they make a TON of references to other "sentai' shows.

All in all it's a great game, and the guys at this studio really need to keep coming up with more games, because you're that breath of fresh air in this industry that they've desperately needed.  It's not going to leave with you a deep message, nor is it a game with a gripping storyline or gameplay that leaves you begging for more, but it's highly enjoyable, easily understandable, and wildly entertaining.

15748303.review:
Now, I know what you must be thinking about this game at the moment...  "What?  A Power Rangers rip off game?  What the fruity pebbles is this doing on steam?"  Well, I will tell you what the fruity pebbles this is doing on steam, It is being one of the better games on steam as of this moment.

It is quite literally a parody of power rangers, because it was quite literally inspired by the same show.  The combat system revolves around the turn-based combat system, but with tactical movements and everything.  You have your basic healer, fast person, tech person, heavy hitter, and balanced fighter.  Using these five (or less) characters, you spend actions fighting an enemy squad of minions which would be followed up by a boss.  Since the characters you are playing as are "actors of their own Sentai Show," a lot of their armors, weapons, skills, and enemies would look studio-made (or for lack of better words, artificial).  Also, if you have a vast knowledge of puns, jokes, or can catch onto references or parodical-cameos of other characters of the past 15 years, then you will chuckle at all of the things Chroma Squad throws at you.

There are also SUPER ROBOT VS. KAIGU {Sorry if I butchered the name} battles, where you go into your own Power Ranger-esque Robot that would fight giant sized versions of the bosses on top of the cities.  And you can customize even your own robot...  OH, and speaking of customization, you get to customize your squad (appearance AND names AND species AND ranger color), your studio name, the hero group's name, the robot's name, and a whole lot of other things!  Meaning you can make the squad as personal as you want :3!

Also, this game's soundtract is very addicting, as I would catch m.yself not playing the game as I just enjoy the amazingness of the soundtrack that plays in the battles.

And this game is very replayable as there are three seperate endings...  as of this moment, I haven't seen any of them, and I have only heard of one of them and I hate one of my friends who spoiled a little bit of that ending for me >:(...  But since I hope you haven't been spoiled yet either, I assure you that if all of the endings are as good as what I heard one of the endings was going to be, it will be amazing!

In conclusion, this game should be on the top of you MUST BUY RIGHT NOW lists, as it is addicting, has a great soundtrack, has SO MUCH CUSTOMIZATION, and has laughs from the start of the game AAAALL the way to the end.  You'll enjoy it, I swear on it!  :D

15733591.review:
Let's start by answering a common question.
 Do you have to be a fan of the inspiration/shows to enjoy this game? No. However Chroma Squad does capture the magic and feeling of its inspiration. The jokes, winks, and nudges are all done hilariously and authentically. Poking fun and at the same time honoring the source material. Being a fan just maximizes your enjoyment and lets you in on some of the jokes. 
That doesn't stop Chroma Squad from being a very deep, rich, RPG. From customization of your Cast(Party) to choosing what weapons(props) to craft. You will mold your team into what you see fit. Battling minions, bosses, kaiju, and a budget. No two save files will be alike unless you want them to be. Not only do you have that turned based tactical combat. You also must manage your own studio. Choose upgrades to boost ratings, and what ad agency will represent you. All these choices and options can deeply affect the flow of combat, crafting, and if you succeed or fail. 
All of this seamlessly blends together in this over the top and humorous RPG. With wonderfully done pixel art, music, and steamy goodness. Chroma Squad is as wonderful of a homage, as it is a game.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/ZkAJZOdxFYw
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

15731120.review:
Chroma Squad is a light tactical RPG featuring a customizable cast of likeable goofballs. Anybody who remembers the Power Rangers and other sentai series knows the formula. 

Bad Guy of the Week.
Mecha Battles.
Twelve gallon jugs of The Rule of Cool applied liberally. 

Chroma Squad is bright, cheerful and a joy to play. The music (particularly the main menu) is catchy and consistent. The graphics are detailed and well crafted. The entire game is a gleeful joyride through a land of complete Space Ham and Cheese. The story is a bit sparce and delivered in broad strokes, but even that  pays homage to the old shows. 

The tactical combat is simple but effective and polished. The teamwork aspect is one I would have loved to have in other games and makes for a solid engine to the entire system. Overall, the game left me with a pleasant impression and a smile on my face. 

It also left me wanting more.

And that's a compliment rarely delivered earnestly in a crowded, overstuffed marketplace. 

I want more. 

Please, Chroma Squad. Fight on for great justice!
The earth still needs you.

THIS GAME IS AMAZING!

Not only did Chroma Squad an amazing Tactical RPG a la Final Fantasy Tactics, it's also a very interesting Tycoon game. Instead of the token knights and wizards you lead your very own "Somewhat Power Ranger" Team into a tile-based battle against ridiculous themed monster. 
Thing is tho - you are actually producing a TV Show. Not only do you have to win the fights (which are the Episodes of the Series) and please your fan-base, you also have to succesfully manage your studio. Gear, weapons and other show props such as your very own Mecha have to be build out of cardboard and duct tape, new filming equipment have to be bought to give your rangers stat-boosts and increase the production value, contracts with advertiser have to be made and Fan Mails have to be answered. Also your actors are not save from wordly worries such as dentist appointments, mean Ex-Producers and Cardboard Cultists...

People who like or just watched shows such as Power Rangers will love his game for it's 4th Wall breaking, inside Humor, but also people who are looking for a new Tactical RPG with a nice management system should totally buy Chroma Squad! Absolutly worth the prize!

15724687.review:
About five minutes ago, I finished my first playthrough of "Chroma Squad". I could end this review here and now by saying/typing "Buy this game, NOW!", but I won't.

What kind of game is it? A Tactical RPG. Most of the time you have five characters to control in turn based battles, each characters may move once and then hit an enemy or use some ability, or it may move twice but not do anything else. The characters are like clones of the Power Rangers and you may name them and also choose their colors, but not how they look... per se. There's some identities with different stats and looks that can be chosen for each "Ranger", but that's it. But speaking of customization, you may name your studio and also different catchphrases that your team will use during battle - for when they're using their finishing move, when they transform into the alter egos etc.

The battles in itself are really good and gets progressively harder as the game goes on, the final battle was for me really challenging, mostly due to the fact that I tried to keep everyone on their feet and I tried to meet every goal. Oh, right, the goals. For each battle you get two "Director's Instructions" that could be "Defeat x enemies" or "Win in y turns" and other things. These goals keeps the game interesting and also, if met, generates more money and fans to the studio.

Graphics wise, it has a retro style, more 16 bit era than anything. Obviously it is modernized and polished to look a lot better. I liked it a lot, but then again I mostly like this graphical style. Sound though, the little I heard (mostly played it muted due to playing music meanwhile playing the game) sounded great but can't say much more than that.

In the end, if you're a fan of Power Rangers (which I'm not, so no requirement) and Mechas, you'll love this. Also, if you like Tactical RPGs you will probably like this, but the lack of depth in customization may put you off.

Like I said/wrote in the beginning of this review: Buy this game, NOW!

Sequel, please?

15709075.review:
Dans Chroma Squad, on incarne un manager invisible qui prend en charge une équipe de cinq cascadeurs, lesquels ont décidé de fonder leur propre studio après avoir quitté la série ultra populaire sur laquelle ils travaillaient. La raison? En plus d'être inconnus au profit des acteurs qui incarnent leurs personnages en version démasqués, ces cascadeurs devaient subir le caractère très désagréable du réalisateur, sans compter ses décisions artistiques pour le moins douteuses.
Avec une misère en poche, ils n'iront cependant pas bien loin. Mais l'oncle d'un des membres accepte de les accueillir dans son garage qu'ils commencent à aménager, garage dans lequel se trouve un étrange accessoire...

Au fil des épisodes, ces héros habillés de costumes improvisés vont devoir acquérir une base de fans, démarcher les médias, étoffer leur matériel de tournage et inventer de nouveaux scénarios en respectant la tradition du genre. Mais il se pourrait bien que cette lutte contre les forces du mal ne soit pas si fictive...

-----------

Chroma Squad est, comme son nom l'indique, un tactical RPG mâtiné de gestion. Dans les grandes lignes, on alterne deux phases, à savoir la partie studio et la partie tournage, qui comprend les différents types de combat.

Côté gestion, une série d'objectifs doivent être remplis pour permettre à ces Bioman du pauvre de se faire un nom dans le milieu. Pour cela, il est nécessaire d'acquérir des fans et de choisir des partenaires média correspondants à ses ambitions. En parallèle, il faut aussi améliorer le studio en s'équipant avec le matériel adéquat et en gérant le mieux possible ses relations avec les téléspectateurs. C'est aussi lors de cette phase que le joueur peut acheter ou fabriquer les accessoires des cascadeurs, lesquels leurs permettent d'acquérir des compétences particulières en vu des tournages. Plus tard dans le jeu, c'est aussi par cet aspect que l'on peut construire le robot géant qui servira lors du grand final.
La partie gestion n'est, en soi, pas bien difficile, mais elle nécessite d'être très à l'écoute des diverses statistiques et d'être en mesure de se projeter dans le temps à chaque veille de tournage. De mon point de vue, le vrai challenge tient surtout à la relation avec les fans qui se fait essentiellement pas mail. Il faut dire que les otakus ne sont pas avares en critiques mais aussi en suggestions, et certains ont un poids considérables dans la petite communauté des fans de sentaïs.

Côté combat, il s'agit ici d'un tactical RPG relativement classique et assez simple à prendre en main.
Le tout se joue au tour par tour, avec une phase de déplacement et une phase d'action pour chaque personnage, héros comme ennemi.
Nos héros disposent tous de compétences spécifiques (un système de personnalisation de l'équipe permet de créer sa propre escouade en début de partie), lesquelles sont à la fois liées aux cascadeurs mais aussi à leurs classes. On retrouve donc le leader qui est le plus équilibré, l'éclaireur qui peut se faufiler dans les rangs ennemis, le technicien qui utilise de nombreux gadgets, le gros bourrin qui ne combat qu'au corps-à-corps et le soigneur. Chaque personnage peut être équipé différemment de ses collègues, y compris au niveau des armes. A cela s'ajoute des compétences que l'on peut débloquer tout au long des tournages, avec des effets divers selon l'équipement utilisé.

Enfin, une commande permet de réaliser diverses actions spéciales telles que des transformations, des cascades permettant d'atteindre une zone éloignée, d'effectuer des attaques combinées ou de poutrer tous ensemble un ennemi bien retors. Reste que si l'on peut effectuer ces actions à peu près n'importe quand, leurs usage est avant tout conditionné par la jauge d'audience. Celle-ci indique en temps réel le nombre de personnes qui suivent la série. Ainsi, il est nécessaire de ne pas se transformer n'importe quand ou d'utiliser une super attaque de groupe alors que le combat contre le boss vient à peine de commencer. Sur ce point, le jeu propose au joueur un ensemble de challenges à remplir en début de chaque tournage. Ne pas les remplir ne fait pas perdre les combats pour autant, mais la chute de l'audience est garantie. Et sous un certain seuil, les fans partent chez la concurrence, menant à terme le studio à la faillite.
Il faut donc combattre non seulement pour remplir la victoire, mais aussi pour faire plaisir aux fans, quitte à ceux que leurs souhaits mettent parfois gravement en danger l'ensemble du groupe.

La plupart des épisodes sont sanctifiés par un combat de boss, généralement en deux temps. En première partie, un combat plutôt classique où des monstres souvent ridicules sont accompagnés d'une armée de minions qu'il va falloir latter sans concession. Ces combats sont plutôt costauds voire carrément balèzes, les boss disposant de techniques qui ratissent large et font bien mal, sans compter que les conditions pour les vaincre sont parfois assez vicieuses.
Dans la deuxième partie, on dirige le robot géant qui, comme à l'habitude, combat le boss également géant au cœur de la ville. Cette phase qui peut paraître simpliste dans les premiers combats se révèle finalement assez fine car elle repose en partie sur la bonne utilisation de telle ou telle compétence, lesquelles nécessite souvent plusieurs tours avant de pouvoir être utilisées à nouveaux. C'est aussi à ce moment que le nombre de fans impacte directement le combat puisque ce sont eux qui déterminent la vraie jauge de vie du robot. Autrement dit, si l'on a pas respecté les conditions des combats "classiques", le manque de fans se fera cruellement sentir. C'est d'autant plus vrai que selon la façon dont on échange avec ses fans, certains guests peuvent nous venir en aide sur des combats délicats.

Pour ma part, j'ai beaucoup accroché et j'en redemande volontiers (j'en suis à la cinquième saison pour 12h00 de jeu). L'humour fait souvent mouche, comme lors de la troisième saison où le leader prend la grosse tête, persuadé que les fans n'aiment que lui, ou cet épisode où les vraies forces du mal débarquent à une convention otaku. C'est à la fois très référencé (contrairement à ce qu'indique le sous-titre, le jeu ne fait pas uniquement écho à Power Rangers, loin de là) mais aussi très accessible, en particulier tout ce qui touche aux relations humaines au sein du studio. On retrouve cet aspect gentiment délirant y compris lors des combats où les héros mais aussi les ennemis dialogues entre eux à base de punch-lines volontairement moisies.
La difficulté est aussi très progressive. Il n'est donc pas nécessaire d'être familier avec le genre pour prendre le jeu en main. En sus, chaque épisode peut se jouer en 15-20 minutes max. Il est donc tout à fait possible de jouer par petites sessions.

15699081.review:
Chroma Squad is a Tactical RPG made by Behold Studios, the developers behind Knights of Pen & Paper. Chroma Squad is a love letter and a tribute to decades of Japanese superhero shows such as: Super Sentai, Kamen Rider and the Metal Hero series. 

=STORY=

You start off as a five-people  team of stuntactors who decide to make their own Sentai-themed TV show in which they become a Sentai team themselves and fight against all sorts of monsters while managing their resources and fan-community behind the scenes. The first two seasons start very tame since you’re still an indie Sentai studio with a low budget, but from season 3 onwards the plot becomes more serious and fascinating.
Depending on your choice during the finale of season 4, you might either end up doing the Rider route, the Metal Hero route or the Sixth Ranger route. I won’t spoil much, but each route has their own scenarios going on with interesting mini stories that contribute to the game’s lore. The finale of the game itself is amazing, and is something to behold and be amazed at – I’ll try not to spoil it, but it’s definitely “empowering”.
Mind you, the game developers have suggested to implement more alternate endings or routes  within future DLC or updates, so this review might end up dated and not give a complete overview to what the story system of Chroma Squad offers.

= CUSTOMIZATION =

This is arguably my favourite part of the game, ‘cuz who doesn’t want to make their very own Sentai dream team? You can customize your team by choosing out of approx. 20 actors, each with their own appearances and bonuses. You can also name them and decide which suit colour they wear, i.e. if you always wanted to make an all-Red ranger team, well here’s your chance! 
Throughout the seasons, the game offers various types of helmets and suits that not only give certain statboosts but also visually alter the appearance of your hero. Unfortunately, the amount of actors and visual-altering equipment you can choose from is quite limited, so you’ll have to either wait for future DLC or step up your modding skills.
You can also name your studio, your team, your giant robot, your transformation and lines of dialogue that call forth said mech, transformation and team attack. While it doesn’t give you the ultimate customization possibilities like customizing your own hero costume or actor from scratch, the game offers a decent amount of customization which will hopefully be expanded in the future.

= GAMEPLAY =

While the game is a turn-based tactical system, it’s not as complex or multi-faceted as Super Robot Wars, but neither is it overtly simplistic. You generally control five characters, each with their own stats depending on equipment, actor, role and bonuses you’ve activated through studio upgrades or siding with the more favourable marketing agencies. Each role offers a variety of skill, the Techie and Support role are for example more oriented on long-range and healing skills, respectively. 
Your characters can generally do two actions per turn – in most cases you’ll (1) move to the enemy and (2) perform an attack or (1)(2) move to the other end of the screen. Your heroes can wield weapons which not only increase attack damage but also provide with an extra skill. Last but not least, there’s the Teamwork mechanic in which you can make two or more of your heroes pull off an combined attack at an enemy they’re both facing.
The giant robot vs giant monster battles have a more mini-game feel to it, but it can still be one heck of an intense battle. It’s a sideview turn-based battle in which you can hit the enemy multiple times until your turn is ended through missing the opponent, ending your combo with the defend options or ending the turn with a super attack. During the enemy’s turn you must step up your reaction game to minimize the amount of damage your mech will receive.
Outside of missions, there’s also a light Studio Simulation system going on – i.e. you’ll get to read and answer fan letters, upgrade your studio for additional bonuses, upgrade your giant robot, buy equipment, craft equipment or materials and side with the marketing agencies that give you the best bonuses or help you earn and gain more money and fans.

= OVERALL =

If you’ve longed for a game in which you can make your own Sentai team and fight against hordes of enemies with the help of unlikely allies and your trusty giant robot , then look no further because Chroma Squad is arguably the best Sentai game if not one of the best Henshin Hero games up to this point. The story, several dialogues and fan letters will make you laugh and smile – and perhaps, even give you the feeling that you’re being a true hero of justice. Gameplay-wise, Chroma Squad is a very accessible game but not without a challenge for those who want to step up their game. While the visuals and soundtrack aren’t AAA-tier, they’re still pleasing and amazing to see and listen to nonetheless. This game is definitely made with love, and it shows. I can’t wait for the future updates and potential-DLC this game has to offer. Behold Studios, you’re the best and thank you for this amazing loveletter to decades of tokusatsu heroism.

15696883.review:
A great and at times, hilarious, retro tactical RPG. No level up system so the equipment system is the only way to change character stats. This causes a pretty simple tactical RPG system character-wise. Most of the strategy is in the battles themselves making sure you choose the right abilites to accomplish the objectives or "director's instructions". Marketing and upgrading your studio are the other two micro managing things you'll do between stages ("episodes"). Both pretty much letting you adjust rewards for completing episodes or helps you gain bonus stats during them. 

The other major part of the game is the Mecha battle! Although they can get a tad bit tedious, it's Costume Quest-esque fun. You ugrade your machine parts, but in the end the pieces are all pretty similar. The mecha fights are all the same, your hits are die rolls, and missing a 95% hit is infuriating when they pummel you 3 times in a row after. The saving grace for Mecha battles is that you can hold Enter to fast forward them like cut scenes.

The dialouge is pretty funny and the story riddled with pop culture references, this makes for a special kind of humor. It has a pretty entertaining story and kept me hooked all the way through. When you do finish the game (I recommend it), keep clicking!

15692647.review:
This game is part tactical RPG and part Business sim and the dynamics between the two is what makes the gameplay so interesting. 

On a tactical level, you have a large variety of options to take in battle. Basic attacks, Team attacks (with 1-4 other team members) single or double moves, teamwork stances and acrobatic vaulting and 5 different classes each with their customizable special abilities. Multiply that 5 and you'll be doing a lot of strategic thinking each round of combat. 

There is an actual strategically meaningful decision to be made between performing actions that are tactically sound and actions that make for good television. Because this game is not *actually* a set of heroes saving the world, but rather about a television show about heroes saving the world, your 'audiance meter' is of serious consideration. Often times the director's instructions (which, if completed, greatly helps your audiance meter) run counter to what one might do otherwise if thinking in a pure strategic manner. Striking a balance between the two is the key to maximizing ratings for an episode while still winning a fight. 

The higher your ratings the more money you get. Money plus material drops allow you to upgrade your studio and further customize your 5 actors. Add to all of that a very awesome, and branching, story and you have a game that is WELL worth the cost of admission. The only thing that would make it 100% perfect would be to make an episode editor allowing players to easily create their own episodes and share them on the workshop. Regardless, this is an indie game that is worth your time and money.

15692636.review:
[b]Primeiramente, o jogo é bom.[/b]

Tirando isso do caminho, vamos falar dele...

Eu adoro esse tipo de jogo. Chroma Squad me deu uma sensação parecida com a que tenho quando passo horas jogando jogos como X-COM ou o mais recente The Banner Saga. Essa combinação de administração com batalha para mim é fascinante.

O problema do Chroma Squad é... Todo o resto ele não faz muito bem. É divertido demais as lutas, os golpes, a colaboração entre personagens, tudo, eu adorei matar cada monstro, mas quando o jogo sai dali, ou antes, quando o jogo vai para a batalha entre "kaijus", ele perde muito do brilho.

A batalha final, o ápice de qualquer série "sentai" que o jogo presta homenagem, é fraca demais. Clique no botão, torça pela porcentagem, clique para se defender, use o golpe especial (ou qualquer variável que você ganhe com o tempo), repita o procedimento. Os monstros as vezes possuem uma vida muito alta, o que acaba deixando todo esse processo extremamente monótono. Eu acredito que poderia ter sido colocado um pouco mais de esforço nessas lutas, afinal, elas são extremamente importantes dentro do conceito que criaram. Visualmente elas são divertidas, mas na prática é meio chato, simples assim.

A história não é o ponto forte também. Mais para a frente, a história fica também desnecessariamente "complicada", tomando rumos que não me agradaram tanto. Acredito que a temática permita a inclusão de tramas simples, mas isso não deve ser um substituto para uma escrita boba, é difícil fazer o simples, eu sempre acreditei nisso. Fica mais uma prova dessa constatação. Mas, sendo mais justo, os personagens são bem caracterizados, cada classe possui sua personalidade própria e ela é bem evidente durante o jogo.

A parte admistrativa é visualmente interessante mas também se torna enfadonha, criar seu estúdio, fazer suas roupas, contratar uma agência publicitária, tudo isso, acaba sendo só uma desculpa para conseguir mais pontos na hora da batalha, você não se sente tão recompensado ao fazer essas coisas.

Bugs. Existem vários, alguns dele eu considero graves. Eu não sei se isso é comigo, se fiz algo de errado, ou qualquer coisa do tipo, mas meu jogo foi prejudicado ou interrompido várias vezes por causa de um problema ou outro, como na batalha de robôs, que mais de uma vez meus "upgrades" não foram aplicados, outras vezes que eu cumpri as "ordens do diretor" mas não foi contabilizado pelo jogo, me fazendo "falhar". 

[b]É um jogo divertido, mas poderia ser bem melhor. Recomendo para quem é fã do gênero, tanto do jogo quanto de super sentais. [/b]

15690349.review:
Go-go SUPER LUCK SQUAD!

I'm reviewing this game purely on the gameplay aspect. There are plenty of positive reviews regarding story and sentai fanservice.

This is based on playing the highest difficulty:
This game is a decent turn-based game in it's own right. There isn't much strategy to it. A bit of planning is involved to complete the director's instructions, but in the end it all comes down to luck. The most important thing to making equipment, materials, all based on luck. 

I have one save file where a certain material I obtain in abundance, and really dont need it as it's mostly for the starter equipment, and another save file where the only material I've been obtaining is the make the same pair of gloves. If you dont keep your equipment up to snuff, your rangers are as good as dead or too weak to complete director's instructions as the episodes difficulty increase.
_____

Now for the actual gameplay. Here is wear luck becomes absolutely infuriating. Let me give some examples:
Now, remember, you control a squad of 5 rangers.
The director wants you to kill all of a certain enemy within, say, 3 turns. There are about 10 enemies on the field, and you need to focus on 3 specific ones. Those specific ones need to all be dead in 3 turns. Sounds simple enough, plan out how you'll position your rangers to catch them and take them out. 
Now, let's get to the problem:

- Most of the squishy enemies, unless you luckily score a critical, can't be killed by a single ranger. This means it will take two of your rangers attacking to guarantee that kill. After a ranger attacks, they're done for that turn. This means it should be no problem for you to kill 3 of the weak enemies within 3 turns. Let's not get into details about some rangers having to use up their turn just to move around and get close to these enemies. We'll just presume you'll probably be spread thin and only have a kill average of 1 enemy per turn.... wait, change that from 'kill' to 'chance to kill'. You have a 'chance' to kill 1 enemy per turn. So if you happen to miss this chance, you can kiss that director's instruction goodbye, and restart the episode. Let's type how this will play out if you're unlucky:

First turn: you manage to kill an enemy.
Second turn: you manage to kill another enemy.
Third turn, your last turn to complete the instructions, and you're only one kill away: you order your rangers to attack and... the enemy dodges. Well, you're screwed. Time to abort episode and try again.
This is how many of your games will play out. This may not be too bad when it's just the start of an episode. However, there are times when an episode has 3 parts and you can spend an hour of your time going through the episode, completing all director's instructions only to have some unlucky crap happen at the very end and have to restart from the very beginning. 
That's a lot of time to be wasting over something that's completely out of your control, luck.

I'll give you one of my recent episodes as an example, there are three parts. The first two parts are simple enough, the third part involves a boss that can heal itself and many enemies around that heal. You have to kill the boss within 10 turns and finish it with a finishing move. A finishing move requires all your rangers to be next to the boss and attack together(use Teamwork). 
Technically, you have to kill the boss within 9/10 turns, since he will stun your rangers(making you unable to use the finishing move on the 10th turn, as it requires all of your rangers) on specific turns... one of those specific turns being the 10th one. Now, that seems like a pretty decent time to take out the boss. That is, if you're lucky. Let's play this out:

(We'll skip the small details and say you manage to get rid of the healing minions within 3 turns. You now have 6 turns left to take out the boss, who will also heal himself for pretty hefty amount. If you're lucky, he wont heal too often. If you're unlucky, he might heal twice in a row, making all your damage done to him in a turn, null. You still should have no problems as long as you manage to keep hitting him every turn and wittle him down. Given you have proper planning, you'll be just fine!)

Turn 1/6: You manage to quadruple the boss, and dealing enough damage that will allow you to outdps his heal.
Turn 2/6: You deal enough to outdps his heal again.
Turn 3/6: He dodges, completely wasting a turn, and heals himself. That's okay, you see that you still have a chance to take him out in time.
Turn 4/6: He dodges again... okay, it might  be close, but just maybe you can make it.
Turn 5/6: He dodges again, and heals. He's now at full health again, it's game over. Time to abort and do the whole episode again, taking up another hour of your time.
_______

Let me give you one last situation. In this one, YOUR luck can be your downfall in completing instructions. Let's say you need to kill 4 enemies in a single turn. Well, remember how it can take two rangers just to kill one enemy? You have 5 rangers, it takes 2 to kill one. Simple math, you can't kill 4 in a single turn. Unless... you plan ahead and simply soften them up to kill at once later. You're so clever. A tactical genius in the making. This shouldn't be a problem, you've got the plan and the means to execute it! What could go wrong?
None of the enemies dodge, you manage to soften up 4 of them enough to where any single ranger can finish them off in your next turn. There's absolutely nothing that could go wrong. Unless... <.<

It's the enemy's turn: The weakened enemy attacks your ranger, it's super effective! At least super effective against the enemy, because your ranger decides that of all times he's going to choose this time to do a counter-attack. The softened up enemy dies. Now you only have three softened up enemies, maybe you still have a chance. You'll have 3 rangers kill the 3 softened ones, and your other 2 rangers can double attack some other enemy. Unless... <.<
It's still the enemy's turn: Another of the weakened enemies attacks another ranger. You couldn't possibly be so lucky you counter attack again, could you? I dont think I need to say where this is going. You know you're screwed, abort episode and try again.


The game could also stand to give some actual info on the stat points. There seems to be no info on the usefulness or effective amounts for Cooldown Cost and Skill Regen. There are other stats as well that have no explanation in the game, and you just have to guess and hope they're worth investing into.

If they cut out all of the luck crap, it would be an entertaining turn-based game that actually rewarded you for proper planning. Instead, it's always a roll of the dice.
I dont know how many hours Steam will say I've played this game, but my first save file is 11 hours. My second save file says 3 hours. So any beyond that was just wasted time from having to abort episodes.

15689153.review:
I don't generally write steam reviews, but I felt compelled to do on this case.

I'll keep this short. First of all, if you're looking for gameplay, Chroma Squad has a semi-decent system going for it. In fact, it's quite fun. Not overtly complex, but it gets the game moving. Figths have some interesting mechanics to them, and you generally won't find yourself being bored. Gameplay wise, it's fine. A Seven out of ten, generally.

The reason I'm giving this game a negative review however, are these two.

First of all - and, I suppose, the less important one. The writing. It attempts to be this cheesy script played for laughs, but all it does is give you cringeworthy references that batffle you at just how badly they are handled. The kickstarter backer appearances are laughable and ham fisted. I'd actually feel embarassed for backing this and being put on it as it was.

It says it's an affectionate parody/homage to Sentai, but it instead feels like it's trying too hard. 

Now, you might say that you don't give a crap about the writing and that's fine. It's a videogame. So what's my second complaint?

How awfully BUGGY the game is, and in the worst ways imaginable. It has a tendency to constantly shut down, crash ,or simply not do anything after a certain sequence of events happened. I've gritten my teeth and bore it for most of the game, but the last straw was, infact, at the very last mission of the game, composed of two long boss fights - the last one being especially long, lasting possibly hours. The game proceeded to crash on the first one, making me lose all progress. It then crashed again at the end of the second one, meaning it put three hours of gameplay to waste, as the game did not foresee it crashing, for whatever reason. That managed to make me give up on the game and not want to finish it. The fact that the bug report icon is ALWAYS there on the top right corner should actually tell you just how unstable this game is.

It's a fun game. It's an embarassing piece of writing, and an awfully coded mess that's unreliable at the worst moments.

UPDATE

After replaying the game post-patch, performance has indeed increased. I've encountered so far only minor visual bugs that did not break the game nor make it crash, so one can assume the stability of the game is indeed being improved. Previous complaints still apply, and the game still has a couple visual glitches, aswell as issues with the achievement unlock system, but right now, it's properly playable. With that done, I shift my opinion to a careful recommendation - if you're a fan of Sentai, you can probably buy it. If not, but you're really curious, wait for a sale.

15685942.review:
101 Miutes played and just finished chapter 1. Oh excuse me "Season 1" with 4 Episodes  + a 4 Part Season FInale! 
and I have to say - I. Am. Pumped!

the game itself is (as the title card says) a Shoot out to the classic Power Rangers series. You take over the role of 5 spandex wearing Super Sentai Actors who grew tired of their old director and start their own studio.
They use Blue Rangers Uncles warehouse to shoot their first episodes and find a prop from a huge Super Hero thing - which their old director finds out himself... From there on he starts plotting and you start raking in fans, money and cardboard to make awesome costumes.

First of all - the Episode stories are HILARIOUSLY terrible! But then, looking back to when Power Rangers was a thing in my life... WHo cared about story? I dont want to see those 5 people at school! I want to see them beat up those evil bastards! Come on, make an entrance and beat the crap out of those Baddies! And thats what those episodes are about 
"F**k Story, lets kick some ass!"
the fighting feels like its fitting into a SUper Sentai series, with acrobatic jumps, multi hit combos and dreadfully colorful Team Attacks, and at times, I feel less like a twenty-something years old dude playing a strategy game, and more like the 6 year old kid, watching those spandexed Actors beating the crap out of other spandexed actors, Striking poses myself and being the Blue Ranger in Kindergarten.

But I have to do some critic here as well. As first - the tutorial covers the basics. and only the basics. It covers moving, acrobatics, Team attacks with basic attacks. But thats it. Okay - other things can be found out within play, like that you can start a Team Attack with a Weapon Attack, instead of a basic attack and that the Weapon musnt be on Cooldown as well.

Secondly - Weapons. Your main weapons are your - gloves. You can buy and craft swords and Guns but they never seemed to use them in battle. just... punching the enemy. Until I found out that those weapons are Active Abilities, with Cooldowns and all.

The Amount of customisation is overwhelming in the beginning, and sometimes you may end up not knowing what to pick. But you'll come to understand.

However, overall the game is awesome, and if you are a fan of old Super Sentai Series and in need of a little nostalgia fix, get this game!


Random Fun Fact : When Haim Saban first bought the US rights for the Power Rangers Series, he only reshot the "Everyday Life" scenes with US actors and took the Fightng scenes from the japanese original series and re-dubbed them. A pretty intelligent move.

15682581.review:
I'm sorry to say that I wasn't a fan, and I wanted to post some of my issues to other prospective buyers. I'd like to clarify that I'm a big fan of both management/sim games, SRPGs and Sentai, so I fall right into the game's key demographic.

The game is spoiled by poor writing throughout the gameplay experience - I understand the developers are working against a language barrier, but this means that much of the dialogue has no flow or substance. Tonally, the dialogue never seems whether to indulge in the action fantasy of sentai, or provide a narrative about the stunt crew pursuing their own career. The result is that the characters are constantly breaking the fourth wall which is not only tiresome, but spoils the atmosphere the game's (very good) graphics are depicting.

The game has been designed without level ups: where this might seem beneficial to some, they've replaced this tried and tested mechanism with a bolted-on crafting system. You become dependent on crafting gear from items dropped by enemies - worse, you have to hope that the 'random bonus' is actually worth having. The removal of level ups takes away a sense of stable progression, and replaces it with gear-dependence, which, for me, sucks the fun out of the game.

The management aspect is not developed or interesting enough as a worthwhile distraction, and the two gameplay modes (simulation/SRPG) don't mesh with each other in a satisfactory way. The lack of depth in the simulation and the lack of levelling are disempowering - you're never sure where you sit on the game's difficulty curve, and ultimately your successes do not feel like they've originated from any choices you've made. This is poisonous for any game, but Chroma Squad simply fails to provide any grit, depth or detail beyond what is an impressive exterior.

TL;DR: It looks great on the surface, but goes to pieces once you get past the unique premises, references, and graphics.
