15678108.review:
Chroma Squad... what a unusual concept.

I grew up watching oldschool japanese films (Godzilla, Ultraman, Rodan, etc), watching shows like Mighty Morphin Power Rangers, oldschool martial arts films that were dubbed by... less than stellar actors, etc.

So lets just say I love the source material and whatnot.

Final Fantasy Tactics style games (Tactical RPGs) are always sorta hit or miss.  Some focus too much on choice leaving you with a mountain of options and a hard time deciding what actually works for you.  Others are far too focused on the story and ignore a good tactical format for combat.

Chroma Squad hits alot of good notes:

-5 classes, all with tie-ins with character archtypes in shows like MMPR
-"Actors" that give different stat boosts to the class you slot them into, or to your progress as a whole, depending on choice.
-Solid combat that feels good, without a mountain of stats and rules to learn
-Various mini-goals for each 'mission' (part of an eppisode) that are typically not too hard to complete and net you more money to spend on upgrades
-MMO style gear levels (White/Green/Blue/Purple) that help you determine which gear is better (not to mention easy to understand stats)
-Alot of comedy moments before/during/and after each fight.  There are more references to pop culture, source material, and strange happenings than I can even begin to list.
-Great badguys, even when they are repetative it's still funny to see the dialog that tries to explain why they are there.

Now some negatives
-Crafting system can turn out garbage gear.  You can break said gear down and try again, but it's a losing system.
-Some of the 'mini-missions' don't work with everyones playstyle, there have been a few so far that I found irritating to try to complete.
-Sometimes the 'jump' feature doesn't seem to want to fire for no reason.  This makes positioning annoying at times.
-Music gets repetative, but not really a big issue, mute works wonders.

I love me a good tactical game, and one filled with humor and references to some of the best (and cheesiest if I'm honest) shows/movies is awesome in my book.  Too bad there isn't multiplayer co-op or pvp, that would send this game to the realm of 'zomg best timewaster ever... for a week or three'

15678029.review:
Chroma Squad is an outstanding tactical RPG that I highly recommend to anyone who is a fan of Super Sentai, Kamen Rider and a ton of other live action hero shows. The game clocks in about 15 hours (give or take) to complete one play through and is loaded with a ton of fan service and pop culture references that keep you constantly hyped and laughing throughout your journey. The blend of simulation and RPG is where the game truly shines and feels unique. You aren't only creating your dream Sentai team, you are a part of the show!

On the tactical side, the game does not get very complex, and I found the game to be quite a breeze on Normal, but honestly, that's okay. A game does not need to be hard as hell in order to be fun. However, I will note that as hype as the Mecha battles are they are pretty one sided and easy to complete most of the time. From the perspective of a fan of Sentai it makes total sense and you feel awesome beating up Kaiju for the sake of justice, but the above mentioned simplicity is why I couldn't recommend the game to someone just looking for a Tactical RPG fix. Though I would say at the very least look up some footage and if you are open minded enough you might really enjoy it anyways! Might even get you interested into Sentai etc.

Chroma Squad as it is may have relatively simple combat, crafting and business simulation but I strongly feel like that's the entire point of the game. The game doesn't just want you to create a Sentai show, it wants you to be the hero! So what are you waiting for? Get out there and deliver some justice! And don't forget to shout a cheesy line like "Justice is best served in a rainbow of colors!" It doesn't have to make sense, as long as you do a cool pose while saying it you'll be FINE.
Pros
•	High replayability
•	Fan service...fan service everywhere!
•	Incredible soundtrack
•	Amazing retro graphics
Cons
•	Individual aspects of the game are simple
•	Left me begging for more customization. (perhaps we might see more in updates)
•	A few annoying bugs, but patches should be coming in quite soon

9/10

15674841.review:
Go Go Po... Chroma Rangers!

If you grew up, like me, watching the Power Rangers or any Japanese Super Sentai, it's probably worth a look. 

The game use a nice pixel artstyle with a lot of color... lot of chroma!
As far as I know, it's the first Super Sentai Simulator and the two years wait since the kickstarter was worth it.
There is a story to follow so it's not a sim per say but you have some freedom with the customization of your squad and studio.

The game fit perfectly in the Super Sentai genre with crazy weird monsters, lots of weird poses and a good amount of friendships and conflicts. There is also some references to other games or memes that can be hit or miss but most of the game is spent in battle or getting ready to battle in the studio. Only a few story scenes are long, most are short unless they are important to the main plot.

The Teamwork mechanic is interesting and add a good amount of strategies to the tactical gameplay. On the normal difficulty, you can go all in like the Rangers usual do and barely win or take your time and overwhelm the baddies. Only as few battle may force you to pick a more specific strategy.

My first playthrough took me about 14 hours on the normal difficulty and, at this time, there are 3 different endings with a few different stages depending on the path taken. Except a few specific choices, the game is linear.

Oh and there are Mecha/Kaiju battles! They are pretty simple but you can't have Super Sentai without monsters growing with those slow battles full of sparks!

This review was inspired by Chroma Squad that was inspired by Saban's Power Rangers that was inspired by Toei and Bandai's Super Sentai Series.

15673819.review:
I'm not really one for writing reviews, but I wanted to make an exception for Chroma Squad.

This game is an absolute gem. It is so suffused with character and charm as to reach points of ridiculousness. It pairs down the infinite complexity of many tactic games to a small team of characters, which allows each to have their own personality. The storyline, though I'm only a few hours in, is the perfect blend of cliché, kitsch, and nostalgia that somehow comes together to be more than the sum of its parts.

I can say wholeheartedly that I really wish I had seen the kickstarter when it was up so that I could say I had done my part to make this game possible.

I would be remiss if I didn't mention a few things I would've like to have seen, after all this is a review. I went in expecting to be able to make small graphical reprentation of my friends and I, but when selecting characters you select them as a whole character. So you can't choose what they look like without also choosing their stat bonuses. So, while there is character customization it's not as indepth as I would've liked.

During gameplay you'll get access to crafting. I would've liked to have seen a slightly more informative UI and perhaps an indication of how deep the crafting tree goes. It would also be nice if there was more options at each tier. As it is, it seems to break down to two options, either straight HP or HP with some added utility. But, as I said, I'm only a few hours in. (Half way through Season 3)

If those two points started to scare you away from this game, please don't let them. I have not had this much goofy fun in a long time, and I wouldn't want you to miss out on it because of my whining.

I unreservedly recommend this game.

15671287.review:
A fun little take on the Power Rangers / Sentai series, simplistic and fun.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Typical tactical turn based RPG, you're able to use class specific skills when 'transformed' with each season bringing new skills to choose from which you can switch between during 'filming', ranging from a passive cleave to 30% extra damage or ways to increase audience.

[h1]I keep hearing about that stupid SJW pandering scene...[/h1]
Although I don't why you'd want to cater to such a narcissistic group of people, the scene in question is when there's an episode that needs filming that involves hostage to be saved and the group decide to talk about not falling into sexist tropes (however falling into the sentai trope is ok and all the clichés that brings).
If you're worried about being preached too, don't. It's a big joke. Poe's law applies to this. Just laugh it off and sigh, letting out a breath of; "Why..."
You have more brain melting scenes like the amount of memes they added to this, so don't let this get to you.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
I've encountered afew, achievements not unlocking, doors that freeze the game, etc, hopefully they are fixed before you read this review.

[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]
It's a funny little game despite its writing. What more do you want?

You leave the next day thinking you should ask for her number, but you don't want to ruin the mood. Actual review:
This game is a paragon of polished indie developing.  Gameplay is nicely balanced between managing a budding hollywood studio, planning show episodes, gearing out your team, and actual filming (combat events) of the show.  The storyline is well written and kept me wanting to find out what happened next, combat is varied with all the different things you can do (teamwork, using items/weapons, skills, morphing ("chromizing") vs fighting as nomral people, and of course all the wonderful abilities that come up through gameplay.   Let's not forget the mini-goals you can choose to complete during each scenario and managing your fan base (answering emails...etc).

I appreciate that you have a casual mode for people who want to build a studio based on purely asthetic decisions vs. the harder modes where you need to manage stats that items give production.

My favorite part is when building a team I can name them anything I want (I can name the squad anything I want too) and you get to choose the people on your team INCLUDING a loveable but useless animal mascot....well he wasn't so useless once I armed him with guns!  mwhahahaha!

15670660.review:
Ever want to make pretend and create your own 'Power Rangers' inspired TV show while actively fighting your way through the story? Well with Chroma Squad you get that chance! 

Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG inspired by the 'Mighty Morphin' Power Rangers' where you get to buy all your set equipment, outfit your heroes with new cardboard armor and weapons, and fight evil villains. All with the help and guidance of CEREBRO! (Cerebro is a floaty brain much like Zordon!) 

I played through the tutorial and the first "episode" of Chroma Squad and it was delightful and full of nostalgia. 

You are a group of stuntmen(and ladies) that leave a show much like the Power Rangers and decide to go off on your own to make your own show! So you are given access to a warehouse which you use as a studio to try and create a better show.

With tactical rpg elements like upgrading your actors skills, costumes and weapons, you increase their stats like a regular rpg. However, you are creating a TV show. So you must also spend the money you earn to upgrade your studio, lighting, cameras and a number of other things.

The goal here is to keep your fanbase happy and create the best show you can. 

Here's my first look! (Still uploading it's so fresh)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GNAKacig2dA

If you are looking for a fun, saturday morning cartoon inspired tactical rpg, then Chroma Squad is on point.(I mean I know you weren't actively looking for a saturday morning cartoon inspired tactical rpg.)

There is a lot to like here - great music, pixel art, and enjoyable gameplay. 

For more reviews and podcast about Early Access and Indie games check out EarlyAccessPodcast.com and YouTube.com/EarlyAccessPodcast

15668892.review:
[b]Developer: Behold Studios
Publisher: Behold Studios
Format: PC
Release Date: April 30th, 2015[/b]

Oh boy here it is Chroma Squad. A game like no other out there.
Let me start of by saying that this is a game for children.
Nothing for adults like me and you. We are big now. We can buy alcohol, drive and get on all roller coasters.
I mean I pretty much watched Power Rangers and the likes whenever I could, because well [strike]I have had smaller siblings so I had an excuse[/strike] ... err I mean I was forced to watch it.

Anyway you don't have to be a fan of Tokusatsu and Sentai to fully enjoy this game. I mean it doesn't hurt if you are it probably makes everything just so much better but all you need to fully enjoy it is a sense of humor.

[h1]Now on to the review. Retsu go![/h1]
Chroma Squad is a Tactical-Management-Business-RPP about running your very own sentai show.
You slip into the role of five stuntmen which basically got fed up that they do pretty much all the work while the actors are just sitting in their chairs most of the time. One comes up with the idea to create their own studio and so they quit their jobs to set up their own sentai studio.
This game is filled with jokes and references to the tv shows or to memes and it's overall a very good laugh.

[h1]Now we get to the management/business part.[/h1]
You now have to setup your studio and buy props like mics, lamps or a better green screen. Those items will give you all special bonuses but also come for a price. You don't only have to pay once for those items well for some you do and others cost something like 25 bucks each episode. So you have to choose wisely on what to upgrade. Also you have to hire actors, choose an agency to help you reach a greater audience and make sure you're fans are happy since hey this is tv show!

[h1]Onto the RPG part! Retsu go![/h1]
In case it wasn't obvious but you take the role of five actors and the director of your sentai tv show. You have to read and reply to fan mail which can grant you bonuses depending on your actions and then there's crafting.
Duct tape, play dough, card boxes and many more stuff you'll need to craft your new items like swords, guns, helmets and so on. You can buy several materials and you can also recycle your old and unused gear for materials. You only have a % chance to get certain materials but hey atleast you have the chance to get some materials back.

Your goal is to record five episodes for a season. Meaning you have to record and fight five different scenarios before you reach the season finale aka end boss battle. While recording the shows you see the directors instructions on screen which you should follow in order to get the max amount of audience.

[h1]What else can I say?[/h1]
If you enjoy tactical and/or rpg games you should definitely give Chroma Squad a try.
If you like the good ol' Mighty Morphin' Power Ranger you will probably drool all over this game.

15666690.review:
Chroma Squad is simply a love letter to what Power Rangers use to be. It has action, comedy, interesting writing, and anything you would want from a PR game. You start out as 5 stuntmen who have recently quit their jobs doing sentai stunts to form their own studio. When you get into the studio thats when the real magic begins. Once there, you're able to design your own suits and mechas, something I'm sure any PR fan has dreamed of. 
          
   You're also able to respond to fan letters and control your fan market to some extent by choosing from a wide selection of advertaisment firms. When you go into battle this game is a mix of an RTS and Turn Based RPG ala Pokemon. The RTS side is used for your simple ranger battles where each class has a variety of skills at their disposal, which grow as the story progresses. You're also able to do showy finishing moves on the bosses in true sentai fashion. My only problem with the RTS board is that sometimes you can't see parts of the grid because they're blocked by objects on the field. 
      The game then becomes much closer to a TurnBased RPG when in mecha form where you're allowed to hit your opposing monster a certain number of times before a hit misses and they hit back. But, all is not lost when they hit back theres a system that if you time it correctly and click in the white area of the bar you can block some of the damage. Think Gears of War's reload system. Everyonce in awhile though this bar lags causing you to get hit by the full blunt of the attack without a chance to stop it.

TL;DR:The Story and writing are amazing and are VERY PR like. The RTS combat while fun has some issues with grid square blocking, nothing gamebreaking though. The mecha combat is far slower than the RTS combat but still quite fun

Score: 8.6/10

15665141.review:
Really fun game with a lot of replay value.  Tactical RPG combat flows well and the team-up system leads to some fun things to do even while abilities are on cooldown.  Branching story paths make for some good incentive to play through multiple times.

Mecha battles are a little one-note, but still fun.  Crafting system seems to have bad drops, but with proper marketing choices and investing in some of the material packs you can make it work out.

My only complaints: YOU CANNOT UNDO ACTIONS, which is so frustrating sometimes, oh boy.  That's the number one problem for me.  Also there is not enough cool stuff to spend money on in the in-game store, as each tier boils down to "defense armor" vs "offense armor".  Crafting has one or two interesting items (the Speed boots and the Team-Toss gloves) but there isn't a lot of variety outside of the gimmick items, when there could be a lot more going on.  More actor choices (and the ability to recast them mid-series) would be nice too, it feels like a very small pool of options.

The game also ends right when you start feeling very powerful so I'd like to see a 'New Series' mode (where you do a new team with a new storyline but keep your studio) or some sort of extra seasons.  Some way to keep going.  The game feels a little short.  A 'mission creator' and some sort of endless mode with escalating difficulty as seasons keep going on could fix this, and I believe the developers are looking into these sorts of ideas.

It's off to a great start, it's an awesome game for anyone into tactical RPGs or sentai/power rangers stuff, and I hope it keeps improving over time.

15662537.review: A long overdue gift to those who grew up dreaming of making a Sentai series all their own. What Chroma Squad lacks in simulation elements it compensates with a neverending celebration of the best parts of Sentai new and old. If there is anything to pity its that Chroma Squad wasn't 3 different games and fans of Metal Heroes and Kamen Rider only get to revel in the last season of the storyline, but their inclusion shows just how much love Behold Studios has to offer, it can't be contained and oozes out of every scene! At the same time, if you step outside what the game celebrates you're left with an honest and simple Strategy RPG with map and encounter designs that genre veterans will find uninspired. The Episodes of the game are filled with colorful characters based on classic Sentai villains and antiheroes or pop culture and it is their presence and strength of personality that bring flavor to each individual Episode. So if you're prepared to be charmed, prepared to fall in love with the idea of being a team of costumed heroes, or prepared to be entertained by a campy throwback to how Sentai captures the hearts of children, Chroma Squad is absolutely the game you're after, look no further.

15661615.review:
This game overall falls far short of what it should or could have been. I was getting more and more disappointed as I played further into the game. First a few key points of the game that are off.

"Hire Actors", "Cast actors" Sorry but this is a once off near the start of the game you pick your 5 heroes which you can't change and must be in the 5 roles forced upon you. There is also no choices in villains or henchmen appear in episodes.

"Customize your TV studio" No you get to pick from a small list of improvements that improve your heroes statistics, drop rate and fans per episode or unlock a skill rank that can only be used from certain seasons onwards even if purchased before that season. You don't get to choose what your sets look like.

"upgrade your gear", "craft weapons" Upgrading does not happen you replace for better gear and in my play through all bought gear was better than anything that could be crafted except a few utility gear that increases throw distance or movement. 

As for the rest of the game each hero only has a choice of 3 weapon to equip either a one handed sword, a pistol or their role's specialty weapon with a very limited selection of skills. During the episodes you play them out with no choices in what you do except for the very few times you change the ending path you are on. Even during a cringe worthy talk about not following sexist tropes I thought I would finally get a choice of rescue a boy or a girl but the game forces their decision on you. I really would have liked to have many choices that would affect what type of fans, how many fans you get and what the media is saying about your show. The game also has quite a repetitive feel to it doing pretty much the same each episode.

As for bugs I have had some random freezes where I can't continue the battle but can access the menu and quit out and reload my game. I have also seen directors orders not being completed where you need to destroy x amount of a boss specially summon (Bombs and Clones) but if your team does enough acrobatics and flashy moves the directors orders don't matter.

Do not be fooled by the small playing time that Steam shows. When I started playing this game for the first time, I was offline, and I played for 7 hours non-stop.

This game is a dream that come true!

When I was a kid, on the 90's I loved to watch tokusatsus (heroes in costumes, like Power Rangers, Super Sentai, Kamen Rider, etc..) and loved to play with my cousins like we were in the show.

If you're like me who always wanted to be the creator of your own tokusatsu show, here's your chance!

Chroma Squad is a beautiful game of tactical RPG  (a bit similar to Final Fantasy Tactics, or Tactics Ogre) where you control your own tokusatsu squad and studio in your way to become very successful and famous.

You can customize the colors, names, and choose the actors that will play them, and even what they say when they call their giant robot, or when they transform!

You equip items (that even change their appearance!) buying from the store, or creating from your workshop to become stronger, and choose wich skills each one will have. Each squad member have it's own role and skills. (There's the Lead, Assault, Scout, Techie and Support.)

If you watched tokusatsus you will notice many references, and the game have very funny conversations and events.

Even if you're not a fan, nor didn't watched any tokusatsu, I recomend this game if you like Tactical RPGs. You will love it!

Don't waste any more time, buy it and have tons of fun!

Now if you excuse me, the world need my help. Random Rangers, let's Randomize!

15656020.review:
Chroma Squad ist eine Mischung aus einem taktischen RPG in dem man eine Power Ranger mäßige Truppe spielt und eines Management Games in welchem man ein Filmstudio verwaltet und eben bestimmte Folgen der Superhelden Serie dreht (die man dann eben auch spielt, als Taktisches RPG).

Erwähnenswert hierbei ist, dass obwohl keiner der beiden Gameplay-Parts für sich eigentlich der Rede wert wäre (es gibt sowohl bessere taktische RPGs als auch bessere Management-Sims) beides zusammen eine tolle Mischung ergibt, die zudem gut ausbalanciert scheint, dh keiner der Parts kommt zu kurz und beide fühlen sich rund an. Dabei greifen die Mechanismen auch gut ineinander: durch Aufrüstungen des Filmstudios oder basteln von Requisiten für die Schauspieler erstellt man quasi Gear für seine Helden für den RPG-Teil oder sorgt dafür, dass in Kämpfen bestimmte Buffs wirken. Das wirkt wie aus einem Guß und macht, kurz gesagt, einfach nur Spaß. 

Das einzige, was ich zu bemängeln habe - und das im wesentlichen weil ich es aus einem anderen Spiel besser kenne - wäre der Einfluss den man auf die einzelnen Folgen die man 'dreht' hat. Knights of Pen and Paper ist ein gutes Beispiel, wie man es einbauen kann, dass man zB bestimmt, gegen welche Gegnertypen man kämpft usw. Etwas ähnliches hätte ich mir hier in Chroma Squad gewünscht, einfach ein paar kleine Optionen um die Folgen zu beeinflussen, die man dreht. Sei es, durch Handlungsstränge, Minibosse oder eine einfache Auswahl welche Gegnertypen man denn bekämpft. Das hätte Vorteile gehabt, wie eben die Möglichkeit die Schwierigkeit anzupassen und das zu belohnen (mehr bzw schwerere Gegner geben mehr Zuschauer als Beispiel). Trotzdem ist Chroma Squad ein sehr lohnendes Spiel.

Dazu wird keiner der beiden Parts langweilig, weil es immer wieder Pausen gibt in denen man sich um andere Dinge kümmert. Das ständige planen der Finanzen, Marketing-Budget, Kostüme usw wird durch die Kämpfe in denen man die Folgen dreht aufgelockert - und umgekehrt.

Meiner Meinung nach ist Chroma Squad ein charmentes, belohnendes Spiel welches zwei Genres verbindet, gut ergänzt und eine Menge Potential hat.

Not really as great as its touted to be. It seems for half a second it would be tactically challenging but then you realize everything you fight is just an issue of placement, which at times could be avoided if you were allowed to pick your path rather than autorouting. The item system relies a little too much on you getting lucky, and only really serves to make you irritated wih things. Squad customizations are funny for a while but you really get tired of what you see soon, and its a bit annoying when you realize into the game you put the wrong person into the wrong role. Audience system is mostly pointless since just running a lot and using the positioning system will top you out easy enough and it just serves to drag fights on if you're going for all of the pointless little guys. 15647200.review:
You don't have to like tokusatsu shows to enjoy this game. It's a lot of fun to play, and the developers clearly have put their heart into it. I highly recommend getting it, though at the time of this writing it still has a number of bugs to iron out.

The game is challenging. It may be possible to resolve an episode quickly, but going straight to the finish line without doing anything interesting doesn't attract an audience, which you'll need if you want fans and money. Figuring out how to build your audience efficiently while keeping your squad standing is difficult and very satisfying.

Between episodes, you produce your show at your studio. Here, you manage your squad's equipment and skills, purchase studio upgrades, answer emails, hire advertising agencies, and choose which episode to shoot next. If you've played X-COM, you'll be familiar with this.

The customisation options really let you craft your own super sentai. You can choose your squad members, pick suit colours, name the mecha (the mecha's colours reflect the team's colours), write catchphrases, and of course, name the squad. The personal touches aren't "cutting-edge" but they make the game more immersive and playing a lot more fun. At least, I get a kick out of it.

Leading my Cuddle Force is a man in a panda suit named Blossom. Squad members Make Love (yes, the button to suit up is labelled "Make Love") and they yell "Cuddles conquer all!" after transforming. Their finishing move is the Beatdown of Love, and their mecha's name is Robert.

15645848.review:
First, I should mention that I played through the game on casual difficulty, so I can't really say much about the gameplay itself. I will say, though, that I greatly appreciate the developers including such an easy level of difficulty for people who just want to enjoy the experience and the production of the game itself.

And what a production! Beautiful pixel artwork, excellent music, and a consistent goofy tone throughout. I think a lot more could have been done with the story, especially in terms of developing the individual characters, but I appreciate that this kind of depth is not really the sort of thing you'd find in the TV shows the game is inspired by. 

The only negative thing I have to say about this game is that it reeks of Kickstarter. Well over half the missions include someone totally unrelated to anything running in, saying, 'Hey, it's me! Steve so-and-so! I know kung fu!' and then being a bizarrely-dressed fifth wheel for the duration of it.

I get that you can sell little cameos to backers and that this is a fun thing to do, but there is so, so much of it in Chroma Squad. You can't help but think that maybe there could have been more interesting things going on in the actual story if there weren't these constant interruptions.

Ultimately, however, the lighthearted tone of the game overall makes it not too big a deal.

Anyways, pick this up! It's great.

15645041.review:
More reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

My goodness… does anyone remember when the Chroma Squad Kickstarter happened? There there was the whole mess with release dates and stuff? Yeh? No? Well I don’t. I just heard about Chroma Squad a few days ago. This game is proof that there is just too many cool game concepts out that, while I may not have time for them all, are way too under my radar. I’m now realizing why indie developers always link other Kickstarters in their emails.

Chroma Squad is a tactics game based on the concept of the Power Rangers’ show. The literal making of a Power Rangers’ show. Chroma Squad, at its heart, is a TV show simulation game. You start out as the five stunt-people (of your choosing from default characters and Kickstarter backer-based characters) that get tired of taking orders and decide to start their own show. You make your way into one of the stunt-person’s uncle’s warehouse (in my case “The Fro”) and find that it has a giant-floating-spikey brain in a jar (which isn’t creepy in the least) and decide to use it as their own personal Zordon.

Now it was listed in the video for Chroma Squad that you’ll get a better reviews for the episodes you record with better and flashier moves you’ll do during the show, but I wasn’t totally convinced of this until I just went around one-hitting the baddies in the second episode. (Let’s just say the tweets were bad for that one.) This part is right up my alley because my favorite moves and/or characters are usually the ones with the flashiest move sets because I am a visually stimulated person and things look cooler with explosions! That’s where teamwork comes in. If you set one of your people to be in the “Teamwork” mode and another Chroma warrior attacks, the ones waiting in that mode will join in for extra damage and a bonus to viewers added. The more surrounding a bad guy, the more damage you’ll do. If all of your buds are waiting around the same bad guy and you’ve put on your Chromatic suits you’ll do a super-special Chromatic finishing move complete with a catchphrase, light beams and power stances… good stuff all around!

It gets even deeper when you start crafting with drops from the level. Upgrades to your armor and your eventual mech are all done with common items like DuctTape, leather and cardboard boxes. I recently upgraded my mech with a cardboard box and silver duct tape and that just made me laugh. I have to admit that playing five stunt people who started their own studio and are making ends meet and working with what they’ve got is pretty stinking interesting and also kind of cool.

Score: Gewd.

Chroma Squad is a solid title. It’s good as a tactics game, but excellent as a parody of the making of a Power Rangers show. The option to upgrade your armor, weapons and mech with common items like play-do and cardboard is hilarious and fun. It definitely sets itself apart from most RPGs in that aspect, but still it’s an RPG. There is humor and humor based on nostalgia and I enjoyed both! However, at its core it’s a TV show simulation and so it all comes down to money and fans attained by the end of each episode. Maybe it gets a little easier at the end game with more things to defeat or something, but the same issue bothers me now. Since you obviously want the most viewers and money, I find myself dragging fights out to complete achievements/goals and to max out that bar. Is it necessary? Probably not too much, but it also feels like it is. Maybe it easier for some, but that meter is not my friend at times. On another note, that may not bother me as much as it does here if I could take this game with me on the go… say on my Nintendo 3DS? That would be pretty sick! Pick-up-&-play may have been better for this game for me.

15641402.review:
It's a bit meta, lots of weird, and a huge amount of fun.

Even as a concept, Chroma Squad is unique: You are stunt actors who decide to leave their job on power rangers to start their own better written power rangers. 

That means winning the battles are only half the fight: You have to win them with style, lest the audience decide your fights are too boring. While some of the directors goals are tricky, they do add to the challenge, and it force you to learn the tricks of the game quickly. You'll soon enjoy tossing actors across the map and pummeling minions as a team for fun and profit.

Outside of combat, it's all about the show. You and your mech will need upgrades that not only give you the usual benefits of gear, but also make you look better. Get a bigger studio! SD Cameras! Flood lights! The better it looks, the move people will watch, and the better your options and cash flow will be.

And this works together, resulting in a good casual strategy game that I can't wait to play more of.

15636208.review: Behold Studio has done it again. A delightful RPG with deceptive depth, Chroma Squad hits home. 15635537.review:
you like grid based strategy RPGs like Super Robot Wars or Fire Emblem?

you like tokusatsu like super sentai/power rangers, kamen rider, metal heroes, and ultraman?

pros:

-unique role for each member of your team
-you can pick what actor goes to what role and color of your team, as well as giving that character any name
-actors range from an Asimo robot, Mike Tyson reference, Michonne from walking dead reference, a goddang beaver, and more
-more content in the future coming
-great crafting system
-combat is easy to learn, flexible and unique to master into any play style
-rewarded for being flashy and creative on execution of combat
-soundtrack is pretty catchy
-each of the unique team roles feels functional and useful
-GIANT ROBOT
-pretty quirky story
-game's management equals out greatly between a balance of your income percentages, team member HP and damages, member and robot appearance, upgrades for the studio which will affect combat
-enemy designs are goofy but unique, everything about the designs just stink of good old cheesy tokusatsu


Cons:

-some battles can really get drawn out, if you've played Super Robot Wars prepare to feel some nostalgia over waves of enemy reinforcements just forcing you to stay in a drawn out level
-Some levels feel too short while others feel too drawn out, there's no real balance between the two
-random difficulty rises and declines, one level can be easy as pie while the next will throw a boss at you that'll cause your damage dealer to turn on you for a turn and one shot your support, then back to being pathetically easy
-MEMES and uses of emoticons outright annoy me but this is just me being a nitpicker, I see enough of that crap in online games and seeing doge references and "XD" being used in game text just makes me roll my eyes.
-Mecha fights feel too simplistic and rely on percent chances which drop your chance to hit the more you have consecutive hits to pull off a combo. Defending feels like a quick time event straight outta golf game
-Sometimes the graphics seem to clash with each other, i'm not sure if the game just had one or multiple sprite artists but some objects and characters look misplaced compared to others. Along with some movement animations seeming awkward. Some maps will look really beautiful while others seem boring and bland.
-The game saves between each episode/stage but if you do anything after that in the studio as far as purchases, upgrades, or crafting goes you have to manually save in a tiny as heck hidden button which brings the pause menu up on top of the hub menu. The game only auto saves once you beat a stage, forgetful upgrades beware. Or you'll have to waste a few minutes on redoing your upgrades if you forgot.




All in all, it's a great game. Wonderful example of how a community driven and backed game should be executed. Others should follow this example and not rush their product but delay it to fine tune the gameplay and add in yet more content.

worth every penny.

15634498.review:
Hier kann man sich ein wenig vom Spiel ansehen

https://youtu.be/gjbGFS0MNs0

[Hinweis: Ich habe dieses Spiel in der damaligen Kickstarter Kampagne gebacked und habe dadurch vor Release einen Key erhalten. Es liegen keinerlei Absprachen mit den Entwicklern vor betreffend meiner Meinung über das Spiel oder ähnliches]

Wer wollte schon immer einmal ein Filmstudio managen?
Und wer wollte schon immer einmal ein Power Rangers - Team managen?

Hier kann man beides tun.... mehr oder weniger.
Dieses Spiel ist voller Anspielungen zu Film und Fernsehen, aber was erwartet ma anderes von einem Spiel über Power Rangers -artige Kämpfer von den Machern von Kights of Pen and Paper!

Der Grafikstil ist recht simpel, aber ausreichend und auch das Gameplay ist nicht sonderlich tiefgründig.
In der Management - Phase kauft man Upgrades für das Studio und die Hauptdarsteller und in der Aufnahme-Phase führt man Gefachte gegen Bösewichte und ihre Minions in Form eines einfachen Taktik-RPGs. 
Jeder Charakter hat eigene Werte für zB Stärke und Bewegungsreichweite. Außerdem hat jeder Kämpfer noch Spezialfähigkeiten wie Heilung oder Multi-Attack.
Die einzelnen Kämpfer können sich durch geschicktes Aufstellen und das Benutzen eine Spezialfähigkeit auch mit Akrobatischen Manövern dabei behelfen, Gegner schneller zu besiegen oder einen weiteren Weg zurück zu legen, und wenn das gesamte Team um einen Gegner versammelt, kann es einen Ultimativen Finishing Blow ausführen.

Mich persönlich erinnert das Spiel ein wenig an die Kairosoft Spiele für Mobile Devices. Zwar hat es seinen eigenen Spiel, aber es fällt für mich in die gleiche Kategorie der Casual Managment Simulationen... und mir persönlich gefällt soetwas.

15631818.review:
As soon as I played it I IMMEDIATELY knew this had to be the same team behind Knights of pen and paper.

If you are buying this expecting it to have some simulation elements or have strong RPG elements then immediately stay away from this game. This development team has sucked me in many times with the premises of their games but they never follow through with this premise.

I certainly would have loved a game about making my own Sentai series where my decisions determine not only how popular the show is with the combat being real tactical battles with impressive "fakey" special effects with many of its comedic moments being just the sort of crud a studio would pull to save money. Yet that isn't how the game works.

Basically to understand the game you take the role of several stunt workers who have decided to make their own "power ranger" type show. You achieve this by having random fights at which you are given goals that you must succeed, there is a story but the characters involved mostly speak entirely out of character at all times.

In fact that is probably my biggest gripe about the game's comedy is that it has absolutely no grounding. The game makes no attempt to even pretend like there is a show actually being recorded because characters almost never say their proper lines and cannot shut up for a moment about their own special effects or plotting. So some jokes, such as the characters not being able to transform because their costumes are in the cleaners out of show, fall completely flat because it never feels like this is interfering with the show because it just feels like a Larp. Another joke that falls flat is their constant references to their cheap teleportation effects, which would certainly be funny if they didn't constantly refer to it. The comedy could have been this game's saving grace, the nectar that would sustain me through the simplistic combat.

Outside of this the vast majority of the game's comedy are references. The majority of them are "references for reference sake" rather then folding them seamlessly in the game's comedy.

What the game really boils down to is a tactical RPG nothing more and nothing less. The studio runs itself and your decisions are just buffs, you are not the one writing the plot, chosing the opponents, deciding on the scenes. Yet what is there is just the barest of a tactical RPG, in fact if they didn't give you the ludicrous goals at the start of every episode the entire game would be too easy.

Yet even in this there are some genuinely good ideas there. Viewership, which you will max a little too quickly, depends on how you fight. Boss monsters for example must be defeated by your finisher otherwise you get a stiff viewership penalty (for obvious reasons) and if you waste a finisher on a boss and don't defeat it? You also get a penalty. Yet even this can come off as forced when you cannot even transform until your viewership is high enough (what is this viewed live?) instead of just allowing the player to carefully contemplate whether taking a penelty is worth it.

These goals are usually things like "defeat all enemies before hurting the boss" which are decent ones. Yet as you go on they become quite complex requiring you to carefully map out the field. The issue with these isn't that they are difficult, and they are, but that they are the only source of difficulty in this game.

You then collect crafting items from ordinary enemies which you can craft into weapons that are usually "comedic" so expect a lot of "Bucket helmets" and "Tinfoil swords". They have their own stats as well as randomized bonus stats based on how good the item is. These are equipped like everything else and to the game's credit all the items show up on your characters.

You can get studio upgrades and even marketing using the money you earn on each episode. Marketing for the most part effects the money and viewership of episodes for a small fee. You can also use your viewers to activate additional powers unlocked by that marketing campaign which can easily turn the tide in a fight from easy to rediculously easy. Studio upgrades amount to buffs and bonuses to shooting or to crafting as well as unlocking more items.

To shoot you are given a selection of fights you must do, and you will do all of them so don't worry, and then you get into a fight. That is what it amounts to. All the shoots are usually fights with usually the characters chiming in, out of character, about what this episode might be about (as said earlier they barely keep up appearances that they are actually shooting this show).

I think what this ultimately boils down to is that this game is a disapointment in every level. It wasn't the game I thought it was going to be. Yet when I tried to like the game, the game actively hurt itself. Its comedy is forced, its tactics bogged down and simplistic, and the game is as linear as heck!

For those who are going to buy this as a comedy game, I should state that the trailer for the game is much more funny then anything you are going to find in this game. So watch 30 minutes of an hour of a letsplay and base how "funny" it is on that.

Get this on sale for 5 bucks! If I could get my money back I would in a heart beat. Also feel free to say this is unhelpful because this review is negative, especially you production crew.

-Edit: playing it a bit more, the "acting in character" does improve but the comedy still falls flat. Mostly because the Out of character events rarely manifest in character.

15631735.review:
If you are a fan of Power Rangers or Super Sentai. You should give it a try!
Lots of subtile references/nods to Super Sentai seasons. (Won't say what they are but if you've seen sentai seasons of the last 2-3 years, you'll see some and will put a smile on your face!) 

Gameplay is really simplistic (Don't go into it expecting complicated mechanics like from the Disgaea Series) but honestly it doesn't need to be overwhelming. The overall episode "goals" challenge you to certain things before the end of the section. Have yet to run into one that wasn't impossible. 

As the seasons (5 in total) go on, you'll come across items to craft and buy to upgrade your Squad members, so there is atleast some customization for you to play with as you're going along the story.

After each episode you get revenue based on how many fans you get. Fans are usually earned if you use an ability or complete one of the episode goals. Most goals tend to give you well enough fans to hit the cap. If a squad member falls, it'll subtract fans. Later on you'll start to get contracts from agencies that can change the end revenue based on what you want. +Money? +Fans? Things like that. The more fans you have, the more bonuses you could have!

Again if you like Power Rangers/Super Sentai or Tokusatsu, try this out! 
If you aren't, you may not understand the fourth wall breaking studio-type story the game has. But the gameplay is still enjoyable!

15629586.review:
Chroma Squad is a tactical strategy game with some management aspect. It kinda resembles new XCOM games.
 
Its main meat, the tactical strategy, part is quite fun with couple of interesting mechanics. Things like doing combined attacks with your team members and or making acrobatic throws. Management part offer quite different choices. Such as transforming your viewers into either fans or cash. It has satisfying amounts of options in character customization and in RPG elements. There five roles and you hire different actors with different bonuses for each role and each role has small skill tree in itself. You can equip your characters with crafted gear with random properties. Even the mecha fights which are not the major component of the game has some fun mechanics. It uses combo mechanic where successive hit increase your damage but reduce your hit chance so you have decide when to use your finishing move. Have not finished it yet but according to the achievements pages it even has multiple endings so some replayability.

Story and design wise i feels like a true old Power Rangers TV show. It has a kinda cheesy humor and characters it was to be expected from it's Power Rangers source and i personally found them funny. This cheesyness also includes popular culture references and memes. A small detail i really liked was that you can customize the color and look of your characters costumes and you can see these changes effect the looks of the effects and mecha and small things like that. You can also customize your warcries like when you finish a boss or transform or summon your mecha.

One last thing, if you do not like pixely art style that might be turn off for you.

10/10, GOTY, would recommend etc.

15629422.review:
Chroma Squad is a tactical RPG where you control suit actors for an indie tokusatsu (Japanese for "special effects") studio, directing them both in shooting episodes and budgeting behind-the-scenes. Your goal is to make the ultimate indie 'sentai' (Japanese for "squadron"; think Power Rangers) show by balancing fan acquisition and retention, and leveraging those fans for an extended budget.

Brief plot synopsis: a group of stunt actors, tired of being pushed around by their short-sighted and creatively-deficient director, break off to form their own indie production team. They find a prop called Cerebro in a warehouse belong to one of the members' uncle, and make Cerebro the 'hook' for their new show. Unfortunately, they wind up garnering attention from more than just a growing fanbase...

Your team is comprised of five members; you choose their suit actors (who each possess various stat bonuses and penalties), their roles (which determine what weapons they can use and what skills they unlock), and their colors (Ever wanted to have a ranger team without a red? Or maybe everyone is pink? Here's your chance!)

The meat of the game is the tactical combat - each episode plays out as a series of turn-based encounters. There is no 'initiative' stat, so you can move your characters in any order. Your get two actions, which you can spend moving and attacking (though attacking uses up all remaining moves, so move first), or you can use up the rest of your turn to use "Teamwork". The "Teamwork" move allows other characters to pool damage for a devastating attack, or to use the teamwork-using party member as a trampoline, bounding across the map in one move action. Each action builds up "audience", which acts as power meter and influences mission profit. Once you get enough audience, the "Chromatize" action unlocks, allowing your group to form up and transform into their super-powered alter-egos. Once in their hero suits, members unlock their special class abilities and weapons. Once you deal enough damage to a boss, a star and the words "FINISH IT!" will appear over their head. This is your cue to use a five-man teammate offensive and unleash one of your two finishing attacks (a standard melee finisher and a "Form the Giant Five-Part Howitzer!" weapon finisher that can be done at each weapons' respective ranges). Special "Director's Instructions" ask you to perform special tasks within an episode (like "rescure the hostage in three turns" or "don't let any team member fall below 50% health") for an extra Audience boost.

The first 'season' of play will end with you unlocking your giant mecha, which you'll use at the end a majority of the missions thereafter. Mecha combat hinges around stringing together punch combos - the higher your combo, the more damage you deal with your next punch, but the lower your chance of landing said punch. You can order the mecha to defend to end its turn (giving it a bonus to defense against the monsters' counterattack that scales with its current combo bonus) have the mecha perform a finishing move for massive damage (Giant bazooka arm? Energy saber? Chest-mounted laser? Take your pick, or take them all!), or use a defensive technique.

After every mission, you're brought back to your studio, where you spend your hard-earned profit on new props and upgrades for your studio. The shop will allow you to buy a few choice weapons and suit parts, but nothing fancy; you'll have to craft the exotic items yourself. During each mission, you collect random materials which can be used to craft props for your heroes or parts for the giant mecha. You can put your fanbase to good use in the Marketing section, where you can hire different firms to grant an array of toggleable bonuses (Need a better drop rate? Go with The Green Team - alternatively, consider an Indie Marketing Gig if you want to improve your Audience-to-Fans turnover ratio). Go to the Studio to buy upgrades to your set (maybe consider some health care?) or mess around with your studio options ("Lights, Camera, Chromatize!" not cutting it for a transformation call? Why not try "Powers Unite!"?). The Mecha section allows you to outfit and upgrade your giant mecha for the kaiju-sized brawls. Finally, the Actors section allows you to review your suit actors' stats, change their special abilities, and mess with their equipment (You can't wear buckets on your heads forever, guys). During the course of the campaign, you'll make decisions through the in-game e-mail system, some of which affect which bosses you fight. While the plot stays relatively the same regardless of what you do (up until the halfway point, anyway!), there are multiple endings depending on the choices you make, and multiple playthroughs are necessary to see everything.

I would recommend Chroma Squad to anyone who enjoys tactical RPGs, regardless if they're a diehard tokusatsu fan (but being a diehard tokusatsu fan won't hurt). Chroma Squad retails for $15, and I would wholeheartedly recommend it at that price.

15628807.review: Love tokusatsu (Power Rangers, Super Sentai, Kamen Rider etc)? Ever wanted to create your own tokusatsu show? Then Chroma Squad is just the ticket! From the creators of Knights Of Pen & Paper comes this rather excellent little tokusatsu inspired indie game. Full of tokusatsu references from Power Rangers to the various fansubbing groups located around the internet, this game comes highly recommended if you're a tokusatsu fan like me. But of course, you dont need to be a tokusatsu fan to enjoy this game. If you like tactical RPGs, then you'll probably enjoy this too. It's a solidly built game that has been a long time in the making. Being one of the backers of the Kickstarter campaign, and having to wait over a year and a half for it to be developed, I can honestly say that Behold Studios have definitely delivered the goods! Show your support, and buy it already :D

15628319.review:
Se você é um jovem na casa dos vinte e poucos ou já passou dos trinta e tantos, possivelmente você assistiu aos Tokusatsus na manchete, não? Ou na Record, Globo, Gazeta, SBT, etc, etc, etc. Estou correto? Pois bem, na época onde o mertiolate ardia e o Biotônico Fontoura era o único contato de crianças normais ao álcool, e se permitia tudo (como bonecos de Ação de Rambo), era normal que nós, seres infantes, pequenos exus, brincássemos de lutinha, fazendo nossos próprios tokusatsus, certo? Nos anos 90 isso não mudou muito, pois muita gente brincava de Power Rangers... O que tecnicamente é a mesma coisa, já que tudo não passava de uma desculpa esfarrapada pra batermos em nossos amiguinhos e eles ainda gostarem da gente. Sim, não me olhe com essa cara que você também era assim! Viu? O fato é que adorávamos fingir que éramos nossos heróis favoritos. E um jogo recém lançado nos dá a chance de criarmos nossos próprios heróis. Falo é claro, de Chroma Squad, jogo brasileiro que permite a criação de um Super Sentai... Será que ele vale a pena?

Chroma Squad é a nova criação do Behold Studios, que você deve conhecer por causa do excelente Knights of Pen & Paper. Nele, você controla um grupo de dublês de Super Sentai que insatisfeito com as condições de trabalho em Super Rangers, decidem largar o estúdio e criar seu próprio sentai. A partir daí, eles precisam gerenciar os recursos e orçamento e elaborar os episódios com o que tiver. E conforme a história avança, as coisas se tornam cada vez mais elaboradas e incríveis. Eu não posso contar mais sobre o roteiro do jogo, que senão eu estarei dando spoilers.

O jogo é um mix de gerenciamento de estúdio de sentai (de maneira simplificada, comparando com a vida real) e rpg tático. A parte de gerenciamento depende da dificuldade em que você escolhe, mas no geral as coisas se baseiam em construção (crafting) de itens (recomendo que use o crafting para o mecha), gerenciamento de recursos (monetário e de fãs) e marketing. Além é claro, de responder e-mails de fãs, que podem lhe garantir bônus de pontos para usar melhor os recursos. Com o dinheiro conseguido nos capítulos da série (explicarei mais adiante), você pode comprar equipamentos novos, melhorar seu estúdio (que lhe garantirá bonus) e bancar a agência de marketing de seu show.

Explicando parece ser complicado, mas fique calmo que tudo funciona de maneira tranquila e cada recurso novo que expliquei no parágrafo anterior é introduzido gradualmente no jogo, de modo que você não fique perdido.

A parte de combates é dividido em duas partes. Na dos episódios normais, é um RPG tático de turnos, com uma ressalva. Além dos vencer os combates, é necessário conseguir audiência, então é preciso dar um show. Como se faz isso? Obedecendo as instruções do diretor, pontos extras de audiência são dados. E no final do episódio, esses pontos se convertem em fãs e dinheiro. Cada personagem tem uma classe, classe essa que possui habilidades únicas que podem ser customizadas com o passar das temporadas.

Os personagens podem trabalhar em equipe, e essa colaboração inclusive é necessária para o golpe finalizador (cês sabem, aqueles que explodem coisas). Tudo funciona de maneira simples e intuitiva.

As batalhas de Mecha são bem simples de se executar, mas complicadas de explicar. Ela se passa em turnos. Há um icone de ataque e um de defesa, além dos golpes especiais, que pode ter um ou mais icones na tela (dependendo dos upgrades de seu mecha). Ligado ao seu icone de ataque, há uma porcentagem (de acerto) e um multiplicador (de dano), quanto mais ataque, maior o multiplicador e menor a porcentagem (diminui 10% a cada hit), e esse multiplicador de dano também serve para o boost de defesa do mecha, e para o dano causado pelos golpes especiais. O turno acaba quando o seu mecha erra o ataque, o ataque especial é desferido ou a defesa é ativada.

O turno de defesa é simples, há uma barra com diferentes cores na parte inferior da tela e um ponteiro navega por ela, da esquerda para a direita. Você precisa clicar (em qualquer ponto da tela) quando o ponteiro estiver mais próximo do centro, que vai definir a redução de dano do ataque. E após 3 ataques do seu oponente, retorna a sua vez. Cada monstro possui 3 barras de energia, e quando ele perde as três, fim de luta.

Graficamente, apesar de ser 8-bits possui cenários muito bonitos (levando-se em conta a limitação da pixelização), e apesar de a princípio eles serem um tanto repetitivos (questão de orçamento da meta linguagem do jogo, quanto maior seu estúdio, maior a variedade de cenários), eles passam a variar mais nas temporadas finais. Cada personagem possui uma característica visual única e muitas vezes pode remeter a alguém famoso, seja ator, esportista ou personagem fictício. Quanto a disposição das cores, quem cria é você, sendo tradicionalista ou maluco (Sei lá, tem gente que quer fazer sentai com roxo, laranja, marrom, branco e verde) e isso se reflete no seu uniforme, que vai se alterando conforme os novos equipamentos vão sendo comprados.

A trilha sonora é muito foda, sério, não tem outro adjetivo. Ótimos chiptunes que casam com cada momento do jogo. Seja ele tenso, tranquilo ou de reviravolta. O tema disponível não decepciona. E ainda temos dois temas cantados no jogo: O tema de abertura: "Power of Love, Chroma Squad!", cantado por Shuu Koyama (vocalista da banda japonesa Scoobie Do), e o tema de encerramento, "Be Brave", cantado por Hitomi Go.

E caso você seja um fã de longa data de Tokusatsu, espere ver um monte de referências a séries do gênero (e a outras coisas da cultura pop) durante a sua jogatina, além do que, há uma campanha extra inspirada por outro gênero, no caso o Kamen Rider, que extende ainda mais seu tempo de jogatina.

Finalizando, Chroma Squad é fantástico. Seja como meta jogo, seja como jogo. Ele entrega uma história simples, mas que se torna grande com o decorrer do jogo. Eu, que não costumo gostar de RPG's táticos, mergulhei absurdamente nesse mundinho. Se você é fã de Tokusatsu, faça um favor a si mesmo e compre ele.

15628309.review:
TLDR: This is an amazing game, but it hinges on one (or two) factors. This is an amazing game IF: You like Power Rangers or Super Sentai. This is the main reason I'm "Not Recommending".  I will still play for another 50 hours or so, but I'm a Rangers and Sentai fan. 

9/10 - Power Rangers/Sentai fans
6/10 - Normal RPG, tactical fans

Chroma Squad has some mis-leading aspects, mainly that this is a simple tactical game, and not so much of a Manager/Studio Simulation, and it lacks any deep RPG elements. 

PROS:
-Best Power Rangers game yet! No joke, easily the best. If you like Power Rangers at all- BUY THIS NOW! You will not be very disapointed.

-Blend of tactical, rpg, and simulation aspects

-Can customize team's colors, equipment, weapons

-Crafting is available

-Can upgrade the studio

-Great retro music and art (some people hate that, I like it)

-You do not gain levels. This is under pros and cons because to some this takes away from how much of an RPG it is. To others, this means no 'grinding'

-Great GUI/UI. It looks very nice, and it's easy to use.

-Contracts with different agencies. This is a really nice touch. I like this a lot. 

CONS:

-The simulation/managing aspect is sort-of fake. You don't really become a fliming studio in the sense you get to create your own episodes. Nor does changing the 'actor' for your Rangers change their personality (a black guy with a mohawk has the same personality as an alien, who also has the same personality as a living beaver-man).  You DO get to choose the order of episodes, but this will only change the ending of the game (as of right now, when I write this). 

-Virtually NOTHING you do has an effect on how the story/studio/managing/episodes etc. Some things effect how many fans you get, and it will change these end-of-episode fake tweets (Twitter) "Wow!  You ended with a finishing move! That was awesome" or "Lame, you need to change your gear! #OldGearIsLame". This is a nice touch at first, but it becomes annoying. Especially when 'fans' want you to change your gear every episode, when there isn't any new gear avaiable.

-Tactical elements are light: I did not feel I had to ever strategize to complete a level. 

-RPG elements are light: Very few RPG-like choices. When you beat a season, you get new 'Season Abilities', ultimately only allowing for 5 different abilities/powers/moves per 'Hero'/Ranger 

-Studio Management aspect is very light: Right now it only improves your heroes, and or Mecha. It can also give you more fans/money.

-Mecha Battle: This is nothing more than a simple time-reaction game. It does not feel engaging, and also Mecha battles do not happen after every fight. So when it /does/ happen, it feels anti-climatic because of how shallow the fights are. 

-Crafting can be fun, but it also feels shallow. Instead of choosing the gear you like (like a damage suit vs a HP suit vs a magic suit etc) you just get scaling gear. So you end up re-crafting your old gear just so you can get the newest set. 

-Due to crafting the items in the 'Shop' are either much worse or much better in comparison. (Level 3 shirt from shop: 120 HP, Level 3 shirt crafted: 87 HP and +1 random property (likely of equal strength)

-The story... If you buy this game for the story PREPARE to be disapointed. It's fully of tongue-in-cheek (aka humorous, funny, comical etc) elements. I am not a huge fan of this. The writing isn't very solid (Sorry Gui) and I never find myself wanting to know what happens next

-There isn't a lot of gear/items/equipment etc. Half way through the game: 14 'equipment' pieces to craft, 17 to buy. Weapons: 14 to buy, 12 to craft. Remember, these only affect some visual looks and your stats. Weapons give you a new attack (which is nifty) but ultimately it's going to be a variation on the same thing (axe doing more damage than sword)

-(Currently) no NewGame+

-There are even fewer studio improvements to buy, making the studio/managing aspect even weaker. (I'm half way through the game and I have 10 available to buy) 

-Buying the "bigger studio' doesn't actually change anything for the episodes. Nothing at all. (It provides stats, but does not change the episodes themselves) At least in Game Dev Tycoon the visuals changed to a larger studio and gave more options to do things. That is not the case here.

-You do not gain levels. This is under pros and cons because to some this takes away from how much of an RPG it is. To others, this means no 'grinding'

Knowing all of this: I will still end up playing quite a bit. And I don't mind posting this, knowing a lot of fan-bois will dislike my review. I still find the game to be fun, but very misleading. You don't really manage very much. (Unless equiping & crafting gear in any other RPG counts as simulation/managing aspect :P ) The studio improvements don't change much. The gear changes your looks and stats (like most games) but there isn't much choice, so everyone at a certain point will be wearing either A) Gear that was Crafted or B) Gear that was bought. You aren't going to use an old gear-set that has worse stats, and there isn't a choice between visuals (you get what you get, right now)

15627692.review: This is a great game.  I backed it as I was a big fan of tactics games like XCOM, but I had no idea it would be such a charming game.  It has great pixel-based art, a funny story, and a surprisingly good tactics engine based around "teamwork".  Very happy to see a successful kickstarter indie game like this succeed.

15627531.review:
Well, so far, it's been a great game. It's a love letter to tokusatsu shows, and to JUSTICE.

What I'm liking about it is that it doesn't really take itself seriously, and it's a bunch of people making their own series because they like it so much that they just had to do it. This is a game I didn't expect to want, yet I did. I'm glad I backed it on Kickstarter and see it deliver. 

While it might have some grammar mistakes, the script so far is pretty good, and it has TONS of references to both SUPER SENTAI (which the game is definitely based on) and Power Rangers (what most of us Westerners know tokusatsu from). It even makes some slight jabs at some people, which is very brave to do.

My only gripe with the game is that I can't customize the suits so I can make a suit based on a Sentai team from the past.

10/10 would henshin again.

15627475.review:
O jogo não é bom, não. O jogo é ótimo. Gráficos, trilha sonora e enredo impecáveis. Pixel Art da melhor categoria. Os caras da Behold conseguiram transformar uma ótima ideia numa verdadeira obra-prima. O esquema de combate é sensacional, desafiante (não ficava empolgado com um jogo desse estilo desde Final Fantasy Tactics). Ainda assim, o melhor do jogo está nos detalhes: após uma hora de jogo, fui surpreendido com diálogos extremamente bem feitos e cuidadosos, brincadeiras com velhos clichês de games e séries, mensagens inacreditavelmente engraçadas entre um episódio e outro (sem contar uma pitadinha política, que deixa história toda ainda mais surpreendente). O jogo é bem feito porque foi criado por um grupo de caras muito atentos a tudo que está acontecendo no mundo, e é muito prazeroso ver que um jogo desse quilate foi criado por brasileiros. Valeu a pena toda a espera.

Parabéns, Behold. Vocês tão representando bem demais a comunidade tupiniquim lá no estrangeiro. Tomara que novos criadores sejam inspirados por vocês.

15625669.review:
日本人ならオープニングテーマ一発で心を掴まれる戦隊物をテーマとしたターンベースストラテジーRPG。
大手スタジオで働く5人のスーツアクターがグリーンバックの撮影に嫌気がさし、巨大ロボで戦いたいという夢も叶えるべく、スタジオを飛び出してインディーズスタジオを立ち上げ、スタジオの経営と撮影を行なっていくというメタな展開がベースになっており、雰囲気的にはレンタヒーローに近い。
ゲームはシーズン毎に契約して各ステージをエピソードとして撮影をするという流れで、撮影終了時にパフォーマンスポイントに応じたオーディエンスからの収入や経費、ファンの増加数が表示される。
各ステージの撮影シーンでは登場する悪役に対して5人のスキルやチームワーク攻撃で工夫しながら戦うシステムとなっている。序盤は素面で戦い、ゲージが溜まると変身してステータスの上昇や武器を使った攻撃が可能になる。監督の演出指示が設定されており、例えば雑魚を全て倒すまではボスに攻撃してはいけない、ボスは5人同時の必殺技でとどめをさすなど戦隊物のお約束を踏まえた戦いをするあたりで頭を使う必要がある。
スーツや装備品の購入(ゲーム開始直後の武器はおもちゃの剣、ブーツはただの長靴)、撮影中に手に入るコットンやダクトテープを使用したクラフト要素、戦闘を有利にするスタジオ設備への投資などゲームの細部も充実。
2016年春に日本語が追加され、かなりの量のテキストが日本語で存分に楽しめるようになった。
戦隊5人の名前、戦隊名、変身のフレーズ、必殺技名、ロボ名、ロボ召還のフレーズなどカスタマイズできるあたり、戦隊物のツボを押さえまくりで驚くばかり。
ちなみにオープニングテーマは日本のファンクバンドScoobie Doのメンバーがボーカルを担当、それ以外のサントラもすばらしい出来。

15625240.review:
Chroma Squad is a Tactical-RPG (i.e.: Final Fantasy Tactics, Fire Emblem), coated with some Management Sim mechanics.

In Chroma Squad you control an independent Super Sentai Studio trying to create its first series. As such, you'll have to manage your money, buy upgrades to the studio, new clothes for your actors and hire people to take care of your marketing strategy. 
The meat of the game, however, lies between these management sessions. Whenever you record an episode, the game becomes a tactical RPG: you start giving orders to your actors on where to move, who to attack, stuff like that.
It's an amazingly stylish game. The pixel-art is awesome, the soundtrack is pure chiptune bliss (plus a main theme with japanese lyrics!) and the game is packed with references to pop culture and super sentais in general.
You don't really need to be a super sentai fan to enjoy the solid tactics mechanics in this game, but it surely adds to the overall experience. I recommend this game to anyone who ever enjoyed a Power Rangers episode or is just itching for a new TRPG game.

TL;DR: Awesome Tactical-RPG with stylish graphics, soundtrack and references. If you like Super Sentais you'll fall in love with it!

15625164.review:
Disclaimer: I’ve been provided a key of this game for free.  My comments are my own.

Chroma Squad is a fun game that does well in bringing the inspirations of Power Rangers into a Tactical RPG

Haven't heard of Power Rangers?  Well this game pretty much sums up on what it is like.  Mass number of the same type of enemies our heroes beat up, bosses that are unique(So far I haven't seen reused bosses), giant robot battles, disembodied thing, funny and cheezy dialogue, finishers, and the transformation sequence(Though I wish I could see more of it because I only saw it once so far.).

I have put a number of hours into this game and I have to say that this is a fun game and you guys will have fun with it as well.

15625135.review:
An excellent and amusing theme, backed by fun and interesting gameplay, chock full of references from the genre s a whole.

You are a group of five actors fed up with a terrible director, shoddy story(or lack thereof), and the boring same ol same ol rehash of a Sentai series, and you all have decided to form your own studio!

The game is a tactical RPG where you control your five heroes/actors through various episodes of your series, trying to earn fans by doing specific goals in each episode, earn enough money to buy and upgrade equipment, and improve your Studio to make bigger and better episodes! A wide variety of events happen, other heroes make cameo appearances, you collect materials and craft your own special equipment, including mecha suits!

Combined with a very amusing story, and a very fitting soundtrack, its a fun and engaging game that I can highly recommend.

15624616.review:
Power an!
Hallöchen zu meinem Ersteindruck von Chroma Squad.
Wer Lust auf Bewegtbilder hat, schaut hier rein:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IqjndyGb_qc

Vorne weg: ich bin Fan von Pixel Art und meine Kindheit und Jugend war durch die Power Rangers geprägt^^ Also super Voraussetzung für ein objektives Review XD

Wer ist das Chroma Squad?
Fünf Stuntmen haben keinen Bock mehr auf ihren Regisseur und entscheiden spontan ihr eigenes Studio aufzumachen und eine eigene "Power Rangers" Sendung zu startenXD Hilfe bekommen sie von Cerebro einem CybergehirnXD

Was machen wir in Chroma Squad?
Kurz gesprochen, es ist ein rundenbasiertes Oldschool- Rollenspiel. Wer auf schnelle Action hofft ist hier nicht ganz richtig. Die Kämpfe gehen zwar flott von der Hand aber es sollte auch ein bisschen Hirnschmalz benutzt werden, da die Kämpfe schnell recht fordernd werden.
Neben den Kämpfen muss man aber noch ein Filmstudio unterhalten, sich um die Ausrüstung kümmern und wie in jedem RPG auch seine Truppe leveln. Ebenso muss Marketing betrieben und Fanpost beantwortet werden um die Reichweite der eigenen Sendung zu erhöhen, denn es muss schließlich auch Geld verdient werden, um die Sendung zu finanzieren. Jede einzelne Folge der Sendung muss produziert werden und am Ende jeder Staffel gibt es ein großes Staffelfinale. Den geschäftlichen Anteil kann man ein bisschen mit Gamedev Tycoon vergleichen.

Musik?
Einfach sooo super. Ich hab selten bei einem Indiespiel so tolle Musik gehört. Es fängt die Stimmung aus den japanischen Superheldenserien aus den 90ern sehr gut ein. Hab selten so oft gegrinst^^

Grafik?
Pixelart halt^^ Wer diese Art Grafik nicht mag, wird sich schwierig mit dem Spiel anfreunden können. Ich mag den Stil sehr gerne und hab deswegen meinen Spaß damit^^

Spielspaß und Umfang?
Da ich bisher lediglich erst knappe 4 Stunden gespielt hab kann ich noch nicht so viel zu sagen, aber es gibt immerhin viel Abwechslung. Jede Folge die man produziert ist anders. Wobei der ablauf einer Folge recht gleich ist. Und es macht so viel Spaß^^ Warum? Weil das Spieldesign sehr gut ist und ich mich regelmäßig über die Dialoge wegschieße^^ Wer auf oldschool-Rollenspiele steht die nicht zu sehr mit komplizierten Skilltrees überladen sind, der sollte denke ich zugreifen.

Ich hab meinen Spaß mit Chroma Squad und werde es mit Sicherheit ne ganze Zeit zocken!

Liebe Grüße

Euer Poolitzer

15624073.review:
I backed this game on Kickstarter, and it's better than I ever could have hoped for. 

This game, at its core, is a tokusatsu simulator. What is tokusatsu? It's a style of Japanese live action television featuring transforming super heroes, martial arts, and special effects and stunts.

Let me first say this: don't let the "Inspired by Saban's Power Rangers" throw you or discourage you from buying it. The designers were forced to put that under threat of legal action from Saban, and there are a few subtle digs at Saban throughout the game. Tokusatsu heroes are much bigger than just what came to the West as Power Rangers. In actuality, many countries including Brazil and France got Japanese tokusatsu super heroes in the eighties and nineties before Power Rangers was a "thing", and that is inspired by the full range of Japanese superhero shows. Fans of tokusatsu heroes will spot references not only to classic Super Sentai, but also to Kamen Rider and Metal Hero shows such as Space Sheriff Gavan and Juspion.

There are two main portions to the game: tactical combat and studio management. In the tactical combat portion, you battle "mook" enemies and a "monster of the week" in a format almost identical to Final Fantasy Tactics or Disgaea in an isometric perspective. There are always "objectives" for each episode given by your show director such as performing a certain number of stunts or defeating the enemy in a certain way. Doing so will boost your ratings and improve the show's income.

In the studio management portion, you purchase and set up upgrades for your humble studio, investing in better cameras, hiring big name actors and skilled crew, and upgrading your special effects and costumes. While your costumed heroes may start out with a mop bucket on their head and bicycle pads for armor, with enough positive fan reaction (which you'll see after each episode is filmed via a sampling of tweets about the episode) you might eventually be wearing costumes on the level of a professional production! Additionally, interactions with other companies and fans might affect your production. What will you do when other studios start coming to you with their hands out? Take them to court or give them a cut? What will you do when overseas fansubbers start subbing your show? Let them on the chance it'll increase your merchandising, or drop the hammer on them?

In addition to this, you have a great deal of customization of your show itself. You can name your studio, name your super hero team, and even customize what they say when they transform or do their super attack. Want them to shout out, "Henshin!" when they transform instead of the default? You can do it! Want to pick your own colors instead of the default? You can do it! Want to have an Orange Ranger instead of a Yellow Ranger? Want them ALL to be red heroes? Yes, you can even do that!

This game follows the standard Sentai story elements: heroes battle foot soldier "mooks" on foot in their civilian clothes until they build up enough power (audience approval!) to transform -- and when they do, it boosts your audience approval even more. Once you defeat the monster of the week, of course, as any fan of the shows know, the monster has to grow huge. And what would Sentai be without giant robot battles? Purchase gear and equipment, assemble your giant robot and have a battle on a massive scale. 

In addition, there is a motorcycle prop you'll receive later, and an option to shift the show into a "solo mode" featuring a lone motorcycle Rider hero with a flowing scarf that favors jump kicks as his preferred method of defeating monsters. So in case you are curious -- yes, you CAN be a Kamen Rider!

The graphics are 8-bit, but don't let that discourage you. The animations are great, the characters are big and bright with big cutscenes when important events happen. The music is catchy and reminiscent of classic Commodore chiptunes or Nintendo 8-bit sounds with a catchier sound.

Overall, I highly recommend this game. If you're a tokusatsu fan, you definitely will want to play this, but even if you just have a passing interest in superheroes, tactical battle games, or managing a TV studio, the charm and uniqueness of this game will certainly entertain you.

15623814.review:
When the game starts, its pretty obvious that the devs are big big fans of the source material. A lot of love and care went into the development of this game. The art style and the audio fits the theme nicely.

As a strategy-rpg, its pretty light fare. Both casual strategy fans and hardcore super sentai fans will find a lot to love in the game. While the tactical battles aren't as deep as can be found in FFT, Ogre Tactics and etc, Chroma Squad has enough meat for strategy fans to be able to sink their teeth into.

Overall, I'm happy with the game and I'm glad that I backed it in KickStarter.
